headline: Belarus Jails Main Opposition Leader; Arrests 3 Others
abstract: Authorities sentenced him to 15 days in prison, after accusing him of participating in an unauthorized rally against the president.

headline: Olmert Clinches Coalition Deal in Israel
abstract: Ehud Olmert, Israel's prime minister designate, clinched a partnership agreement with the left-leaning Labor Party today.

headline: Germany Will Open Records on Holocaust Victims
abstract: The German government announced that it is dropping its decades-long resistance to opening the archives.

headline: 5 Men Are Arrested in Attack on Saudi Oil Plant
abstract: Saudi security officials also announced the seizure of about 1.5 tons of explosives and  of videotape showing preparations for the attack.

headline: Putin Reverses Decision on Pipeline's Path
abstract: An oil pipeline being built across Siberia will now steer clear of the world's most voluminous fresh-water lake.

headline: Third World Bloc Thwarts U.N. Reform Plan
abstract: The group representing nations from the developing world succeeded in stalling and possibly scuttling plans for overhauling the management of the United Nations.

headline: Israeli Cabinet Revises Route of Separation Barrier
abstract: The new route seeks to speed up construction while still incorporating several settlements inside the West Bank.

headline: Egypt Extends Emergency Law Allowing Detentions
abstract: For 24 years, the law has effectively let the government detain prisoners indefinitely and without charge.

headline: Iran Is Described as Defiant on 2nd Nuclear Program
abstract: Iran has said that it will refuse to answer questions about a secret uranium-enrichment program and other elements of its nuclear program, according to Western diplomats.

headline: Survivors Put Kremlin on Trial in Russian School Siege
abstract: Instead of focusing solely on the officers accused of negligence in the seizure of a school by Chechen militants, the hearings have become a public challenge to the Kremlin.

headline: Russian Business Discussed at Forum in London
abstract: Reports from the Russian Economic Forum, and other news from Russia and the post-Soviet nations.

headline: Nepal Calms as Coalition Picks a Premier
abstract: Nepal's politicians today inherited the unenviable challenge of crafting peace after days of protest.

headline: U.S. Economy Still Expanding at Rapid Pace
abstract: Forecasters expect the Commerce Department to report that the economy grew about 5 percent in the first quarter, the biggest increase since 2003.

headline: South Korea Arrests Head of Hyundai Motor
abstract: Prosecutors portrayed the arrest of Chung Mong Koo as a sign of South Korea's commitment to fight corruption.

headline: Iraqi Civilian Killings by Insurgents Soar, U.S. Says
abstract: The figures for 2005, reported in the State Department's annual terrorism survey, showed a doubling from 2004.

headline: Poland's Governing Party Joins With Populists
abstract: The agreement links the largest parliamentary party with a populist group whose leader has previously been charged with several criminal offenses.

headline: Israel Orders Security Fence Plugged to Bar Suicide Bombers
abstract: Israel's prime minister-designate, Ehud Olmert, told security officials today to swiftly plug the gaps in the barrier around Jerusalem.

headline: She Who Controls Her Body Can Upset Her Countrymen
abstract: A "kiss and tell" book by a Brazilian call girl has revealed that Brazil is not as sexually uninhibited as the world often assumes.

headline: Putin Reroutes Oil Line to Avoid Landmark Lake
abstract: The edict reversed a decision last month to allow Russia's pipeline monopoly, Transneft, to build the line within a half mile of Lake Baikal.

headline: World Briefing: Africa, Europe, Americas and Asia
abstract: AFRICA.

headline: For Blair, a New Set of Woes Only a Week Before Elections
abstract: The British prime minister found himself dealing with three embarrassing problems this week, each involving a different cabinet minister.

headline: Premier-Elect in Israel Closer to a Coalition
abstract: Ehud Olmert, Israel's prime minister designate, clinched a partnership agreement with the left-leaning Labor Party.

headline: Opposition Leader in Belarus Jailed Over Rally Against President
abstract: The arrest of Aleksandr Milinkevich, a challenger in the presidential election last month, intensified a crackdown on political opponents.

headline: Memories of Hamburg, Enough to Build a Dream On
abstract: In his memoir, Horst Fascher writes about his adventures and misadventures with some of the legends of the music business.

headline: Chinese Leader Focuses on Business as 4-Day U.S. Visit Begins in Washington State
abstract: Chinese President Hu Jintao's tour is intended to soothe qualms about China's surging trade surplus and rising political power.

headline: Militant's Death in Gaza Spurs Violence Between Rivals
abstract: Palestinian security forces  were accused of being involved in the militant's death, prompting gun battles that killed 3 people.

headline: Freed Reporter in Recovery in U.S. Zone in Baghdad
abstract: Jill Carroll spent Friday in the heavily fortified Green Zone despite a warning from her captors to avoid the area.

headline: Bush and Fox Repeat Vows on Immigration
abstract: The two leaders ended a two-day meeting agreeing on an approach, but unable to win the support to turn their vision into law.

headline: In a Surprise, Embattled Leader of Thailand Says He'll Resign
abstract: Thaksin Shinawatra, a business tycoon turned populist politician, said today he would step down as Thailand's prime minister.

headline: I.R.A. Turncoat Is Murdered in Donegal
abstract: Denis Donaldson, a former member of the I.R.A. exposed last year as a British spy, was found shot dead at his isolated home.

headline: The Papuans Say, This Land and Its Ores Are Ours
abstract: Native tribes that claim lands in Indonesia atop some of the world's largest copper and gold reserves want a fair share of mining profits.

headline: French Premier Refuses to Bow to Protests by Angry Youths
abstract: Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin, weakened but defiant, refused to bend to the demand that the government scrap a disputed youth labor law.

headline: Today's Russian Newspapers
abstract: Russia's defense minister has proposed military reforms and other news from Russia and the post-Soviet nations.

headline: Sudan Blocks U.N. Official From Darfur
abstract: The U.N.'s top humanitarian official to the western Darfur region, Jan Egeland, accused Khartoum of attempting to hide the dire conditions there.

headline: Berlusconi and Prodi Play to Italy's Undecided
abstract: In the second televised debate the two politicians traded insults and statistics, each blaming the other for Italy's current economic slump.

headline: Canada's New Prime Minister Takes Tough Stance on Marijuana Laws
abstract: Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced that he was scrapping draft legislation to decriminalize possession of small amounts of marijuana.

headline: A Mexican Mother Turns Detective, Driven by Devotion to Her Kidnapped Son
abstract: In Mexico, where kidnappings are on the rise, many relatives are left to conduct the investigative work the police regularly fail to complete.

headline: Article on Bird Flu Criticizes Effort to Monitor Cats and Dogs
abstract: Five leading European scientists think officials should better monitor cats, dogs and other carnivores for their possible role in transmitting avian influenza.

headline: Bomb Explodes Near Shiite Shrine in Iraq
abstract: A car bomb ripped through a crowd of worshippers, killing at least 10 people.

headline: Britain Confirms Bird Flu in Scottish Swan
abstract: A swan found dead in eastern Scotland is the first recorded case of the deadly strain of bird flu in a wild bird in Britain.

headline: Work it Out, Blair Warns Belfast's Rival Parties
abstract: The prime minister of Britain warned that London and Dublin could find a new way to govern the province.

headline: U.S. Won't Seek a Seat on the U.N. Rights Council
abstract: A State Department spokesman said the U.S. would sit out the first election but would probably run a year from now.

headline: Alone and Broke, Hamas Struggles to Rule
abstract: Ismail Haniya faces not only diplomatic isolation and a bankrupt treasury but an intense rivalry with Fatah.

headline: Sudan Blocks Visit of U.N. Official to Darfur
abstract: The U.N.'s top humanitarian official to the western Darfur region, Jan Egeland, accused Khartoum of attempting to hide the dire conditions there.

headline: Charles Taylor Pleads Not Guilty to War Crimes
abstract: The former Liberian president refused at first to recognize the court's jurisdiction and accused it of meddling.

headline: Rice and Straw Keep Pressure on Iraqis
abstract: The secretary of state and her British counterpart pressed Iraqi leaders for a second day today to speed up their efforts to form a new government.

headline: Shiite Alliance Splits Over Fate of Iraqi Leader
abstract: An official demanded that the prime minister resign, as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made a surprise visit to Baghdad.

headline: Iraqi Shiites Split Over Prime Minister
abstract: A powerful Shiite faction publicly demanded that Ibrahim al-Jaafari resign over his inability to form a unified government.

headline: By Bridging 5,000 Years, China Courts Taiwanese
abstract: China held a ceremony for Huang Di, the emperor believed to have first unified China 5,000 years ago, in an effort to promote unification with Taiwan.

headline: Chinese on Buying Trip in U.S. Seek to Pave Way for Leader
abstract: The buying mission is the largest China has assembled since reestablishing diplomatic relations with the United States in late 1979.

headline: Italian Minister Won't Seek Extradition of C.I.A. Agents
abstract: The C.I.A. agents were accused of kidnapping a Muslim cleric from the streets of Milan and flying him to Egypt for interrogation.

headline: Europe Stalls on Road to Economic Change
abstract: Europeans are worried that weak leaders in Germany, France and Italy are preventing economic changes.

headline: Chronology: A.Q. Khan
abstract: Some key events in Pakistani nuclear scientist Abdul Qadeer Khan's life, his career and his illegal nuclear dealings.

headline: Rebuilding of Iraqi Pipeline as Disaster Waiting to Happen
abstract: A failed project to repair a pipeline has a wider significance as a metaphor for the entire $45 billion rebuilding effort in Iraq.

headline: Rice, in Greece and Turkey, Holds Talks on Iraq and Iran
abstract: She said the U.S. would work to keep Iraqi Kurd insurgents from infiltrating Turkey, and cautioned that Turkish troops should not enter Iraq.

headline: Asia, Europe, Africa and Americas
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Palestinian Prime Minister Calls Western Aid Cutoff 'Blackmail'
abstract: The Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya, said the suspension of aid would not affect his government's refusal to recognize Israel.

headline: U.S. Stepping Up Plans to Attack Iran, New Yorker Article Says
abstract: The article says the Bush administration is accelerating planning for possible attacks against Iran, and has not ruled out tactical nuclear weapons.

headline: With Big Boost From Sugar Cane, Brazil Is Satisfying Its Fuel Needs
abstract: Brazil is meeting its growing fuel demand by increasing production not only of petroleum, but also ethanol.

headline: France Drops Labor Law That Led to Protests
abstract: The move was a humiliating defeat for both President Jacques Chirac and his political protégé, Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin.

headline: At Least 71 Die as Bombers Hit Mosque in Baghdad
abstract: The mosque is the religious bastion of the Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq, the country's most powerful Shiite party.

headline: Chief of U.N. Monitoring Agency to Conduct Nuclear Talks in Iran
abstract: Mohamed ElBaradei is to meet with Ali Larijani, Iran's chief nuclear negotiator, and other senior Iranian officials.

headline: Deputy Premier of Australia Is Questioned on Kickbacks
abstract: The deputy prime minister was asked whether he knew about kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government under the United Nations oil-for-food program.

headline: London Bombers Tied to Internet, Not Al Qaeda, Newspaper Says
abstract: A forthcoming government report concludes that the July 7 bombings were a low-budget operation carried out by four men who had no ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: HealthSouth Woes Line Lawyers Pockets
abstract: HealthSouth Corp. has helped lots of lawyers become more prosperous in recent years. The Birmingham, Ala., company expects eventually to pay a total of about $147 million in legal fees for litigation expenses incurred since 2003, according to the company’s annual report, which was filed last Wednesday.

headline: Illinois May Gamble on Lottery I.P.O.
abstract: For investors who like to gamble on initial public offerings, the state of Illinois may soon have an appropriate multi-billion dollar offer.

headline: Kraft Reaches For United Biscuit
abstract: Kraft Foods, along with a British partner, Premier Foods, and a Dutch private equity group, are set to bid up to 2.3 billion pounds ($4.3 billion) for United Biscuits as early as this week, Reuters reported.

headline: Aegis Holders Reject Bollore Seat Bid
abstract: Shareholders in the media buyer Aegis voted down two board nominees put forward by the French financier Vincent Bollore on Wednesday, but Mr. Bollore vowed to continue his quest for representation by calling an emergency meeting in the autumn.

headline: Poison Pills Lose Their Appeal
abstract: When Sun Microsystems announced last week that it would ditch its poison pill anti-takeover provision, it was hardly alone. Thanks in part to pressure from institutional activist shareholders, including hedge funds, the proportion of companies with active poison pills has recently declined for the first time in many years, according to Institutional Shareholder Services, a proxy advisory firm. The proportion of companies with poison pills has dropped from 55.1 percent two years ago to 51.2 percent of the 1,925 public firms included in the survey.

headline: Chief Named for Troubled G.M. Unit
abstract: General Motors named the head of its profitable Asia Pacific region Tuesday to run its troubled North American operations. The company’s chief executive, Rick Wagoner, who has been in charge of North America for the last year, said the company’s turnaround plan was far enough along to hand off the responsibilities so he could focus on broader restructuring efforts.

headline: Belarus Jails Main Opposition Leader; Arrests 3 Others
abstract: Authorities sentenced him to 15 days in prison, after accusing him of participating in an unauthorized rally against the president.

headline: Olmert Clinches Coalition Deal in Israel
abstract: Ehud Olmert, Israel's prime minister designate, clinched a partnership agreement with the left-leaning Labor Party today.

headline: Germany Will Open Records on Holocaust Victims
abstract: The German government announced that it is dropping its decades-long resistance to opening the archives.

headline: 5 Men Are Arrested in Attack on Saudi Oil Plant
abstract: Saudi security officials also announced the seizure of about 1.5 tons of explosives and  of videotape showing preparations for the attack.

headline: Putin Reverses Decision on Pipeline's Path
abstract: An oil pipeline being built across Siberia will now steer clear of the world's most voluminous fresh-water lake.

headline: Third World Bloc Thwarts U.N. Reform Plan
abstract: The group representing nations from the developing world succeeded in stalling and possibly scuttling plans for overhauling the management of the United Nations.

headline: Israeli Cabinet Revises Route of Separation Barrier
abstract: The new route seeks to speed up construction while still incorporating several settlements inside the West Bank.

headline: Egypt Extends Emergency Law Allowing Detentions
abstract: For 24 years, the law has effectively let the government detain prisoners indefinitely and without charge.

headline: Iran Is Described as Defiant on 2nd Nuclear Program
abstract: Iran has said that it will refuse to answer questions about a secret uranium-enrichment program and other elements of its nuclear program, according to Western diplomats.

headline: Survivors Put Kremlin on Trial in Russian School Siege
abstract: Instead of focusing solely on the officers accused of negligence in the seizure of a school by Chechen militants, the hearings have become a public challenge to the Kremlin.

headline: Willis Stein Unloads Media Distributor
abstract: Willis Stein & Partners is selling book, DVD and music distributor Baker & Taylor to fellow buyout shop Castle Harlan, for $455 million, an enterprise value of about 80 percent more than what it bought the company for three years ago.

headline: Beck and Johnson to North Carolina Bank
abstract: A former chief executive of Capital Bank, Jim Beck has turned to Greenville, N.C., to once again run a Raleigh bank. Mr. Beck and a partner, Steve Johnson of Atlanta, will buy Greenville-based Millennia Community Bank, rename it TrustAtlantic Financial, and move it to Raleigh. Founded in 2000, Millennia has total assets of about $30 million, 19 employees and two offices.

headline: Grasso Hands Over Testimony Transcripts to Spitzer
abstract: Richard Grasso has handed over to the New York attorney general’s office transcripts of testimony he gave to SEC investigators looking at trading misdeeds at the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Leisure Link Opts for I.P.O.
abstract: British slot machine operator Leisure Link has opted for an accelerated public offering instead of a sale to another private equity fund. Leisure Link, which is being advised by the boutique investment bank Hawkpoint, was put up for sale by its private equity owner, Henderson Private Equity, several months ago.

headline: Kodak Developing Uncertain Strategy
abstract: Kodak‘s business is looking increasingly risky, says Breakingviews. The photo group has put its health business on the block in what looks like a desperate attempt to pay down debt. Strip out acquisitions, and all of Kodak’s units saw shrinking sales and margins in the past quarter – even supposed digital growth engines.

headline: Are I.P.O. Investors  Label-Conscious?
abstract: Following J. Crew‘s dramatic I.P.O. on Wednesday and with companies lining up to test the choppy waters of the initial public offering market, brand recognition may be a key factor in driving stocks skyward.

headline: F.T.C. Approves Boston Scientific-Guidant Deal
abstract: Boston Scientific said Thursday that the Federal Trade Commission has approved its $27 billion purchase of heart device maker Guidant, clearing the final hurdle for the merger. Regulators also signed off on Abbott Laboratories‘ acquisition of Guidant’s vascular business.

headline: Constellation Closes Deal for Vincor
abstract: Wine and beer company Constellation Brands said on Monday it had completed its acquisition of a Canadian winemaker, Vincor International, for 1.23 billion Canadia dollars, or about $1.09 billion.

headline: Days Later, Televisa Bid Turns Up
abstract: Shares of Univision crept higher on Friday after Grupo Televisa and its fellow bidders — or what remains of them — submitted an offer for the Spanish-language broadcasting company. The takeover bid may have been tardy, missing Univision’s supposedly final deadline of Tuesday by a long shot, but it was reportedly greater than the one previously lodged (pre-deadline) by a rival consortium including media entrepreneur Haim Saban. That earlier bid was said to value Univision at $11 billion.

headline: Red Diamond Buys Avon to Create Rubber Parts Platform
abstract: Red Diamond Capital agreed to buy Avon Automotive for $118.9 million and said it was aiming to leverage its ties with Mitsubishi International to create a rubber auto parts platform out of the company.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Lawyer May Be Requestioned Over E-Mail
abstract: Richard Bernard, general counsel for the exchange, may be questioned further about the compensation case against Richard A. Grasso.

headline: Charges Against Hyundai Chairman Renew Concerns Over Chaebol
abstract: The embezzlement charges levied yesterday against the chairman of the Hyundai Motor Company have drawn renewed attention to the economic power and political influence of South Korea’s mighty industrial groups, or chaebol. Prosecutors cast the arrest as proof of their intention to crack down on the groups, which dominate South Korea’s economy.

headline: Enron Prosecutors Aim to Rattle, Not Be Rattled
abstract: After methodically laying out their case against Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay over nine weeks and 22 witnesses, the Enron prosecutors now have to start all over.

headline: Talks Between the N.Y.S.E. and Euronext Heating Up, Report Says
abstract: The chief executives of the New York Stock Exchange and Euronext have met face-to-face for the first time in a bid to hammer out a possible merger of the two exchanges, The Telegraph reported Tuesday.

headline: Will U.S. Bancorp Buy or Be Bought?
abstract: U.S. Bancorp is a ripe takeover target, says one analyst. U.S. Bancorp might buy itself a bank, says another. Either way, the company — which has a market capitalization of more than $56 billion — seems to be on a few analysts’ short-lists after Wachovia agreed to buy California’s Golden West Financial in a $25 billion cash-and-stock deal on Sunday.

headline: Hedge Funds Continue to Oppose Lexar-Micron Deal
abstract: Several hedge funds continue to oppose Micron‘s acquisition of Lexar Media, and recently told the companies that they plan to vote against the merger when shareholders vote on the matter Friday.

headline: More Deals for Mortgage Lenders?
abstract: Even as investors and analysts debated the wisdom of Wachovia‘s proposed $26 billion acquisition of Golden West Financial, Forbes.com is taking a look at other potential takeover candidates in the mortgage-lending field. Although critics of the Wachovia deal argue that the mortgage industry is stalling, Forbes.com suggests that the big banks will probably descend on the still-lucrative business anyway.

headline: Pritzker Family May Be Mulling Hyatt IPO
abstract: Hotels are hot: Occupancies and room rates continue to rise, and large private-equity investors continue prowling for hotel properties, while public chains trade at high multiples.

headline: Morgan Stanley Adds Oracle President to Board
abstract: Morgan Stanley said Friday that its board of directors has elected Charles E. Phillips Jr., president of Oracle, as its newest director. Mr. Phillips currently also serves on the boards of both Oracle and Viacom.

headline: Cendant Says Sale of Travel Unit Is Likely
abstract: Instead of being slowly drawn and quartered, Cendant is considering a short, sharp shock. The travel-and-hotels-and-real-estate conglomerate, which has been arranging a four-way breakup for months, said late Thursday that it may spin off two of its businesses at the same time, instead of on different dates. The double spinoff, expected in mid-July, would simultaneously liberate its real estate business, to be called Realogy, and its hospitality business, Wyndham Worldwide, as separately traded entities.

headline: Harassment Suit Is Filed Against Toyota
abstract: A woman has filed a lawsuit accusing a high-ranking Toyota executive of sexually harassing her when she worked as his personal assistant.

headline: Blankfein Gets Nod as Goldman’s Next Chairman and C.E.O.
abstract: Goldman Sachs named its president Lloyd Blankfein, to succeed Henry Paulson as chairman and chief executive of the company, the world’s biggest securities firm by market value. Though Mr. Blankfein was widely considered to be Mr. Paulson’s heir apparent, the board’s announcement threw cold water on recent speculation that the firm would split the roles of chairman and chief execuive.

headline: Icahn Fund Raises Stake in South Korea’s KT&G
abstract: An investment fund led by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn said on Wednesday that it had raised its stake in South Korea’s top cigarette maker, the KT&G Corporation.

headline: Skype Dials Up Deal for Startup
abstract: eBay‘s Skype unit said Tuesday that it has agreed to acquire a San Francisco-based speech-processing start-up for roughly $27 million in stock. eBay will issue 700,000 shares of stock to buy Sonorit and its subsidiary, Camino Networks. Skype said it bought the company for its engineering team, which should help Skype build new voice products for the future.

headline: Bawag Reaches a Settlement With Creditors
abstract: Bawag, an Austrian bank, reached a settlement with creditors of the bankrupt U.S. futures broker Refco and received pledges from the government and from banks to help withstand an increase in customer withdrawals.

headline: Morgan Stanley, King of the Russian I.P.O.
abstract: No bank has played as big a role as Morgan Stanley in pioneering the fast-growing market for Russian I.P.O.s. Over recent years, the U.S. investment bank’s success in winning Russian deals has left rival United States banks trailing in the dust.

headline: Tokyo Electron Starts Venture Capital Unit
abstract: Tokyo Electron is starting a venture capital unit to invest in start-up and early-stage technology companies.

headline: Should Intel Hang Up the Phone?
abstract: With Intel preparing a sweeping reorganization, the company might have to make some tough decisions when it comes to its communications efforts.

headline: Vector Climbs Aboard Inter-Tel Buyout Bid
abstract: Vector Capital, which has been actively seeking to acquire troubled public companies, has found a new target: telephone provider Inter-Tel. Vector is teaming with Inter-Tel’s founder and former chief executive, Steven Mihaylo, to back Mihaylo’s all-cash tender offer for the Tempe, Ariz.-based company. The alliance is in its early stages, and it isn’t clear how much the group is willing to pay for Inter-Tel.

headline: Software Maker Primavera Sells Stake to Private Equity Firms
abstract: Two investment firms have taken a “substantial interest” in software maker Primavera Systems as part of a recapitalization of the company, the firms and Primavera announced on Monday.

headline: Arcelor to Study Latest Mittal Bid
abstract: Mittal Steel  moved a step closer to making the steel industry’s biggest takeover after Arcelor said it would examine an improved offer from its larger rival.

headline: 2 Buyout Firms Team Up to Buy Dining Chain Bravo
abstract: Two buyout firms, Bruckmann Rosser Sherrill and Castle Harlan, are going out on a second date, agreeing to buy a casual Italian dining chain, Bravo Development, from its family owners.

headline: 2 Sides Differ Over Results of Hearing on Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft left a two-day antitrust hearing in Brussels on Friday claiming it had reached a breakthrough with European regulators, but regulators and rivals dismissed the claim as an exaggeration. Microsoft was making a last-ditch attempt to avoid daily fines of up to two million euros ($2.4 million) for failing to honor an antitrust ruling handed down by the European Commission in March 2004.

headline: Lehman Strengthens Asian Team with Yen
abstract: In a continuing effort to strengthen and expand its investment banking teams across the region, Lehman Brothers has appointed Wei Yen as managing director and head of ratings advisory for Asia. Dr. Yen will be responsible for advising Lehman Brothers’ clients in all aspects of their rating agency relationships, as well as providing general corporate finance advice.

headline: 3M Shares Rise on Possible Sale of Drug Business
abstract: Investors gave a 2 percent lift to 3M‘s stock on Tuesday after the company said it was considering a sale of its branded pharmaceuticals business. Goldman Sachs  is acting as 3M’s investment banker.

headline: Sara Lee Sells British Apparel Unit
abstract: The consumer products maker Sara Lee Corporation said Tuesday it is selling its British-based Courtaulds apparel business as the company streamlines its operations.

headline: Macquarie to Stagecoach: All Aboard
abstract: Macquarie Bank, Australia’s biggest securities firm, agreed to buy Stagecoach Group‘s London bus operation for 263.5 million pounds ($482 million) to expand in Britain. Stagecoach shares rose as much as 6.5 percent.

headline: CDC Software Frets Over M2M’s Role in Onyx Bid
abstract: CDC Software, which is making a last-minute bid to buy Onyx Software, said it is “deeply troubled” by the fees that will go to Onyx’s preferred suitor, M2M Holdings.

headline: BAA Shares Take Flight Amid Bid Rumors
abstract: Shares of BAA climbed closer to 900 pence yesterday as investors responded to renewed speculation over the weekend about offers for the airports operator. The shares closed up 18.5 percent at 860 pence amid suggestions that Grupo Ferrovial, the Spanish construction group, was close to sending out an offer document to shareholders. Ferrovial’s 810 pence-a-share offer for BAA has been rejected.

headline: McAfee Buys SiteAdvisor
abstract: McAfee Inc. on Wednesday said it acquired SiteAdvisor Inc., a private firm that tests and rates Web sites to identify those that could present a security threat. By adding the technology to its offerings, McAfee, which didn’t disclose terms of the deal, aims to help protect computer users from both incoming security threats and those faced during jaunts through cyberspace.

headline: Apple Faces Fresh Legal Attacks in Europe
abstract: Apple‘s popular iTunes music-download service is facing fresh legal attacks in Europe.

headline: HowStuff Works in China
abstract: Online education portal HowStuffWorks and China’s Intac International unveiled plans Wednesday to create a new company to take advantage of the booming Chinese Internet market, drawing a $22.5 million injection from investors including Carl Icahn.

headline: Will Net Access Fears Drive Spectrum Deals?
abstract: In an effort to solve the “network neutrality” problem in their own favor, big Internet and media companies could decide to join forces to bid for radio spectrum, according to a report in Investor’s Business Daily.

headline: French Poison Pills May Be  a Lot of Trouble for a Little Gain
abstract: The French version of the new E.U. takeover law, enacted in February, allows companies to pre-authorize the issue of warrants in the event of a hostile takeover. Breakingviews sees these new French poison pills as, well, unwarranted.

headline: European Bank President Says He, Too, Prefers Deutsche Borse Bid
abstract: The president of the European Central Bank said Thursday that he would prefer to see Euronext merge with another European stock exchange operator, but added that the view was a personal one.

headline: Hedge Fund Demands Houston Exploration Open Its Books
abstract: A New York hedge fund is demanding to see certain books and records of Houston Exploration, saying the company’s board of directors has demonstrated “repeated and potentially actionable disregard” for its duties to shareholders.

headline: Wasserstein Wins Back Name
abstract: Bruce Wasserstein, the legendary Wall Street banker and head of Lazard, will soon be able to reclaim his name from Allianz, the German insurance giant that became the ultimate owner of the firm he founded with Joe Perella.

headline: Is Google Targeting Chinese Portal Sina?
abstract: As Google spreads its wings in China, many think it may try to buy Sina, the country’s top Net portal. With its online ad business projected to grow 30 percent to 35 percent annually for the next three years, Sina is a “very attractive target” for Google, says Jane Hsieh of investment firm Clay Finlay, whose $7 billion portfolio is heavily invested in China, Japan, and Korea. Google wants to gain a larger foothold in China, she says, and is “considering Sina as a buyout.”

headline: Ritzy Laguna Hotel Sold for $330 Million
abstract: The Ritz-Carlton Laguna Niguel, the posh seaside resort that launched the luxury building boom along Orange County’s coastline 20 years ago, is being sold in one of California’s priciest hotel acquisitions.

headline: China’s Mindray Channeling  Nasdaq IPO
abstract: Mindray, China’s largest maker of blood monitoring equipment, hopes to raise up to US$300 million on the Nasdaq in a possible record IPO on the exchange by a mainland Chinese firm, The Standard said. Mindray Bio-Medical Electronics, which makes equipment measuring blood pressure and blood oxygen levels, hopes to list on the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index in July.

headline: Liberty Media Splits and Sells. What’s Next?
abstract: It has been a big week for John Malone’s Liberty Media. The media holding company split its stock in two, replacing it with two tracking stocks and moving them from the New York Stock Exchange to the Nasdaq. And on Friday, Time Warner announced that it bought Liberty’s 50 percent stake in their joint venture Court TV for $735 million, sealing a deal that has been in the works for awhile.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Investigation Broker Over Hedge Fund Trades
abstract: NYSE Regulation is investigating a major Wall Street broker over allegations it gave an in-house hedge fund preferential trading treatment, according to an exchange official.

headline: Shell Talks Up Plans to Buy CNOOC Refinery
abstract: Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday it was in talks with CNOOC about taking a stake in the Chinese firm’s 240,000 barrel-per-day Huizhou refinery and it aims to expand a neighbouring joint-venture petrochemical plant.

headline: Britain’s Prudential May Sell Buyou Arm, Report Says
abstract: The financial services group Prudential is in talks to sell its private equity division, PPM Capital, to the company’s management team, according to The Telegraph.

headline: U.S. Accuses Abbott of Inflating Drug Prices
abstract: The Justice Department said on Thursday that it had joined a whistle-blower lawsuit accusing Abbott Laboratories of inflating the prices of drugs for government health care programs.

headline: Sara Lee Agrees to Drop Poison Pill, But Not Yet
abstract: They say nobody doesn’t like Sara Lee, but plenty of people don’t like its poison-pill takeover defense. The company’s shareholders approved a non-binding resolution to dissolve the poison-pill provision in October, and Sara Lee management responded on Monday by meeting them halfway, the Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Washington Publisher Puts Papers on the Block
abstract: The King County Journal and nine other local newspapers have been put up for sale because their publisher said it lacks the resources to help them flourish.

headline: EDS makes Formal Offer for Indian Outsourcer
abstract: EDS has made a $380 million offer to buy a majority stake in an Indian business-process outsourcing company. EDS has made the offer for a 52 percent stake in Bangalore, India-based Mphasis, which has around 12,000 employees.

headline: A.C.L.U. Raises Surveillance as Issue in Big Phone Merger
abstract: As regulators weigh the many elements of  AT&T‘s proposed $89 billion acquisition of BellSouth, they are being asked to consider one more: allegations that the two phone giants turned over call records to the National Security Agency.

headline: CPI Mulls Sale
abstract: CPI, a portrait photography company, said on Tuesday its board has begun the process of exploring strategic alternatives, which could include the sale of the company.

headline: Waiting — and Betting — on an Enron Verdict
abstract: Jurors began deliberations on Wednesday in the criminal trial of Jeffrey Skilling and Kenneth Lay, the two former chief executives of Enron accused of deceiving investors as the energy company collapsed.

headline: Bulls Are Running to India, Raising Fears of a Bubble
abstract: India’s bellwether Sensex stock market index in Mumbai soared 45 percent in 2005, and it has already risen 20 percent in the first three months of this year. At the same time, the country has attracted more overseas investors, who poured $10.7 billion into Indian equities in 2005, and $4.13 billion in just the first quarter of this year.

headline: Dimon Smarter than Mack? In Highly Flawed Survey, Yes
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase‘s Jamie Dimon edged out Morgan Stanley‘s John Mack as “the smartest C.E.O. on Wall Street” in an opinion poll conducted by New York magazine that is about as unscientific as it gets.

headline: Level 3 to Acquire a Data Services Provider
abstract: Level 3 Communications, a provider of dial-up and broadband Internet service, said on Monday it had agreed to buy a data transport services company, Looking Glass Networks, for $96 million.

headline: Morgan Stanley Impresses Wall Street
abstract: John Mack got a financial pat on the back from investors on Wednesday, as better-than-expected financial results sent shares of Morgan Stanley up as much as 5 percent. The quarterly figures showed Morgan Stanley’s net income more than doubling to $1.96 billion in the second quarter as revenue hit record levels. The results came as Mr. Mack celebrated his one-year anniversary as the firm’s chief executive.

headline: Charity Begins at Home: Quattrone Raises Cash for Wrongfully Jailed
abstract: Indicted dot-com financier Frank Quattrone and his tech mogul pals are raising millions for a tiny charity that helps free the wrongfully imprisoned.

headline: Why Banks Love Lending to Hedge Funds
abstract: The brokerage industry “has begun to look like a business in decline,” The Economist writes in its latest issue. As a result, big investment banks are working to strengthen their ties to hedge funds, because for now, at least, that is where the money is.

headline: When Media Moguls Play Video Games
abstract: Sumner Redstone’s financial dealings with Midway Games have left many onlookers baffled.

headline: Arcelor Shareholders Demand Meeting to Protest Stake Sale
abstract: The stage is set for a showdown among angry shareholders, the steel company Arcelor and the government of Luxembourg.

headline: Forgeard Says He’s Staying Put at EADS
abstract: A determined Noel Forgeard vowed Wednesday to stay on as co-chief executive of EADS and help civil jet unit Airbus through its crisis, despite German demands for his resignation and questions about suspect share sales.

headline: Private Equity Bid for VNU Finally Prevails
abstract: A group of private investors said Sunday that their 7.7 billion euro ($9.7 billion) bid for the Dutch publishing company VNU, owner of Nielsen Media Research, which compiles television ratings, has succeeded.

headline: Following Rivals’ Leads, Chinese Ports Operator Plans IPO
abstract: Tianjin Port Development, which starts pre-marketing of an initial public offering of up to HK$1.05 billion ($136 million) this week, will be the third mainland port operator to list in Hong Kong in relatively short succession after Xiamen Port, which listed in December, and Dalian Port, which will start trading on April 28.

headline: An Unconvinced Grasso Agrees to Sit-Down
abstract: Former New York Stock Exchange Chairman Dick Grasso said that while settling a lawsuit over his $193 million pay package did not seem likely, he was willing to go along with a judge’s suggestion in the case. On April 6, N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice Charles Ramos urged settlement talks in the lawsuit brought by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. Ramos said it was “not going to do anyone any good to try this case.”

headline: Gresham in Swift Buyout
abstract: Private equity firm Gresham is poised to back a management buyout of the support services company Swift Technical Group. Gresham is reportedly set to pay 21 million pounds ($39 million) to founder Pat Swift for a significant stake in Swift Technical.

headline: Canaan Partners Sets Its Sights on India
abstract: Canaan Partners believes its new India office, which will invest in early-stage Internet and wireless investments, may one day rival its Menlo Park, Calif., space.

headline: Mad, Hot Plotkin: Retracing Alleged Insider Trader’s Steps
abstract: Much is known about Eugene Plotkin: He is a Harvard graduate and an aspiring cineaste, and was, until recently, an associate in the fixed-income research department of Goldman Sachs. That last part came to end a week ago, when federal prosecutors charged Mr. Plotkin and two others with running an insider trading ring that scored more than $6.7 million.

headline: U.S. Prosecutors Revise Indictment Against Former Refco Chief
abstract: A revised indictment of former Refco Chief Executive Phillip Bennett will include a longer list of investors injured by the fraud he is accused of carrying out, according to court papers filed by government prosecutors.

headline: Mixed Prognosis for J&J’s Pfizer Deal
abstract: Two research shops had opposing takes on Johnson & Johnson‘s victory in the auction for Pfizer‘s consumer-products unit. It won with a $16.6 billion bid.

headline: DLJ Merchant Banking Returns to the Waste Business
abstract: Perhaps looking to build on prior success in the waste services industry, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners said it has agreed to buy United Site Services, a provider of portable restrooms and services at sports stadiums, construction sites and other locations, from Odyssey Investment Partners.

headline: Reliance Petroleum Prices IPO in Mid-Range
abstract: Greenfield Indian refinery and petrochemicals company Reliance Petroleum surprised the market Monday by pricing its initial public offering just above the mid-point of the indicated price range despite the fact that more than 99 percent of all orders were placed at the top end of the range.

headline: Airline to Pay $14 Million to Settle Air Canada Suit
abstract: WestJet Airlines agreed on Monday to pay 15.5 million Canadian dollars ($14 million) to settle accusations of spying on an internal Web site of its bigger rival, Air Canada.

headline: Europe Said to Plan to Fine Microsoft $2.5 Million a Day
abstract: European Commission authorities plan to recommend that Microsoft pay up to two million euros ($2.5 million) for every day it has failed to disclose information about its operating system to competitors, The International Herald Tribune reported.

headline: Collapsed Hedge Fund Bayou Wants Its Money Back
abstract: There may be a rude surprise in store for investors who think they escaped getting burned by last year’s scandal at hedge fund Bayou Group.

headline: Bids for Pfizer Unit Due Today
abstract: Pfizer will collect offers Tuesday afternoon — and possibly some stragglers into the evening — for its over-the-counter drugs business, a unit that includes such well-known brands as Listerine mouthwash and Sudafed decongestant. Notably absent from the sale process are private equity funds, who are expected to sit on their hands ahead of the bid deadline, leaving pharmaceutical and consumer-products companies (and one British retailer) to fight it out.

headline: AXA in Talks to Acquire an Insurer From Credit Suisse
abstract: AXA, the French insurance company, is in exclusive talks with Credit Suisse to buy its Winterthur insurance division in a deal worth more than $8 billion.

headline: Bertelsmann: to I.P.O. or not I.P.O.?
abstract: The German media conglomerate Bertelsmann said that it might buy out a minority shareholder, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, and avoid the need for an initial public offering.

headline: As Vonage Woos Investors, Rival Skype Gives It Away
abstract: They say you can’t compete with free. By that theory, Skype‘s latest business decision is bad news for Vonage, the telephone-over-Internet provider that is gearing up to stage an initial public offering, says hedge fund manager Andy Kessler.

headline: J.P. Morgan Faces Votes on Lobbying, Governance
abstract: The same shareholder that took aim at Goldman Sachs over its links to environmental causes has set its sights on J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Is Paulson Going Public?
abstract: For several decades, senior partners at Goldman Sachs have pursued second careers in politics. Now, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the firm’s chief executive, must decide if he will continue what has become a Wall Street tradition. As speculation builds in Washington that President Bush will move to replace his Treasury secretary, John W. Snow, Mr. Paulson’s name has cropped up as a possible choice.

headline: Great Florida’s I.P.O. Plan Not so Great?
abstract: Great Florida Bank‘s chairman says the bank is taking steps to form a holding company, which would be used for a possible initial public offering.

headline: Australia’s RiverCity Motorway Gears Up for I.P.O.
abstract: RiverCity Motorway, the winning consortium behind Brisbane’s north-south bypass tunnel, will lodge the prospectus for its A$725 million ($540 million) equity fund raising on Friday with the institutional bookbuild set to start two weeks later.

headline: Veteran OVP Closing $207 Million Fund
abstract: OVP Venture Partners, one of the Pacific Northwest’s oldest venture capital firms, set out earlier this year to raise $200 million.

headline: For Kraft, Separation Brings Anxiety
abstract: Altria‘s years-long spinoff of its Kraft subsidiary is contributing to some pessimism about Kraft’s shares.

headline: Reynolds and Reynolds Buys British Software Provider
abstract: Reynolds and Reynolds has agreed to buy a software provider, DCS Group for 21.7 million pounds, or about $41 million including net debt of about 10.8 million pounds. DCS shareholders would receive 31.5 pence for each DCS share.

headline: When Leveraged Lenders Let Their Guard Down
abstract: Remember covenants?

headline: Frontenac Unloads IT Firm 101 Communications
abstract: Midmarket buyout firm Frontenac Co. has agreed to sell IT media company 101 Communications to fellow buyout firm Nautic Partners for $75 million, according to LBO Wire.

headline: Big Bonuses Still Flow, Even if Bosses Miss Goals
abstract: As executive pay packages have rocketed in recent years, their defenders have contended that because most are tied to company performance, they are both earned and deserved. But investors who plow through company filings often find that executive compensation exceeds the amounts allowed under the performance targets set by the directors.

headline: Harrah’s and Pinnacle to Exchange Casinos
abstract: Pinnacle Entertainment will get what’s left of Harrah’s Entertainment‘s Lake Charles casino complex in Louisiana, while Harrah’s will take over what’s left of Casino Magic in Biloxi, Miss., under a deal announced Wednesday.

headline: Health Care Property Buys CNL Retirement
abstract: Health Care Property Investors, the largest healthcare REIT in the United States, said Tuesday that it would acquire CNL Retirement Properties, the No. 3 company in the industry, for $3.6 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Hertz Buy Drives $1 Billion Dividend to Investors
abstract: Six months after buying Hertz in a $14 billion leveraged buyout, Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, Carlyle Group and Merrill Lynch Private Equity are about to collect a $1 billion dividend, recouping almost half their original equity investment. The financing is expected to close Friday, June 30.

headline: InBev to Pay $1.2 Billion For More of Quinsa
abstract: InBev, the brewer of Stella Artois, agreed to pay about $1.2 billion for most of the shares it doesn’t own in Quilmes Industrial, gaining a larger slice of Latin American beer revenue. InBev will increase its shareholding in Quinsa, as the company is known, to about 91 percent from 57 percent.

headline: Embattled VW Chief Gets 5-Year Contract Extension
abstract: Ending a protracted boardroom battle, Volkswagen announced Tuesday that it would extend for five years the contract of its chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, despite the qualms of employees and an earlier expression of no confidence by the company’s chairman.

headline: Langone Wants Spitzer to Apologize
abstract: Billionaire financier Kenneth Langone said he would settle a suit involving former New York Stock Exchange Chairman Richard Grasso’s pay, if New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer apologized.

headline: Postcard from Hedgestock
abstract: For those of us who did not make it to Hedgestock — the 1960’s-themed be-in for hedge fund professionals and people who want to sell them things — Friday’s report from The New York Times’ Heather Timmons offers the next best thing.

headline: The Triumphs, and Obsession, of New Hedge Fund Managers
abstract: Size matters in hedge funds. But bigger is not always better.

headline: Brazil: Judge Approves Varig Offer
abstract: A Brazilian judge approved an offer by a Varig employee group to buy the debt-ridden carrier, which was once Latin America’s largest airline.

headline: Spurned Severstal Takes Charm Offensive Online
abstract: Severstal‘s Aleksei Mordashov wears many hats these days, including Russian steel baron and jilted suitor. Now, we can add blogger to that list.

headline: Can Microsoft Fight Threats With Deals?
abstract: Microsoft is the world’s dominant force in computing, but the software giant is also facing some significant threats to its reign. One of those is the Internet. The New York Times writes on Wednesday that Microsoft and Google, the powerhouse of Internet search tools, appear to be “on a collision course, as the realms of desktop computing and Internet services and software overlap more and more.”

headline: France Telecom Joins Carlyle in Austrian Telecom Bid
abstract: France Télécom surprised industry observers by joining the Washington buyout shop Carlyle Group in negotiations to buy Austrian telecom One for an estimated 1.5 billion euros ($1.9 billion).

headline: Devon, Crosstex Buy Oil and Gas Assets in Joint Bid
abstract: Devon Energy and Crosstex Energy said Tuesday that they would acquire Chief Holdings‘ oil and gas properties in north Texas. Devon will acquire Chief Holdings’ oil and gas properties for $2.2 billion, while Crosstex will pick up the natural gas pipelines for $480 million.

headline: WI Harper Nears Close of New Fund
abstract: Following a $50 million first close last year, WI Harper Group, a San Francisco-based investor focused on greater China and the U.S., expects to see a final close of a $150 million new fund in May, according to VentureWire Professional. Founded in 1993, the firm previously raised five funds worth a total of $225 million.

headline: NASD Drops Spinning Case  Against Quattrone
abstract: Frank Quattrone said in a statement today that NASD’s Department of Enforcement withdrew all its charges against him. The agency had accused him of “spinning” — doling out hot I.P.O.’s to corporate clients in exchange for business — and misusing his oversight of Credit Suisse First Boston’s research department to direct favorable coverage for clients. NASD’s decision to drop the matter marks the third major win for Mr. Quattrone in the past year. His conviction on obstruction of justice charges was overturned and a lifetime ban from the securities business reversed. The Justice Department could still decide to retry the obstruction of justice case against Mr. Quattrone.

headline: Not Exactly Breaking Even in a Format War
abstract: Toshiba loses money on every high-def DVD player that it sells. What gives?

headline: G.O.P. Senators Hurry to Quell Furor Over Gas
abstract: Senate Republicans tried on Thursday to get the upper hand in the escalating political battle over high gasoline prices by proposing a $100 rebate for taxpayers and by suggesting that they might increase taxes on oil-industry profits.

headline: Scandals Leave Chinese Banks Vulnerable
abstract: Three junior Bank of China managers are accused of conspiring to embezzle at least $485 million from the bank’s branch in Kaiping, a small city in the booming Pearl River Delta, before fleeing overseas.

headline: Former Tyco Lawyer Reaches Settlement With S.E.C.
abstract: The former general counsel of Tyco International, Mark Belnick, has agreed to pay a $100,000 penalty to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit alleging he defrauded the company’s shareholders.

headline: Delek’s Energy I.P.O Turns On Investors
abstract: Delek U.S. Holdings shares rose Thursday as investors favored the firm’s energy offering to the day’s other I.P.O., private military contractor DynCorp International.

headline: Nasdaq Raises Stake in London Exchange
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market has strengthened its grip on the London Stock Exchange  by increasing its stake in its British counterpart to 18.7 percent. Nasdaq, which previously held nearly 15 percent of the London exchange, said it bought an additional 9.8 million shares for 1,218 pence each, or 119.2 million pounds ($219.4 million).

headline: NBC Is Poised to Hire Couric’s Replacement
abstract: As CBS nears a deal to make Katie Couric the next anchor of its evening news program, NBC has nearly concluded an agreement with Meredith Vieira of ABC to replace Ms. Couric as co-host of the “Today” morning show.

headline: Focus Ventures Zeroes In On Early Stage Firms
abstract: Focus Ventures has closed its third fund with $250 million – nearly half the size of the firm’s previous $465 million fund. With its newest fund, Focus Ventures is sticking to a long-held strategy of putting modest amounts of capital into expansion stage rounds for information technology companies financed by large, early-stage firms.

headline: Google Page Creator Backlash
abstract: There has been some grumbling about Google’s new Page Creator service.

headline: Company Decides to Cancel Stock Options of Ex-Chief
abstract: The Mercury Interactive Corporation, a software maker, canceled 2.63 million stock options issued to its former chief executive, Amnon Landan, after a company inquiry found that he manipulated the price.

headline: Morgan Stanley Beefs Up Energy Team
abstract: Morgan Stanley on Wednesday moved to strengthen its energy investment banking team, moving one of its top bankers to Houston from New York and hiring two more amid a dealmaking boom brought on by high commodity prices.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Specialists ‘Front-Running’ Trial Begins
abstract: Two former New York Stock Exchange specialists broke the N.Y.S.E.’s “golden rule” by putting themselves ahead of their customers, a prosecutor said in opening arguments at their criminal trial.

headline: Bertelsmann to Buy Back Stake for $5.8 Billion
abstract: German media giant Bertelsmann said on Thursday it had agreed to buy back the 25.1 percent stake held by an investment group, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, for $5.75 billion, eliminating the prospect that the company could be forced to be a publicly traded firm.

headline: Ide out, Montagny in
abstract: French Super Aguri driver Franck Montagny. (AFP) Damien Meyer.

headline: Edouard Michelin
abstract: Fernando Alonso of Spain holds up a Michelin cap after winning the Formula One Monaco Grand Prix. (AP/Luca Bruno).

headline: Prometheus Energy Gets Backing for Natural Gas
abstract: Americans are looking for all sorts of new ways to power their cars and trucks, from ethanol to biodiesel to hydrogen.

headline: Waterstone’s Founder Wants His Namesake Book Chain Back
abstract: The founder of British bookseller Waterstone’s went public Monday with his 280 million pound ($501.1 million) offer to buy back the unit from struggling books and music retailer HMV.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Names Directors for Regulatory Arm as Split Advances
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange moved a step closer to distancing itself from its regulatory arm, as it announced the members of a newly created board of directors to oversee the unit.

headline: U.K.  Car Dealer Says Rival’s Bid is Too Low
abstract: Lookers came out fighting when it urged shareholders to reject a 260 million pound bid from a rival U.K. motor dealer, Pendragon, because it would put their investment at risk. Lookers said the bid undervalued the firm by more than 21 pence and claimed that the “highly indebted” Pendragon had financial commitments of more than 1.4 billion ($2.4 billion) pounds.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Bids $10 Billion for Euronext
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange announced its $10. 2 billion proposal to acquire its European counterpart Euronext on Monday in a deal that would create the world’s first trans-Altantic exchange.

headline: Former Merrill Analyst to Launch Auto Industry Investment Firm
abstract: Former Merrill Lynch auto analyst John Casesa has joined forces with a former high-level executive from one of the nation’s largest automotive retailers to establish an investment and advisory firm.

headline: Former Playmate Wins Round in Inheritance Feud
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that one-time stripper and Playboy Playmate Anna Nicole Smith could pursue part of her late husband’s oil fortune.

headline: Penthouse Outbids Rivals for Adult Film Library
abstract: Adult entertainment company Jill Kelly Production has been stripped naked of its film library in bankruptcy court.

headline: Taittinger Poised to get Its Bubbly Back
abstract: the Taittinger family of France has teamed up with Crédit Agricole, the French bank, to bid more than 600 million euros to buy back the Taittinger champagne brand that it was forced to sell last year.

headline: Rave Wireless Dials Up $12 Million
abstract: Rave Wireless Inc., a New York-based cell-phone software company developing location-based services for college students, has tapped venture investors for a $12 million second round of funding. New York-based RRE Ventures joined the company’s investor syndicate for the new round.

headline: Canadian Power Company Brookfield Expanding in Chile
abstract: Brookfield Asset Management, the biggest non-government owner of power plants in North America, agreed to buy a controlling stake in Transelec Chile SA for $1.55 billion from Hydro-Quebec, adding transmission lines to its South American energy assets.

headline: EMI and Warner Music May Be Ready for That Duet
abstract: Senior executives at EMI, the British record label, and its American rival Warner Music Group are preparing for preliminary talks that could lead to the creation of the world’s third-largest music company, The Sunday Times of London reported.

headline: A Former Citigroup Trader Closing Down Hedge Fund
abstract: Ross Margolies, the former Citigroup trader who started one of the largest new hedge funds of 2004, is closing it down after client defections erased about 80 percent of assets.

headline: Sale of Digital Security Firm Said to Be Near
abstract: RSA Security, a pioneering digital security company, quietly put itself up for sale several months ago and is now near a deal with EMC or at least one other bidder, The New York Times reported Thursday.

headline: How the stewards say they came to their decision on Schumacher
abstract: Because some very interesting and valid comments continue to come in on the Michael Schumacher affair in two or three posts below, I thought that I had better post some of the details from the report of the race stewards on that qualifying incident. Rather than doing it in the two or three comments areas below where the incident is being discussed, I thought I’d do it as a new post.

headline: Nationwide Mutual Sells London-Based Investment Unit
abstract: The Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company agreed to sell Gartmore Investment Management Plc, the London-based arm of its Gartmore Group money management business, to a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman Advisors, for undisclosed terms, the companies said on Thursday.

headline: Mike Gascoyne “suspended” from Toyota
abstract: Today Toyota announced that it has “suspended” Mike Gascoyne, the technical director, for in indefinite period over “fundamental differences” with the team over ideas about technical procedures. Some people are surprised about that since Ralf Schumacher finished third in his Toyota in Australia last weekend. Others may not be so surprised – like Dennis in Wisconsin, who asked on this blog the day after Toyota’s poor results in the first race, “How long will it be before Toyota fires a driver?” I said they wouldn’t fire a driver…

headline: Shareholders Defy J.P. Morgan on Stock-Grant Resolution
abstract: Shareholders of J.P. Morgan Chase have taken a stand on the issue of executive compensation, according to an article recently picked up by the Under the Counter blog. Flouting the recommendation of J.P. Morgan’s board, the shareholders at Tuesday’s annual meeting narrowly approved a resolution calling for the firm to link vesting of restricted stock more closely with the its financial performance, Reuters reports.

headline: A New York Venture Firm Goes to Washington
abstract: A New York venture capital group will invest as much as $150 million in Washington D.C. companies developing technologies for commercial and military uses. Chart Venture Partners raised $70 million for the fund in March, expects to get an additional $30 million by June and might bring in $50 million more before closing the fund to new investors.

headline: Lehman Looks Into Its Crystal Ball And Sees Bank Consolidation
abstract: As regulatory and integration issues wind down and factors like valuations converge with foreign interest in the U.S. market, Lehman Brothers said Wednesday it expects mergers and acquisitions activity in the banking sector to accelerate.

headline: Nokia Sues Two Cell Phone Manufacturers in China
abstract: Nokia, the world’s biggest cell phone maker, has sued two Chinese competitors in its first Chinese legal action alleging illegal product copying.

headline: Ahoy, Wi-Fi Connection
abstract: Royal Caribbean has installed Wi-Fi wireless Internet not just in its public areas, but also in every single stateroom.

headline: Where Private Equity Goes, Hedge Funds May Follow
abstract: As private equity companies eagerly await the return of optimal market conditions which would allow them to file an I.P.O. and secure the holy grail of money management, permanent capital, they will not be alone.

headline: Question: Who Is MediaNews’s Dean Singleton?
abstract: William Dean Singleton, the maverick chief executive of the MediaNews Group, is thought of as something of a magician in the newspaper world – having transformed himself from the son of a ranch hand in a tiny town in Texas to a media baron who now controls a newspaper empire that sprawls from coast to coast. He has, in a manner of speaking, sawed many of his competitors in half, only to have them hop off the table and become his partners.

headline: Microsoft Settles California Antitrust Suit
abstract: Microsoft will pay $70 million to thousands of California government agencies in the latest legal settlement spurred by price-gouging allegations against the world’s largest computer software maker.

headline: Sprint Wireline Business Embarks on a New Life, Alone
abstract: The final piece of the merger that created wireless carrier Sprint Nextel last summer falls into place today when its local wireline business, renamed Embarq, begins trading as a separate company.

headline: A Tale of Two Ethanols
abstract: The ethanol boom is leading to drunken speculation, according to Breakingviews. High oil prices and U.S. clean air regulations have temporarily made distilling corn into fuel more profitable than refining gasoline. And eventually, producing ethanol from agricultural waste will be cheaper than corn. But Breakingviews says investors are combining and confusing the two stories.

headline: West Coast Banking Boom Looks Familiar
abstract: The resurgence of the technology sector is finally generating business for investment bankers on the West Coast, according to a feature in Investment Dealers’ Digest.

headline: Origin Drops Plans for Contact
abstract: Origin Energy, Australia’s second-largest power retailer, abandoned plans to merge with its New Zealand unit, Contact Energy, citing a lack of support from shareholders.

headline: Hydrogen Energy Developers May Get $100 Million Prize
abstract: With energy prices skyrocketing, lawmakers considered a bill Thursday that would offer more than $100 million in prize money to developers of technologies that would move the oil-dependent U.S. economy toward a hydrogen energy base.

headline: Alberto-Culver to Spin Off Sally Beauty Unit
abstract: Alberto-Culver said Monday it would split off its beauty-supply distribution business, Sally Beauty, with buyout firm Clayton Dubilier & Rice taking a 47.5 percent stake in the spun-off entity. The transaction comes a few months after Alberto-Culver’s attempt to sell the unit to the Regis Corporation for $2.78 billion fell apart.

headline: French Want More Say in Management of EADS
abstract: The crisis at EADS, the majority-owner of Airbus, deepened yesterday when the French government indicated over the heads of its German partner it wanted to seize more control of the pan-European aerospace and defence group.

headline: Arcelor Unveils Severstal Merger to Fend Off Mittal
abstract: Arcelor has agreed to take control of Russian steelmaker Severstal in a 13 billion euro ($16.6 billion) deal that could scupper Mittal Steel‘s hostile bid for the Luxembourg-based group. The move prompted an angry response from Mittal, which accused Arcelor of “manipulating” shareholders.

headline: For Phelps Dodge, a Big Bet on Metal Prices
abstract: In agreeing to buy Inco and Falconbridge in two deals worth a total of $40 billion, the mining giant Phelps Dodge is wagering that the breathtaking rise in metal prices will continue. An analyst in London told the Associated Press on Monday that “from the price they are prepared to pay, you have to infer that Phelps Dodge believes that prices will stay strong. It’s the only way they can justify these sorts of numbers.”

headline: Chicago Firm Seen as Strong Bidder for Extendicare
abstract: Chicago private equity firm Madison Dearborn appears to be the frontrunner in the bidding for Canadian nursing home operator Extendicare, The Globe and Mail reported on Friday. The newspaper cited “an investment banker who is aware of the process.”

headline: More Companies Show Uncanny Stock-Option Timing
abstract: Stock options awarded to top executives at five companies, including KLA-Tencor and Boston Communications, showed an unusual tendency of being granted just before a runup in the underlying stock, according to an analysis by The Wall Street Journal published on Monday. The findings follow up on a similar analysis conducted by the Journal in March. That research identified six companies, all of which now face government investigations.

headline: Finally, Face to Face on a Steel Merger
abstract: The public face-off between Mittal Steel and Arcelor, the rival steel giants, may soften a bit as a result of a meeting on Tuesday evening in Brussels in which they were expected to discuss a potential merger.

headline: A Sated Federated Ends M&A Bankroll
abstract: Federated Department Stores is planning to end a financing agreement used to pay for its $17 billion acquisition of May last August, and will resume its stock repurchase program.

headline: Scrushy Lawyer Takes Issue With Lay’s Defense
abstract: Donald Watkins, the Alabama lawyer and businessman who last year engineered the acquittal of Richard Scrushy, the former chief executive of HealthSouth, was not impressed with the defense strategy of Kenneth L. Lay. Mr. Watkins said the convicted former Enron chief was a “dream client” hobbled by a fundamentally flawed approach.

headline: Investors Get a Compass to Guide Them in the Travel Services Industry
abstract: Compass Group, the world’s largest caterer, agreed to sell its travel-services business to investors led by Sweden’s billionaire Wallenberg family and Macquarie Bank for 1.82 billion pounds ($3.2 billion). EQT Partners, a private equity business controlled by the Wallenbergs, will buy the airport and railway food operations of Compass’s Select Service Partner unit, Chertsey.

headline: Fortress Said to Consider $6 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity investment firm with $21 billion of assets under management, is considering filing for an initial public offering of stock, according to Breakingviews.

headline: Ex-Gemstar Chief Is Ordered to Pay $22 Million for Role in Fraud
abstract: A federal court yesterday ordered Henry C. Yuen, former chief executive of Gemstar-TV Guide International, to pay $22 million for his role in a scheme to defraud investors by inflating the company’s revenue, regulators said.

headline: L.S.E. Shareholders Approve $910 Million Cash Return
abstract: The London Stock Exchange‘s shareholders voted in droves Wednesday to approve the bourse’s plan to return 510 million pounds ($910 million) to investors. About 99.6 percent of shareholders backed the deal, which will be followed by a 50 million pound-per-year share buyback.

headline: Austrian Bank to Pay Millions in Refco Case
abstract: The Bawag PSK Bank of Austria will pay at least $675 million to avoid prosecution and to settle bankruptcy claims after admitting its role in the collapse of the commodities brokerage firm Refco, American authorities announced yesterday.

headline: M &A Boom Lures Lehman Back to Canada
abstract: In a sign that Wall Street sees plenty more takeover traffic coming, New York-based investment dealer Lehman Brothers returned to Canada yesterday by hiring BMO Nesbitt Burns deal maker Geoff Belsher to open Toronto and Calgary offices.

headline: Deutsche Börse Changes but Doesn’t Add to Euronext Bid
abstract: Deutsche Börse made some structural changes yesterday to its proposed bid to merge with Euronext, but fell short of analysts’ expectations of sweetened financial terms.

headline: Hearst’s New Home: Xanadu in Manhattan
abstract: Chances are that William Randolph Hearst, the legendary founder of the Hearst Corporation, would be pleased with the seemingly flush condition of the empire he left behind on his death 55 years ago. With a resplendent new midtown tower — paid for with $500 million in cash – as well as a string of new deals, the privately held Hearst is gaining a higher profile at a time when publicly traded companies like Time Warner and the Tribune Company are under mounting pressure from disappointed investors.

headline: Merck to Acquire Biotechnology Company for $400 Million
abstract: Merck & Company said on Tuesday it had agreed to acquire GlycoFi, a privately-held biotechnology company, for about $400 million.

headline: Airlines’ Communication Firm Turns On the ‘For Sale’ Sign
abstract: ARINC, a 77-year-old military and aviation communications company owned primarily by the nation’s largest airlines, is up for sale after more than a year of deliberations about how to raise the capital necessary to grow. The Annapolis, Md., company, which had $890 million in revenue in 2005, derives two-thirds of its business from the U.S. military, for which it provides wireless systems that allow all branches to communicate over multiple devices.

headline: Villeneuve quits GPDA
abstract: Jarno Trulli, a director of the Grand Prix Drivers’ Association, just told a small group of journalists that Jacques Villeneuve yesterday quit the GPDA. He would not say for precisely what reason, but the subject of Villeneuve quitting came up when Trulli was discussing how the GPDA yesterday had discussed the Michael Schumacher affair in Monaco. Schumacher, who was penalized for deliberately blocking his adversaries during qualifying in Monaco, is president of the GPDA. The group of Formula One drivers meets at every race to discuss safety issues. Yesterday it decided to take no action against Schumacher. Villeneuve had rejoined the GPDA last year.

headline: Andrew Kissel, Brother of Murdered Banker, Found Dead
abstract: Andrew Kissel, the real estate developer charged with defrauding mortgage lenders and stealing from a co-op, was found dead today in his home with multiple stab wounds, less than three years after the murder of his brother.

headline: I.B.M. to Step Up Its Investments in India
abstract: International Business Machines said on Tuesday it plans to invest nearly $6 billion in India over three years, underscoring the country’s growing importance as a global hub for information technology expertise.

headline: Goldman to Buy Chunk of Indian Exchange
abstract: Goldman Sachs plans to buy a stake in India’s National Commodity & Derivatives Exchange to gain from a surge in trading in Asia’s second-fastest growing major economy, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Albertson’s Shareholders Approve Sale of Company
abstract: Shareholders of supermarket chain Albertson’s have voted in support of the company’s plan to sell itself to a group of retailers and private equity investors for about $9.7 billion, Albertson’s said Tuesday in a press release. The deal must also be approved by shareholders of Supervalu, one of the proposed acquirers. That vote was expected later on Tuesday.

headline: As Backdating Scrutiny Grows, So Do Tech Companies’ Fears
abstract: The options-backdating scandal has not exactly been good news for the beleaguered tech sector. But things could get worse, potentially a lot worse, TheStreet.com writes.

headline: Barron’s Picks Wireless I.P.O.s in the Making
abstract: A clutch of recently funded wireless start-ups could result in a wave of initial public offerings in a year or so. The likely candidates, according to Barron’s Online, are companies who piggyback on others’ spectrum and deliver games, content and ringtones through their virtual network.

headline: Australian Bank Said to Consider Bid for U.S. Port Terminals
abstract: Australia’s Macquarie Bank is reportedly lobbying United States lawmakers to assess their receptiveness to a possible bid for the port terminals that Dubai Ports World is selling.

headline: Will VNU Reel In NetRatings Stake?
abstract: NetRatings “could be re-consolidated within Nielsen before long, at a nice premium to the present share price,” columnist Michael Santoli writes in this week’s edition of Barron’s. The Web audience-measurement outfit, an offshoot of Nielsen Media, is 62 percent owned by VNU Media, which was recently acquired by a group of private equity investors. Mr. Santoli sees the possibility that VNU’s new owners will decide to sop up the publicly traded piece of NetRatings at a nice premium to their current price.

headline: Golfsmith Prices I.P.O.
abstract: A golf equipment retailer Golfsmith International Holdings priced an initial public offering worth $69 million Wednesday, according to an underwriter.

headline: Richard Clarke Buys Himself Some Security
abstract: Richard Clarke has $50 million burning a hole in his pocket. Mr. Clarke, the former White House security adviser who criticized President Bush for a lack of focus on counterterrorism prior to Sept. 11, 2001, and the former chief executives of two technology companies have created Good Harbor Partners Acquisition.

headline: BP Traders under Fire in Propane Scandal
abstract: Houston-based traders for BP illegally cornered part of the propane market in February 2004, creating a sharp jump in prices for the popular heating fuel used by millions of rural homes, according to federal investigators.

headline: Ameristar Casinos Drops Bid for Aztar
abstract: And then there were three.

headline: Russian Entrepreneur Says Arcelor Deal Is Misunderstood
abstract: Aleksei Mordashov, the chief executive of the Russian steel company Severstal, said Tuesday that he was baffled that his 13 billion euro ($16.5 billion) deal with the steel giant Arcelor had set off such a stir.

headline: What Now for Paulson’s Goldman Stake?
abstract: If the Senate confirms Goldman Sachs chairman Henry Paulson Jr. as the next Treasury Secretary, he will pack up his bags and head to Washington. One thing he will probably not take with him — at least not in its current form — is his huge equity stake in Goldman Sachs.

headline: S.E.C. Suit Dismissed Against Former Gateway Executive
abstract: The former chief executive of Gateway, Jeffrey Weitzen, won the dismissal of a fraud lawsuit after a federal judge said the Securities and Exchange Commission had not provided evidence of intentional wrongdoing.

headline: UnitedHealth’s William McGuire: The Luckiest Man on Wall Street?
abstract: How lucky is William McGuire, wonders Bloomberg News columnist Graef Crystal, suggesting that the answer to that question is related to the $2.1 billion in options he amassed in the last 12 years as head of UnitedHealth.

headline: Hedge Funds in Limbo
abstract: Most hedge funds do not want someone looking over their shoulder. So it was seen as a big victory for the industry on Friday when an appeals court threw out the Securities and Exchange Commission’s rule that forced thousands of these investment pools, which cater largely to wealthy and institutional investors, to register with the agency.

headline: It Tracks Your Every Move…at the Water Park
abstract: While visiting a water park, my family and I wore wrist bracelets with radio-frequency identification tags that took the place of both wallet and hotel room key.

headline: Spanish Companies Flex Their Acquisition Muscle
abstract: With a hot real estate market and a growing generation of internationally seasoned managers, Spanish corporations are shopping for companies in Europe and the United States, outmaneuvering many of their neighbors in Germany, France and Britain.

headline: Battle for BAA Raises Questions About City Valuations
abstract: The dogfight for BAA has been the best takeover battle yet of the current M&A boom, writes John Waples in The Times of London. It had it all – big numbers (BAA went for north of 10 billion pounds, or $18.4 billion), big politics (the prickly question of handing over Britain’s biggest airports to foreign owners), big personalities (wily Spanish entrepreneur Rafael Del Pino versus City grandee Marcus Agius) and big drama.

headline: Call-Center Operator West Agrees to $4.1 Billion Buyout
abstract: Call center operator West Corporation said on Wednesday it had agreed to be acquired by an investor group led by Thomas H. Lee Partners and the Quadrangle Group in a deal valuing West at $4.1 billion, including debt.

headline: Another Takeover Option for NYSE?
abstract: Liquidnet — the electronic trading service that enables block traders to deal directly with each other, bypassing the hassles that come with using traditional trading desks and exchanges — is readying a new product: Liquidnet H20, which will match unanswered block trades with activity from liquidity providers such as (for example) Ameritrade.

headline: Actor Gets an Encore as Broker’s Spokesman
abstract: Sam Waterston is taking on a new role. No, he is not leaving the NBC series “Law & Order,” where he has portrayed stalwart Jack McCoy for 11 seasons. Rather, Mr. Waterston, who served for two years as the spokesman for the TD Waterhouse brokerage firm, is becoming the face and voice of TD Ameritrade.

headline: Getty Images Snaps Up Image Partner
abstract: Getty Images, a Seattle-based supplier of stock images for businesses and consumers, said Thursday that it has acquired Ireland-based Pixel Images Holdings for $135 million in cash.
