Pixel owns Stockdisc and Stockbyte, Getty’s largest image partner. Getty said owning the content it is already distributing will give it more flexibility and higher margins.

headline: The Fever for Exotic Stocks
abstract: Four years into what has become the longest bull market in the brief, turbulent history of investing in emerging markets, investors from hedge funds to mutual funds to public and private pension funds have shown a willingness to take on increased levels of risk in developing markets. Benchmark stocks in the largest markets – like Brazil, Russia, India and China, collectively labeled B.R.I.C. – have experienced gravity-defying run-ups, prompting return-starved investors to look farther afield.

headline: Lord & Taylor Said to Seek $1.2 Billion
abstract: The price to buy Lord & Taylor has been set, according to Women’s Wear Daily, and it is a steep one: $1.2 billion, to be exact.

headline: Australian Ports Group Patrick Agrees to $4.2 Billion Takeover
abstract: Australian ports operator Patrick has accepted a 5.81 billion Australian dollar ($4.23 billion) takeover offer from shipper Toll Holdings that will create one of the world’s largest transport and logistics group.

headline: Deutsche Borse Will Not Raise Bid for Euronext, C.E.O. Says
abstract: A merger with Euronext is Deutsche Borse‘s top priority but the German exchange will not raise its bid and has other options, the head of the German stock market operator said on Wednesday.

headline: Is the Blush Off Juniper?
abstract: Networking equipment maker Juniper Networks, frequently considered a takeover candidate this year, appears less likely to be an acquisition target amid growing concerns about its business outlook and a statement by one potential acquirer that it is uninterested.

headline: CDC Ups Offer for Onyx in Bidding War
abstract: Upping the ante in a potential bidding war for Onyx Software, rebuffed suitor CDC on Tuesday said it would offer up to $96 million for the customer relationship software maker.

headline: J.P. Morgan Names a Vice Chairman for European Banking
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase said this week it named Pascal Ravery as a vice-chairman of European investment banking coverage.

headline: Post race notes
abstract: Just wanted to check in to mention why I have not done a couple of the regular features of the blog. Because the race was advanced by two hours for the World Cup, the timing of everyone in the paddock was thrown off – except that of Fernando Alonso, who won with his usual metronome precision. So I didn’t do a Stars ‘n Cars. But I did see a few: Axl Rose of Guns ‘N Roses, the band members of the Kaiser Chiefs and Nick Mason and Jay Kay.

headline: European Central Bank Warns on Hedge Funds
abstract: Europe’s central bank said that hedge funds are a major risk to the stability of financial markets, and demanded greater transparency for the massive industry, according to a report Friday.

headline: Troubled Mall Developer Taps Goldman for Cash
abstract: Mills, a troubled developer of shopping centers, will borrow $2.23 billion from Goldman Sachs, a deal that will give the Arlington, Va. company some breathing room and sets the stage for a likely sale of the company, which owns Potomac Mills and 41 other D.C.-area malls.

headline: Nasdaq Buys 15 Percent Stake in London Stock Exchange
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market may have officially dropped its bid for the London Stock Exchange, but its latest move suggests the story is far from over.

headline: MySpace.com Hires Official to Oversee Users’ Safety
abstract: MySpace.com, the social networking Internet site popular with young people that has alarmed some parents and law enforcement officials concerned about sexual predators, announced yesterday that it was hiring a former federal prosecutor to be its first chief security officer.

headline: Wal-Mart Promises to Limit Its Banking
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores arrived in Arlington, Va., Monday with a reassuring message for banking regulators: It promises that it will never, ever open bank branches. That pledge could prove crucial for Wal-Mart, whose banking ambitions have sparked considerable protest and prompted the first public hearing in the 73-year history of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which would regulate a Wal-Mart bank.

headline: Two U.S. Equity Firms Consider Nordbank Stake, Report Says
abstract: Two private equity investors in the United States may buy a stake in the German state bank HSH Nordbank in a move that could signal Germany’s petrified bank ownership structure is starting to crumble.

headline: Bayer Sells Diagnostics Division to Siemens for $5.3 Billion
abstract: Just two weeks after winning drug maker Schering AG in a $21.3 billion deal, German drug maker Bayer AG announced plans to sell the diagnostics division of Bayer HealthCare to Siemens AG for $5.3 billion. Bayer said the unit no longer fits with the rest of Bayer’s healthcare-focused businesses.

headline: Wachovia Hiring Two Former J.P. Morgan Executives
abstract: Wachovia Securities has hired two former J.P. Morgan Chase executives to direct the company’s media and communications investment-banking group.

headline: Reverse Breakup Fees Gain Traction
abstract: Reverse breakup fees are showing up more and more in deals, as a strong sellers market is giving companies an increasing amount of leverage in a merger and acquisition market that continues to blaze after a record 2005.

headline: Carlyle Closes Asia Growth Fund
abstract: The Carlyle Group announced Wednesday that it had closed Carlyle Asia Growth Partners III (CAGP). The $668 million fund will continue to invest in growth capital companies across China, India, Japan and Korea.

headline: Big Bank Is Betting Big on Expansion
abstract: Since taking over as Bank of America‘s chairman and chief executive five years ago, Kenneth D. Lewis has made some big bets. In 2003, he snapped up FleetBoston and then last June swooped in to buy MBNA to become the country’s largest credit card issuer. Now, he has plans to expand the investment banking operations overseas.

headline: Deutsche Bank Finance Chief to Replace Chairman
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, said finance chief Clemens Boersig will become supervisory board chairman and replace Rolf Breuer, who resigned to help shield the company from a legal battle with media entrepreneur Leo Kirch.

headline: G.M. Entangled in Pay-for-Publicity Dispute
abstract: A public relations firm has apologized to General Motors after acknowledging that it may have offered money to former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich in exchange for public comments supporting the automaker’s employee buyout program. The offer would violate General Motors’s policy against payments to opinion makers.

headline: On Goldman Call, May Meltdown Looms Large
abstract: A fiscal quarter may consist of three entire months, but as Goldman Sachs reported its latest quarterly earnings on Tuesday, Wall Street analysts seemed to obsess about the last two weeks in May. That is when the world’s equity markets began their recent tumble, leaving some to wonder if the boom times for the financial services industry were in danger of ending.

headline: Le Mans!
abstract: This year’s Le Mans 24-Hour race, tomorrow and Sunday, will be worth watching for several reasons. Naturally the first reason is because it is Le Mans, one of the three greatest races in history, along with the Monaco Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500. Secondly, it will be interesting also to see if Audi can win yet again, but this time with a diesel engine. They have already set a new record as the first team to set pole position with a diesel engine.

headline: Twist in the Intrigue at VW May Help Chief Keep His Job
abstract: Volkswagen still churns out more cars than any other European manufacturer, but the biggest thing pouring from its headquarters in Wolfsburg these days is the smoke of political intrigue.

headline: EU Warns Spain on Move to Protect Endesa
abstract: European Union regulators threatened Wednesday to sue Spain for shielding its biggest utility, Endesa, from a takeover bid by E.ON of Germany as part of a broader crackdown on resistance to cross-border mergers.

headline: Consortium Mounts 14 Billion Euro Bid for Portugal Telecom, Report Says
abstract: A consortium of venture capital firms is preparing a 14 billion euro bid for Portugal’s biggest phone group in a further private equity assault on the telecoms market, The Times of London reported.

headline: Dynegy Executive Asks for Release Pending Resentencing
abstract: Attorneys for former Dynegy employee Jamie Olis argued before an appeals court Thursday for his release on bond while he awaits resentencing. Olis has served two years of a 24-year sentence for his role in Project Alpha, a transaction that helped Dynegy inflate its reported cash flow by as much as $300 million.

headline: Cendant Ships Travelport Unit to Blackstone
abstract: Cendant said on Friday that it has agreed to sell its Travelport travel services unit to a Blackstone Group affiliate for $4.3 billion. The deal is expected to close in August.

headline: Keeping Up With the MySpaces
abstract: Social-networking sites like MySpace are growing at an astonishing rate. Facebook, a site for students, is now the seventh-busiest spot on the Web.

headline: Polar Capital Plans Offering on London’s AIM
abstract: Polar Capital Partners, the hedge fund manager backed by Caledonia Investments, is to go public on London’s AIM market later this year with an expected value of between 50 million pounds and 70 million pounds.

headline: Gas Natural Chief Says It Needs to Spark Up Endesa Bid
abstract: The managing director of the Spanish group Gas Natural said Wednesday that his company’s bid for the electric utility Endesa was not competitive and would need to be reconsidered.

headline: A Rule at eBay: No Human Skin Suits
abstract: Looking for a killer land deal? Better look somewhere other than eBay. The online auction giant recently halted an auction on land in Wisconsin that was once owned by Ed Gein, the murderer who inspired the classic Alfred Hitchcock movie “Psycho.”

headline: Ambient Raises $10 Million in Private Placement
abstract: Ambient, a Newton development stage company specializing in broadband over power lines products, reports it has closed a private placement of $10 million to investors.

headline: Activision Buys Rights to Games Based on Mattel’s Barbie
abstract: An Activision subsidiary, Activision Publishing, said on Tuesday it had signed a multiyear agreement giving it exclusive worldwide distribution rights to new video games based on Mattel‘s Barbie brand.

headline: Oak Hill Capital Takes Stake in Primus
abstract: Oak Hill Capital Partners has acquired a controlling stake in Primus International, an aerospace parts company that had $100 million in annual sales last year, from another buyout fund, Rhone Capital.

headline: It’s a Deal: NYSE Agrees to Buy Euronext
abstract: After a whirlwind weekend, NYSE Group chief executive John Thain sealed a deal for his company to buy Euronext, the pan-European stock and derivatives exchange, for $10.2 billion. The agreement came after the NYSE, which runs the New York Stock Exchange, made its initial bid on May 22.

headline: M&A: Partying Like It’s 2000
abstract: Arguably, the most popular phrase on Wall Street these days is: “Let’s make a deal.” The hottest bull market in recent months is not the usual buying and selling of shares of a company’s stock; it is companies buying other companies.

headline: L.B.O.’s Double Down in First Quarter
abstract: Despite closing only a few high-profile deals, the leveraged buyout market forged ahead in the first quarter of this year as buyout shops began to put all the money they’ve raised over the past several years to work. The total value of completed L.B.O.’s reached $33.54 billion in the first quarter, double the $16.88 billion recorded a year earlier, and the number of deals almost tripled to 141 from 54.

headline: The The Dalles, OR?
abstract: In today’s Times, I read about Google’s new secret computer center in The Dalles, Oregon:

headline: Charges Called for in Option Schemes
abstract: Executives guilty of manipulating their stock option grants should be prosecuted to the fullest extent possible, Senator Charles E. Grassley, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said yesterday.

headline: Arcelor Faces Shareholder Suit over Severstal Deal
abstract: The Steelmaker Arcelor has been summoned to appear before a Luxembourg court on Thursday as part of a lawsuit filed by a French shareholder defense group, ADAM, which seeks to postpone the June 30 general meeting on the planned merger with Severstal, and change the voting procedures.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Buys Rolling Rock — Is Goose Island Next?
abstract: In a deal that has been in the works for months, Anheuser-Busch, the largest brewer in the United States, said Friday it purchased the Rolling Rock beer brand from InBev, the Belgian brewer, for $82 million.

headline: Burkle May Bid ‘Em Up For McClatchy Newspapers
abstract: Los Angeles investor Ron Burkle may be willing to pay more than $2 billion for the 12 Knight Ridder newspapers now up for sale – a price that could make him a serious contender in the bidding.

headline: BlackBerry Maker, $613 Million Poorer, Presses Patent Reform
abstract: Few people know the perils of the current patent system better than James Balsillie, whose company, Research in Motion, recently agreed to pay $612.5 million to settle a legal dispute over its popular BlackBerry messaging device.

headline: Private Equity Acquisitions Reach Record Levels
abstract: The volume of private-equity backed mergers and acquisitions in the United States so far this year has reached record levels, according to research firm Dealogic. Through June 14, more than 500 deals worth $157.4 billion and backed by private equity have been announced. That’s almost double the volume during the same period of 2005.

headline: Four Companies Want a Piece of Toshiba’s Westinghouse Buy
abstract: Four companies, including Japanese trading firm Marubeni , U.S.-based Fluor and two others will take stakes in Toshiba‘s $5.4 billion acquisition of Westinghouse, the Nihon Keizai business daily reported.

headline: Two Buyout Groups Said to Submit Bids for Michaels Stores
abstract: Two groups of private-equity firms submitted formal bids for the arts-and-crafts retailer Michaels Stores Wednesday night, coming close to $40 a share, or roughly $5 billion, The New York Post said.

headline: Canadian Miner Gammon Lake Acquires Mexgold
abstract: Inco and Falconbridge aren’t the only Canadian mining companies partaking in Monday’s merger mania.

headline: Santander Expects a Rise in Year-End Profits
abstract: Santander Central Hispano, Spain’s largest bank, expects 2006 profit to rise 13 percent to 7 billion euros ($8.85 billion) because of cost cuts in Britain and higher sales in Latin America, the chairman, Emilio Botin, said.

headline: Goldman Sachs Buys iHealth
abstract: Goldman Sachs Capital Partners has agreed to acquire iHealth Technologies, which helps insurance companies process medical claims, from the company’s founder, Doug Williams, said LBO Wire, citing an unidentified source.Financial details of the deal, which was approved by the Federal Trade Commission recently, were not available. The buyer is deploying GS Capital Partners V, an $8.5 billion fund that closed last year, according to the FTC.

headline: Analysts Rate Google’s Chinese Takeover Possibilities
abstract: Google‘s obsession with China could not be clearer. The Internet search company has recently unveiled a Chinese name — Gu Ge, or “harvest song” — and said it plans to build a research lab in that country. This, plus Google’s cash pile of more than $10 billion, have stoked speculation that a Chinese acquisition could be next.

headline: Televisa Fills Seat on Univision Board
abstract: Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications said Tuesday that an executive from Mexico’s Grupo Televisa had joined its board of directors.

headline: Will Murdoch Buy Into Saudi Prince’s Media Group?
abstract: Saudi Prince Al-Waleed bin Talal is expanding his media ventures, but instead of investing in the West, the West is now investing in him. Variety reported Saturday that Rupert Murdoch, head of media conglomerate News Corporation, is set to acquire a stake in the billionaire’s Mideast media titan, Rotana. The size of the stake and the price had not yet been announced.

headline: Arcelor Takes Out  $4.7 Billion Loan to Defend Against Mittal
abstract: European steel group Arcelor laid claim to external and internal cash on Wednesday as it tries to win flexibility and shore up its defenses against a hostile bid from Mittal Steel. The steel group said it had signed a 4 billion euro ($4.97 billion) three-year loan with a group of banks.

headline: Seed Money, It Seems, Doesn’t Need Much Rain
abstract: Venture capital firm Domain Associates‘ 2005 move from Princeton, N.J. to Southern California is part of a significant boom in the investment of seed money in a region known more for the entertainment and defense industries, surfing and sun-tinted skin.

headline: Goldman Ceases Talks With BAA
abstract: A consortium led by the investment bank Goldman Sachs said on Thursday it was no longer in takeover talks with BAA, the British airport operator, in a move that analysts said should now give Spain’s Grupo Ferrovial a clear run to take control of BAA.

headline: Mirant’s Power Play Ends Up in Court
abstract: Less than a day after it was announced, Mirant‘s hostile bid for NRG Energy is getting even more so.

headline: Mark Cuban Invests in Site Targeting Financial Foul Play
abstract: A new investigative Web site, Sharesleuth.com, is getting all its financing from Mark Cuban, the technology entrepreneur, independent media mogul and owner of the Dallas Mavericks  basketball franchise, according to PaidContent.org.

headline: Start-Ups Offer Solutions to Internet Video Traffic Jam
abstract: Internet video — from episodes of “South Park” to videos of your friend singing karaoke to the latest Prince single — has exploded in popularity. But it’s still harder than you might think to move video around. And the huge amount of video online is straining the Internet.

headline: Univision Auction Remains in Doubt as Bids Come in Low
abstract: The auction for Univision, the Spanish-language media company, was put into more doubt over the weekend as it emerged that a bid from a group led by Grupo Televisa, the Mexican media giant, was much lower than expected, The New York Times reported.

headline: Shimao Completes Largest Chinese Real Estate I.P.O.
abstract: Shimao Property Holdings has defied the difficult market environment and completed its initial public offering, which came to 3.72 billion Hong Kong dollars ($480 million) after the price was fixed at the bottom of the indicated range.

headline: China Considers Making Acquisitions Easier for its Companies
abstract: China is considering rules that would allow companies to use their own equity for acquisitions to increase the number of takeovers, according to a draft released Tuesday.

headline: New Charges in LendingTree Insider-Trading Investigation
abstract: David Anderson, a senior vice president of online loan broker LendingTree, was charged Monday with insider trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Also on Monday, federal prosecutors in Charlotte, N.C., unsealed an April 4 indictment charging Mr. Anderson with obstruction, making false statements and witness tampering in connection with the S.E.C. investigation.

headline: Bank of China Raises $9.73 Billion
abstract: The Bank of China Ltd. raised 75.4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($9.73 billion) in the world’s biggest initial public offering in six years, despite a rocky time for Asian stock markets.

headline: Chirac Lukewarm on NYSE Group’s Deal for Euronext
abstract: The struggle for control over stock exchanges took a political turn on Tuesday as President Jacques Chirac of France said that he preferred an all-European deal but backed away from the overt protectionism that has characterized French economic policy.

headline: McAfee Acquires Preventsys, a Security Software Developer
abstract: McAfee, a provider of computer security software and services, said on Tuesday that it had acquired closely held Preventsys, a developer of security software.

headline: Arctic Glacier to Acquire California Ice for $190 Million
abstract: The Arctic Glacier Income Fund plans to acquire California Ice, a distributor of packaged ice, for about $190 million. Arctic Glacier, which is based in Winnipeg, said the acquisition would be made through a subsidiary, Arctic Glacier Inc.Go to Press Release from Arctic Glacier>>

headline: Suit Alleges Investors Sunk Start-Up
abstract: A group of wealthy investors, including the brother of Texas Rangers owner Tom Hicks, seized and bankrupted a promising Internet start-up to snap up its technology, according to allegations in a trial that opened yesterday.

headline: Pinnacle Entertainment Accepts Bid From Columbia Sussex
abstract: The casino operator Aztar said on Friday it has agreed to be acquired by the Columbia Sussex Corporation for $54 a share in cash and has terminated its merger agreement with Pinnacle Entertainment.

headline: Rambus Says E-Mails Back Up Price Fixing Claims
abstract: Rambus said on Thursday e-mails from Micron Technology and Hynix Semiconductor support its claims that the rival memory chip makers conspired to fix prices, sending its shares up 18.5 percent.

headline: Private Equity Bid for VNU Dealt Fresh Blow
abstract: A private equity group’s plan to buy Dutch media giant VNU, owner of Billboard magazine and the Nielsen television ratings service, was dealt a serious blow yesterday after a powerful advisory firm told shareholders to vote against several key provisions of the deal.

headline: Carrying Your Digital Life on a Keychain
abstract: My review of Lexar’s PowerToGo software, which lets you install Windows programs onto a flash drive, prompted many responses from readers.

headline: Columbia Sussex Joins Bidding War for Casino Owner Aztar
abstract: For casino operator Aztar, the stakes just keep getting higher.

headline: Mittal Preparing to Pounce on Arcelor
abstract: Mittal Steel will launch its 20.5 billion euro ($25.13 billion) offer for rival Arcelor in two weeks’ time, Mittal chief executive Lakshmi Mittal said on Wednesday.

headline: Chief Executive Is Ousted at Kraft Foods
abstract: With earnings growth lackluster and the share price stagnant, the directors of Kraft Food yesterday ousted the chief executive, Roger K. Deromedi, and named Irene B. Rosenfeld to succeed him.

headline: How to Clear the Clutter of Speaker Wires
abstract: OK, am I the only person on earth who finds it incredibly annoying that the average PC doesn’t have built-in speakers?

headline: Amdocs Buys Qpass for $275 Million
abstract: Amdocs, a maker of customer-management software, will buy Qpass, which makes e-commerce software, for $275 million in cash.

headline: J.P. Morgan Chase Names New Global Co-Heads of M&A
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase named Jimmy Elliott and Dag Skattum as the bank’s new global co-heads of mergers and acquisitions on Wednesday night. The appointments come after Robert Kindler, the former head of M&A, defected to Morgan Stanley to become vice chairman.

headline: Invensys Sells a Unit to Schneider Electric
abstract: A British engineering firm, Invensys, said on Wednesday that it had sold its building management systems operations in the United States and Asia Pacific to Schneider Electric of France for $296 million in cash.

headline: NTL’s Virgin Mobile Buy Raises Questions About One-Stop Shopping
abstract: NTL yesterday billed its 962 million pound takeover of Sir Richard Branson’s Virgin Mobile as the creation of a “truly national entertainment and communications company” that will challenge the might of its closest rivals Sky and BT.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Shareholders Sell $1.54 Billion in Stock
abstract: The parent of the New York Stock Exchange, the NYSE Group, said yesterday that shareholders had sold 25 million shares at $61.50 each for a total of $1.54 billion, less than two months after the Big Board went public. Shareholders involved in the sale include Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch, as well as executives of the NYSE Group.

headline: Buyout Firms Go to Mars, Return With Vending Machine Business
abstract: When you have $8 billion to play with, where do you begin?

headline: Rosneft I.P.O. Brings New Possibilities to the Russian Masses
abstract: This week millions of Russians have the chance to buy shares in Rosneft, the controversial Russian oil company, whose $10 billion initial public offering is taking place on the London and Moscow exchanges. As much as 30 percent of that is being offered to Russian retail investors, in what is being dubbed the “people’s I.P.O.”

headline: Big Bonus Talk Starts Early
abstract: Last Friday afternoon, as many Wall Street workers were fighting traffic to get to the Hamptons or some other holiday weekend getaway, Bloomberg News reported a notable milestone. It seems that Friday’s proposed deal between steel makers Arcelor and Severstal pushed year-to-date mergers and acquisitions volume past the previous record set in 2000, at least by Bloomberg’s reckoning.

headline: Photo-Sharing Site Shutterfly Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Shutterfly, an online photo-sharing service funded partly by a co-founder of Netscape, Jim Clark, filed with regulators to raise as much as $92 million in an initial public offering. The preliminary prospectus did not indicate how many shares it would sell or at what price.

headline: Heinz’ Cuts Leave Activist Shareholder Wanting More
abstract: Employees about to lose their jobs at H.J. Heinz may be tempted to pin the blame on billionaire investor Nelson Peltz. Heinz said Thursday it will shut down 15 plants and eliminate 2,700 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force, with the savings going toward marketing and product development — the kind of cost-cutting moves recently called for by Mr. Peltz, whose Trian Capital Management owns a 5.4 percent stake in Heinz.

headline: Bank of China Increases I.P.O. by 15%
abstract: Bank of China, the nation’s second-largest lender, increased the size of last month’s share sale by 15 percent to $11.2 billion, making it the world’s fourth-largest initial public offering.

headline: Is Microsoft Preparing A Big Attack?
abstract: Microsoft reported strong third-quarter revenue growth on Thursday, but analysts said the company also telegraphed a significant increase in spending, an indication that it was preparing to take on its big online rivals, Google and Yahoo.

headline: Harvey Pitt’s Modest Proposal: Hold Back C.E.O. Pay
abstract: Now that he has been out of government for nearly four years, Harvey Pitt, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a radical idea for how to reform corporate America. In an interview with The Globe and Mail, Mr. Pitt said companies should put a big portion of executive compensation into escrow accounts, to be paid out after a scandal-free period.

headline: Private Equity Firms Eye British Furniture Retailer
abstract: NM Rothschild has teamed up with Merchant Equity Partners, the private equity firm set up by a former Deutsche Bank managing director, Henry Jackson, to bid for the struggling retail arm of MFI Furniture, The Times of London reported.

headline: California Pensions Put Together Investment Database
abstract: California’s two largest pension funds are building a database of emerging managers and financial service providers, including emerging private equity funds and PE funds of funds.

headline: A Different Kind of Internet Stock
abstract: You can, of course, trade stocks online. If that is too stressful or too expensive, you can pretend to trade stocks on game sites. If that is too boring, there are all kinds of online “markets” that allow trading in everything from celebrities to disease epidemics.

headline: Firing Up the Burger King I.P.O.
abstract: Investors have gorged on restaurant deals this year, but do they have room for Burger King?

headline: Secretive Trilogy Equity Reveals Another Big Name Partner
abstract: Trilogy Equity Partners, a new investment firm that has quietly funded Seattle start-ups without publicly announcing itself, has revealed a third partner: former McCaw Cellular Communications executive and Western Wireless Vice Chairman Don Guthrie.

headline: International Paper Slims Down, Selling Unit to Apollo
abstract: International Paper said on Tuesday that it would sell its coated paper business to a unit of Apollo Management for $1.4 billion in a continuing effort to streamline its business operations.

headline: Invesco’s Troubled Venture Arm Said to Dangle Bonuses
abstract: Faced with the recent defection of many of its top venture capital professionals, Invesco is offering raises, bonuses and stock to try to hold on to those who remain, according to Private Equity Week. Invesco did not comment for the article, which said some of the packages were worth more than $100,000.

headline: Genworth, an Insurer, Expands With Acquisition in Australia
abstract: Genworth Financial, an insurance company based in Richmond, Va., said on Wednesday its Australian mortgage insurance subsidiary would buy Vero Lenders Mortgage Insurance in Sydney, Australia, for about $165 million before a substantial post-closing dividend.

headline: France’s BNP Paribas Eyes U.S. Acquisitions
abstract: BNP Paribas, France’s largest lender by market value, may seek acquisitions in the U.S. to expand in an economy that’s growing more than twice as fast as its home market, Chief Executive Officer Baudouin Prot said.

headline: Teck Bid For Inco Mixes Up Deals  on Several Fronts
abstract: Teck Cominco‘s surprise C$17.8 billion ($16 billion) bid for Inco Monday has set the stage for a global bidding war for the nickel producer, driven by sky-high metal prices and the need of major producers to lock down future metal supplies.

headline: McClatchy In Bind Over Newspaper Sale
abstract: As McClatchy weighs the bids it received this week for the 12 Knight Ridder papers it is selling — including The San Jose Mercury News — observers say the Sacramento company must balance the need for a quick deal with holding out for top dollar.

headline: Hedgestock: A Festival of Peace, Love and Greed
abstract: “Hedgestock,” wherein hedge fund executives gather at England’s Knebworth House for “a festival of networking” to watch rock bands perform in a 1960s-like atmosphere, must be a parody, right?

headline: Citibank Looking at Saudi Arabia
abstract: Citibank, the retail banking arm of Citigroup, is exploring ways to return to Saudi Arabia and is open to acquisitions in the Middle East and North Africa as part of aggressive regional expansion plans, William Rhodes, Citibank chairman, said on Monday.

headline: Is Canadian Link in Chicago’s Future?
abstract: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange is strong enough to resist weak merger offers, even in this era of consolidation madness, Craig Donahue, the exchange’s chief executive, recently suggested to Reuters. The exchange can be “very selective” because it is growing faster than any other exchange, he said, adding, “we are always looking at different kinds of opportunities.”

headline: Owner Puts Britain’s Moody on the Block, Report Says
abstract: An industrial testing and inspection business, Moody International, has been put up for a potential $250 million-$300 million sale by its private equity owner, Close Brothers Private Equity, The Telegraph reported.

headline: In Warnaco Takeover Rumors, Some See Nice Fit
abstract: Is Phillips-Van Heusen trying Warnaco on for size? It is just speculation at this point, but Wednesday’s anonymously sourced report in apparel-industry trade publication Women’s Wear Daily drew a positive response from some analysts. Phillips-Van Heusen bought Calvin Klein in 2002, and Warnaco is Calvin Klein’s biggest licensee. Lazard Capital Markets  analyst Todd Slater published a report Thursday stating that such a combination “simply makes compelling financial sense.”

headline: NYSE Shareholder to Push for London Alliance, Not Merger
abstract: One of the biggest shareholders in the New York Stock Exchange is to propose a strategic link between the Big Board and the London Stock Exchange, instead of a merger or takeover, at a meeting with John Thain, the N.Y.S.E. chief executive, set to take place within the next week, according to a report in The Times of London.

headline: Merrill Analyst Backs VNU Takeover Bid
abstract: The soap opera over the buyout of Dutch media giant VNU, owner of Nielsen TV ratings and Billboard magazine, appears close to being over after a Merrill Lynch analyst called for shareholders to support the sweetened $9.6 billion takeover bid from a group of private-equity giants.

headline: Aztar Bidding Breaks $50-Per-Share Barrier
abstract: Officially, the world’s longest poker tournament was a 72-hour affair in 2004. Unofficially, the seven-week bidding frenzy for casino operator Aztar is a strong candidate.

headline: UBS to Buy Piper Jaffray’s Private Client Unit
abstract: UBS, Europe’s largest bank by assets, agreed to buy the private client network of Minneapolis- based Piper Jaffray Companies for as much as $875 million to expand its wealth management business in the U.S. UBS will pay $500 million in cash and an extra $75 million depending on business performance, the Zurich-based bank said in an e-mailed statement Tuesday.

headline: Buffet to Auction His Ukulele
abstract: In case you didn’t know, Warren Buffett plays the ukulele. Now the billionaire is auctioning one on eBay. The world’s second-richest person, who runs Berkshire Hathaway, plans to auction an autographed ukulele, on eBay’s Web site later this month.

headline: Hedge Funds: Let’s Regulate Ourselves, and Quick
abstract: As European governments make noises about imposing stiff regulations on hedge funds, the industry is talking more about regulating itself, according to Bill Barnhart, a columnist with the Chicago Tribune.

headline: Home Depot Alters Rules for Electing Its Directors
abstract: Home Depot, in a bow to disgruntled shareholders, said yesterday that it would require a majority vote from shareholders for the election of board members.

headline: Host Hotels Acquires a Resort in Scottsdale, Ariz.
abstract: A real estate investment trust, Host Hotels & Resorts, said on Monday it had agreed to buy Westin Kierland Resort & Spa in Scottsdale, Ariz., for about $258 million. Host Hotels, which is based in Bethesa, Md., will also assume $135 million of existing debt.

headline: Lone Star’s Korea Head Embezzled Millions
abstract: Lone Star Funds founder John Grayken said the buyout firm’s former South Korea country head embezzled “millions of dollars,” causing the firm to breach tax rules.

headline: The Banks Have Paid Up, but Investors Fail to Collect
abstract: Investors entitled to $164.3 million in compensation for losses from faulty Wall Street research appear in no hurry to collect what they are owed.

headline: Promoting Formula One
abstract: Spanish Renault driver Fernando Alonso (C) celebrates with the Renault team after winning the Formula one Spanish Grand Prix. (AFP/Damien Meyer).

headline: Sun Countersues Azul Over Java Patents
abstract: Sun Microsystems filed a countersuit Wednesday against Java hardware maker Azul Systems, arguing that the start-up infringed six Sun patents and misappropriated trade secrets to build its Java hardware.

headline: Rating Skilling’s Court Debut
abstract: The trial of two former Enron executives entered an important new phase as Jeffrey Skilling, the energy company’s former chief executive, took the stand in his own defense this week. He was nothing if not emphatic, declaring that he was “absolutely innocent” of charges that he conspired to defraud Enron and vowed that he would fight the charges “until the day I die.”

headline: China’s Worries May Halt PCCW Sale
abstract: Opposition from the Chinese government could prevent Hong Kong’s PCCW from completing a deal with foreign bidders trying to acquire the company’s telecom and media assets, according to media reports Tuesday.

headline: Independent Research Not Really Working Out
abstract: When Wall Street’s top investment banks formalized their $1.4 billion global research settlement with the SEC in April 2003, in addition to making numerous reforms, they agreed to pay $450 million over five years to provide clients with independent equity research alongside their own. The idea was to create a new model for the industry that would avoid the conflicts of the old investment banking-driven one, while still producing a high-quality product. But in practice, it doesn’t seem to be working for much of anyone.

headline: European Regulators Likely to Start Action Against France Over Foreign Investment
abstract: The European Commission is likely to begin legal action against France on Tuesday over a French decree declaring 11 business sectors, from casinos to military technology, off limits to foreign investment. The decision will intensify a growing showdown between the commission and Paris over concerns that France is increasingly skewing markets and industries for domestic political and commercial ends

headline: Aerovance gets $30 Million in Fresh Funding
abstract: Berkeley, Calif.-based respiratory and inflammatory drug developer Aerovance said it has secured $60 million of Series C funding. The deal was co-led by Clarus Ventures and marks the Cambridge, Mass., firm’s first investment from its $500 million inaugural fund.

headline: As Google Looks to China, Some See 51Job As Target
abstract: American depositary receipts of 51job, a Chinese human resources company, touched a new 52-week high on Monday after an analyst included the company in a list of possible acquisition targets for Google. The A.D.R.’s closed at $21.53 on Monday, up nearly 13 percent.

headline: Annual Meeting Today to Test G.M. Theory of Relativity
abstract: Even though General Motors lost $10.6 billion last year and faces a particularly uncertain future, its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, will undoubtedly find plenty of good news to talk about at its annual shareholders’ meeting in Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday.

headline: American Mold I.P.O. Doesn’t Gather Moss
abstract: American Mold Guard‘s initial public offering notched gains Wednesday on the first day the maker of anti-mold coatings became a publicly traded stock. American Mold Guard opened at $12.75, below its $13 price, and rose to $13.30 in its debut on the Nasdaq Small Cap Market.

headline: Game Maker Settles with F.T.C. on Racy Hidden Content
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software, publisher of the video game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, has agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission accusations that it failed to disclose that animated sex scenes were hidden on the game’s discs.

headline: NetSuite On Track for I.P.O.
abstract: On-demand business software vendor NetSuite has confirmed that it is on target for an initial public offering around the turn of the year, which it hopes will see the company valued at $1 billion.

headline: Deutsche Borse Board Plots Counteroffer for Euronext
abstract: The executive board of Deutsche Borse has met its financial advisers in an attempt to establish by how much it can raise its offer for pan-European stock exchange group Euronext, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Weill, Lee Help Raise Funds (But Not That Kind)
abstract: In case you were wondering what former Citigroup chairman Sandy Weill and buyout veteran Thomas Lee were doing now that they are between jobs, the New York Social Diary Web site offers a partial answer — complete with party pics of not only Messrs. Weill and Lee, but also the still-employed Donald Trump, Martha Stewart, Federated Department Stores Chief Executive Donald Lundgren and other business and media types.

headline: Silver Exchange-Traded Fund Set for Sparkling Debut
abstract: At long last, a silver exchange-traded fund that has been in the works for over a year is expected to begin trading Friday. A registration statement for the highly-anticipated E.T.F. from Barclays Global Investors was declared effective at 10 a.m. Eastern time Thursday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, clearing the way for the E.T.F. to list, an SEC spokesman said.

headline: J.P. Morgan Chase Reports Record 1st-Quarter Profits
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase, the third-biggest U.S. bank, said first-quarter profit rose to a record, buoyed by higher fees from investment banking and fewer credit card defaults.

headline: Challenge to Sarbanes-Oxley Anti-Fraud Law May End Up in Supreme Court
abstract: A constitutional challenge by conservatives to the law that reshaped corporate governance after a wave of business scandals likely will end up before the Supreme Court, attorney Kenneth Starr says.

headline: Would Stolichnaya Taste So Sweet Under Any Other Name?
abstract: What’s in a name? Well, quite a lot actually, if the name happens to be Stolichnaya, the world’s best-selling vodka. To be precise, some $2 billion in annual sales, including $400 million in the U.S.

headline: Heinz Plans Campaign Against Shareholder
abstract: The H. J. Heinz Company said it was planning a vigorous campaign against attempts by the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz to get the company to raise profit.

headline: Time Warner C.E.O. Sees Wireless Push Ahead
abstract: Only a few weeks have passed since Time Warner C.E.O. Richard Parsons put down an insurrection from shareholders seeking to break up his company. But Mr. Parsons has clearly moved on — and he is now is talking about acquisitions.

headline: Carlyle Picks Up Party Favors
abstract: The private equity powerhouse Carlyle Group announced Tuesday that it would buy a party supply company, the Oriental Trading Company from a fellow buyout shop, Brentwood Associates. According to an earlier report in The Wall Street Journal, the deal is valued at about $1 billion, including $300 million to $400 million in equity.

headline: Interpublic Moves Closer to a Big Consolidation
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies is stepping up talks on plans to combine two of its four largest worldwide agencies. The plans, if they reach fruition, would result in the most significant changes at Interpublic in five years.

headline: Ignition Adds $80 Million to Third Fund
abstract: Ignition Partners, the Seattle-area venture capital firm run by wireless industry notables and Microsoft alumni, has expanded its $300 million third fund with an additional $80 million earmarked for helping its start-ups grow up fast through acquisitions.

headline: Adept Sells Stock to Private Equity Firm
abstract: Adept Technology agreed Monday to sell $10 million worth of its common stock to Crosslink Capital. Livermore-based Adept will sell the shares at $13.6752 each. The deal represents about 11 percent of the company’s outstanding shares before the financing.

headline: Merrill’s Talks to Settle Discrimination Case Break Down
abstract: Merrill Lynch said Tuesday settlement talks have broken down in a lawsuit accusing it of discriminating against African-American brokers.

headline: The Two Sides of the Biovail-Overstock Story
abstract: Are Biovail and Overstock.com promising companies victimized by unscrupulous investors illegally conspiring with stock analysts and journalists? Or are they troubled firms whose executives have turned to wild conspiracy theories to divert attention from underlying business problems?

headline: Stars ‘n cars (Part 3)
abstract: American actor Kevin Spacey (L) seen with Red Bull Racing team drivers Austrian Christian Klein (2nd L), Dutch Robert Doornbos (C) and Scottish David Coulthard (R). (EPA/Oliver Weiken).

headline: Foot Locker Gains on Outlook and Takeover Talk
abstract: Shares in Foot Locker, the athletic shoe retailer, rose as much as 14 percent on Friday, lifted by two bullish brokers’ notes predicting stronger sales and profitability later this year. The company reported solid quarterly results on Wednesday.

headline: Calpine to Sell Power Plants
abstract: Calpine said Tuesday it plans to sell about one-fifth of its power plants, pare its work force and close some offices in a bid to re-emerge from bankruptcy as a leaner company centered on its profitable operations.

headline: Hamilton again
abstract: Sunday morning at Silverstone with massive traffic backed up on the roads leading into the circuit, I would later wish I could deal with that the way Lewis Hamilton dealt with the “traffic” in the second GP2 race. Starting eighth, the British driver who leads the series and won the race yesterday and in Monaco, fought his way up to win. Two magnificent moments of passing included moving into second after going around the outside of two other cars, three abreast, and coming out ahead as if on a different track. He then passed the leader a few laps later and cruised through to the victory 9.0 seconds ahead of the second placed driver, Felix Porteiro.

headline: Zale Says It Is Target of Inquiry by S.E.C.
abstract: Zale, the largest U.S. jewelry retailer, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started a probe into the company’s accounting, executive pay and other matters. Shares of Zale fell $2.64, or 9.5 percent, to $25.16 in New York Stock Exchange trading.

headline: Orphan Drug Developer Raises $50 Million
abstract: Orphan drug developer CardioKine raised $50 million in a second round of venture capital co-led by Advent Venture Partners and Fidelity Biosciences to finance Phase 3 clinical trials of a lead drug candidate and to continue a search for additional abandoned drug projects for the treatment of heart disease.

headline: Bain About To Get Its Investment in Bombardier Back
abstract: An investor group led by the Boston buyout house Bain Capital is engineering a dividend recapitalization of Bombardier Recreational Products of Canada that could more than repay the investors’ original investment in the company, which makes snowmobiles and outboard motors, after just two and a half years.

headline: Lockheed Inks Deal for ISX
abstract: Lockheed Martin reached a definitive agreement to acquire ISX of Camarillo, Calif. Terms were not disclosed, but Lockheed, which is based in Bethesda, Md., said ISX makes military decision systems and other information technology solutions for government customers.

headline: A Handy Tip From a Reader on Flash Drives
abstract: It’s mind-blowing: you can run an entire operating system off of your flash drive.

headline: Wikia Hires eBay Executive to Take CEO Role
abstract: Wikia, a for-profit company founded 18 months ago by Wikipedia’s founder, Jimmy Wales, hired eBay veteran Gil Penchina as its chief executive on Monday. Mr. Penchina, who worked at the online auction site for eight years, served as vice president and general manager at eBay.

headline: JDA Software Picks Up Manugistics
abstract: JDA Software has agreed to acquire supply-chain software maker Manugistics in a deal that values the company at $211 million. Under the terms of the transaction, JDA will pay $2.50 for each Manugistics share.

headline: Euronext Dumps L.S.E. Bid After Nasdaq Takes Stake
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market‘s purchase of a 15 percent stake of the London Stock Exchange has succeeded in turning away one potential competitor as Euronext on Wednesday said it is no longer interested in buying the British exchange. Euronext specifically cited the Nasdaq’s stake purchase as its reason for backing out of contention to buy the L.S.E.

headline: A Torrent of Comments on a New Blog Format
abstract: The feedback I’ve received about my blog’s new format makes you ask yourself: What is a blog, really? And how much of it is in the formatting?

headline: ‘Ace’ Greenberg’s Magic Act Is Back
abstract: As some industry veterans may know, Alan “Ace” Greenberg, who spent a half-century at Bear Stearns before stepping down as chairman of the securities firm in 2001, is also an amateur magician. He will perform some tricks at the Parkinson’s Disease Foundation gala on May 17 at New York’s Pierre Hotel, The New York Post’s Page Six reports. Mr. Greenber’s father suffered from Parkinson’s.

headline: Troubled Times for Distressed Funds
abstract: There may be signs of distress among distressed debt investors, driven by a lack of opportunities as fund managers scramble for new investment choices.

headline: Wal-Mart Treads Lightly Into Private Equity
abstract: There has been plenty of publicity over Wal-Mart Stores‘ recently stated desire to open a bank. But we would wager that few people were aware that the retail giant has just dipped its toe into private equity investing.

headline: Google Pockets $2 Billion in Stock Sale
abstract: Google  raised $2.07 billion in a stock sale that will bolster cash reserves to fight Yahoo and Microsoft. The 5.3 million shares were priced at $389.75 each, Mountain View, California-based Google said Friday in a statement. Its second stock sale in seven months raised more than Google’s $1.67 billion initial public offering in August 2004.

headline: Media General to Buy NBC Affiliates for $600 Million
abstract: Katie Couric is not the only asset that is leaving the NBC fold. The company has agreed to sell four NBC-owned and -operated television stations to Media General for $600 million in cash, Media General said early Thursday. UBS Investment Bank advised NBC in the transaction.

headline: Chief’s Pay Is Docked by Raytheon
abstract: Raytheon directors punished the chief executive, William H. Swanson, by taking away almost $1 million from his 2006 compensation Wednesday because he failed to give credit for material that was in a management book he wrote.

headline: J. Crew Shares Climb 28 Percent in Debut
abstract: The J. Crew Group‘s shares rose nearly 28 percent yesterday on their first day of trading after being priced at a higher-than-expected level, capping off the most successful retail initial public offering in years.

headline: Pennsylvania Wind Power Company Sells Out to Spanish Rival
abstract: U.S. wind-power company Community Energy agreed yesterday to be bought for $30 million by Iberdrola, a big Spanish rival. The Wayne, Pa.-based company said it was selling out because wind’s sudden emergence as a competitive alternative has made it difficult for a small company to obtain equipment increasingly in short supply.

headline: Possible Verizon Deal for Phone Lines Stirs Up Vodafone Talk
abstract: It doesn’t take much to stir speculation that Verizon Communications will purchase Vodafone Group‘s 45 percent stake in the companies’ wireless venture.

headline: Insitu Gets Fresh Funding
abstract: Robotic aircraft manufacturer Insitu Group has already reached profitability on the strength of several government contracts. Now, the company hopes to aim for the commercial marketplace with $23 million in fresh capital from venture investors.

headline: Texas Pacific Pushes for Compromise in Mobilcom-Freenet Merger
abstract: Mobilcom‘s top investor, the Texas Pacific Group, is pressing for a compromise in a row involving dissident shareholders opposing mobilcom’s merger with freenet.de.

headline: V.C.s Size Up Fashion Start-Ups
abstract: Can investing in a fledgling fashion house reap profits?

headline: Canadian V.C.s Want Help Attracting Investment
abstract: Canada’s venture capital industry is having trouble attracting as much investment as it would like, and it wants governments to help attract money from pension funds by providing loan guarantees.

headline: Sanpaolo Picks Citigroup as Acquisition Adviser
abstract: Sanpaolo IMI has appointed Citigroup as its adviser to study possible alliances, the Italian bank’s director general, Pietro Modiano, said on Wednesday.

headline: Water Street Capital Invests in Pathology Firm
abstract: Private equity firm Water Street Capital Partners‘ $50 million investment in a New Jersey pathology company helps maintain the Chicago area’s reputation as a major source for the health-care industry’s capital needs for growth.

headline: Fatter Salaries Await New M.B.A.’s, Survey Finds
abstract: For the latest crop of M.B.A. holders, here is a number to ponder: $92,360. That, according to the Graduate Management Admission Council, is the average starting base salary for business school graduates in the class of 2006 (among those who had jobs, that is). That is up 4.2 percent from last year, according to the nonprofit organization, which may be best known to business students as the outfit that administers the Graduate Management Admission Test.

headline: Phillips-Van Heusen Likes the Looks of Warnaco, Report Says
abstract: Phillips-Van Heusen may be exceeding its quarterly financial projections, but it remains hot on the acquisitions hunt to maintain the momentum. And one company that Women’s Wear Daily said PVH has its eyes on is Warnaco.

headline: SAP to Start Its Own Venture Fund
abstract: German software giant SAP is expected to announce soon a $100 million venture capital fund to promote its NetWeaver software, according to The San Jose Mercury News. SAP is creating the NetWeaver Fund to finance start-up companies that will create products that use NetWeaver software. NetWeaver is used to develop corporate Web applications.

headline: Art That Distorts Perspective, All on a Sidewalk
abstract: These photos of sidewalk art will blow your mind.

headline: Seeking to Repel Mittal, Arcelor  Puts Canadian Unit Into a Trust
abstract: Plans announced on Tuesday by European steel company Arcelor to repel a $23 billion takeover bid by Mittal Steel left the hostile bidder undeterred. Mittal said that Arcelor’s plan – which included raising its dividend and putting its steel maker Dofasco into a protective trust — did not change its intention of pursuing the company, adding that its bid was not dependent on the sale of Dofasco. “Nothing in this announcement alters our resolve or ability to proceed with our offer,” Mittal said.

headline: With Acquisitions Scarce, Buffett Bets on Global Markets
abstract: Warren Buffett, struggling to find acquisitions large enough to improve Berkshire Hathaway‘s returns, is making a $14 billion bet on the global stock market. Berkshire sold a form of insurance to buyers who wanted protection from a drop in “four major equity indexes” over the next 15 to 20 years. Instead of buying the individual shares, Mr. Buffett is wagering the indexes, three of which are outside the United States, will not fall and force Berkshire to pay a claim.

headline: Jilted Severstal Now Eyes Corus
abstract: The Russian steel company Severstal is considering a bid for an Anglo-Dutch rival, Corus, just days after its merger attempt with Luxembourg’s Arcelor was derailed, Reuters reported.

headline: MasterCard’s Legal Woes Are Lesson for Investors
abstract: MasterCard shares have been on a tear since its highly anticipated initial public offering late last month but legal concerns continue to hang over the company, an issue that could give investors a reason to proceed with caution.

headline: Apple’s Jobs Has No Intention of Entering Magic Kingdom
abstract: Apple Computer C.E.O. Steve Jobs said Thursday he had no interest in becoming an executive at The Walt Disney Company, which will soon complete its acquisition of Jobs’ other company, Pixar Animation Studios.

headline: Bermingham Three to Face Extradition in Enron Case
abstract: The European Court of Human Rights refused on Tuesday to halt extradition proceedings against three British bankers wanted in the United States on fraud charges related to the Enron collapse.

headline: Interpublic to Decide Soon on Merger of Two Units
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies will decide in the next few weeks whether to combine two of its largest agencies, the direct-marketing specialist Draft and the general agency Foote Cone & Belding.

headline: Michaels Stores Mulling Offers
abstract: The directors of Michaels Stores, the nation’s largest arts and crafts retailer, are expected to meet today to consider two takeover bids that could value the company at more than $5.2 billion, said the New York Times.

headline: Protecting Jeff Bezos
abstract: Amazon.com spent $1.1 million last year protecting Chief Executive Jeff Bezos, according to regulatory filings.

headline: Lukewarm Response for Pacific Shipping Trust’s I.P.O.
abstract: Asia’s first business trust to seek a listing has met with lukewarm response from institutional investors, forcing it to lower the price and bump up the yield.

headline: As Tech Giants Hunt for Startups, Oracle Pounces
abstract: Oracle announced yet another acquisition on Thursday. This time the target is Demantra, an Israeli startup that makes product-management software. Financial terms were not disclosed, but an Israel-based newsletter, Globes, put the price at $41 million in cash. Oracle has recently agreed to buy SleepyCat, Net4Call and Portal Software, among other companies.

headline: Macau Gambling Mecca’s Owners Will Take Casino Public
abstract: James Packer’s Publishing & Broadcasting and Melco International Development are planning to sell $1 billion of shares in an initial public offering of their Macau casino venture, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Stars and cars (Part 2)
abstract: Actor Owen Wilson poses as he arrives for the premiere of the Disney/Pixar animated film “Cars” at Lowe’s Motor Speedway in Concord, North Carolina. (AP/Terry Renna).

headline: Australian Regulator May Delay Ferrovial’s Move on BAA
abstract: Plans by the Ferrovial consortium to buy enough shares of BAA, the British airport operator, to stop a Goldman Sachs-led rival from breaking up its agreed 10.1 billion pound bid for BAA have been thwarted by a regulatory issue in Australia.

headline: Cisco Buys 2 Start-Ups
abstract: Cisco Systems, one of the more frequent shoppers of venture-backed companies, has snapped up two communications software start-ups, Metreos and Audium, for a combined $47.8 million.

headline: Myriad Groups in Race for MotoGP
abstract: Six venture capital groups are racing to buy the Spanish company that owns the rights to MotoGP – motorcycling’s answer to Formula One – which is up for sale with a price tag of 500 million euros.

headline: Evercore Shows M&A Muscle
abstract: Evercore Partners‘ well-connected, experienced executives and its focus on the largest clients and biggest deals has catapulted the boutique investment bank into the top echelon of merger and acquisition advisers during the first quarter of 2006.

headline: OECD Calls Warns Canada on Restrictve Bank Mergers
abstract: The Organization for Economic Co-Operation and Development is warning that Canada’s effective ban on bank mergers could be hampering the country’s productivity and is urging Ottawa to remove the political red tape that has been choking the industry’s efforts to consolidate.

headline: Buyout Group Acquires  World’s Largest Dialysis Maker
abstract: Investor AB and EQT Partners AB agreed to buy Gambro AB, the world’s largest maker of dialysis products, for 38.3 billion Swedish kronor ($4.9 billion).

headline: LBOs Don’t Necessarily Line Banks’ Pockets
abstract: The worldwide boom in leveraged buyouts isn’t translating into record fees for some of the biggest banks and securities firms, including Citigroup and Merrill Lynch.

headline: Fold, Fold and Fold Some More
abstract: You think YOUR job requires hours of concentration and mind-numbing detail? These photos of Robert J. Lang’s origami ought to put that in perspective.

headline: Stern-Less CBS May Sell Stations
abstract: Howard Stern’s defection from CBS so badly damaged the company’s radio business that CBS chief executive Les Moonves — the shock jock’s latest archenemy — is considering selling off stations.

headline: Debenhams Makes $1.7 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: Debenhams, the second-largest department-store owner in Britain, sold shares for 950 million pounds ($1.7 billion) in an initial public offering to repay debt and allow existing investors to realize gains.

headline: Hedge Fund Increasing Stake in Mills
abstract: Stark Investments, a hedge fund with a sizeable investment in Mills, the troubled mall developer, has increased its stake in the company. Stark has purchased 720,000 shares in the company since late March and now controls 4.95 million shares, or 8.7 percent of Mills’s stock.

headline: European Regulator Relaxes Poison Pill Laws
abstract: The European Union is set to enact a less-restrictive law that would leave in place “poison pills” and other defenses against hostile corporate takeovers.

headline: Dexia of Belgium Buys Stake in Turkish Lender
abstract: Dexia, the third-biggest bank in Belgium, agreed to buy 75 percent of Turkish lender DenizBank for about $2.44 billion to expand in an economy that’s growing faster than its home market.

headline: Stock Case Puts Icahn Back in the Spotlight
abstract: Three weeks ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission brought a closure of sorts to a Wall Street swindle, charging the financier Adnan Khashoggi in a stock-rigging scheme known as the Genesis Intermedia affair.

headline: A White Elephant, Whiff of Scandal Included
abstract: No. 10 Toronto Street, an elegant three-story Greek Revival building, is arguably one of Canada’s best-known business addresses. Since 1978, when he took over Argus, it has been known as both the personal office of Conrad M. Black and the hub of his business empire. Now Hollinger, one of the corporations that succeeded Argus as Lord Black’s main corporate vehicles, has put the 153-year-old building up for sale after evicting its former chairman.

headline: On Wall Street, What’s Good for The Google Is Not Good for The Times
abstract: On Wall Street, it’s all about money. Even when it comes to noble sentiments like democracy and equality, stock price counts for lots more than principle does, writes Allan Sloan. Consider, if you will, the differing ways the Street is treating The New York Times Company and Google, both of which have high-voting stock for insiders and low-voting stock for regular old public shareholders.

headline: Burst.com Files Countersuit Against Apple
abstract: Burst.com has filed a countersuit against Apple Computer claiming that the iTunes software, the iPod and the Quicktime streaming software all infringe on patents held by Burst.com, Burst announced Monday.

headline: Investors Should Beware of Ethanol I.P.Os
abstract: A crop of ethanol producers is fetching premium I.P.O. valuations, but their growth is predicated on unsustainable ethanol prices, according to Breakingviews. As Alan Greenspan noted this week, the economics of the business aren’t there and Breakingviews warns that investors may be in for some nasty surprises.

headline: Villeneuve’s “penalty”
abstract: Canadian Formula One driver Jacques Villeneuve (front) of BMW Sauber steers in front of Italian Giancarlo Fisichella of Renault during the Qualifying session at the Grand Prix on Saturday. (EPA/Jens Buettner).

headline: Analyst Changes Tune on N.Y.S.E. Pay
abstract: Facing the wrath of the New York Stock Exchange, a Bear Stearns research analyst has gone back and re-crunched the numbers related to the exchange’s compensation. His new conclusion, according to The New York Post? The N.Y.S.E.’s average per-employee pay is right in the middle of its peer group.

headline: Investors Boost Online Auctioneer
abstract: Gmarket has raised $139.1 million from its Nasdaq I.P.O. Investors appear to have ignored the still-shaky market environment and bought into the company’s quest to become the top e-commerce marketplace provider and online auctioneer in Korea.

headline: Movie Gallery Set for Blockbuster Deal?
abstract: Monday’s 17 percent jump in shares of Movie Gallery  added fuel to recent speculation that the video rental chain is ripe to be acquired. A larger rival, Blockbuster, and the online rental service Netflix were mentioned as potential buyers of Movie Gallery, whose market capitalization now stands at about $220 million.

headline: Skadden Arps Promotes 32 to Counsel
abstract: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP announced Thursday that it had appointed 32 attorneys to counsel. Last month, the firm named 30 new partners.

headline: Lehman Woos Away Bush Cousin
abstract: After months of courtship, Lehman Brothers landed George H. Walker IV – a gilded Goldman Sachs partner and President Bush’s second cousin – as head of its huge asset management business.

headline: Apollo Wants to Fast Track Its I.P.O.
abstract: Apollo Management, the New York-based private equity firm, is raising a $1.5 billion publicly traded private equity vehicle similar to the one raised on May 3 by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Branson Spins Sale of Record Label
abstract: Richard Branson, the eccentric British billionaire whose businesses run the gamut from health clubs to airlines, is getting out of the business in which he first made his mark: music.

headline: MediaNews Group and McClatchy Sidestep Questions
abstract: Two newspaper executives sidestepped questions on Tuesday about reports that MediaNews Group was close to a deal with McClatchy to buy four Knight Ridder papers.

headline: Chinese Oil Producer Sets $1.98 Billion Stock Sale
abstract: Cnooc, China’s biggest offshore oil producer, is selling as much as HK$15.4 billion ($1.98 billion) in existing stock as the company expands to meet energy demand in the world’s fastest-growing major economy.

headline: Google Trends and Scottish Short Sellers
abstract: Dealbook spent some time playing — ahem, conducting research — on Google‘s new Web tool, Google Trends. The service reports how often a given term has been searched on Google, as well as where in the world the searches originated.

headline: Trade in Arcelor Shares Suspended as Board Meets
abstract: Shares in takeover target Arcelor were suspended on Wednesday while directors of the steel group held a board meeting in Luxembourg, pending a statement from the company.

headline: Morgan Stanley Takes Bid for TransMontaigne Higher
abstract: It has been a while since the last bidding war — one of DealBook’s recent favorites involved the casino operator Aztar — but it seems that Morgan Stanley is doing its best to spark a new one. The securities firm said Monday said it had sent TransMontaigne a letter proposing to buy the petroleum-products marketer and distributor for $11.35 a share in cash, up from its previous bid of $11 a share and ahead of a rival $11.25-a-share bid from SemGroup.

headline: The Hard Edge of a Fluff Machine
abstract: Beneath its gossamer skin of celebrity sightings and innuendo, Page Six occupies a significant coordinate in the business cosmology of New York City. Scores are kept and settled on the page, deals are floated and brands, both personal and corporate, are forged and melted down.

headline: Arcelor Rejects Mittal as Battle Continues
abstract: Arcelor, the world’s second-largest steelmaker, said it rejected a revised offer by hostile suitor Mittal Steel and will meet Mittal again to discuss the prospect of a higher bid.

headline: In Phelps Dodge Deal, Atticus Looms Large
abstract: Institutional investors gave Phelps Dodge executives a “rude reception” this week during a meeting at New York’s Park Avenue Cafe to discuss the copper miner’s plans for a three-way acquisition of Inco and Falconbridge, TheStreet.com reported Friday.

headline: Spitzer Adds To Case Against H&R Block
abstract: New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer has added more allegations to his $250 million lawsuit against H&R Block, which he accused in March of marketing money-losing IRAs to its customers.

headline: Intelsat Slashes Bond Sale Amid Waning Demand
abstract: Intelsat, the satellite provider to the United States military, cut the size of its planned sale of junk bonds on Tuesday by $600 million, to $2.9 billion, in a reflection of waning investor demand for high-yield, high-risk debt.

headline: Attorneys Say Enron Law Firm Was Complicit in Fraud
abstract: Plaintiffs’ attorneys in the Enron shareholder lawsuit filed papers Tuesday saying Houston law firm Vinson & Elkins helped executives at the company conduct a massive accounting fraud that led to that firm’s December 2001 bankruptcy and billions of dollars in investor losses.

headline: Fortis to Acquire Energy Trading Units from Duke
abstract: The Dutch-Belgian financial services group Fortis said on Tuesday it would buy two North American power and gas trading companies for about 330 million euros ($415 million).

headline: Eurotunnel Inches Closer to Restructuring Its Debt
abstract: Eurotunnel has signed a preliminary binding restructuring agreement over 6 billion pounds of debt with its major creditors and will present the plan to other debt holders in coming weeks.

headline: Delphi Says It Needs More Time to Reorganize
abstract: The auto parts maker Delphi has asked the United States Bankruptcy Court to extend until February its sole right to file a reorganization plan, citing the size and complexity of its restructuring.

headline: Know When to Hold ‘Em: Advice on Shareholder Activists
abstract: As hedge funds like Jana Partners fire off scathing letters to boards of directors — see item below — a prominent law firm is offering some advice for companies on handling shareholder activists (which seem to be especially active these days).

headline: Can Private Equity Resist Call of Public Markets?
abstract: Private equity players Blackstone Group and Carlyle Group have reportedly postponed plans to launch listed buyout funds. In the current market conditions, it’s not surprising. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts  already mopped up most of the demand.

headline: Betsey Johnson on the Block?
abstract: The designer Betsey Johnson has never been one to conform to the latest trends, but even this wild child of American fashion seemingly can’t resist the lure of Wall Street.

headline: For Goldman, British Retreats Are Becoming a Habit
abstract: It looks like the battle for the world’s biggest airport operator, BAA , is over, with a group led by Spain’s Ferrovial outmaneuvering a consortium with Goldman Sachs up front.

headline: Two Firms Form Pelican Life Sciences
abstract: Grotech Capital and Ferrer Freeman have committed about $100 million in equity to roll out Pelican Life Sciences, a platform that will acquire companies that make products used in life sciences and pharmaceutical research.

headline: Icahn and Lichtenstein Cooking Up Hostile Bid for KT&G
abstract: Carl Icahn and Warren Lichtenstein are preparing a hostile takeover for KT&G after South Korea’s biggest tobacco company rejected a $10 billion bid by the U.S. investors, according to a local securities company.

headline: Last Year’s Bordeaux May Go Well With This Year’s Bonuses
abstract: With talk of big bonuses for 2006 already swirling on Wall Street, investment bankers may find that a few cases of exceptional Bordeaux go well with a fat pay-check. The Berry Brothers wine-buying team has recently returned from Bordeaux and they say that there is little doubt that 2005 is one of the greatest vintages of all time: more structured than 2000, more concentrated than 1996, purer fruit than the 1990 and more classic and terroir-driven than the 1982.

headline: New World Pasta Acquired by Spanish Food Company
abstract: A Spanish food company, Ebro Puleva, said on Wednesday it had bought the leading pasta company in North America, New World Pasta, for $362.5 million.

headline: ‘Unbundling’ Trend Grows With Cowen Disclosure
abstract: Cowen Group, which is being spun off from France’s Societe Generale, has revealed that it is the latest investment bank to try “unbundling,” TheStreet.com reported. Unbundling involves the decoupling of research and trading services, which have historically been sold together — an arrangement that has recently drawn criticism over potential conflicts of interest.

headline: As Remarkable as One, Two, Three
abstract: Yesterday, I posted a note about the freaky time and date that popped up today: 01:02:03 04/05/06, and the blogosphere reacted quickly.

headline: Angel Closes New Fund Aimed at Women and Minorities
abstract: Officials have announced the initial closing of a new angel investment fund that will target high growth, women and minority-led companies located in Wisconsin and the Midwest.

headline: UnitedHealth Halts Executive Options
abstract: The UnitedHealth Group, under fire for the timing of lucrative options grants to executives, said Monday that it had discontinued equity-based awards to its two most senior managers and that it would cease other perks like paying for personal use of corporate aircraft.

headline: Biotech Proteolix Raises $45 Million
abstract: Proteolix closed its series B round of venture funding after raising $45 million. The South San Francisco biotech company said Wednesday that Delphi Ventures led the round and that Deepa Pakianathan, a Delphi partner, took a seat on the Proteolix board.

headline: Stone Energy Favors $1.4 Billion Bid Over Current Deal
abstract: An oil and gas producer, Stone Energy, said on Monday that a $1.4 billion takeover offer from Energy Partners was “superior” to its previous agreement to be bought by Plains Exploration & Production. The decision gives Plains Exploration until Friday to decide if it will make a counterbid.

headline: Weekend Reading: Profile of  a Short Seller
abstract: As the controversial hedge fund manager David A. Rocker prepares to retire, Michelle Celarier of Absolute Return magazine offers this look at how he created one of the best-known short-selling machines on Wall Street. Here’s the complete text of the story, plus a link to the table of contents of Absolute Return’s current issue.

headline: Private Equity Firms Buy Berry Plastics for $2.25 Billion
abstract: Apollo Management and Graham Partners, two private equity firms, said on Wednesday that they agreed to buy the Berry Plastics, a maker of plastic containers and packaging, for $2.25 billion.

headline: Who Let These Tech I.P.O.s In ?
abstract: The quality of several technology companies that have recently filed for I.P.O.s has Fortune wondering if we’re back in a tech bubble after all. Of six prominent tech I.P.O.s in registration right now – Vonage, Riverbed Technology, Clearwire, Alien, GoDaddy and DivX – just one, DivX, is profitable.

headline: Proxy Battle to Be Waged Over Electronic Exchange
abstract: Although the future of Arbinet-thexchange could hinge on a proxy fight pitting management against the company’s founder, Alex Mashinsky, whichever side wins faces a major task nursing the ailing electronic telecommuncations exchange back to health.

headline: Tzero Technologies Nabs $25 Million
abstract: TZero Technologies, a developer of ultra wideband chips used to wirelessly transmit video inside of households, has raised a $25.5 million Series B round of funding to help it start marketing and selling to equipment manufacturers.

headline: Takeover Chatter Lights Up Western Digital
abstract: Just a few months ago, the bigwigs at Samsung Electronics boasted that flash memory would wipe out the hard-drive industry in the next few years. Now there are persistent rumors that the Korean giant may buy Western Digital , the world’s No. 2 maker of hard drives — and the chatter is giving Western’s shares a bit of a lift.

headline: Japanese Central Bank Head Apologizes for Scandal
abstract: The head of Japan’s central bank apologized Tuesday for an investment scandal that triggered calls for his resignation and said the bank had set up a committee to review investment rules for its officials.

headline: What Will Warren Buffet Do?
abstract: Warren Buffett ignited an M&A guessing game when he told Berkshire Hathaway shareholders that he is close to making a $15 billion acquisition. Now everyone is (including DealBook) is drawing up shortlists.

headline: 64 Parmalat Executives Begin Hearings
abstract: Two and half years after Parmalat collapsed in one of the worst accounting scandals in corporate history, preliminary hearings opened behind closed doors Monday against 64 individuals accused of bringing the dairy giant down under 14 billion euros ($18 billion) in hidden debt.

headline: French Digital Music Copyright Bill Advances
abstract: Resisting pressure from business, French lawmakers have moved the country a step closer to a copyright law that would have wide-ranging effects on those selling or listening to digital music.

headline: Goldman Backs Off Hostile Bids
abstract: Goldman Sachs‘ C.E.O. has reportedly ordered an end — with some exceptions — to the firm’s financing of hostile takeovers, a move that suggests the investment bank is not immune to the kinds of conflicts of interest that have snagged its peers.

headline: The Big Three and the Ethanol Car They Rode in On
abstract: Leaders of the Big Three U.S. automakers rode to Capitol Hill in ethanol-powered vehicles Thursday to seek lawmakers’ support on issues including energy policies, health care and competition from foreign cars.

headline: DOJ Extends AT&T-BellSouth Antitrust Review
abstract: The Department of Justice has extended its antitrust investigation of AT&T‘s nearly $90 billion acquisition of BellSouth, company officials confirmed Tuesday. The Justice Department had until Monday to clear the merger if it found no competitive issues warranting further review.

headline: Kinder Morgan Stock Soars on Buyout Proposal
abstract: Will a rival bidder emerge for Kinder Morgan? Investors on Tuesday seemed to have their doubts. The pipeline company’s shares surged as high as $103 early in Tuesday’s session but later eased back to close at $100.31. That was only slightly above Monday’s offer to take the company private at $100 per share in a deal whose overall value is $22 billion.

headline: At Tribune, Board Clashes Over $2 Billion Buyback Plan
abstract: The media company Tribune has revealed an internal disagreement over a $2 billion share repurchase plan that is at the center of its strategy for raising its stock price. Opposition to the buyback, disclosed late Tuesday in a regulatory filing, comes from representatives of the Chandler family, which owns a 12.2 percent stake in Tribune through various trusts.

headline: Price of Two Miners: a Bit of Canadian Pride
abstract: Phelps Dodge‘s proposed takeover of nickel producers Inco and Falconbridge is just the latest deal involving foreign takeovers of large Canadian companies. Other recent targets have been Molson, Hudson’s Bay, Dofasco and Fairmont Hotels and Resorts.

headline: Vector Renews Bid for WatchGuard
abstract: Vector Capital, a buyout firm focused on software makers, renewed its two-month effort to buy the Internet-security company WatchGuard Technologies by disclosing an offer price of $5.10 a share.

headline: Austin Ventures Partners Up
abstract: Continuing to look at middle-market buyout deals, Austin Ventures has partnered with Elisabeth DeMarse, the former head of publicly traded Bankrate, to acquire or develop a company in the information services market.

headline: Post Gossip Writer Investigated for Burkle Blackmail
