abstract: A gossip writer for the New York Post has been suspended pending the outcome of a federal investigation into whether he tried to extort money from billionaire financier Ron Burkle, the newspaper said Thursday. Jared Paul Stern, who worked as a freelancer for the newspaper’s Page Six column, is suspected of demanding $100,000 and an annual $10,000 stipend from Burkle in exchange for not writing negative stories about him.

headline: Credit Agricole May Still Pursue Alliance & Leicester
abstract: Credit Agricole just announced that it was gobbling up Greek lender Emporiki for 3.1 billion euro ($3.9 billion). And it may not be full yet.

headline: Croda Pays More than Expected for Uniqema
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries has sold its Uniqema business to Croda International for 410 million pounds ($752 million), saying it will use over half the proceeds to cut its debt.

headline: N.Y.S.E. to Raise $1.7 Billion in Share Sale
abstract: NYSE Group shareholders — mostly former seat holders — will raise about $1.7 billion in a planned stock offering, according to a Wednesday regulatory filing.

headline: Private Equity Players Lead the Pack on REITs
abstract: Private equity firms have jumped to the forefront of the REIT privatization wave, and major industry players say the firms will stick around as buyers so long as cheap debt remains plentiful. Since the beginning of 2004, there have been 15 REIT privatizations, and all of the buyers were private equity firms or other institutional investors. Their common trait is that they can employ large amounts of debt and are able to flip properties quickly — two things public REITs can’t do.

headline: ITC Holdings Powers Deal for Michigan Electric
abstract: ITC Holdings, a Michigan-based owner of high-voltage transmission lines, has agreed to buy Michigan Electric Transmission for $866 million, LBO Wire reported.

headline: Rice’s Deputy Considers Investment Bank Job, Reports Say
abstract: Robert Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, may be ready to trade Washington for Wall Street. Speculation is mounting that Mr. Zoellick, who has worked for Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice for barely 15 months, may soon leave the Bush administration for a post at an investment bank, according to news reports.

headline: In Enron Trial, a Calculated Risk
abstract: Two of the country’s best corporate salesmen are about to make the most important pitches of their lives. After prosecutors rested their case last week against Enron’s former chief executives, the trial has moved to what may be the make-or-break moment for both sides: the testimony of Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay. Mr. Skilling could take the stand as early as Wednesday.

headline: Smith Barney Pays $98 Million For Past Overtime
abstract: Citigroup’s Smith Barney brokerage unit has agreed to pay $98 million to settle claims that thousands of current and former brokers are owed overtime pay and other reimbursements.

headline: Northern New England Energy Acquires Green Mountain Power
abstract: Green Mountain Power on Thursday said it had agreed to be acquired by Vermont-based Northern New England Energy, a unit of Gaz Metro Limited Partnership, for about $187 million. Green Mountain shareholders will receive $35 a share under terms of the deal.

headline: Windows Live Executive Leaves Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft said Martin Taylor, a vice president appointed in March to revamp marketing for the MSN Web sites and Windows Live services, has left the company.

headline: BAE Said to Be Considering Sale of Airbus Stake
abstract: BAE Systems, Britain’s largest defense contractor, is considering selling its 20 per cent stake in Airbus, the European aircraft maker. Senior industry executives told The Telegraph that the company could make a final decision on the sale, which could raise more than 3 billion pounds, within the next few months.

headline: Markets Closed for Good Friday; Limited Updates on DealBook
abstract: Markets are closed today in observance of Good Friday. As a result, DealBook will only publish limited news updates. The DealBook newsletter will not be published today. Full coverage and the newsletter will resume on Monday.

headline: Michaels Discloses Potential Stock Options Problems
abstract: Michaels Stores filed its delayed quarterly report late Tuesday and confirmed that there may be accounting discrepancies in its financials related to stock options granted before 2001.

headline: KKR Snags Flextronics in India’s Biggest LBO
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts will buy Flextronics Software Systems for $900 million in India’s biggest leveraged buyout. Flextronics International, the world’s largest producer of electronics for other companies, will sell 85 percent of its Indian unit to an affiliate of KKR, the Singapore-based company said in a statement distributed yesterday.

headline: Takeover Speculation Lifts Shares of InterContinental Hotels
abstract: Shares of InterContinental Hotels Group jumped to an all-time high on Thursday after a British newspaper said that private equity house Permira Advisers was considering making a bid for the hotel company. The stock rose 5.9 percent to about 10 British pounds per share in London trading, giving InterContinental a market capitalization of 4.37 billion pounds ($8.1 billion).

headline: BackFence Picks Up Bayosphere
abstract: Backfence, a Washington-based portal of community Web sites, announced Monday it will buy San Franciso-based Bayosphere, a “citizen journalism” site developed by grassroots media advocate Dan Gillmor. Backfence, which did not disclose the terms of the deal, said it plans to expand throughout the Bay Area over the next two months beginning with Palo Alto.

headline: Hedge Funds With Ticker Symbols
abstract: Following up on Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ $5 billion stock offering last week on the Euronext, TheStreet.com asks whether hedge funds will follow the cue of their private equity colleagues and decide that they, too, should sell shares to the public. Some have already done so in Europe. But would they ever list their shares in the United States?

headline: PPR Confirms Talks to Sell Printemps for $1.35 Billion
abstract: Breaking days of silence over the fate of its its Printemps department-store chain, French retail and luxury-goods group PPR said Tuesday that it was in “exclusive talks” to sell the business for 1.075 billion euro ($1.35 billion). The would-be buyer is a partnership between Deutsche Bank‘s real estate investment arm and Italy’s Borletti family, PPR said.

headline: Pipeline Giant Hooks Oil Field
abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, the world’s largest publicly traded pipeline partnership, will spend as much as $115 million to buy and develop an oil field in West Texas from two closely held partnerships. Kinder Morgan is one of the biggest oil producers in Texas, averaging 53,600 barrels daily last year from its Sacroc and Yates projects in the state.

headline: Yellow Pages Picks Up Classified Media
abstract: Yellow Pages Group is paying $760-million for Classified Media (Canada) Holdings, a deal that it expects will extend its online retail reach to about 45 percent of all Canadian web users.

headline: Reef Point Dials Up Financing Deal
abstract: Telecom networking equipment maker Reef Point Systems is expected to announce Monday the closing of a new $21 million round that will recapitalize the company.

headline: Ports Row May Have Diminished Arab Investment in U.S.
abstract: The International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday that the Dubai Ports World row may have had an impact on investment flows to the United States from Arab countries, an increasingly important source of financing for the United States’ trade deficit.

headline: Venture Capital Investment Rises in First Quarter
abstract: Venture capitalists secured $6.53 billion for their future investments during the first quarter, putting the industry on pace to boost its fundraising efforts for the fourth consecutive year.

headline: Stock Option Inquiries Bring an Ouster and a Lawsuit
abstract: The fallout from the federal investigation into stock option manipulation spread yesterday as McAfee, the maker of antivirus software, became the latest company to dismiss an executive. In addition, shareholders sued the American Tower Corporation.

headline: Merck Lost — But Did It Really Win?
abstract: Everything seemed to be on track for German drug maker Bayer‘s $20.8 billion takeover of Schering until Merck started buying Schering stock last week.

headline: Prison Sentence for Short Seller Convicted of Fraud
abstract: A federal judge sentenced a former stock picker, Anthony Elgindy, to 11 years and 3 months in prison for using inside information to make short sales and extort money from companies he had criticized in an online newsletter. Mr. Elgindy, 38, was convicted last year in federal court on 11 counts of racketeering conspiracy, securities fraud, wire fraud and extortion.

headline: VNU Shareholder Drops Opposition to Bid
abstract: Knight Vinke Asset Management, a shareholder in Dutch market research group VNU, said it is ending its campaign against a takeover bid for VNU, owner of the Nielsen TV ratings business, by a group of private equity firms.

headline: April Showers Bring Healthy I.P.O.s
abstract: The mattress giant Sealy and the energy company Complete Production Services were among the initial public offerings in April, which turned out to be a healthy month for new issues. Sixteen new I.P.O.s priced in April, compared with nine in March and seven in April 2005.

headline: Daewoo’s Founder Is Given 10-Year Sentence for Fraud
abstract: Kim Woo Choong, whose career as the rags-to-riches founder of the Daewoo Group ended in South Korea’s biggest corporate fraud scandal, was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years in prison and ordered to forfeit 21.4 trillion won ($22.5 billion).

headline: Report Revives Talk of Verizon Wireless Stake Sale
abstract: A British newspaper has reported that Verizon Communications is close to acquiring the rest of its wireless joint venture from Vodafone for about $48 billion. Sources told DealBook on Monday there was little substance to the unsourced story, however.

headline: British Fund Giant Warns Against Rosneft Float
abstract: One of the U.K.’s largest asset management groups has advised investors to steer clear of the flotation of Rosneft because shares in the Russian state oil company carry unacceptable legal and governance risks.

headline: Dimon: J.P. Morgan Chase Will Take It Slow
abstract: The major theme from CNBC’s recent sit-down with J.P. Morgan Chase chief executive James Dimon? Caution.

headline: For Goldman, Univision Auction Is Soap Opera of Conflicts
abstract: The sale of Univision may be providing a prime example of the conflicts inherent in private equity investing and investment banking.

headline: Businessman Pleads Guilty to Bribing a Representative
abstract: A Kentucky technology executive pleaded guilty Wednesday to charges of bribing a member of Congress in an investigation that has centered on Representative William J. Jefferson, a Louisiana Democrat.

headline: Walden to Invest $100 Million in I.B.M. Partners
abstract: Walden International, Asia’s biggest venture capital firm, said on Thursday it is ready to invest $100 million in companies building products designed to work on compact I.B.M. computer servers.

headline: Sage of Britain Hits Resistance in $580 Million Bid for Visma
abstract: Hopes of a deal between Britain’s Sage and Norway’s Visma faded Wednesday as the two software makers suddenly found themselves at odds over the price.

headline: Stealth VC Firm Trilogy Equity Comes Out in the Open
abstract: New Seattle-based venture capital firm Trilogy Equity Partners, founded by former T-Mobile USA and Western Wireless’s chief executive, John Stanton, has officially begun following a flurry of speculation about its stealthy funding of local start-ups.

headline: Small Colleges Pile Into Hedge Funds
abstract: Many small colleges, looking with envy upon the returns reported by endowments at the likes of Harvard and Yale, are piling into hedge funds. They do so at their peril, according to BusinessWeek.

headline: ING Said to Seek European Targets
abstract: The French-Belgian bank Dexia is “almost certainly” on a list of ING‘s European takeover targets, according to unnamed sources quoted by The Financial Times.

headline: Of engines, aerodynamics and rubber
abstract: Time for another visit to the virtual paddock. Toof came up with some very interesting questions about engines in the last comment on one of my Monaco posts. So I decided to go and ask three people closely linked to the theme.

headline: Crown Castle Adds Wireless Towers to Its Kingdom
abstract: Publicly-traded Crown Castle International has agreed to acquire wireless tower operator Mountain Union Telecom from its equity sponsors Toronto Dominion Capital and Sansome Capital for $309 million.

headline: Dutch Insurer Takes a Stake in a Mexican Rival
abstract: Aegon, the Dutch-listed insurance group rumored to be interested in Prudential, has agreed to buy a 49 percent stake in a Mexican insurer.

headline: U.S. Takes First Shots at Skilling
abstract: A prosecutor in the Enron fraud trial bore in on the credibility of Jeffrey K. Skilling on multiple fronts Monday, suggesting that the former chief executive knew the company was in trouble when he tried to sell shares and that he failed to disclose his interest in a small company run by a former girlfriend.

headline: Credit Suisse to Add 900 to Singapore Office, Reports Says
abstract: Credit Suisse Group, the world’s third-biggest money manager, is adding more than 900 people in Singapore to support asset management and investment banking, according to press reports.

headline: Founders Hope Investors Want to Put Money in The Bank
abstract: A group of nearly two dozen investors led by a local banking veteran hopes to raise as much as $60 million to start a bank in Leesburg, Va. The proposal, spearheaded by Sidney Bostian, former C.E.O. of four banks in Virginia, and Fletcher Jewett, a real estate developer and telecommunications executive, has garnered $2 million so far from more than 20 founding organizers.

headline: Archstone-Smith Acquires Germany’s DeWAG
abstract: An apartment company, Archstone-Smith, said Thursday that its Archstone BV unit is buying Deutsche WohnAnlage, a reseller of residential properties, for about $649 million.

headline: Steel Executive Sees Prize Beyond Setbacks
abstract: Lakshmi Mittal is sure he is going to win and he is going to win the whole thing.

headline: Citigroup Is Biding Its Time on Big Deals
abstract: Citigroup chief executive Chuck Prince said Thursday his company is not under any pressure to do a big deal, and will wait until possible transactions are priced more rationally.

headline: L-3 Must Pay OSI Damages, Jury Says
abstract: A federal jury has awarded $125 million in damages to OSI Systems, a California maker of airport security-detection systems, after lawyers successfully argued that a dispute with L-3 Communications caused it to lose substantial business after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

headline: Pinnacle Raises Offer for Aztar Ongoing Poker Game
abstract: In the latest maneuver in the fierce battle to win the owner of the Tropicana, Pinnacle Entertainment has raised its offer for casino operator Aztar in an attempt to fend off rival suitor Columbia Entertainment.

headline: In Emerging Markets, Private Equity and Hedge Funds Find Respite from Each Other
abstract: Private equity firms face less competition from hedge funds when they invest in emerging markets, rather than in the U.S. and Europe, said fund managers at the 8th Annual Global Private Equity Conference in Washington.

headline: Oracle’s Ellison Considers Linux Moves
abstract: Larry Ellison has never shied away from a fight. Now he’s apparently looking at taking on Microsoft in the operating system arena, by going the Linux route. Ellison told the Financial Times that he was considering launching a version of the Linux operating system, and has looked into buying either Red Hat or Novell, the two companies which dominate the Linux market.

headline: Reports of Hedge Funds’ Decline Were Greatly Exaggerated
abstract: George Soros, Bill Gross and other investing luminaries were flat wrong when, about a year ago, they predicted that the hedge fund business was stalling out, writes Bloomberg columnist Matthew Lynn. Hedge funds, he says, are “roaring ahead.”

headline: Fisher Agrees to Sell 24 Radio Stations
abstract: Fisher Communications said Wednesday that it is selling 24 small-market radio stations in Washington and Montana, and plans to reinvest the money in the pending acquisition of a Spanish-language TV station and other potential broadcast deals.

headline: Constellation Energy Executives to Reap Rewards of Merger
abstract: Thirteen executives at Constellation Energy Group stand to receive up to a total of $73 million in payouts from company stock and incentive plans if the company’s proposed merger with a Florida power company goes through.

headline: Xstrata Gets U.S. Approval for Falconbridge Deal
abstract: U.S. regulators have not found any antitrust issues with Xstrata‘s proposed takeover of the Canadian miner Falconbridge, the Swiss-based company said Wednesday.

headline: IndyMac Considers I.P.O. of Reverse Mortgage Unit
abstract: IndyMac Bancorp, a California-based home mortgage lender, said Monday it was considering offering a 20 percent stake of its reverse-mortgage business in an initial public offering. IndyMac estimated that the unit, Financial Freedom Senior Funding, originated $1.1 billion in loans and earned $8 million in the first quarter of 2006.

headline: In Plasterboard Bet, Buffet Wins and Icahn Loses
abstract: New York City’s richest man – Carl Icahn – lost $66 million in a wrong-way bet on a plasterboard company while rival Warren Buffett, the nation’s richest investor, held pat on his gamble in the firm to score a $711 million windfall.

headline: Himax Stock Gains After Lackluster Nasdaq I.P.O.
abstract: Himax Technologies may have fallen 2.8 percent in its first day of trading on Nasdaq last Friday, but strong bidding from large investors in the aftermarket indicated good support for the fabless integrated-circuit design house at current valuations, market watchers said. In early trading Monday in the United States, the stock was up 3.4 percent at an above-I.P.O. price of $9.05.

headline: Analysts Play Down Symantec’s Giant Tax Bill
abstract: An unexpected $1 billion tax bill has got to be at least really bad, if not devastating. Right?

headline: Tech Party Still Waiting For I.P.O.’s to Arrive
abstract: As techies debate just exactly what Web 2.0 is supposed to mean — or whether it means anything at all beyond marketing hype — its significance is quite clear to financial types. As The Economist describes, Web 2.0 can be seen in the renewed flow of venture capital dollars to entrepreneurs, in the flow of revenues to start-ups and even in the flow (or lack of it) of traffic on the increasingly busy highways of the San Francisco Bay Area.

headline: Microsoft in European Court Says 2004 Ruling Is a Failure
abstract: While Microsoft and the European Commission took turns denouncing each other’s interpretation of events that resulted in the 2004 antitrust ruling against the company, they did agree on one thing on Tuesday: The commission’s remedy for restoring competition in the market for software that plays music and videos has failed.

headline: Suez Gives Deadline for Gaz de France Deal
abstract: The utility company Suez has given France’s wavering conservatives an ultimatum over its disputed plans to merge with Gaz de France, saying it would seek alternatives if it did not receive approval this summer.

headline: BankAtlantic to Buy Back Shares
abstract: BankAtlantic Bancorp expects to begin a share buyback plan in the next month, Chairman and C.E.O. Alan Levan said. The Fort Lauderdale-based company on May 3 announced a plan to repurchase up to 6 million of its 57 million shares of Class A common stock.

headline: Kimco May Be In a Shopping Mood
abstract: Speculation that Kimco Realty is considering an acquisition of New Plan Excel Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust concentrated in shopping centers, has driven up shares of New Plan over the past two days. The stock was at $25.08 in midmorning trading on Thursday, up more than 5 percent from Wednesday’s opening price.

headline: Vodafone Shareholder Agrees Verizon Lowballed Bid
abstract: Standard Life, one of Vodafone’s largest shareholders, has voiced its support for the mobile operator’s decision to reject Verizon Communications‘ $38 billion approach for its 45 percent stake in Verizon Wireless.

headline: Stern’s Accountant Avoids the Big House in Insider Trading Decision
abstract: The former head of Howard Stern’s accounting firm skirted jail time yesterday when a federal judge sentenced him to probation for hoarding stock in Sirius, the satellite radio company the radio host moved to, days before the deal was announced.

headline: Televisa Considers Options After Univision Loss
abstract: One can imagine this scene in one of the telenovelas, or Spanish-languange soap operas, that runs on Univision. A jilted groom stands at the altar, groaning bitterly and hinting at revenge.

headline: Credit Suisse to Merge Private Banks
abstract: Credit Suisse on Thursday said it would merge its five independent private banks to meet rising competition and to address the needs of rich foreign clients, particularly those in Asia.

headline: Marconi Purchase Clips Profits at Ericsson
abstract: Many companies have surprised Wall Street by beating first-quarter profit estimates. Telecommunications giant Ericsson also had a surprise for investors on Friday — but it was the unexpectedly large costs associated with its $2.1 billion purchase of Britain’s Marconi.

headline: Lone Star’s Korean Troubles Put Kink in Bank Sale
abstract: Kookmin Bank, South Korea’s largest, is this week set to sign a contract to buy KEB from Lone Star, the U.S. private equity fund, on Friday following the end of an extended period for due diligence.

headline: In the Enron Trial, Intent Is in the Mind of Defendants
abstract: What were Ken Lay and Jeff Skilling thinking? A lot of what will happen to them in their fraud and conspiracy trial will come down to what was in their heads. That is, what they knew about Enron‘s financial health and what they intended while talking about it to investors, analysts and their own employees.

headline: Whirlpool Puts Hoover on the Block
abstract: Whirlpool has sifted through the assets of recently acquired Maytag and decided to divest several business lines that it picked up in the deal. Among the brands slated for sale are Hoover, which makes vacuum cleaners, as well as Amana and Jade, both of which make commercial appliances, Whirlpool said Tuesday in a press release.

headline: For Credit Suisse, a Chief But Not a Celebrity
abstract: Everything you always wanted to know — and much, much more -– about Oswald Gruebel is available from Bloomberg News’s 4,200-word profile of the Credit Suisse chief executive.

headline: It’s a Wonderful Life for Golden West Founders
abstract: Herbert and Marion Sandler are among the few chief executives who wouldn’t look out of place in a Norman Rockwell painting, even though they can now afford to live like Rockefellers after striking a deal to sell Golden West Financial to Wachovia for $24.2 billion.

headline: G.E. Bids for Swedish Life Sciences Concern
abstract: General Electric agreed on Tuesday to pay $390 million to buy a Swedish life sciences company that makes machines used in biomedical and drug discovery. G.E. said it bid 3.22 billion kronor ($438 million), or 330 kronor a share, for the company, Biacore International.

headline: J.P. Morgan Executive Nominated to the I.M.F.
abstract: Rodrigo de Rato, who heads the International Monetary Fund, has nominated John Lipsky, vice chairman of J. P. Morgan Chase, to be his top deputy, succeeding Ann Krueger.

headline: Winn-Dixie Maps Out Bankruptcy Exit
abstract: More than a year after tumbling into bankruptcy protection, the supermarket chain Winn-Dixie Stores has detailed its plan to climb back out again. Its proposed Chapter 11 reorganization, filed with the bankruptcy court on Thursday, would turn Winn-Dixie’s new stock over to its suppliers and creditors and leave the company’s existing shareholders with nothing. This revelation apparently came as a shock to some investors, because Winn-Dixie’s thinly traded shares plunged 60 percent on Thursday to about 8 cents apiece.

headline: Can the Man Who Charmed Houston Do the Same to the Enron Jury?
abstract: After two weeks of testimony by Jeffrey K. Skilling, a fellow former Enron chief executive, Ken Lay is expected to take the stand in his own defense Monday morning in federal district court here. While both men are charged with conspiring to defraud Enron’s investors, Mr. Lay, legal experts say, may stand a stronger chance of acquittal than Mr. Skilling, who found his credibility under constant assault during cross-examination.

headline: Air America Founders Seek Their Own Stations
abstract: Anita and Sheldon Drobny, two of the founders of Air America Radio, are taking the next step to ensure that liberal programming stays on the air: obtaining radio stations. The couple has announced plans to begin buying or leasing radio stations across the United States through their new company, Nova M Radio.

headline: Sun Microsystems Gives Up Campus Life
abstract: Sun Microsystems is ready to move off campus. In a bid to cut costs, Sun sold its Newark campus for $215 million to BioMed Realty Trust, which plans to turn it into a life sciences complex to house companies in the growing biotechnology industry.

headline: The Rise and Fall of Revolution
abstract: For more than a year, Joe Roth has been hearing the Hollywood gossips predict the demise of his six-year-old movie studio, Revolution Studios. Now that they are right, he wants to set the record straight.

headline: Visicu Raises I.P.O. Target, Then Prices Even Higher
abstract: Visicu priced its initial public offering at $16 a share, less than a day after raising the expected price range to $13 to $15. The company pegged its offering at $11 to $13 last month.

headline: Two Funeral Giants to Merge in $856 Million Deal
abstract: Service Corporation International is expected to announce today that it has agreed to buy the outstanding shares of Alderwoods Group in an $856 million deal that would combine the nation’s largest and second-largest funeral and cemetery companies.

headline: Silicon Graphics Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
abstract: Silicon Graphics, whose powerful computers are used by movie makers and NASA, has landed in bankruptcy court after its previous turnaround efforts fell short.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Profits More Than Double
abstract: Morgan Stanley said its net income more than doubled in the fiscal second quarter, as the securities firm completed its first full year under the leadership of chief executive John Mack. The company’s net income in the three months ended May 31 was $1.96 billion, compared with $928 million a year earlier. Income was up 25 percent from the fiscal first quarter.

headline: VNU Shareholders Get Rowdy at  Meeting
abstract: Shareholders of VNU who oppose a 7.5 billion-euro ($9.1 billion) takeover bid for the Dutch publisher blasted its management and supervisory boards and predicted the deal is bound to fail during an unruly meeting Tuesday. The meeting was originally scheduled as the annual shareholders meeting, but VNU last week altered the agenda and said the meeting would instead focus on the bid by private investors.

headline: After a Quick Stop at Loehmann’s, Arcapita Sells
abstract: Making a quick and profitable exit from Loehmann’s after less than two years, Arcapita has agreed to sell the women’s retailer to Dubai’s Istithmar for $300 million.

headline: Documents Show Link Between AT&T and Agency in Eavesdropping Case
abstract: Mark Klein was a veteran AT&T technician in 2002 when he began to see what he thought were suspicious connections between that telecommunications giant and the National Security Agency.

headline: Owens Corning Clears Bankruptcy Roadblock
abstract: The building products maker Owens Corning will pay more than $5 billion to asbestos claimants and as much as $2.27 billion to holders of bank debt as part of a plan to exit federal bankruptcy protection, a company lawyer told a bankruptcy court Wednesday.

headline: Lucent-Alcatel Deal Gets Antitrust Clearance
abstract: Regulators at the Federal Trade Commission have waved through Alcatel‘s proposed acquisition of Lucent Technologies. Lucent said Thursday that the F.T.C. had ended its consideration of the $13.4 billion deal with no action, an outcome that had been generally expected. Shareholders must still approve the transaction, which is expected to close within six to twelve months of the April 2 agreement date, Lucent said Thursday. The two telecommunications companies may need the extra time: They still haven’t announced a new name.

headline: Companies Don’t Want to Hear that Whistle Blow
abstract: When Congress passed the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley Act with the goal of protecting investors, it included sweeping provisions to encourage employees to blow the whistle on corporate wrongdoing by shielding them from retaliation.

headline: Falconbridge to Sell Refinery to Advance Inco Merger
abstract: Falconbridge has agreed to sell its Norway-based Nikkelverk refinery and other assets for $650 million, paving the way for regulators to speed up approval of its takeover by Inco, the companies said on Wednesday.

headline: London Stock Exchange to Welcome Bollywood Player
abstract: On Tuesday next week, Eros International, a well-known Indian film distribution company in Britain, will create history when it goes for a listing on the London Stock Exchange. The aim is to raise $100 million with shares offered initially only to institutions.

headline: Bank Compliance Officer Fired Over Sultan Query
abstract: Fiduciary Trust International, a New York bank catering to the super-rich, allegedly fired its watchdog compliance officer after he tried to blow the whistle on an unexplained $2 billion found in an account used by one of the Sultan of Brunei’s three wives.

headline: Vivendi Hires Investment Banks to Stave Off Unwanted Suitors, Report Says
abstract: French media conglomerate Vivendi Universal has moved to fend off unwanted predators by hiring investment banks Goldman Sachs and N. M. Rothschild, The Telegraph reported.

headline: About Vonage’s Huge Underwriting Fee? Nevermind.
abstract: Vonage seems to have made a lot of missteps in its recent initial public offering. So the Internet telephone company must be relieved to know that the latest goof is somebody else’s fault.

headline: Phelps Dodge to Buy Two Miners for $40 Billion
abstract: Phelps Dodge, the world’s largest copper producer, said Monday it would acquire two of the biggest nickel miners in a huge deal worth $40 billion. The acquisition of Inco and Falconbridge would create a mining behemoth that will reshape the industry as commodity prices continue to soar.

headline: Canadian Miner Inco Rejects Hostile Bid as ‘Opportunistic’
abstract: The complex takeover maneuverings of the world’s mining giants continued on Wednesday, when the board of Inco  urged its shareholders to reject an unsolicited offer from Teck Cominco, a Canadian rival.

headline: S.E.C. Names Head of Boston Office
abstract: After overseeing investigations into several high-profile cases involving Massachusetts companies, David Bergers was named head of the Boston office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Bergers replaces Walter Ricciardi, who is now deputy director of the SEC’s division of enforcement in Washington, D.C.

headline: British Investment Group Wins Auction for De Vere Hotels
abstract: A British hotel company, De Vere, has accepted an 825 pence-a-share ($15-a-share) takeover from the Alternative Hotel Group, valuing the operator of the Belfry golfing hotel at 724 million pounds. The recommended deal follows an abortive last-ditch attempt by Permira to submit an 840-pence offer for De Vere, which runs a portfolio of 18 four- and five-star hotels in Britain.

headline: Level 3 Announces $1 Billion TelCove Buy
abstract: Telecom services provider Level 3 Communications announced Monday it will buy TelCove for $1.08 billion. Level 3 will pay $637 million in shares and $445 million in cash, and will assume $155.5 million in debt, for a total consideration of $1.24 billion.

headline: Picture This: Common Sense
abstract: A story about copyrights on digital pictures really rings the bell on the Ridiculous meter.

headline: Customer Management Firms Ripe for Consolidation
abstract: After a spate of consolidations in the customer relationship management sector in which both Siebel and PeopleSoft were snapped up by Oracle, there will be no letup in merger activity, according to analysts at Gartner.

headline: After Failed BAA Bid, Goldman Eyes U.K. Ports Operator
abstract: A consortium including Goldman Sachs may agree to a 2.5 billion pound ($4.6 billion) deal to acquire Associated British Ports as soon as this week, according to press reports.

headline: Yahoo and eBay Form Advertising Alliance
abstract: Yahoo and the Web auctioneer eBay announced a partnership designed to improve their position against Microsoft and the Web search leader Google, underscoring recent speculation the two companies could eventually merge.

headline: Endoart Raises $10.5 Million
abstract: Endoart, a company that started out targeting arterial disease but changed direction to develop an implantable device to combat obesity, said that it has raised CHF 13.5 million ($10.5 million) in Series C financing. The new money will fund sales of Endoart’s device in Europe, where marketing began this year, as well as the process of getting the device approved in the U.S.

headline: Network Consolidation Talk All the Rage
abstract: In the network-equipment industry these days, every vendor is involved in “the conversation.”

headline: French Utilities Merger May Hit Snags
abstract: Plans by Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin to fend off foreign takeovers and create a second French energy champion looked less certain Wednesday after an Italian utility, Enel, showed continuing interest in buying its French rival Suez and some French lawmakers appeared to be having second thoughts.

headline: Another CA Officer Quits
abstract: CA, a large maker of software for mainframe computers, said yesterday that the chief financial officer, Robert W. Davis, would step down, becoming the third top executive to resign in a month.

headline: Playboy Goes Hardcore with Club Jenna Buy
abstract: Playboy Enterprises has headed deeper into hardcore adult entertainment with a deal to buy Club Jenna, a business founded by porn star Jenna Jameson, for an undisclosed sum.

headline: Youthful Investment Banker Brings Home the Bacon
abstract: Fresh-faced policemen are one thing; choirboy investment bankers quite another. The UBS clients must certainly have been feeling their age at the closing dinner at Momo’s Moroccan restaurant in London last week.

headline: Understanding Islamic Finance
abstract: A talent war for financially literate Islamic scholars has erupted as western investment bankers rush to sell their services to devout Muslims.

headline: Sale of Philadelphia Newspapers Close
abstract: McClatchy‘s negotiations to sell The Philadelphia Inquirer and Philadelphia Daily News have progressed to a late stage this weekend with Philadelphia Media Holdings, a group organized by local advertising and public relations executive Brian P. Tierney, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: Stephen Schwarzman’s New Neighbor
abstract: Randolph Lerner, the chairman of credit-card giant MBNA, plans to move into a two-bedroom penthouse in what many consider to be New York’s most prestigious Park Avenue address. The New York Observer on Wednesday pegged Mr. Lerner as the buyer of the $27.5 million apartment, which is at 740 Park Avenue and was was once owned by the philanthropist Enid A. Haupt.

headline: Chinese Offering Faces Scrutiny
abstract: The first share float on the Chinese stock exchanges since the end of a temporary moratorium on initial public share offerings by state-run firms is being investigated by the Chinese authorities because of suspicions of market-rigging.

headline: American Express to Buy Back $10 Billion of its Own Shares
abstract: American Express weighed in Monday with a $10 billion stock buyback program and boosted its quarterly dividend by 25 percent as the Dow component puts its cash to work.

headline: Debating David Rocker’s Legacy
abstract: Even in his retirement, short seller David Rocker is creating controversy.

headline: G.E., Betting on the Future, Finances a Solar Farm in Portugal
abstract: The sheep that have long grazed on 150 acres of farmland in Serpa, Portugal, will soon have to share their space with the world’s largest solar energy plant.

headline: Textron Sells Fastening Business to Platinum
abstract: Six months after it announced plans to sell ancillary businesses, Textron said Thursday that it has agreed to sell its fastening systems unit to Los Angeles private equity firm Platinum Equity for $630 million in cash and assumed debt.

headline: Deutsche Bank Buying Stake in China’s Hua Xia
abstract: Deutsche Bank has completed the purchase of a total of 416,000,000 shares or 9.9 percent of the issued capital of Hua Xia Bank in China.

headline: Fortress to Take Telent
abstract: Telent, the telecommunications equipment maker formerly known as Marconi, said Thursday it had agreed on a possible 346 million pound ($647 million) takeover by Fortress Investment Group.

headline: Is Starck Too Cool for Boston’s School?
abstract: Philippe Starck, the international design superstar who once fashioned a baby bottle resembling a perfume dispenser for Target, has struck gold by selling condominiums in Manhattan and Miami Beach.

headline: Credit Suisse Takes Private Banking to Australia
abstract: A bank known to high-net-worth individuals around the world, Credit Suisse is taking its brand of private client services Down Under.

headline: Colin South Completes Fund Raising For His Sapling Company
abstract: Colin South recently raised $4 million in funding for his sapling company, Mascoma, which is developing a system to liquefy plants and trees into ethanol.

headline: Golfsmith Has Lackluster Debut
abstract: Golfsmith International, a seller of golf and tennis gear, priced an initial public offering of 6 million shares at $11.50 each, but investors apparently felt that was a bit on the high side. Golfsmith’s stock was down 19 cents at $11.31 in morning trading.

headline: Flipping Over Private Equity I.P.O.s
abstract: Private equity-backed companies often come to the market with plenty of baggage, but that doesn’t mean investors should always take flight, CNN Money says.

headline: Apollo’s Me-Too I.P.O. Comes Up Short
abstract: Many a hit is followed by lackluster imitations, which may explain the less-than-stellar stock offering that Apollo Management reportedly just completed in Europe. The private equity firm raised $1.5 billion, or about $1 billion less than it had hoped, according to Bloomberg News. The stock sale came a few weeks after Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the behemoth of the buyout world, pulled in $5 billion, or more than three times its target, in its European I.P.O.

headline: Maryland Lawmakers Overturn BG&E Veto, Raising Questions About Merger
abstract: In a move that may have significant repercussions for the planned $11 billion merger of the Constellation Energy Group and the FPL Group, Maryland’s lawmakers Friday overrode Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich’s veto of a bill that both fires the state’s Public Service Commission and provides temporary rate relief for residential customers of Baltimore Gas & Electric.

headline: Chinese and U.S. Venture Capitalists Teaming Up
abstract: Kodiak Venture Partners of Waltham, Mass., is teaming up with another venture capital firm, Dragonvest Partners II of Shanghai, as a way to help both expand business on their respective sides of the world.

headline: European Commission Drastically Raises Fines
abstract: Companies found guilty of anti-competitive practices will face multi-billion euro fines or more than 10 times the current tariffs for abusing their monopoly and taking part in cartels, under new guidelines adopted by the European commission yesterday.

headline: Will Shareholders Gain From Tyco’s Breakup Plan?
abstract: A breakup of the conglomerate Tyco International may not be the magic bullet company management needs to create value for shareholders, Newsday writes.

headline: Hoping to Turn Tepid Performance Into a Hot Offering
abstract: In 1999, companies with no profits and questionable business models were flying off the public market shelves like homemade chocolate chip cookies. Has anything changed?

headline: The Prodi Factor
abstract: As Silvio Berlusconi and Romano Prodi duke it out over the election results, Breakingviews takes a look at what a Prodi win will mean for Italy’s banks, utilities and M&A.

headline: MB Financial Buys First Oak Brook
abstract: In a deal that will expand its Chicago-area branch network by 50 percent, particularly in the western suburbs, MB Financial said Tuesday that it plans to buy the parent of Oak Brook Bank for $372 million. The union of the Chicago- and Oak Brook-based financial institutions will create the market’s ninth-biggest bank in terms of deposits, with a total of 61 branches.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Investigating Role of Vonage Short Sellers, Report Says
abstract: Securities regulators are investigating whether short sellers may have played a role in the steep decline in the stock price of Internet phone carrier Vonage Holdings since its initial public offering last month, according to a published report.

headline: Panel to Propose Exceptions to Governance Rules
abstract: An influential advisory committee appointed by the Securities and Exchange Commission is about to formally propose that thousands of smaller companies be exempted from significant parts of the four-year-old law that imposed significant new auditing rules on corporate America.

headline: Alonso cautious – what does it mean?
abstract: Fernando Alonso in today’s press conference at Indianapolis in preparation for Sunday’s U.S. Grand Prix:

headline: Microsoft and Google Set to Wage Arms Race
abstract: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, described Google in an interview late last year as a worthy adversary, a company to test Microsoft’s mettle. “This is hypercompetition, make no mistake,” Mr. Gates observed.

headline: Icahn Said to Be Backing Off Blockbuster
abstract: Financier Carl Icahn will not seek control of Blockbuster Inc. at its shareholder meeting next month, despite his earlier threat and the company’s declining video rental revenue, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Hynix Creditors to Sell Stocks and Bonds Worth as Much as $2 Billion
abstract: Hynix Semiconductor, the world’s second-largest maker of memory chips, and its creditors will sell shares and bonds valued at as much as $2.7 billion this month after the stock jumped sevenfold in the past three years.

headline: A Fannie Mae Settlement Is Reported
abstract: Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage buyer, is expected to pay more than $400 million today as part of a settlement to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990’s so they could receive bigger bonuses, The New York Times reported.

headline: Lay Loses His Cool on Stand
abstract: After waiting 13 weeks to respond to his accusers, Kenneth L. Lay lost his legendary cool on the witness stand Wednesday.

headline: Split Rock Goes All Out on xTech Funding
abstract: Split Rock Partners splurged on data-mining software company xTech, supplying all $8 million of the start-up’s Series A round.

headline: Report Says Intel Wants to Unload Communications Units
abstract: Intel has put several communications businesses on the block, according to the San Jose Mercury News, which cited anonymous sources who said they have seen documents describing the businesses that are up for sale. The report, published over the weekend, comes shortly after Intel made an announcement intended to squelch rumors that it was considering a spinoff of its memory chip business.

headline: Big Buyout in the Pipeline
abstract: If there was a question about whether potential conflicts would prompt investment bank Goldman Sachs to lower its profile in private equity investing, here is a $22 billion answer. The firm’s buyout arm has a prominent role in Monday’s proposed management-led buyout of Kinder Morgan, which, if it gets done, would be the largest leveraged buyout since Henry Kravis’ private equity shop made its audacious run at RJR Nabisco in the late 1980’s.

headline: Hollywood Dons Its Swords and Sandals for Executive Pay Battle
abstract: A plan to force companies to disclose salaries of high-paid employees who are not corporate officers is in jeopardy after a backlash from Hollywood, where film and TV stars often get bigger paychecks than executives.

headline: Veolia to Study Vinci’s Code
abstract: Veolia Environnement, the world’s biggest water company, said it is considering a bid for Vinci, the world’s largest builder with a market value of 18.9 billion euros ($23.8 billion).

headline: Assets May Be Thrown Off Pier 1
abstract: Home furnishings retailer Pier 1 Imports said it may sell assets including its credit-card business and forecast a first-quarter loss. The shares fell 18 percent, the biggest decline in five years. The company hired J.P. Morgan Chase for advice on potential transactions and to review its store portfolio.

headline: Overstock Chief to Wall Street Journal: Thanks, Sort Of
abstract: Wall Street Journal columnist Holman Jenkins Jr. is getting a mixed review from Patrick Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com who has been a loud critic of short sellers and, in many instances, the financial press as well.

headline: Fidelity International to Split Special Situations Fund
abstract: Fidelity International is to split its 6 billion pound Special Situations Fund into one fund focusing on UK stocks, and another called the Global Special Situations Fund.

headline: Big Gap in Verizon’s Bid for Wireless Stake, Report Says
abstract: A value gap of $12 billion has opened up between Vodafone and Verizon Communications over the pair’s U.S. joint venture, Verizon Wireless, America’s number two cellphone network, according to The Telegraph.

headline: Schumacher’s future
abstract: No sooner does Michael Schumacher have his first very bad result this season – finishing eleventh in qualifying today – then talk about his future at Ferrari comes up again. Schumacher certainly sounded baffled about his results in Melbourne today. But his future could prove to be even more complicated to figure out. During his whole career in Formula One he has been linked to the same key people at both Benetton and Ferrari, namely Ross Brawn, the technical director, and Rory Byrne, the car designer.

headline: Saudi Prince Offers $2 Billion for Bank of China Stake
abstract: The Bank of China‘s massive $9.7 billion initial public offering apparently did not quench the desire for shares in the country’s flagship lender. Even as the bank was completing its offering — the world’s biggest I.P.O. in six years — a group led by Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday offered to pay $2 billion dollars for a 2.7 percent stake in the company, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Investment Ranks Raise Advising Rates as M&A Demand Grows
abstract: The boom in mergers and acquisitions that is sweeping the globe has just about everyone from Wall Street to Canary Wharf working overtime and getting a lot richer. If Goldman Sachs , the No. 1 merger specialist the past five years, is any indication, the New York-based firm is selling its advice in 83 transactions so far in 2006, up 24 percent from this point last year.

headline: For TD Banknorth, Happiness Is Massachusetts Bank
abstract: Fresh on the heels of its latest U.S. expansion, TD Banknorth is eyeing more acquisitions in the prosperous New England states over the next few years as it bolsters awareness of its American-based brands.

headline: Gartmore Investment Sells to Hellman & Friedman
abstract: Gartmore Investment Management, a $45 billion asset manager, agreed on Thursday to be acquired in a management buyout backed by private-equity firm Hellman & Friedman, in a move designed to help expand its hedge-fund business.

headline: Ellison Also Turns Charitable — to Settle a Suit
abstract: For Oracle’s Larry Ellison, a charitable donation also settles a lawsuit.

headline: Mirant Makes Unsolicited Bid to Buy NRG for $7.8 Billion
abstract: The Mirant Corporation, a power company that recently emerged from bankruptcy protection, said Tuesday that it had made an unsolicited bid to buy NRG Energy for $7.8 billion. The announcement comes a week after NRG rejected a Mirant offer and declined to enter takeover discussions.

headline: Citigroup Analyst Plays Matchmaker for Telecom Firms
abstract: Which telecommunications equipment makers will be the next to hook up? Alcatel and Lucent Technologies have agreed to merge. Nokia and Siemens are forming a giant joint venture. “Naturally, those deals have led investors to ask: who’s next?” Citigroup analyst B. Alexander Henderson wrote in a research report Thursday.

headline: Former Invesco Executives Announce New Venture Firm
abstract: Three executives who recently left Invesco Private Capital have launched a new firm, Vedanta Capital, as noted in a brief mention by PE Week Wire. According to Vedanta’s press release, the firm “initially will focus on venture investments but anticipates a wider array of global venture capital and private equity activities.”

headline: Biggest Merger Ever in the Credit Union Industry
abstract: Empire Corporate Federal Credit Union is joining a Chicago-area institution in what is said to be the biggest merger the industry has ever seen.

headline: Skilling’s Temper Is Tested in Day 2 Under Fire
abstract: Jeffrey K. Skilling struggled to keep his temper in check on Tuesday, repeatedly accusing a federal prosecutor of not allowing him to answer questions more fully. But Mr. Skilling, one of two former Enron chief executives on trial here, managed to maintain his composure despite a few close calls during his second day of cross-examination.

headline: Microsoft Buys ProClarity
abstract: Microsoft announced Monday that it plans to acquire business analytics software developer ProClarity to increase its presence in the business intelligence market.

headline: Icelandic Firm Flies the easyJet Coop
abstract: Fears over Iceland’s economy intensified last night when one of the country’s most aggressive investment funds unexpectedly put on sale a 17 percent take in easyJet, the budget airline, to raise an estimated 233 million pounds.

headline: Exelon and PSE&G to Sell Six Plants Before Takeover
abstract: Exelon and Public Service Enterprise Group have agreed to sell six power plants in Pennsylvania and New Jersey to complete Exelon’s $16.6 billion takeover of the New Jersey utility, the Justice Department said Thursday in approving the deal.

headline: Court Halts $28 Billion Hostile Bid for Spain’s Endesa
abstract: Gas Natural suffered a setback in its quest to buy power utility Endesa when Spain’s Supreme Court suspended government approval of the deal.

headline: Tribune Lines Up Financing for Disputed Share Buyback
abstract: The media group Tribune said late Monday that it had secured commitments for a total of $2.25 billion in loans to provide funds for a proposed repurchase of the company’s shares. The agreements, which include a $750 million revolving facility and a $1.5 billion term loan, come from a group including Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and J.P. Morgan Chase, Tribune said in a regulatory filing.

headline: Film Director Is Accused of Lie to F.B.I.
abstract: Prosecutors investigating illegal wiretapping by a former private detective, Anthony Pellicano, have charged a film director, John McTiernan, with hiring the detective to wiretap conversations of a movie producer and then lying about it to F.B.I. agents.

headline: Advent Picks Up Mexico’s Milano
abstract: Advent International, the global buy-out firm, will on Tuesday announce the acquisition of Milano, Mexico’s biggest discount clothes retailer, for $200 million in a deal financed with a high proportion of debt against future cashflow.

headline: Telecoms Want a Little TV Help from Their Friends in Washington
abstract: Having invested billions of dollars to upgrade their communications networks so that they are capable of offering TV service, phone giants now want laws making it easier to actually offer it. For all the talk about broadband technology and video-content agreements, the biggest hurdle to phone companies sending TV into homes has been getting local government approval.

headline: Goldman Sachs Chief Donates Cash to Environmental Charity
abstract: Goldman Sachs’ Henry Paulson, the highest-paid chief executive on Wall Street, transferred about $100 million to a charitable foundation he established to donate to environmental causes.

headline: Veolia Will Pick Up U.K. Trash with Brambles Buy
abstract: Veolia Environnement, the world’s biggest water company, agreed to buy Brambles Industries‘s U.K. trash collection unit for $1.1 billion, doubling the size of its waste management division in Britain.

headline: With Last Paper Sold, McClatchy’s Draw Totals $2.1 Billion
abstract: And then there were none.

headline: International Paper Sells Acres of Forest in Record Deal
abstract: International Paper is raising a record $6.1 billion with the biggest sale of United States forest land ever. North America’s largest paper maker will sell 5.1 million acres, an area larger than the state of Massachusetts, to groups led by Resource Management Service and TimberStar. The buyers agreed to supply wood to International Paper’s mills for decades, the Stamford, Conn.-based company said Tuesday.

headline: British Brewer Dampens Takeover Talk With Foster’s Binge
abstract: British brewer Scottish and Newcastle announced that it will buy the European and Russian rights to Foster’s beer, which it has brewed, bottled and marketed under license since 1995.

headline: Nestle’s New Diet Plan
abstract: In some deals, the synergies are a bit too obvious. In this category might go Nestle‘s decision to pay about $600 million for Jenny Craig, a purchase that would put the maker of KitKat candy bars and a well-known weight-loss company under the same corporate ownership.

headline: TransMontaigne Accepts Revised SemGroup Bid
abstract: Petroleum storage and shipping company TransMontaigne said it will accept the revised buyout offer from SemGroup of Tulsa.

headline: For Knight-Ridder Chief, Parting Gets Sweeter
abstract: When a company is acquired, its top management often get sizable sendoff packages. At newspaper chain Knight Ridder, which is about to be bought by McClatchy, several executives are set to collect several million dollars more than previously expected, Footnoted.org said after scanning an amended regulatory filing from McClatchy.

headline: Proposal Would Ease Media Merger Rules
abstract: Telecom and media mergers would have an easier time winning government approval under legislation unveiled Monday by staffers for Senate Commerce Committee Chairman Ted Stevens.

headline: Symphony Technology Nets Software Maker Hummingbird
abstract: Enterprise software developer Hummingbird said Friday it agreed to be acquired for $465 million cash by affiliates of holding company Symphony Technology Group. Shareholders of Toronto-based Hummingbird will receive $26.75 for each share held, a premium of 16 percent to its Thursday closing price of $23.12.

headline: Goldman May Consider Splitting Power at the Top
abstract: Goldman Sachs prides itself on power-sharing. It has co-heads and co-presidents of everything from global sales and trading – there are four – to investment banking (three).

headline: Nasdaq’s London Creep Continues
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market pressed on with its piecemeal purchases of the London Stock Exchange on Wednesday, announcing that it had increased its stake in the British bourse to 22.7 percent. The American exchange said in a statement Wednesday that it had bought 10.3 million shares for 1,248 pence each, or 128.5 million pounds ($239.4 million).

headline: SanDisk May Pounce on Lexar
abstract: SanDisk, a computer memory manufacturer, has hired Morgan Stanley to explore a possible unsolicited bid for Lexar Media, according to The Daily Deal.

headline: Facebook Gets Funding, Quelling Buyout Talk
abstract: Facebook, the popular online hangout for college and high-school students, has received a $25 million round of venture capital funding led by Greylock Partners.

headline: Underwriters Have Egg on Their Face After EasyJet Sale
abstract: The Icelandic company FL Group‘s sale of its stake in easyJet has left underwriters with red faces and an estimated bill of 6 million pounds following an abrupt nosedive in the budget airline’s share price.

headline: European Antitrust Officials Raid Gas Company Offices
abstract: Antitrust officials have raided the offices of some of Europe’s largest gas companies as part of an investigation of the energy sector, the European Commission said Wednesday.

headline: Antitrust Suit Challenges MasterCard’s Stock Offering
abstract: Merchants suing Visa International and MasterCard International in an antitrust suit may ask a federal judge in New York to undo MasterCard’s $2.39 billion initial public offering last month, a lawyer said.

headline: Lights Go Out on Cineworld I.P.O.
abstract: The British cinema chain Cineworld Group, owned by the Blackstone Group, has postponed its planned initial public offering, citing stock-market volatility.

headline: Biomet Won’t Say So, but Investors Expect a Sale
abstract: Biomet will not say the company is for sale. But movement of the company’s stock indicates some investors think a sale could be in the offing. And analysts who follow the company and its competitors in the $20 billion orthopedics industry have little doubt that Biomet’s independence is in play and that its predicament spotlights broader trends as well as the company’s particular problems.

headline: Justice Department Extends Microsoft’s Antitrust Oversight
abstract: Citing Microsoft‘s lapses under part of a landmark antitrust settlement, the Justice Department and the software giant agreed to extend by two years the agency’s oversight of some of the company’s business practices.

headline: Apollo Co-Founder Reveals Latest Venture
abstract: Less than three months after resigning from New York private equity powerhouse Apollo Management, Michael Gross is looking for a company (or several) to acquire.

headline: Investment Banks Feast on BAA Fees
abstract: City banks and lawyers are to share a bumper 315 million pounds ($582 million) in fees for helping a consortium led by Grupo Ferrovial, of Spain, to win the fiercely contested £10.1 billion bid battle for BAA, the world’s biggest airports operator.

headline: Mainland China Lifts I.P.O. Ban
abstract: China lifted a yearlong ban on initial public offerings in its mainland exchanges Thursday, as both its mainland and Shanghai markets posted gains far above their international counterparts.

headline: Babcock & Brown Lays Tracks With NorthWestern Purchase
abstract: Babcock & Brown Infrastructure Group, a fund run by Australia’s second-biggest investment bank, agreed to buy U.S. utility NorthWestern for $2.2 billion and will acquire rail assets in West Australia. The Sydney-based owner of ports and utilities will also purchase 51 percent of West Australia’s rail network for A$435.3 million ($338 million).

headline: G.M. to Sell Majority Stake in GMAC for $8 Billion
abstract: General Motors is expected to announce a deal today to sell a majority stake in its financing arm, GMAC, to a group of investors led by Cerberus Capital Management for about $8 billion in cash, according to people involved in the negotiations. The complex deal could be worth as much as $14 billion total over time, these people said.

headline: British Online Trader Prepares I.P.O.
abstract: CMC Markets, a pioneering online trading business, is poised for an 800 million pound ($1.5 billion) float that will underscore the wealth of its founder Peter Cruddas, one of the richest men in the City of London on paper. Mr. Cruddas is preparing to reveal as early as this week that he plans to sell about one-third of the company in an initial public offering, say people close to CMC.

headline: Antitrust Experts Say Regulators Should Block More Deals
abstract: Federal regulators should block more mergers.

headline: Mueller Water Prices I.P.O.
abstract: Mueller Water Products‘ initial public offering of 25 million shares priced at $16 each late Thursday, raising $400 million.

headline: Warring at the Tribune Could Put the L.A. Times in Play
abstract: Could the Los Angeles Times once again be up for sale? That question is on the minds of several of the city’s richest businessmen, who reaffirmed this week their interest in bidding for the country’s fourth-largest daily newspaper.

headline: HMV to Make Another Run at Rival Ottaker’s
abstract: HMV, the retail group that owns Waterstone’s, is expected next week to make a fresh bid for rival book chain Ottakar’s, after the proposed merger was officially cleared by the Competition Commission. However, it is expected that HMV will table a bid at substantially less than the 440 pence ($8.27) a share offer it submitted last year.

headline: Florida Bank Settles Money-Laundering Claims
abstract: Florida-based BankAtlantic Bancorp agreed to pay a $10 million fine to settle allegations it violated federal anti-money-laundering laws. The bank said the settlement with federal prosecutors includes a deferred prosecution agreement, meaning the bank won’t be charged with any wrongdoing if it improves its compliance procedures.

headline: Halliburton to Protestors: the Feeling is Mutual
abstract: Sixteen protesters were arrested outside Halliburton‘s annual meeting in Duncan, Okla., on Thursday after trying to leave the area partitioned off for demonstrators. They were attempting to enter the building where shareholders were meeting to ask questions of company executives.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Wachovia Broker With Insider Trading
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a Wachovia Securities broker with insider trading relating to Blue Rhino‘s 2004 merger with Ferrellgas Partners.

headline: Shareholder Blasts Oracle Offer for Portal
abstract: A large shareholder in Portal Software is objecting to Oracle‘s pending $220 million acquisition of the billing software vendor, saying the company is worth roughly double what the database titan is offering.

headline: WiMax Firm Aperto Picks Up  $43 Million
abstract: WiMax network equipment maker Aperto Networks has closed its Series E round of funding at $43 million, thanks to a $26 million follow-on from new investor GunnAllen Venture Partners. The new capital brings the total funding for the seven-year-old company, which has made noise about going public, to roughly $120 million.

headline: Topps Faces Second Proxy Fight to Force Sale
abstract: Topps Company faces another shareholder revolt led by Pembridge Capital Management. After dropping plans last year to gain representation on Topps’ board of directors, the hedge fund is again staging a proxy contest and urging the New York-based trading card and candy manufacturer to find a buyer.

headline: Apple Wins the Day in iTunes Pricing
abstract: Apple Computer has renewed contracts with the world’s four largest music companies to sell songs through its iTunes Music Store after blocking their attempts to end iTunes’ flat-rate pricing scheme, Apple said on Tuesday.

headline: Missing Link Is Vonage’s Latest I.P.O. Woe
abstract: A flood of stories in recent days have questioned whether Internet telephone service Vonage can pull off its proposed initial public offering in the face of mounting competition. Deep in Vonage’s recent regulatory filings, however, the company revealed a different potential problem related to its roughly $500 million offering.

headline: PE Firms Reap Gains from Secondary Offerings
abstract: With stock markets up, financial sponsors are taking the opportunity to lock in gains. Thursday brought news that Cypress Group and Oak Hill Capital Partners affiliate Keystone Group stand to recoup their original money in Williams Scotsman International, which makes modular buildings, after about nine years.

headline: DaimlerChrysler to Cut Stake in Airbus Parent EADS
abstract: DaimlerChrysler and Lagardere will reduce their stakes in European Aeronautic, Defence & Space, Europe’s biggest aerospace company, after EADS shares rose more than five-fold in the past three years.

headline: For Interns, It’s Nice to Feel Wanted Again
abstract: Every spring, college students vie for coveted summer internship spots at the top investment banks. This year, they are also giving the banks a lesson in supply and demand. With offers for this summer’s programs now sent out, Wall Street firms have found themselves competing with hedge funds and consulting firms for top students.

headline: As Nasdaq Defends Pricetag, Hopes for L.S.E. Takeover Dim
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market‘s chief executive, Bob Greifeld, stood firmly by his decision on Wednesday to pursue the London Stock Exchange as its archrival, the NYSE Group, seeks to take over the pan-European stock exchange operator Euronext.

headline: Kaboodle Gets Kitted Out by VCs
abstract: Kaboodle, a free ad-supported service that lets people do collaborative Web research, was set to announce on Monday that it has raised $3.55 million in Series A funding from investors, including former Google-related scientists.

headline: EMI May Raise Warner Music Bid
abstract: EMI, the world’s third-largest music company, may raise its offer for smaller rival Warner Music to $30 per share this week after the U.S. firm rejected its $28.50 offer earlier this month, The Observer reported Sunday. But it may not be enough for Warner, which could still hold out for a higher bid of about $33 per share.

headline: Calpers Questions Pay at UnitedHealth
abstract: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the largest public pension fund, said yesterday that the UnitedHealth Group, the health insurance company, must explain the $2.4 billion in stock options granted to its top executives.

headline: Credit Agricole Posts First Quarter Profit Increase
abstract: Credit Agricole, France’s biggest retail bank by assets, said first-quarter profit increased 53 percent as rising stock markets lifted revenue from investment banking and asset management.

headline: Tribune Speaks: Buyback Is on Track
abstract: Responding to a cloud of speculation that has engulfed it, media company Tribune said Thursday that it is proceeding “expeditiously” with a $2 billion share buyback program despite resistance from a leading shareholder. Its shares closed 4.2 percent higher, though they stumbled early in the trading session after Tribune made its announcement.

headline: Concern Over Golden Parachutes Snags Utility Deal
abstract: Two top Democrats in Maryland’s legislature want the state’s largest electric utility to produce information on the “golden parachutes and huge windfalls” they say are being offered to top executives as part of its proposed merger.

headline: Google Buys Its H.Q. for $319 Million
abstract: Google said on Wednesday it plans to pay $319 million for property and buildings, including its headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., to accommodate a growing work force.

headline: Fidelity Said to Sell Stake in London Stock Exchange
abstract: As speculation about the fate of the London Stock Exchange continues to swirl, Reuters is reporting that fund manager Fidelity International, once the London exchange’s largest shareholder, cashed out its remaining shares of the L.S.E. last week.

headline: Stewart & Stevenson  Shareholders Approve Sale to Armor
abstract: Shareholders of military-truck maker Stewart & Stevenson approved Thursday the $1.11 billion sale of the Houston company to Armor Holdings, the only provider of armor for vehicles used by U.S. armed forces in Iraq.

headline: Power Well of Houston Acquired by British Energy Company
abstract: A British gas and oil services company, the Expro International Group, said on Wednesday it was buying Power Well Services of Houston for $674.5 million to expand geographically and move into new markets.

headline: Deal Stirrings Help to Lift Tribune Stock
abstract: The Tribune Company says it is sticking to a stock buyback plan, but investors yesterday reacted as if the company might be in play.

headline: Alcatel and Lucent Agree to Merge in $13.4 Billion Deal
abstract: Alcatel of France and Lucent Technologies said on Sunday that they had reached agreement on a $13.4 billion merger that would create a French-American maker of telecommunications equipment with revenue of $25 billion, 88,000 employees and phone company customers across the world.

headline: Microsoft Gets ‘God Games’ Guru With Lionhead Deal
abstract: To read the BBC News Web site’s article on Microsoft‘s purchase of British videogame maker Lionhead Studios, the story is not one company buying another — it is the acquisition of one person.

headline: Connecticut Encouraging Start Ups
abstract: The state of Connecticut is backing a pilot program designed to connect entrepreneurs with startup companies and encourage more angel investment in the state.

headline: The Bernanke Bombshell: How Bartiromo Moved Markets
abstract: Still scratching your head over how CNBC anchor Maria Bartiromo roiled the markets with her scoop (if that is what it was) on what Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke really meant in his Congressional testimony last week?

headline: CA Executive Splits for Private Equity
abstract: Mark Barrenechea, the executive vice president and chief technology officer of CA, on Wednesday said he will leave to join private-equity firm Garnett & Helfrich Capital as a director.

headline: Reviewing Cox’s Performance
abstract: Tomorrow morning Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Chris Cox will make his first appearance before the Senate Banking Committee since becoming S.E.C. chairman nine months ago, under the room-emptying title “A Review of Current Issues in the U.S. Securities Markets.”

headline: Anadarko to Buy Two Energy Companies for $21.1 Billion
abstract: Anadarko Petroleum on Friday unveiled a pair of multibillion-dollar deals, adding to what has already been a very active period for big mergers and acquisitions in the energy sector. The company said it had agreed to buy Kerr-McGee and Western Gas Resources in two separate all-cash transactions for a total of $21.1 billion in cash. It will also assume debt estimated at $2.2 billion.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Intelsat-PanAmSat Merger
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the merger of Intelsat and PanAmSat Holding, removing one of the final hurdles to the deal, which will create the world’s largest satellite operator. The two companies, which announced their $3.2 billion merger in August 2005, said Tuesday they expect to complete the transaction on July 3.

headline: Ide out, Montagny in (Part 2)
abstract: French Super Aguri driver Franck Montagny. (AFP/ Damien Meyer).

headline: UBS Brings Australian Strategist on Board
abstract: UBS Australia has hired Kenneth Allen as a senior adviser to the bank on policy and strategic issues in Australia, the U.S. and China. Between 2001 and 2006 Allen was the Australian consul general in New York where he was responsible for representing the country’s interest in the northeastern United States.

headline: Merrill Lynch Will Take $1.2 Billion 1Q Charge
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co. said Monday it will take a $1.2 billion first-quarter charge, $850 million more than it had expected, as it switches to new accounting rules for employee stock compensation and modifies existing stock awards. The charge will nearly wipe out the $1.4 billion that analysts expect Merrill to earn in the quarter.

headline: Second Thoughts in Congress on Oil Tax Breaks
abstract: As anxiety spread in Congress on Wednesday over soaring oil prices, lawmakers in both parties said they were ready to take a tough look at oil and gas incentives they passed as recently as eight months ago.

headline: A motor racing Utopia?
abstract: For most of the long history of automobile racing, car designers developed new, often bizarre, technology in order to make the cars go as fast as possible. Some of that technology was not so bizarre and ended up in road cars after proving itself in the laboratory of racing.

headline: Paulson Clears Senate Finance Committee
abstract: The Senate Finance Committee on Wednesday approved the nomination of Goldman Sachs chairman Henry M. Paulson Jr. to be the country’s next treasury secretary.

headline: Malone May Swap Time Warner Stake for Atlanta Braves
abstract: Cable industry pioneer John Malone is set to take ownership of the Atlanta Braves as part of an asset swap with media giant Time Warner, The New York Post said. Malone and Time Warner have been locked in talks for weeks over how to unwind Liberty’s 4 percent stake — valued at about $3 billion, based on recent stock prices — in Time Warner in a way that minimizes taxes for Malone.

headline: Level 3 Wants to Add More Fiber to Its Diet
abstract: Level 3 Communications is on the prowl for more acquisitions, and it is getting more serious about buying another provider of fiber optic services in metropolitan areas, according to Light Reading.

headline: Cooking Up a Hot I.P.O.
abstract: The dismal performance of Vonage‘s initial public offering could make it seem as if 2006 has been a lousy year for new stocks. But there have been some winners. Many will remember the sizzling debut of  Chipotle Mexican Grill, the McDonald’s spinoff that went public at $22 per share in late January and recently closed at $60.98. But several smaller, lower-profile I.P.O.’s have also done well: Fortunet and Calumet Specialty Products, for example.

headline: Sprint Gets Antitrust Clearance for UbiquiTel Deal
abstract: Sprint Nextel has received U.S. antitrust clearance to acquire its wireless affiliate UbiquiTel for about $1 billion, U.S. officials said on Thursday.

headline: Oracle’s Buying Spree Has Not Helped Share Value
abstract: Oracle has spent $20 billion in the past few years gobbling up more than 20 software companies as it seeks to grow in the maturing business software industry.

headline: Madrona Heads North With PiXPO Company
abstract: Madrona Venture Group of Seattle is venturing north of the border with an investment in PiXPO, a Victoria, B.C.-based company that helps consumers set up online channels to broadcast videos and other personalized digital media.

headline: AttachmateWRQ  Snags NetIQ
abstract: Seattle-based AttachmateWRQ agreed to buy NetIQ, a maker of computer-management software, for $495 million to add programs to run Windows-based networks.

headline: Pogo to Pay $750 Million for PE-Backed Latigo Petroleum
abstract: Oil and gas exploration company Pogo Producing said Monday it agreed to buy Latigo Petroleum, a company founded by two private equity shops, for $750 million in cash.

headline: 3 Chip Makers Reach Settlements
abstract: Samsung Electronics, Hynix Semiconductor and Infineon Technologies have agreed to pay $160 million to resolve claims that they conspired to drive up the price of computer memory chips.

headline: Mediaset of Italy Eyes Endemol
abstract: Mediaset, the broadcaster owned by the former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi, said it was interested in buying Big Brother production company Endemol. Endemol, a Dutch company owned by Telefonica of Spain has said it is considering offloading the production house.

headline: Swiss Re and G.E. Agree to Change Merger Terms
abstract: Swiss Re said Friday it has agreed to change the terms of its acquisition of General Electric‘s reinsurance unit for $7.6 billion, with the Swiss insurer paying more cash and issuing fewer shares to the U.S. industrial giant. Swiss Re, poised to become the world’s largest reinsurance company when the deal is completed, said General Electric has agreed to take $2.4 billion in Swiss Re shares.

headline: Ashland in Talks to Sell Paving Unit
abstract: The chemicals company Ashland said Monday it was considering a sale or spinoff of its paving and construction subsidiary and is in talks with a potential buyer. The company, which has a market capitalization of about $4.6 billion, has agreed to an exclusive negotiating period with Oldcastle Materials to discuss the sale of its Ashland Paving and Construction unit. Ashland retained Credit Suisse Securities as an adviser.

headline: P.E. Firms Lead Bidding for Unilever Unit
abstract: CapVest and Blackstone Group, the private equity firms, are the favorites to acquire Unilever‘s frozen food businesses for an estimated 1 billion pounds ($1.8 billion) in an auction that could be a prelude to the sale of the Anglo-Dutch group’s home-cleaning business.

headline: Wireless Companies Agree to $1.5 Billion Merger
abstract: FiberTower announced Monday that it would merge with wireless transport services operator First Avenue Networks in a $1.5 billion all-stock merger. First Avenue will issue 73.7 million shares to privately held FiberTower, which will own about 51 percent of the combined entity. The deal is expected to close by the third quarter this year.

headline: Even Lawyers Do It: Clifford Chance Partners Plan Private Equity Fund
abstract: Determined not to be last to the private equity party, partners at the prestigious London-based law firm Clifford Chance are said to be preparing to start a fund of funds, The Lawyer reports. The fund would allow Clifford Chance’s equity partners to put money into their private equity clients’ investments.

headline: Supporting VoIP Actors Are Now Taking the Lead
abstract: Despite the flurry of investments in the Internet telephone market, opportunities are still available for venture capitalists — just not in those companies who connect the calls.

headline: Wall Street Tees Up at New Club in the Hamptons
abstract: The newest golf course in the Hamptons may already be No. 1 in at least one category: price.

headline: Supreme Court to Review Antitrust Case Against Phone Companies
abstract: The Supreme Court announced Monday that it would consider a lawsuit that accuses the nation’s largest telephone companies of violating federal antitrust law by conspiring to carve up local markets to preserve their monopolies.

headline: Canada’s Descartes Systems Buys Security Firm
