abstract: The Descartes Systems Group, a provider of business software, has acquired Ottawa-based ViaSafe, a private company that develops secure electronic logistics services for global traders.

headline: Ince Moves to Credit Suisse
abstract: Keith Ince has been appointed executive vice chairman and acting head of asset management for Credit Suisse in Australia while the firm looks for a new person to head the division permanently.

headline: Japanese Restaurant Chain Skylark in Management Buyout
abstract: Nomura Holdings and a private equity firm, CVC Capital Partners, said on Thursday they would lead a buyout of the restaurant chain Skylark Company for up to $2.4 billion, marking Japan’s biggest management buyout to date.

headline: MasterCard I.P.O. Comes With a Warning
abstract: MasterCard is expected to hit the market with a bang when it makes its debut on the New York Stock Exchange as early as next week.

headline: Japanese Retailer Sells Barneys Japan
abstract: Barneys and Isetan are winding down a long and sometimes anguished relationship.

headline: Enron Appeal? Good Luck, Lawyers Say
abstract: Minutes after his client was found guilty of fraud and conspiracy on Thursday, the lawyer for former Enron chief executive Jeffrey Skilling promised a “full and vigorous appeal.” The general consensus on Friday, however, was that lawyer Daniel Petrocelli and Mr. Skilling will find it extremely difficult to get the verdict overturned. The same applied to former Enron chief Kenneth Lay, who was found guilty of all six of the fraud and conspiracy charges against him.

headline: California Controller Influenced CalPERS to Invest in Campaign Backers
abstract: California State Controller and gubernatorial candidate Steve Westly steered California’s giant pension system to invest in a fledgling venture capital fund whose politically connected partners helped him raise campaign cash, The Los Angeles Times reported

headline: Marshall & Ilsley Hires CFO
abstract: Gregory Smith has been named senior vice president and chief financial officer of Marshall & Ilsley, the financial company said Monday. Mr. Smith has worked in investment banking since 1990, most recently as a managing director, specializing in Midwest financial institutions for Credit Suisse in Chicago.

headline: Law Firm Paul Hastings Sued Over Role in Alleged Memo Destruction
abstract: The collapse of a billboard-selling business has led to a lawsuit against prominent law firm Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, alleging that it directed its client to destroy a legal memorandum, The Wall Street Journal reports.

headline: Mexican Broadcaster in Talks With S.E.C.
abstract: The Mexican broadcaster TV Azteca said on Monday that it was in talks with U.S. regulators over fraud charges involving the company.

headline: Financier Denies Inflating Price of Stock
abstract: The Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi denied accusations yesterday that he had helped inflate the share prices of a telemarketing company as part of a $130 million securities deal.

headline: After Being Bought, Will Eircom Be Split Up ?
abstract: Pierre Danon is to enter talks with the Irish government about a break-up of the country’s former phone monopoly, Eircom, once his backers complete a 2.42 billion euro ($3.11 billion) takeover of the company.

headline: Frogger in Real Time
abstract: Remember the old arcade game Frogger, where you try to guide a little animated frog across a busy highway without getting smushed by traffic? Now there’s a real-world version.

headline: Law Firm Merger Raises Questions One Year In
abstract: Pillsbury Winthrop‘s merger with Shaw Pittman a year ago was touted by leaders of both law firms as creating a formidable new player among the nation’s top shops. But tough choices that the firms made to get the deal done have raised questions about whether the marriage was worth the sacrifices.

headline: F.C.C. Rules on Ownership Loom in Duel for Univision
abstract: The auction for Univision, which is expected to conclude Tuesday, has become focused in recent days on the potential regulatory hurdles that the two suitors who are dueling for control of the company may face, according to The New York Times.

headline: Google Dumps Stake in a Chinese Rival
abstract: Some thought Google might buy Chinese rival Baidu.com. It has done just the opposite.

headline: U.S. Refiner Delek Acquires Refining and Marketing Assets from Pride
abstract: An oil refiner, Delek US Holdings, said on Wednesday it had agreed to acquire the refining assets and marketing business of the Pride Companies of Abilene, Tex., and its affiliates for about $54.4 million in cash.

headline: After a Good Night’s Sleep, Sealy Will Wake Up Public
abstract: Mattress giant Sealy plans to wake up as a public company Friday some 17 years after the 125-year-old company was taken private. The Trinity, N.C., company plans to offer 23.33 million shares at a price range of $14 to $16 a share in a bid to raise about $350 million. Underwriters are Citigroup and Goldman Sachs.

headline: Polish Energy Company to Buy Most of Lithuanian Oil Refinery
abstract: Despite immense resistance from Russia, the largest energy group in Poland has signed a deal to buy a majority stake in a Lithuanian oil refinery from a subsidiary of Yukos, the energy giant that was bankrupted by Kremlin tax claims.

headline: Canadian Broadcaster Channels IPO
abstract: Canada’s largest privately owned media conglomerate has hired investment banks to advise it on a potential initial public offering that would value the company at about $1 billion.

headline: In Telecom Sector, a Mania to Merge
abstract: Nortel Networks and Motorola. Nortel and Huawei. Motorola and Huawei. Juniper Networks and Nortel.

headline: Prosecutor Zeroes In on Ex-Enron Chief’s Finances
abstract: Kenneth L. Lay’s sale of Enron shares to meet bank calls was long thought to be his best defense against charges that he conspired to defraud the company, which collapsed in December 2001. Mr. Lay argued on Monday that he went to great lengths to hang onto his Enron shares, even as the debacle unfolded.

headline: Charging the Green Car Market
abstract: Silicon Valley engineers have always been closet gearheads. When they’re not writing code or designing semiconductors, many tinker with exotic cars, airplanes, even rocket ships. Couple that with a Californian environmental bent, and techies seem like ideal candidates for building nonpolluting vehicles.

headline: Looking Through Enron’s Inbox
abstract: A company that monitors employee e-mail uses all of the e-mail that was gathered during the Enron trial as a free sample of its service.

headline: Lucent-Alcatel Merger Gets Lost in Translation
abstract: It was a small detail, but one that speaks volumes about the cultural challenges ahead for Lucent Technologies and its French merger partner, Alcatel.

headline: Spanish Property Tycoon Pays Big for Stake in Rival
abstract: A Spanish property tycoon, Luis Portillo, laid the foundation Tuesday for what may be the biggest coup of his career with a deal by his Grupo Inmocaral for a 39.37 percent stake in Inmobiliaria Colonial that values the larger property group at 6.58 billion euros ($8.52 billion), including debt.

headline: Keyspan Chief to Reap Windfall from Sale
abstract: KeySpan Energy chief executive Robert B. Catell is set to reap a $45 million payout when British energy conglomerate National Grid Group buys KeySpan early next year, the company disclosed in a federal securities filing.

headline: Investor’s Demands Rebuffed by Heinz
abstract: The H.J. Heinz Company, the food manufacturer, said yesterday that it had rejected a demand by the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz for representation on the board. Heinz, based in Pittsburgh, also said Mr. Peltz’s demand to cut annual costs by $575 million was “unrealistic.”

headline: Nasdaq’s LSE Move Ups Ante in Overseas Poker Game
abstract: While Nasdaq‘s purchase of a 15 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange does not guarantee a merger down the road, it does give Robert Greifeld, Nasdaq’s chief executive, an important strategic chip to use while putting the pressure on his New York Stock Exchange counterpart, John A. Thain, to respond in kind.

headline: Will PE Firms Continue Their Spree Unfettered?
abstract: Private equity firms have enjoyed a perfect storm over the past year. This was the consensus of three industry leaders speaking last Thursday at a forum hosted by the Conference Board and the Week magazine. Low interest rates, enormous global liquidity, receptive capital markets, and a continuing flow of money into the sector from corporate pension funds have meant rapidly growing coffers and nonstop activity. But the big question is: Will the government leave them alone?

headline: McClatchy Unloads Five More Knight Ridder Titles
abstract: The newspaper publisher McClatchy said Wednesday it would sell five more newspapers it acquired from by Knight Ridder for about $450 million. The announcement brings Knight Ridder, the second-largest U.S. newspaper company, one step closer to dissolution.

headline: Verizon to Sell Latin American Assets For $3.7 Billion
abstract: Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim is picking up Latin American assets from Verizon Communications in a series of deals valued at a combined $3.7 billion, Verizon said on Monday.

headline: Reuters and C.M.E. Team Up to Create Exchange
abstract: A Reuters Group and Chicago Mercantile Exchange deal to create the first centrally cleared foreign exchange marketplace aims to tap growing institutional and hedge fund activity, the two companies said.

headline: Deutsche Post C.E.O. Sees Smaller Deals Ahead
abstract: After stuffing itself with billion-dollar acquisitions, Deutsche Post World Net is content to sit back for the next two years, chief executive Klaus Zumwinkel said. But the company will still seek out smaller deals — that is, those under 250 million euro ($306 million).

headline: Goldman Tops Alpha’s Hedge Fund 100
abstract: It took third place last year, but Goldman Sachs Asset Management has jumped to the top of the heap in Alpha magazine’s latest Hedge Fund 100 list, which ranks funds by assets. A tidy $21 billion under management was enough to put Goldman Sachs’ hedge fund arm in the No. 1 spot. D.E. Shaw moved from No. 7 to No. 3 on the list, with $19.9 billion in assets, according to Alpha.

headline: First Republic Bank Expands Its Home Base
abstract: First Republic Bank agreed to buy BWC Financial, the parent of Bank of Walnut Creek, for $177 million in stock.

headline: Rehire of Investment Banker Is Coup For Morgan Stanley
abstract: Parting is sometimes sweet sorrow. Returning? That’s a different question.

headline: Chinese Chip Maker Prices I.P.O. at Mid-Range
abstract: Chinese chip maker Advanced Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp  has priced its IPO at the mid-point of the indicated range, allowing it to raise HK$650.7 million ($84 million) before the April 7 trading debut.

headline: Citigroup Reports 4 Percent Rise in Quarterly Profit
abstract: Strength in its international businesses and its investment banking operations helped Citigroup report a 4 percent rise in first-quarter profit on Monday.

headline: Greenfuel Cleans Up
abstract: Greenfuel Technologies has received an additional $7 million in Series B funding from Polaris Venture Partners, as Greenfuel develops algae bioreactors that convert smokestack gases into fuel. The Cambridge, Mass., company received $11 million in a B round last August from Draper Fisher Jurvetson of Menlo Park, Calif., and Access Private Equity.

headline: Novastar Takes Banks to Court Over Short Selling
abstract: The mortgage company Novastar Financial is suing some of Wall Street’s largest firms for helping short sellers batter its stock for the past three years.

headline: Fannie Mae and Former Execs Back in the Hot Seat
abstract: Fannie Mae is likely to come in for another round of intense criticism when the Senate Banking Committee meets Thursday for a hearing about a stinging government report on the housing giant’s accounting scandal.

headline: Oracle Extends Offer for Portal Software Shares
abstract: Business software maker Oracle on Wednesday said it extended its tender offer for all shares of Portal Software, its second extension of its bid in two weeks.

headline: Energy Partners Fires Up Deal for Stone
abstract: Energy Partners, an oil and natural gas producer, offered to buy Stone Energy for about $1.4 billion after the value of another suitor’s agreement to acquire Stone plunged along with its stock price.

headline: VNU Shareholder Declares Victory Against Private Equity Bidders
abstract: The head of a little-known investment firm is claiming victory against a band of the world’s savviest buyout firms in the long-running battle over Dutch media giant VNU, owner of Billboard magazine and the Nielsen TV ratings.

headline: Macquarie Drops Out of Contest for AB Ports
abstract: The Macquarie Bank consortium that was considering a $5.1 billion cash offer for Associated British Ports has pulled out of the bidding war for the U.K.’s biggest ports owner.

headline: Whales Up Close, in High-Def
abstract: You would think that it would be easy to record whales on video underwater, but they have eluded underwater cinematographers for years.

headline: Afghan Parliament Rejects Budget Over Teacher Raises
abstract: Lawmakers said that spending was not evenly distributed around the country and that the budget was unfair to civil servants, who earn $40 a month.

headline: Lockheed Martin Picks Up Savi Technology
abstract: Savi Technology, a Sunnyvale company whose radio frequency identification technology is used in U.S. military gear, is being purchased by Lockheed Martin, the companies announced Thursday. Terms of the sale were not released, but The San Jose Mercury News reported the sale price to be around $400 million.

headline: Bank of China I.P.O. May Unleash Anti-Foreign Backlash
abstract: Bank of China, the country’s third-largest lender, will this week seek regulatory approval to raise up to $8 billion in Hong Kong, in a listing that could hand foreign investors led by Royal Bank of Scotland a paper profit of more than $4 billion.

headline: Adelphia Sues Motorola Over Links to Company Fraud
abstract: The bankrupt cable TV operator Adelphia Communications sued Motorola this week for more than $1 billion, alleging that Motorola assisted in the fraud that led to Adelphia’s collapse in 2002.

headline: Pulling I.P.O., Fiber Chip Firm Passave Sells to PMC-Sierra
abstract: Dropping plans for an initial public offering after legal tangles with UTStarcom, fiber-to-the-home chip company Passave has agreed to be acquired by semiconductor giant PMC-Sierra in a $300 million stock deal.

headline: Prosecutors Lay Out the Case Against KPMG Defendants
abstract: Federal prosecutors have provided the first clear indication of how they plan to build their criminal case against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG, who are to stand trial in September over questionable tax shelters.

headline: N.Y.S.E. Looks at Market Abuse
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange, which has already sued 23 specialists for illegal floor trading, is investigating improper activities by other market makers between 1999 and 2003.

headline: What’s Peltz Up to At Heinz?
abstract: In the 1980s, corporate raiders dismantled companies for the sums of their parts. Now, as private equity and hedge funds have become powerful forces in mergers and acquisitions, many are trying to recast themselves as smart managers.

headline: Investors Get Another Crack at an Ethanol I.P.O.
abstract: An ethanol producer, Aventine Renewable Energy, headlines this week’s initial public offerings. The offering comes on the heels of No. 2 ethanol producer VeraSun Energy‘s red-hot I.P.O., which priced above expectations and surged 30 percent when it made its market debut earlier this month.

headline: Treasury Official Welcomes Pensions to Hedge Fund Party
abstract: Assistant Treasury Secretary Emil Henry sounded a bit like a money manager — which, until last year, he was — as he praised the positive aspects of alternative investments at a Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta conference on Tuesday.

headline: At Tribune, a Loud Call for a Split
abstract: After Tribune‘s second-largest shareholder, the Chandler family trusts, threw down the gauntlet in a letter calling for a breakup of the company, the question becomes: Who could the possible bidders be?

headline: Schumacher breaks Senna’s record for pole positions
abstract: Michael Schumacher celebrates after setting the fastest time during a qualifying session. (AP) Luca Bruno.

headline: Icelandic Investment Firm Starts Diligence on U.K. Retailer
abstract: Baugur, the Icelandic group vying for control of House of Fraser, is set to start due diligence on the department stores group after its indicative 356 million pounds offer won initial approval.

headline: Greenhill Grabs Canada’s Beaufort
abstract: In a sign that American deal makers see more Canadian takeovers coming, a United States investment bank, Greenhill, rolled north on Monday by snapping up Toronto-based Beaufort Partners, an advisory firm run by veterans of Morgan Stanley and the Goldman Sachs Group.

headline: British Airport Operator Advises Against Spanish Bid
abstract: The British airport owner BAA said on Wednesday it had formally advised shareholders to reject Grupo Ferrovial‘s 8.75 billion pound ($16.08 billion) takeover bid.

headline: Cravey Green Looks to Unload TruckPro
abstract: Cravey Green & Whalen has retained Robert W. Baird to explore a sale of TruckPro, an aftermarket distributor of truck parts, less than two years after buying the company, LBO Wire reported.

headline: EADS to Streamline Management Structure, Putting C.E.O. at Risk
abstract: The two main industrial shareholders of EADS, the parent company of Airbus, have agreed in principle to streamline the management structure — potentially pushing out the embattled French co-chief executive, Nöel Forgeard, a person close to both companies said Monday.

headline: A Trans-Atlantic Merger of Equals? Not Exactly
abstract: Have the lessons of the last merger boom-and-bust already been forgotten?

headline: Titan’s Long-Running Takeover Talks Collapse
abstract: After six months of wrangling, tire manufacturer Titan International and One Equity Partners have walked away from a proposed transaction to take Titan private. Titan announced the end of talks on Wednesday and said it will focus on acquisition opportunities instead.

headline: Ex-Broker Accepts Ban
abstract: A former broker with Merrill Lynch who gave day traders access to the firm’s internal communication system was banned from the industry under a settlement with federal regulators Monday.

headline: Mittal Steel Wins U.S. Approval as Bid Target Arcelor Profits Beat Expectations
abstract: Mittal Steel, the world’s largest steel maker which is trying to buy its closest rival Arcelor, said on Friday it had received U.S. clearance for its bid.

headline: Mittal Willing to Raise Its Bid for Arcelor
abstract: Mittal Steel said on Tuesday that it was willing to increase its bid for Arcelor, the second-largest steelmaker in the world, and that it has made preliminary contact with Arcelor’s chairman.

headline: Woori Bond Offering Largest Ever for a Korean Bank
abstract: On Thursday night joint bookrunners Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Woori Investment & Securities priced a benchmark $1 billion 10-year non-call five-year lower-tier 2 deal for Korea’s Woori Bank. It was Korea’s second largest corporate bond ever.

headline: Cendant to Put Travel Unit Up for Sale
abstract: Cendant  said Monday it will consider a sale of its travel business, which includes Orbitz, CheapTickets.com and Galileo International. The unit is expected to be sold for more than $4 billion, analysts said.

headline: Nasdaq’s Greifeld Plays the Tortoise in L.S.E. Talks
abstract: Nasdaq‘s chief executive, Robert Greifeld, is clearly not sprinting to close a deal with the London Stock Exchange. In a meeting with his counterpart, Clara Furse, yesterday at the London exchange’s headquarters, Mr. Greifeld did not raise the possibility of a friendly takeover of the exchange, nor even the possibility of any form of co-operation or strategic venture, according to The Telegraph.

headline: Shareholder Presses Vivendi Harder on Breakup Plan
abstract: Norwegian entrepreneur Alexander Vik has written to Vivendi about his idea to break it up, a source close to him said on Friday, stepping up pressure on the French media and telecoms group to defend its strategy.

headline: Speculation: Citigroup to Target Washington Mutual
abstract: CNBC’s Charles Gasparino reported Thursday morning that he expects Citigroup to target Washington Mutual now that the Federal Reserve has lifted a ban that prevented Citigroup from making large acquisitions. The report cautioned that a deal is not imminent and that Charles Prince, Citigroup’s chief exective, is more likley to pursue smaller deals with regional banks and abroad in the near term. Exectives close to both Citigroup and Washington Mutual told DealBook that the companies are not in talks.

headline: Maxim-ed Out: Dennis Said to Seek Sale of U.S. Magazines
abstract: Felix Dennis, the maverick British publisher behind bawdy lad-mag Maxim, is putting the United States unit of Dennis Publishing on the block. Allen & Company won the mandate to sell the firm, which could carry a $250 million price tag.

headline: EADS Executives Meet, Seeking Ways to Right Airbus
abstract: Executives at the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company held an emergency meeting Monday to discuss their stumbling Airbus subsidiary, as an investigation about a stock sale by one of them continued.

headline: Cuban’s Sharesleuth.com Poses Conflicts of Interest
abstract: The tech billionaire Mark Cuban, the high-profile owner of the NBA’s Dallas Mavericks, may be out of bounds with his plan for a new Web site aimed at ferreting out corporate fraud, says BusinessWeek.

headline: Suez Shareholders Allow CEO to Prescribe Poison Pill
abstract: In a development sure to ratchet up the debate in Europe over economic nationalism, shareholders of French utility Suez, which plans to merge with Gaz de France to create a 70 billion euro ($89 billion) juggernaut, granted C.E.O. Gérard Mestrallet permission to issue a poison pill to protect the company against an unsolicited offer.

headline: All Eyes on Microsoft’s European Legal Adventure
abstract: Tech executives from around the globe will be focused on a Luxembourg courtroom over the next week, as one of the world’s most closely watched legal battles reaches its next step. Starting Monday, Microsoft will square off against the European Commission in an appeal of the commission’s tough 2004 antitrust ruling against the software giant, which included a record $612 million fine.

headline: Mirant and NRG: a Conference-Call Showdown
abstract: It is still early in the game, but attorneys for power company Mirant do not seem to have impressed the court with their lawsuit against NRG Energy, the company Mirant hopes to acquire. At least, that is the impression we got from a transcript of Tuesday’s conference call with the judge overseeing the case. (For excerpts from the call, keep reading.)

headline: Televisa Closer to Snagging Univision in $11.2 billion Deal
abstract: A group of investors led by the Mexican entertainment giant Grupo Televisa inched closer late Thursday to bidding $11.2 billion for Univision Communications, the largest Spanish-language media company in the United States, according to the Los Angeles Times.

headline: For Kodak, Sale Effort Comes at Weak Moment
abstract: Shares of Eastman Kodak tumbled as much as 8.9 percent on Thursday after the photography and imaging giant reported quarterly financial results that were far worse than Wall Street had expected and said it would consider a sale of its health unit.

headline: Chairman of RadioShack Will Resign
abstract: Leonard H. Roberts said on Wednesday that he was resigning as executive chairman at RadioShack, which has still not replaced the chief executive who left two months ago because of questions about claims on his résumé.

headline: Blackstone Reloads for More Real Estate Deals
abstract: Here are several billion reasons why the recent string of big real-estate buyouts is probably not over.

headline: Thanks, Mr. Kravis! Columbia B-School Feels Alumni Love
abstract: Three giants from the private equity and hedge fund industries will give a combined $45 million to Columbia Business School, their alma mater. The biggest donation– $25 million — is coming from Arthur Samberg, chairman and chief executive of hedge fund Pequot Capital Management, Columbia said Thursday in a press release.

headline: Massachusetts Venture Capitalist Joins Race for Governor
abstract: Venture capitalist Christopher Gabrieli formally announced he is running for governor, becoming the third Democrat to join the race. Gabrieli announced his run Thursday morning in a 10-minute speech at his campaign headquarters on Canal Street in Boston.

headline: Greenhill Set for Showdown Over Fees
abstract: The stage has been set for a legal face-off between noted bankruptcy-lawyer-turned-investment-banker Harvey Miller and the creditors of Loral Space & Communications, a satellite company that recently reorganized under bankruptcy protection.

headline: Companies Cough Up Dough for  Pension Fraud Settlement
abstract: Time Warner and other defendants including America Online and Ernst & Young have agreed to pay $23 million to settle a lawsuit accusing them of defrauding pension and investment funds in Pennsylvania, the state’s Attorney General said Thursday.

headline: ADC Telecommunications Makes $2 Billion Wireless Buy
abstract: The broadband equipment maker ADC Telecommunications said Wednesday it would acquire a communications equipment maker, the Andrew Corporation, for about $2 billion in a stock swap that will create a company with $3.3 billion in annual sales.

headline: Russian Magnate May Consider Raising Arcelor Bid
abstract: Alexei Mordashov, the billionaire owner of Severstal in Russia, said Wednesday that he would consider sweetening the terms of an agreement with Arcelor, the Luxembourg-based steel maker seeking to repel a hostile bid from Mittal Steel.

headline: For Morgan Stanley Shareholders, Mack Effect Is Muted
abstract: In the past year, shares of Goldman Sachs have jumped 41 percent and those of Lehman Brothers have risen 28 percent. Morgan Stanley‘s stock, meanwhile, is up only 9 percent.

headline: Korean Prosecutors Seek Arrest of Hyundai Chairman
abstract: South Korean prosecutors sought an arrest warrant on Thursday for the chairman of Hyundai Motors on charges of creating 100 billion won ($106 million) in slush funds with which to bribe government officials. A district judge will decide whether to grant the warrant by Friday.

headline: China’s Goldwind Looks to U.S. for Listing
abstract: China’s largest homegrown maker of wind-power generators, Goldwind Science and Technology, is pursuing a listing in the United States to bankroll an expansion aimed at driving an eight-fold increase in sales to 4 billion yuan ($500 million) by 2008.

headline: Utility Buyers Think Twice as Regulators Delay Mergers
abstract: Potential buyers of utilities in the United States are likely to tread carefully, with two mergers mired in regulatory issues and local politics. Speaking at the Reuters Global Energy Summit this week, executives and regulators said that while more consolidation is ahead for the industry, companies would have to work carefully to get deals done.

headline: Morgan Stanley Opens Prime Brokerage Down Under
abstract: Morgan Stanley intends to open a prime brokerage office in Sydney later this year. The firm will be sending back two existing (antipodean) Morgan Stanley officials and hiring a pair of local staff members. Together they will handle sales, capital introductions, client services and consultancy.

headline: Fears Raised Over Monopolies in Health Insurance Sector
abstract: Consolidation among health insurers is creating near-monopolies in virtually all reaches of the U.S.–with the most dominant firms grabbing more market share by several percentage points a year – according to a study released Monday.

headline: Unilever Indonesia Looking For New Flavors
abstract: PT Unilever Indonesia, the nation’s biggest consumer goods maker, has acquired an appetite for vanilla tea.

headline: F.T.C. Staff Clears Purchase of Guidant
abstract: Boston Scientific said Wednesday that it had won antitrust clearance from the Federal Trade Commission’s staff for its $27 billion acquisition of Guidant.

headline: Milberg Weiss’s Unlikely Defender
abstract: What is one of the last places one would expect to see a defense of recently indicted law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman?

headline: WiFi Player Gets New Funding
abstract: AnchorFree has raised a $6 million Series A round to help it pull other free WiFi providers into a unified marketing and advertising system.

headline: U.S.-Style Pay Packages Are All the Rage in Europe
abstract: Along with hip-hop and Hollywood movies, Europeans are eagerly importing another American phenomenon: soaring pay packages for chief executives, The New York Times writes.

headline: Thermo Electron’s Deal for Fisher Looks Sweet to Some
abstract: Thermo Electron‘s, acquisition of Fisher Scientific International for $10.6 billion, looks like a good deal all around to Breakingviews.

headline: Fannie Mae Finds More Accounting Problems
abstract: Fannie Mae, still investigating $11 billion in accounting problems, said on Tuesday it had identified new errors in two areas, but that it still expects to meet capital requirements set by regulators.

headline: Arcelor Leaves an Opening for All-Cash Mittal Bid
abstract: Arcelor Chairman Joseph Kinsch said Friday that his company could re-examine its position regarding a planned hostile bid from rival Mittal Steel if Mittal made a properly valued cash-only bid.

headline: Arcelor Deal With Mittal Establishes Steel Giant
abstract: After a bitter battle, Arcelor agreed on Sunday to a merger valued at 26.8 billion euros, or about $33.53 billion, with a rival, Mittal Steel, creating a new steel giant.

headline: Credit Agricole Considers Bid for Alliance Leicester
abstract: French bank Credit Agricole said it was considering making a takeover bid for Alliance & Leicester, which analysts said could kick-start a 6 billion pounds ($11.3 billion) bid battle.

headline: Sedwick to Buy Security Capital for $191 Million
abstract: A claims management provider, Sedgwick CMS Holdings, said on Tuesday it had agreed to buy the Security Capital Corporation, a provider of workplace health and safety services, for about $191.5 million.

headline: Hedge Fund Real Estate Watch: Jackie’s Flat
abstract: The markets’ recent volatility does not seem to be keeping hedge fund heavyweights from paying enormous sums for New York City real estate. The New York Observer reports that Glenn Dubin, a co-founder and managing partner of $8-billion-plus hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management, has signed a contract to buy Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis’ former apartment on New York’s Fifth Avenue for $32 million. He is acquiring the storied property from billionaire David Koch, who bought it in 1995 for a mere $9.5 million. Mr. Koch told the Observer that he “gutted the apartment and redid everything.”

headline: Milberg Case Fans Flames of Client Privilege Debate
abstract: As the government’s demands for waiver of privilege in white-collar prosecutions have sparked the ire of attorneys worried about the sanctity of client communications, the waiver issue in the Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman case is presenting an especially prickly problem.

headline: Breaking the Curse of Vonage, LoopNet Gains 25% After I.P.O.
abstract: Shares of LoopNet took off Wednesday, closing 25 percent above their offering price. The San Francisco-based online marketplace for commercial real estate opened on the Nasdaq at $14.75 after pricing its 6 million shares at $12 apiece – the midpoint of its expected range – on Tuesday. Shares of the company went on to close at $15.00 for the day.

headline: The Source Goes Up for Auction
abstract: The auctioneer’s gavel should slam down tomorrow on hip-hop magazine The Source. When it is over, The Source’s founder, David Mays, will see the stock he once held as the controlling shareholder passed to a new owner who will try to revive the magazine he founded more than a decade ago.

headline: Credit Suisse Picks Up Gaming Bankers From CIBC
abstract: Credit Suisse has recruited four investment bankers away from CIBC World Markets to cover the gaming industry out of its Los Angeles office. The team, which will be part of Credit Suisse’s real estate group, is co-led by managing directors David Berman and Dean Decker and also includes Sung Chun and Jonathan Rein.

headline: For Book Publishing in '05, Harry Potter Worked Magic
abstract: Harry Potter, books by religious leaders and textbooks for elementary and high school students were the bright spots in publishing last year.

headline: This Time Around, Bush Lets Former Secretaries Speak
abstract: Ten former secretaries of state and defense met with President Bush in what was described as a robust dialogue.

headline: Brand-Name Bankers Rule the Street Again, for Now
abstract: Evercore Partners is jumping on the latest flavor-of-the-cycle bandwagon of boutique banks seeking to go public.

headline: People and Account of Note
abstract: Advertising Educational Foundation, New York, named Linda Sawyer as chairwoman, assuming the duties of Ken Kaess, who had been chairman at the time of his death in March. Mr. Kaess was president and chief executive at DDB Worldwide, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, and Ms. Sawyer is chief executive at Deutsch, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: The Plane That Won't Die
abstract: The C-17 Globemaster III cargo jet, a $200 million flying giant, is at the center of a war involving the White House, the Pentagon, Boeing and lobbyists.

headline: Groups Opposing Wal-Mart Get Help From New Web Site
abstract: Wal-Mart Watch and Sprawl-Busters have teamed up to create an online toolkit for groups opposing the giant discount retailer.

headline: Another Patent Case Is Filed Against Maker of BlackBerry
abstract: A wireless e-mail software company partly owned by NTP has filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Research In Motion seeking a shutdown of its popular BlackBerry service.

headline: Gunmen Kill Russian Embassy Worker in Iraq
abstract: Gunmen ambushed five Russian Embassy workers on Saturday in Baghdad, killing one and kidnapping the others.

headline: A Critic of Muslim Intolerance Faces Loss of Dutch Citizenship
abstract: The Dutch government on Monday abruptly threatened to revoke the citizenship of one of the country's most prominent members of Parliament.

headline: Arcelor's Chief Is Ousted From Mittal Partnership
abstract: The takeover of Arcelor by Mittal Steel claimed its first victim on Monday in the person of the chief executive of Arcelor, Guy Dollé.

headline: From Top of the Corporate World to Appeals Court
abstract: JUDGMENT day arrived for the two top executives at Enron, and the jury found both men guilty of fraud and deceit. The case was perhaps the most closely watched corporate crime trial of the decade.

headline: Less Jitter and Also Less Cost
abstract: The Pentax K100 has a sensor that moves to counteract the jitter that results in the blur.

headline: Compensation Payments Rising, Especially by Marines
abstract: Almost half of the more than $19 million  that the U.S. military allocated last year to compensate for killing or injuring Iraqis came from Marine-led units.

headline: Putin Nominee for Prosecutor Draws Praise From All Sides
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin named Justice Minister Yuri Chaika as his candidate for chief prosecutor Monday, an announcement covered on the front page of all leading newspapers.

headline: Stocks Fail to Recover From Big Sell-Off
abstract: Stocks failed to rebound today from a sharp sell-off on Wednesday, with prices falling in the afternoon as traders remained concerned about the prospect of higher inflation and interest rates.

headline: Corrections
abstract: The Armchair M.B.A. column on May 7, about chief executives who have taken their companies through Chapter 11 bankruptcies, misstated the status of US Airways. The company emerged from bankruptcy reorganization last September; it is no longer in bankruptcy.

headline: Time Warner Takes Full Control Over Court TV
abstract: Time Warner bought the rest of Court TV yesterday for $735 million from the Liberty Media Corporation.

headline: May's Treo Leapfrogs Past January's
abstract: Good things come to those who wait. The Treo 700P smartphone is the Windows Treo without the Windows, and it's almost everything you'd wish it to be.

headline: Tyson Foods Posts $127 Million Loss
abstract: Tyson Foods, the world’s largest meat processor, said yesterday that it lost $127 million in its most recent quarter as concerns about mad cow disease and avian flu reduced beef and chicken exports and prices.

headline: U.S. Is Sending Reserve Troops to Iraq's West
abstract: The movement of a brigade comes as officials have raised doubts about possible troop reductions.

headline: Addenda
abstract: Accounts.

headline: Next Wave of Camera-Wielding Tourists Is From China
abstract: For the first time in history, large numbers of Chinese are leaving their country as tourists, resulting in an unparalleled explosion in Chinese travel.

headline: Bernanke's Remarks on the Economy
abstract: Following is the prepared text of a speech by Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, as released by the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: Price Report Sends Stocks Into Reverse

abstract: The head of an inquiry said that he was making "considerable progress," but he revealed nothing new about who was behind the assassination of Rafik Hariri.

abstract: Protests have gripped Nepal in the last several days, with demands for the end of palace rule and the reinstatement of Parliament.

abstract: Experts said that Tehran lacks the skills, materials and equipment to make good on its immediate nuclear goals.

abstract: Australia's recent decision to grant asylum to more than 30 Papuans brought the issue of Papuan independence to international attention.

abstract: Iran said it would give $50 million in aid to the Hamas-led Palestinian government after the U.S. and the European Union froze financing.

abstract: President Bush urged China to use its influence to help resolve nuclear disputes in North Korea and Iran. Earlier, a heckler interrupted the opening ceremony by shouting while the Chinese Leader spoke.

abstract: Hundreds of police stormed the plant to force out protesting workers in a violent clash that spilled into the streets and left three workers dead.

abstract: Australian troops and police officers patrolled the Solomon Islands capital after two days of rioting over the new prime minister.

abstract: The coalition that organized the demonstrations demanded that the king restore Nepal's Parliament and relinquish control of the government.

abstract: A report's findings of government collusion and incompetence crushed efforts by Egypt to blame the ferry's captain for the tragedy.

abstract: Hu Jintao started his second day in the United States at an enormous Boeing plant where he endorsed increased trade.

abstract: Riots by second-generation immigrant youth last fall have strengthened the anti-immigration National Front party and its leader, Jean-Marie Le Pen.

abstract: As he has since the close of voting last week, Silvio Berlusconi continued to speak of election fraud and demands for further recounts.

abstract: Mahmoud Ahmedinejad said talks with the U.S. on Iraq were not necessary now that a government was set up.

abstract: The occasion drew headlines like "Elizabeth the Great" and "Our Great Mum" and also raised questions about her succession.

abstract: Haitians went to the polls in a legislative election billed as the final step in the often-delayed process to restore democracy to the poorest nation in the Americas.

abstract: The two leaders made some progress on nuclear proliferation and trade imbalances, but broke no new ground on the most delicate issues that divide the two nations.

abstract: Silvio Berlusconi said today he would demand more scrutiny of Italy's election results despite a court ruling.

headline: Dispute Over Evidence in Pellicano Wiretap Case
abstract: Four-year federal investigation of Hollywood private detective Anthony Pellicano has produced only single recording in which two people were unknowingly wiretapped; government claimed to have hundreds of recorded calls of Pellicano describing wiretaps in detail; defense lawyers have been waiting for evidence since indictments of Pellicano and seven others on wiretapping and conspiracy charges in February (M)

headline: Low-hanging fruit for identity thieves
What the Fed Is Up to, and Why You Shouldn't Fret
abstract: Paul Lim column on Wall Street reaction to possibility that Federal Reserve will raise interest rates by another quarter-point next week and again in August; holds that, for long-term, buy-and-hold investors should ignore noise and prepare for next phase of economic cycle by diversifying and lessening risks in their portfolios; graph (M)

Researchers Say New Chip Breaks Speed Record
abstract: Researchers at IBM and Georgia Institute of Technology are set to announce that they have broken speed record for silicon-based chips with semiconductor that operates at 500 gigahertz, 250 times faster than chips currently in use; researchers, using liquid helium, achieved speed by freezing chip to 451 degrees below zero Fahrenheit; at room temperature, chips operate at 350 gigahertz, far faster than other chips in commercial use today (M)

headline: Panchen Lama makes rare public appearance at Buddhist conference
AT&T Revises Privacy Policy for Customer Data
abstract: AT&T revises privacy policy for its television and Internet customers, clarifying that personal information it collects is owned by company and may be shared in response to court orders and other legal processes; AT&T, BellSouth and Verizon Communications have come under criticism for cooperating with government investigators trying to track terrorists through domestic phone records (M)

headline: Markets Seesaw on Dueling Words on Inflation
abstract: Roundup of past week's stock listings; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Where AIDS Galloped, Lessons in Applying the Reins
abstract: Kenya is a rarity in Africa, a nation where experts say the AIDS epidemic shows signs of easing. So this land of safaris has become a hunting ground of a different sort, attracting policy makers and researchers looking for keys to slowing the relentless spread of AIDS elsewhere on the continent.      The trends are heartening. Medical experts here estimate that the number of new H.I.V. infections has plummeted over the last decade from a peak of more than 200,000 a year to fewer than 90,000.

headline: Australian Forces in Timor Capital to Deter Warring Sides
abstract: Australian forces patrol parts of East Timor capital Dili, but conflict continues between warring factions of country's military; 600 rebel East Timorese soldiers are skirmishing with 800 government troops over what started as grievances over pay but reveals long-simmering political and ethnic tensions; goal of Australians is to urge both sides to move into temporary quarters and give up their weapons; fighting within East Timorese military illustrates fact that country has failed to settle into properly functioning state since independence four years ago; map (M)

headline: U.S. economy rolling
Never Mind the Clip-On Ties, Geek Squad Can Fix Your PC
abstract: Geek Squad computer repair company's success follows steady decline of do-it-yourselfers; company has grown since being sold to Best Buy in 2002 from 60 employees to 12,000 agents; founder Robert Stephens discusses origins of business, company image and room for growth; photos (M)

headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills High Hamas Commander
abstract: In an airstrike against a militant training camp in southern Gaza on Thursday night, Israeli forces killed Jamal Abu Samhadana, a senior commander in the Hamas government, but said he was not the target of their attack.      The attack occurred just hours after Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel promised King Abdullah of Jordan that he would make every effort for progress on a negotiated settlement before moving unilaterally to remove some Israeli settlers from the West Bank.

headline: Mexican Economy Grows 5.5% on Strength of Autos and Oil
abstract: Finance Ministry reports Mexican economy expanded 5.5 percent in first quarter over similar 2005 period, fastest growth since 2000; analysts cite surge in manufacturing begun in late 2005, soaring oil export revenues and rebound of auto industry (M)

Briefly: U.S. warns Venezuela about 'thuggish' acts
Berlusconi renews attacks on 'slandering' foes
NYSE Group Reaches Deal To Acquire Euronext
abstract: NYSE Group chief executive John Thain announces deal to buy Euronext, pan-European stock and derivatives exchange, for $10.2 billion; deal would form first trans-Atlantic marketplace (M)

headline: Riots raging over Karachi suicide bomb
Gentlemen, Start Your Proxy Fight
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on proxy fight for three board seats at Acxiom Corp, which is turning into referendum between longtime chief executive Charles Morgan and company's largest shareholder ValueAct Capital; photo (M)

headline: History's Judgment
abstract: Enron will always stand for an era.   BY KURT EICHENWALD, PAGE C1

headline: For Migrants and the Poor, Tents Must Count as Homes
abstract: The Arc de Triomphe, the towers of Notre Dame and, now, pup tents for the poor. There is new architecture springing up along the streets of this stately city, a counterpoint to the stone monuments and Beaux-Arts apartment buildings for which the French capital is known.     Since the frigid days of late December, Doctors of the World, a French organization that helps the homeless, has been distributing nylon tents to the growing number of people who sleep on the city's sidewalks and beneath its bridges.

headline: 4 Knight Ridder Papers to Be Sold for $1 Billion
abstract: The MediaNews newspaper chain controlled by William Dean Singleton announced plans on Wednesday to acquire four Knight Ridder newspapers, although two papers would first pass through the hands of another chain, the Hearst Corporation.     The four papers, fetching a price of $1 billion in cash, are among 12 Knight Ridder publications that the McClatchy Company agreed to buy last month but does not want.

headline: Fighting Inflation: Higher Rates and Tough Talk
abstract: Mark A Stein Five Days column; consumer prices rose 0.4 percent last month, pushing annual rate to 2.4 percent for year; economists and investors assume Federal Reserve Board will continue to raise interest rates, most likely at next two-day meeting of policy-making Federal Open Market Committee; financial markets reacted strongly to news about inflation; stock fell for Airbus parent company European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company after delivery delays of new A380 airliner; Singapore Airlines said it would buy 20 787-9 aircraft from rival Boeing with options on 20 more; Tribune Company directors disagreed about strategy, raising possibility that newspaper conglomerate could be broken up; Chandler family accused management of pursuing failed strategy and failing to compete with rivals; investors began filing lawsuits against companies under suspicion of backdating stock options; photo (M)

headline: Qwest Goes From the Goat to the Hero
abstract: FEW customers are given to gushing about their phone companies, but before last week's report that Qwest Communications was apparently the lone holdout among the Big Four telecommunications companies secretly supplying the National Security Agency with call records on ordinary Americans, the Denver-based company was often referred to by online grumblers as ''the Qworst.''     Whether or not that reputation had been healed by the company's unexpected (and perhaps overstated) turn as defiant protector of consumer privacy is unclear.

headline: Lifting Rates in '00, Fed Knew of Market Risk
abstract: Transcripts show that Michael Prell, former head of Federal Reserve research and statistics division, warned of economic consequences of possible stock market collapse if Fed raised main interest rate in May 2000; Fed did raise rate by 0.5 percent, to 6.5 percent, sixth increase in eight meetings; Fed's rate committee voted unanimously in December 2000 to say that 'economic weakness' was now bigger threat than inflation, signal that rate reduction would come soon (M)

headline: When a Newsmaker Buys the Newspaper
abstract: Brian Tierney and his team of business leaders hope to revive Philadelphia's main newspapers; editors at Philadelphia Inquirer and Philadelphia Daily News vow to work with new owners to make changes and adapt to times; critics fear Tierney will use newspapers as platform for his personal and political agendas; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Pro-Democracy Leader Shot And Wounded
abstract: Edil Baisalov, the director of the Coalition for Democracy and Civil Society in Kyrgyzstan, was wounded by a gunshot to the head as he left his office in Bishkek, the capital. The gunman escaped, witnesses said. Mr. Baisalov, who has repeatedly criticized the government for failing to combat organized crime -- and the presence of underworld figures in government -- recently told a reporter, ''I hope you cover my murder.''    ETHAN WILENSKY-LANFORD (NYT)

headline: Can the Dollar's Loss Become Your Portfolio's Gain?
abstract: Stock market strategists offer advice on investing in foreign stocks when US dollar slides; foreign stocks have outpaced American stocks for more than three years and individual investors have poured nearly $75 billion into foreign stock funds so far this year; growing number of strategists predict further weakening of dollar; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Intelligence Chief Is Badly Wounded in Bombing
abstract: Palestinian intelligence chief Maj Gen Tareq Abu Rajab, also known as Muhammad Shanyura, is badly wounded in bombing at his heavily guarded headquarters in Gaza City; Rajab is senior member of Fatah and ally of Pres Mahmoud Abbas; no one claims responsibility for explosion; attack comes at time of heightened tension between Fatah and Hamas; some Palestinians suggest attack could be revenge for killing of Popular Resistance Committees leader Abu Youssef al-Quqa (M)

headline: N.B.A. Wants Women to Talk Basketball
abstract: Richard Sandomir Advertising column on National Basketball Assn's new print-ad campaign aimed at attracting female fans age 18 to 34 and stoke viewership among women during playoffs; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Cult Leader Gets 20 Years
abstract: Paul Schäfer, the German-born, 84-year-old leader of Colonia Dignidad, an apocalyptic religious sect established in southern Chile more than 40 years ago, was sentenced to 20 years in prison for sexually abusing 25 children who lived at the group's compound. He went underground in 1997, after the charges were filed but was captured in Argentina last year and extradited to Chile. Mr. Schäfer, who was also ordered to pay $1.4 million to his victims, still faces rights abuse charges, including kidnapping and torture, stemming from his cooperation with the military and intelligence services during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.   LARRY ROHTER (NYT)

headline: Rice, in Greece and Turkey, Holds Talks on Iraq and Iran
abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice assured Turkish leaders on Tuesday that the United States would step up efforts to stop Kurdish insurgents in Iraq from infiltrating into Turkey, but she cautioned the government not to send troops to Iraq to do the job.     The Turkish foreign minister, Abdullah Gul, said there had been a surge in infiltration in recent weeks.

headline: Britain and France Press U.N. to Oppose Iran Nuclear Efforts
abstract: Britain and France circulated a draft Security Council resolution on Wednesday demanding that Iran give up nuclear activities that the West believes are aimed at building bombs.     The measure was drafted under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter, which makes resolutions mandatory and opens the way to penalties or military action.

headline: Amid border shelling, Palestinian rifts show
Guidelines For Radio Tags Aim to Protect Buyer Privacy
abstract: Some of the opponents in the debate over the potential privacy abuses of identification and tracking systems using tiny radio tags have come together to draft best-practices guidelines that are to be released today at a technology trade show in Las Vegas.     Radio tagging technology, called RFID for radio frequency identification, is already widely used in wireless toll collection systems and to control access to buildings, track livestock and manage industrial assets. It is also rapidly spreading into libraries, hospitals and systems that track consumer goods through the retail supply chain. Radio tags, which are based on microchips, carry more information than bar codes, and large numbers of them can be scanned at the same time.

headline: 25 Sentenced for Plotting Paris Terror Attacks
abstract: A French court on Wednesday sentenced 25 people convicted of plotting terrorist attacks on the French capital in 2002 to prison terms ranging from 6 months to 10 years.     Prosecutors had charged them with planning attacks on several sites, including the Eiffel Tower. One of the convicts, Menad Benchellali, 32, was accused of trying to concoct chemical or biological weapons at his mother's apartment in a suburb of Lyon.

headline: 'Hairspray' Gets Ready for Next Life
abstract: HOLLYWOOD is constantly seeking the next big thing by mugging the past. But sometimes the kernel of an idea is found in the cracks, a move that, properly executed, turns subculture into mass entertainment.      Amid the bland, reliable retreads -- neither the financial nor the dramatic arc of ''Mission Impossible III'' is tough to predict -- New Line Cinema is betting that ''Hairspray,'' a musical fable about a chubby girl with a dream and a cross-dressing co-star, can triumph anew.

headline: Endless Meetings: The Black Holes of the Workday
abstract: Excel Survey for tech company PolyVision Corporation shows American workers question value of time spent in meetings; 75 percent surveyed say meetings could be more effective; graph shows men spend nearly twice as many hours in meetings as women; graph (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Memo Pad column; United and other major airlines hastily withdraw $50 hikes in one-way business fares after American Airlines fails to join in; $2 to $5 increases in leisure travel fares seem to be holding; Delta adds five new nonstop flights between La Guardia in New York and O'Hare in Chicago; Virgin Atlantic Airways plans marketing campaign to increase business-class travelers by 10 percent in next 12 months (M)

headline: Lawyer Leaves A.I.G.
abstract: Ernest Patrikis, top lawyer at American International Group, will leave to join law firm Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman; chief financial officer Steven Bensinger will oversee legal division until successor is named (S)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: SENATE APPROVES TAX BILL -- The Senate voted 54 to 44 to pass $70 billion in tax cuts, most of which will flow to the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. The action ensured that virtually all of President Bush's tax cuts will be locked in place until after the next presidential election. [Page A1.]    STOCKS FALL -- Stock prices fell sharply as investors worried that rising oil prices would quicken the pace of inflation and force policy makers to raise interest rates further. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.3 percent, to 1,305.92. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 1.2 percent, to 11,500.73, and the Nasdaq fell 2 percent, to 2,272.70. [C1.]    MARKET REVIVAL IN CHINA -- After sinking to an eight-year low last year and being declared all but dead, the Chinese stock market has recently soared to a level more than 50 percent higher from a year ago. [C9.]    WAL-MART SUPPLIER CONTROVERSY -- Wal-Mart, having helped start an advocacy group that trumpets the company's contributions to America, is quietly helping that organization recruit Wal-Mart's suppliers to join the public relations offensive -- a move that some vendors say puts improper pressure on them. [C1.]    ORGANIC FOOD AND WAL-MART -- Starting this summer, there will be a lot more organic food on supermarket shelves, and it should cost a lot less. The reason is that Wal-Mart wants to sell more organic food -- and because of its size and clout, Wal-Mart usually gets what it wants. [A1]    INHALER SHORTAGE -- A federally mandated shift to a more ozone-friendly version of hand-held inhalers for asthma attacks is creating spot shortages of the devices. [C1.]    MERGER RESISTANCE IN EUROPE -- Few business executives are as determined to forge a single European market as Alessandro Profumo, the Italian banker who took over HVB, the German bank. For other European chief executives eager to expand across borders, Mr. Profumo's experience shows that building a pan-European enterprise requires luck, stamina, and a thick skin. [C1.]    NEW TWIST IN TRADING CASE -- Federal prosecutors arrested Jason C. Smith and charged him with leaking secret information from grand jury proceedings to David Pajcin and Eugene Plotkin, two men previously accused of running an insider-trading ring that reaped $6.7 million in illegal profits in 2004 and 2005. [C1.]    WARNING ON PAXIL -- GlaxoSmithKline has sent letters to doctors warning that its antidepressant drug Paxil appears to increase the risk of suicide attempts in young adults. [A26.]    SUIT OVER AIDS DRUG -- Two patients' rights groups in India sued to stop Gilead Sciences, a California biopharmaceutical company, from patenting the AIDS drug Viread, which is available in India in a generic form. If the drug is patented, it will become too expensive for patients in developing countries, the groups argue. [A4.]    BLACKBERRY IN CHINA -- Research In Motion said it would introduce its BlackBerry wireless service in China. But the announcement prompted questions about how the service would fit into the Chinese government's program of communications surveillance and censorship. [C3.]    HEALTH BILL FAILS -- A small-business health insurance bill collapsed in the Senate as critics contended that the bill would strip away years of consumer protections. [A23.]    PAY-FOR-PLAY SETTLEMENT -- The Universal Music Group has agreed to pay $12 million to settle accusations that executives paid radio programmers to play songs. [C3.]    ONLINE    SHORTS AS OFFICE WEAR -- Dress codes these days are as elastic as a bungee cord, expanding to accommodate all manner of once unthinkable workplace infractions. This year dress codes have stretched to encompass shorts, of all things. A report can be found at nytimes.com/fashion.    INVESTOR TOOLS -- Information on all United States stock, plus bonds, mutual funds, commodities and foreign stocks, as well as analysis of industry sectors and stock indexes is at nytimes.com/business    POGUE'S POSTS -- A blog on the latest in technology from the Times's David Pogue, with a new look is at nytimes.com/pogue.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    Expedia Inc., the Internet travel agency, said first-quarter profit fell 51 percent on higher expenses and waning demand for vacation packages. Net income declined to $23.3 million from $48 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 1.8 percent to $493.9 million.   (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Delta Air Lines Inc., the nation's third-largest carrier, said in a regulatory filing Thursday that it expected a first-quarter loss of $2.1 billion, almost all of it because of bankruptcy restructuring costs. Delta said in the filing that excluding the cost of restructuring, losses for the quarter would be $356 million.   (AP)    Shareholders of Google Inc., the world's most popular Web search provider, rejected a dissident investor proposal to end a two-tier ownership structure.   (REUTERS)    Ford told shareholders that the company was considering a plug-in hybrid vehicle.   (REUTERS)

headline: Eisner Buys Maker Of Videos for Babies
abstract: Former Disney chief Michael Eisner's Tornante Co reportedly acquires Team Baby Entertainment, producer of sports. videos for infants and toddlers; terms are not disclosed (S)

headline: Publicly Debating Privacy
abstract: What's Online column; Wired News publishes documents supporting accusations by former AT&T employee that company helped government monitor private Internet traffic; bloggers agree that accusations are true but disagree on importance; Hollywood WireTap reveals several famous pornography stars are promoting themselves on social networking site MySpace; advertisers are withdrawing advertising as result; Guy Goma, who was accidentally interviewed by BBC about music downloading, has become Internet celebrity; drawing (M)

headline: Somali Islamists Cement Control of South Amid Border Tension
abstract: The leader of the Islamists who now control most of southern Somalia accused the United States on Saturday of orchestrating what he called a border incursion by hundreds of Ethiopian troops.     ''We want the whole world to know what's going on,'' Sheik Sharif Ahmed, chairman of the Islamic Courts Union, told reporters in the provincial town of Jowhar. ''The United States is encouraging Ethiopia to take over the area.''

headline: Networks Pick Up Pace of Fall Season Ad Sales
abstract: Broadcast television networks sell commercial time in so-called upfront market; pace of sales varies from year to year; Fox Broadcasting, CBS, NBC and CW network are all selling at accelerated pace for 2006-2007 season (S)

headline: Poll Finds Discord Between the Muslim and Western Worlds
abstract: Non-Muslim Westerners and Muslims around the world have widely different views of world events, and each group tends to view the other as violent, intolerant and lacking in respect for women, a new international survey of more than 14,000 people in 13 nations indicates.     In what the survey, part of the Pew Global Attitudes Project for 2006, called one of its most striking findings, majorities in Egypt, Indonesia, Jordan and Turkey -- Muslim countries with fairly strong ties to the United States -- said, for example, that they did not believe that Arabs had carried out the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States.

headline: Thai vote fails to solve political crisis
Professor Gets Accounting Board Seat
abstract: Professor Gets Accounting Boa

headline: Sentence in Impath Fraud
abstract: Former Impath Inc president Richard P Adelson is sentenced by Judge Jed S Rahoff to 3 1/2 years in prison, fined $1.2 million and ordered to pay $50 million in restitution on charges of conspiracy, securities fraud and filing false statements with Securities and Exchange Commission (S)

headline: Jury Chosen to Retry Broadband Executives
abstract: Jury is chosen in retrial of former Enron Broadband Services finance vice president Kevin A Howard and former accountant Michael W Krautz; each face charges of wire fraud, falsifying records and conspiracy; prosecutors say Howard and Krautz plotted to overstate unit's financial prospects and falsified $110 million in revenue (M)

headline: Judge indicts 29, citing election influence in Madrid bombings
Death by Smiley Face: When Rivals Disdain Profit
abstract: Richard Siklos column on new-media ventures that are driven not by quest for profits but rather by their creators' desire to do something they feel good about; says these ventures, which he calls 'purpose-driven media,' present perculiar challenge to traditional media; comments on Craigslist.org, Firefox, Chowhound.com and LaLa.com; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Prominent Dissident Arrested
abstract: The authorities arrested Michel Kilo, a prominent opposition figure and writer, over the weekend. It was latest in a number of arrests of government critics. Mr. Kilo's arrest came just days after he signed a petition calling for a radical overhaul of Syria's relations with neighboring Lebanon, a rights group said.   HASSAN M. FATTAH (NYT)

headline: GOOGLE DREAMS
abstract: Heidrick & Struggles executive search firm chairman Thomas Friel has collected deferred profit of $17.6 million from warrants to buy Google shares that he sold in September 2004 (S)

headline: AOL to Add Free Phone to Instant Messaging Feature
abstract: AOL is preparing to offer the 41 million users of its instant messaging system a free phone number that will allow people to call them from regular phones while they are online.     The move is part of a broad effort by AOL -- which has been buffeted by defections from its flagship dial-up Internet service -- to capitalize on the continued popularity of its decade-old AIM instant message system.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         Bankrate, 2.3 million shares. Credit Suisse and Citigroup Global Markets.     Delek U.S. Holdings, an initial public offering of 10 million shares. Lehman Brothers and Citigroup Global Markets.     DynCorp International, an initial public offering of 25 million shares. Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs.     Northstar Neuroscience, an initial public offering of six million shares. Citigroup Global Markets and SG Cowen.     Novacea, an initial public offering of 6.3 million shares. Bear Stearns and SG Cowen.     NYSE Group, 25 million shares. J. P. Morgan Securities, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley.     Spectranetics, 3.6 million shares. Jefferies.    (Source by MCM EquityWatch)

headline: Password Protection for Portable Drives
abstract: Password Protection For Portable Drives    Q. Can the data on a U.S.B. flash drive be password-protected?    A. Those tiny flash-memory drives that plug into a computer's U.S.B. port are great for hauling large files between computers -- but can cause worry if they get lost while storing sensitive information. Anyone who finds an unprotected portable drive could plug it into a computer and browse the files stored on it.

headline: U.S. step stirs doubt on global trade talks
Fund Manager Indicted
abstract: A leading shareholder activist, Yoshiaki Murakami, was indicted for insider trading, Tokyo prosecutors said on Friday.     The Tokyo District Public Prosecutors Office said that Mr. Murakami knew about a plan by the Livedoor Company to seek control of a Japanese broadcaster, and bought shares based on that information.

headline: Pentagon Picks Troops for Iraq, Maintaining Current Contingent
abstract: The Pentagon announced Tuesday that it planned to send 21,000 troops to Iraq in the next rotation of forces. That would keep the American presence at current levels into next year, unless the security situation improved.      Senior military officials said that the announcement of units to be deployed between August and January could change, depending on conditions in Iraq, and that so-called off ramps for the troops bound for Iraq were still under discussion.

headline: Pay for Oil Chiefs Spiked Like Prices
abstract: Compensation for oil companies executives rose in

headline: Chinese File New Indictment Against Times Researcher
abstract: Chinese prosecutors have filed a new indictment against a researcher for The New York Times, but it is unclear if they have introduced new charges or simply restated the case that was withdrawn in March, his lawyer said Monday.     The new indictment against Zhao Yan was filed last Friday in a Beijing court. Mo Shaoping, the lawyer who has represented Mr. Zhao, said he had not yet been able to see the indictment and could not determine if the charges had changed.

headline: Interest Rate Concerns Keep Lid on Dow
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 6.8 points, to 11,584.54; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 1.1 points, to 1,324.66; Nasdaq composite index adds 2.42 points, to 2,344.99; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 2 Held On Terror Charges
abstract: The police in northern England said they had arrested a 21-year-old man and a 16-year-old on charges of conspiracy to murder and of conspiring to ''cause a public nuisance by use of poisons and or explosives.'' Both are to appear in court today. The arrests took place last week at Manchester Airport and in Dewsbury, Yorkshire.   ALAN COWELL (NYT)

headline: Exxon moves to top of Fortune 500 list
50 Killed in Bombing at a Sunni Prayer Service in Karachi
abstract: Powerful explosion apparently set off by suicide bomber rips through large congregation at prayer service in Karachi, Pakistan, leaving about 50 dead, including three prominent Sunni religious leaders; blast sets off panic and hours of rioting as protesters clash with police and set fires around city; about 100 people are wounded; there is no immediate claim of responsibility; photo (M)

headline: Bomb Kills 12 Worshipers at Sunni Mosque in Iraq Near Site of Zarqawi's Death
abstract: At least 12 worshipers are killed when bomb explodes at Sunni mosque in Hibhib; photo (M)

headline: Panel Reverses Bush Cuts in Family Planning Aid
abstract: House subcommittee approves foreign aid budget that would reverse deep cuts Pres Bush proposed for international family planning programs; committee also scales back Bush's ambitious plans for Millennium Challenge Corp, new foreign aid agency that provides large aid packages to poor countries considered to be well governed; agency will get $2 billion rather than $3 billion that Bush requested, and far short of $5 billion that he originally envisioned (M)

headline: Fighting escalates in beleaguered Nepal
Snow Did Well on the Economy, but His Boss Did Poorly in the Polls
abstract: Floyd Norris Off the Charts column assesses tenure of Treasury Sec John Snow, compared with performances under each of previous 10 secretaries; focuses on annual growth in real gross domestic product and payroll employment as well as performance of dollar, stock market and Consumer Price Index; charts (M)

headline: 7 Tribune Directors Say Call for Breakup Is Power Play
abstract: Seven independent directors of Tribune Company support chief executive Dennis J FitzSimons in fight over breakup of company from Chandler family, which owns 12 percent of company; directors accuse shareholders of using public campaign to further own agenda (M)

headline: Australian Chief Denies Seeing Cables on Payoffs
abstract: Australian Prime Min John Howard says he never saw cables that over six-year period raised suspicions about AWB Ltd's payoffs to Saddam Hussein's government for wheat sales to Iraq; Howard appears before judicial inquiry; iconic Australian company is accused of paying more than $200 million under UN's oil-for-food program in 1990's (M)

headline: Moving Favorites When You Switch
abstract: Moving Favorites When You Switch    Q. How do I transfer my Internet Explorer Favorites from my old PC to the Web browser on the new Mac?    A. One quick way to move your Favorites, or browser bookmarks, to a new computer is to start Internet Explorer, go to the File menu and select ''Import and Export.'' When the Import/Export wizard starts up, choose ''Export Favorites'' from the list of actions and click on the Next button.      Once you select your Favorites file, you can export it to the desktop or a folder on your PC. From there, you can copy the exported Favorites file onto an external drive or recordable compact disc, copy it to your new Mac over a network connection or send the file to yourself as an e-mail attachment from the old computer to the new one.

headline: Iran to Give $50 Million to Hamas-Led Government
abstract: Iran's foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki, announced the donation on the last day of a pro-Palestinian conference.

headline: Appointee of Hamas is blocked by Abbas
Wal-Mart sends bigripples to suppliers
Will Women Have an Equal Say at the Tricentennial?
abstract: Catalyst, nonprofit group focused on women's issues, calculates that, at current rate of advance, women will have equal power in corporate America in 2076; graph (S)

headline: Buyout deal by KKR is India's largest ever
Labor to Align With Kadima in Israel, Party Leaders Say
abstract: The union was expected, with both parties favoring the removal of additional Jewish settlements in the West Bank.

headline: A Way to View 'Desperate Housewives' While Cruising the Nile
abstract: Thanks to a handful of hardware and software products, viewers can see their favorite programs anywhere in the world at the same time they are being broadcast back home.      As long as the user has access to a high-speed Internet connection, both live and recorded programs can be transmitted from one's home across the globe, to be viewed on a PC or often other types of portable devices, like a palmtop, a cellphone or a portable game unit.

headline: Protestant Spurns Offer of Top Position in Ulster
abstract: Ian Paisley, Northern Ireland's firebrand Protestant leader, on Monday rejected a proposal by Sinn Fein, his archenemy, that he should lead a power-sharing executive body to revive the province's stalled peace effort.     ''Madam, certainly not,'' Mr. Paisley said when the speaker of the Northern Ireland Assembly, Eileen Bell, asked whether he would accept the position of first minister, with Martin McGuinness of Sinn Fein as his deputy. For decades, Mr. Paisley has built his reputation as Sinn Fein's most intractable foe.

headline: Universal Music Settles Big Payola Case
abstract: Vivendi unit Universal Music Group agrees to pay $12 million to settle accusations that its executives paid radio programmers to play songs; settlement is largest yet in probe by New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer that has shaken music business; Spitzer's office is still investigating EMI Group as well as several radio companies; Federal Communications Commission has requested documents from radio companies as part of separate inquiry; photo (M)

headline: Report Cites Europe's Role in C.I.A. Renditions
abstract: A Council of Europe report to be released today on the C.I.A.'s practice of secretly abducting and transporting terrorism suspects to third countries for interrogation beyond the jurisdiction of American laws says that several European countries acted as staging areas or transfer points.      The report, a summary of which was seen by The New York Times, says that rendition missions set off from airports in Azerbaijan, Germany, Spain and Turkey. Airports in the Czech Republic, Greece, Ireland and Italy were used for refueling, it says. Detainees were picked up for ''unlawful transfer'' in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Italy, Macedonia and Sweden. Detainees who passed through those places were dropped off for interrogation or transfer onward in Poland, Romania, Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Uzbekistan, among other countries.

headline: WHERE WILL SHE SHOP?
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission filing shows Catherine West, new chief operating officer at J C Penney, will receive pay package worth more than $20 million (S)

headline: The Calculus of Taking the Buyout
abstract: Consciously or not, the tens of thousands of General Motors workers who face decisions about the company's buyout offers before an early June deadline are getting a crash course in medical cost-benefit analysis.      The prospect of losing General Motors health coverage can be terrifying for workers who went straight from high school into factory jobs and have few good prospects for employment beyond the assembly line.

headline: Addenda
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies is in the final stages of discussions to form an alliance with Facebook, the popular social-networking Web site for students.     Philippe Krakowsky, executive vice president for strategy at Interpublic in New York, confirmed a report of the negotiations that appeared Friday on Adweek.com. A partnership with Facebook would help give Interpublic agencies and the advertisers working with them useful insights into the youth market, Mr. Krakowsky said.

headline: MTV Will Test Its Own Entry in Online Music
abstract: A test version of MTV's long-delayed online music service, called Urge, will be introduced today.      The service was developed in cooperation with Microsoft, and will be heavily promoted from within the latest version of the Windows Media Player, which also begins public testing today.

headline: How EU's No. 2 court works
An overseas surprise for Berlusconi
China Installs Another Bishop, Angering Vatican
abstract: The state-controlled Catholic Church in China installed a second bishop on Wednesday over the objections of the Vatican, a move that could derail efforts to re-establish diplomatic relations between China and the Holy See.     The Chinese Catholic Patriotic Association, set up by Mao to control the church, arranged for the consecration of Liu Xinhong on Wednesday morning as bishop of Wuhu, in Anhui Province, in eastern China. China has two Catholic hierarchies, the government-authorized church and an underground church of bishops and other priests loyal to Rome.

headline: China Urged to Reassess Tiananmen
abstract: A group of 126 people whose relatives died in the suppression of the June 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square issued a joint appeal on Monday to reassess the episode and compensate victims, even as Chinese authorities worked to stop any possible commemorations of it as the anniversary approached.     In an open letter released by Human Rights in China, a United States-based monitoring organization, the relatives, who call themselves the Tiananmen Mothers, urged the government to conduct a fresh investigation into the killings, allow family members to openly mourn lost loved ones, and compensate people condemned as criminals for supporting the demonstrations. They also called on the government to restore the political status of those who had been condemned.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: NESTLÉ SET TO BUY JENNY CRAIG -- Nestlé, the Swiss food company, is planning to announce today that it has agreed to acquire Jenny Craig, the weight-loss company, for about $600 million. [Page C1.]    QUESTIONS ON OPTIONS -- A case involving Micrel, a semiconductor company, raises questions about how companies that were pushing the envelope of accounting and tax practice were able to get the blessings of auditors and lawyers.
