[C1.]    GAME MAKERS' STOCKS SINK -- Video game companies have been taking a beating in the stock market, reflecting a realization that the game industry will recover considerably more slowly than expected from the transition to a new generation of consoles, the Xbox 360 from Microsoft, the Sony PlayStation 3 and the Nintendo Wii. [C1.]    TRIBUNE STRATEGY FALTERS -- Recent financial troubles at the Tribune Company show that its ''synergy'' strategy -- sharing broadcast and print content -- is not working out as planned. [C1.]    DOWLOADABLE EXERCISE -- More personal trainers are packaging their services in audio or video files that can be downloaded to an iPod or P.D.A. for a quick trip to the gym. For example, Kimberly Fowler, left, who owns the YAS Yoga and Spinning Studio in Venice, Calif., uploaded a 53-minute workout video to iAmplify.com, the first of what she said would be a video series that could be viewed online or on devices like iPods. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C5.]    REPORTERS TOLD TO LEAVE -- Last Wednesday, after spending four days reporting from the United States Naval Base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, three newspaper reporters and a photographer were ordered off the island by the Pentagon. But it is not clear why they were banished. [C3.]    BEYOND TOYS FOR PLAYSKOOL -- In a foray into the infant care market, Playskool's owner, Hasbro, will introduce a line of Playskool diapers, baby wipes and sippy cups. [C1.]    TRYING IT, AGAIN -- The comedian Kathy Griffin is appearing in a remake of one of Madison Avenue's most popular commercials, the humorous 1971 spot for Alka-Seltzer known as ''Try it, you'll like it.'' Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C8.]    ONLINE    CHINA'S DARK CLOUDS -- David Barboza discusses how China's coal industry is creating an environmental and health care crisis in a video report at nytimes.com/business.    LITTLE LEAGUE'S LAST DAY -- Harry Hurt III, the writer of Executive Pursuits, reports on the last day of Little League at nytimes.com/business.    THE CLASSICS -- Previous columns from Gretchen Morgenson, Joe Nocera and Floyd Norris can be found at select.nytimes.com/pages/timesselect.

headline: Besieged Taiwan Leader Sets Deal on China Flights
abstract: Facing an attempt in the legislature to pass a referendum on recalling the president, the government here unexpectedly announced on Wednesday that it had reached a deal with Beijing to allow many charter flights to and from mainland China.     The agreement is the latest of several signs that relations between Taipei and Beijing may be thawing, a change that has occurred as a political crisis surrounding the president, Chen Shui-bian, has deepened.

headline: 3 Oil Firms May Alter Gulf Leases
abstract: Facing angry lawmakers from both political parties, executives from three major oil companies -- Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips -- indicated on Wednesday that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies for drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.     But one of the most active players in the gulf, the Kerr-McGee Corporation, showed no signs of compromise and told a House hearing that it was entitled to the subsidies -- known as royalty relief -- even if oil prices remained above $70 a barrel. And Exxon Mobil said it saw no reason for the subsidies to be changed.

headline: Mitsubishi Harnesses Colored Lasers to Produce New-Generation Lightweight HDTV
abstract: As if shopping for new flat-panel, high-definition television is not hard enough, Mitsubishi is scheduled to announce this week that it has developed commercial television that uses colored lasers to display bright, deep images on large, thin, lightweight screens -- surpassing images seen on film. The television sets, which Mitsubishi is calling the first of their kind, are expected to reach stores sometime late next year.     At the heart of the first generation of this new television is an existing rear-projection technology called digital light processing. In the past, this technology, developed by Texas Instruments, used white-light mercury lamps as the television's light source. With laser television, separate red, green and blue lasers are used in conjunction with an HDTV chip, said Frank DeMartin, vice president for marketing and product development at Mitsubishi.

headline: Intel Details Broader Role in Indian PC's
abstract: Intel plans to introduce low-cost computer in India as part of wider global strategy to promote use of technology in emerging markets; processor, chip set and software will be designed by Intel and computer's hardware will be produced by Indian companies (M)

headline: Today In Business | Generic Cholesterol Drug
abstract: Food and Drug Administration authorizes Teva Pharmaceutical Industries and Ranbaxy Laboratories to sell generic copies of Merck's cholesterol drug Zocor (S)

headline: Dow Rises After Commodity Prices Fall
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 3.26 points to 1,294.50; Dow Jones industrial average adds 47.78 points to 11,428.77; Nasdaq composite index loses 5.26 points to 2,238.52; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; graphs; chart (M)

headline: Palestinian Leader Orders Force to Find Israeli
abstract: The Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, ordered his security services on Monday to find a kidnapped Israeli soldier in the Gaza Strip. The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Olmert, warned of ''comprehensive and ongoing military action'' in Gaza by the Israeli military, which massed troops and armor on the border.     Tensions were building over the fate of the soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, 19, who was captured early Sunday morning in a raid by Palestinians into Israel through a long tunnel from Gaza. The groups holding him said that before any information on him would be disclosed, Israel must release all Palestinian women in its jails and all Palestinian prisoners under the age of 18.

headline: Staying Focused on Steel
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Mittal Steel chief executive Lakshmi Mittal, who comments on steel production and consumption, particularly in China and running company while seeking to acquire next-largest rival Arcelor in unsolicited takeover bid; photo (M)

headline: Briefly: A bomb scare halts all outgoing flights
People
abstract: Nancy Hill joined Lowe Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group, as chief executive for North America. She assumes some duties from Susan Cantor, chief executive for the New York office, who left. Ms. Hill had most recently been executive vice president and managing director on the Visa account at BBDO Worldwide, New York, part of the Omnicom Group.     Andy Sims joined ZenithOptimedia USA, San Francisco, as senior vice president and interactive director, part of a reorganization of digital media operations. He succeeds Brenda Goodman, who is leaving, the agency said. Mr. Sims had been senior vice president and director for interactive services at SF Interactive, San Francisco, part of Butler, Shine, Stern & Partners. ZenithOptimedia USA is part of the ZenithOptimedia Group division of the Publicis Groupe.

headline: Quake Upsets the Cradle of Indonesian Culture
abstract: Behind a painted sign on a sidewalk reading, ''This is not an exhibition, it's a disaster,'' hundreds of traditional ceramic sculptures lie shattered beneath a collapsed roof.     More than half the houses, shops and galleries lining this small street here were destroyed in the earthquake on Saturday and are littered with the broken remains of their owners' livelihoods. The hundreds of artists who live in Kasongan, a village in Bantul, the district hardest hit by the quake, have survived for generations by selling the pottery they make to tourists.

headline: Legislate Learning English? If Only It Were So Easy
abstract: Austan Goolsbee Economic Scene column on Pres Bush's call for illegal immigrants to learn English as part of plan to gain citizenship; explores reasons why millions of immigrants, trapped in low-paying jobs with no obvious means of advancement, still do not know English; study conducted by University of Chicago economist Hoyt Bleakley and University of Houston economist Aimee Chin finds it is difficult for adults to become fluent in new language and virtually impossible to speak without accent (M)

headline: Merkel to press for EU unity
Poland Averts Clash With Europe Over Italian Bank Deal
abstract: Poland reaches agreement with UniCredito allowing Polish banks Bank BPH and Pekao SA to be combined under Italian owner; disputed deal has been criticized as example of resurgence of protectionism and economic nationalism in Poland; agreement is likely to ease tensions with European Union, which is fighting countries blocking foreign corporate takeovers (M)

headline: This Knee Doesn't Jerk at Every Deal
abstract: Qwest Communications chief executive Richard C Notebaert, in Saturday Interview column, discusses challenges facing company; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Candidate And Chávez In Verbal Attacks
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela threatens to sever diplomatic relations with Peru if Alan Garcia wins presidential runoff against nationalist Ollanta Humala (S)

headline: Ethnic Tensions Over Cartoon Set Off Riots in Northwest Iran
abstract: Four people reportedly were killed and 70 injured in recent riots in Iran's Azeri region in protests over cartoon in official newspaper that depicted cockroach speaking Turkish Azeri; paper was shut down and cartoonist and editor jailed but tensions have increased among members of minority group that makes up more than quarter of population; photo; Ayatollah Ali Khamenei blames West and lauds Azeris (S)

headline: Telecom Carriers and Suppliers Go Their Separate Ways on Profits
abstract: AT&T says first-quarter profit grew by better-than-expected 63 percent, thanks in part to cost-cutting measures after merger with SBC Communications and expanding revenue at Cingular; says quarterly earnings were $1.45 billion, compared with $885 million in 2005 period; says sales rose 55 percent, to $15.8 billion; says Cingular Wireless added 1.7 million subscribers in quarter, while AT&T signed up 511,000 high-speed Internet customers; Lucent Technologies says fiscal second-quarter earnings were $181 million, down from $267 million in same quarter last year; says sales fell 8.6 percent, to $2.14 billion; photo (M)

headline: Airbus Considering a Request for State Aid
abstract: Facing mounting problems over its inability to deliver the A380 superjumbo plane on time, Airbus appears set to request state aid for the development of a midsize jetliner in what some analysts described as a rescue package.      A move toward development loans from governments for the midrange A350 jet would almost certainly worsen a bitter trans-Atlantic dispute over the different forms of government support received by Airbus and its American rival, Boeing.

headline: Rage swells in the streets of Katmandu
Yes, You Can Edit Your Photos. But You Needn't.
abstract: Panasonic plans to introduce KX-PX10M Digital Photo Printer, which requires just two button clicks to print 4x6 photos; photo (S)

headline: Indictments are near in Madrid attacks
After Long Hunt, U.S. Bombs Kill Al Qaeda Leader in Iraq
abstract: With the two 500-pound bombs that killed Abu Musab al-Zarqawi on Wednesday evening, American forces eliminated Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq and boosted the flagging confidence of American officials and the new Iraqi government as they moved into the fourth brutal year of warfare here.      But the American officials themselves offered an immediate warning against overstating the impact that the death of Mr. Zarqawi, the most wanted insurgent in Iraq, would have on prospects that American and Iraqi forces can gain the upper hand in the conflict. Among other things, they said they expected Al Qaeda to name a successor to Mr. Zarqawi quickly from among his closest aides.

headline: To Charge Up Customers, Put Customers in Charge
abstract: John Fluevog solicits customer design ideas for possible future shoes; posts submissions on company's Web site, inviting viewers to vote for favorites; manufactures and sells most promising designs; Fluevog says process is way to interact with customers and get them more involved; says it improves offerings; follows trend of more tech-savvy customers influencing companies in new ways; Jones Soda uses customer-submitted photographs as labels for its products; Threadless.com sells T-shirts based on customer-submitted designs; drawing (M)

headline: For Visitors, Graveyard Holds Memories of a Bloody Era
abstract: One of the many unexpected things about the small graveyard here where Xi Qingsheng buried his mother during the mayhem of the Cultural Revolution is that it still exists.     The rusted front gate, locked for many years, opens into a walled cemetery that amounts to a time capsule from an era the Communist Party wants to forget. Revolutionary slogans, long since discredited, are etched onto huge, ornate tombstones, including the large concrete marker that Mr. Xi built for his mother when he was a teenager.

headline: Hot potato in Italy's shadows
Bin Laden Says West Is Waging War Against Islam
abstract: Osama bin Laden denounced what he called a ''Zionist-crusaders war on Islam'' in an audiotape broadcast Sunday, pointing to the isolation of the Hamas-led Palestinian government, talk of a Western peacekeeping force in Sudan and Muslim outrage over Danish cartoons mocking the Prophet Muhammad as new evidence of a clash of civilizations.     His voice sounding strong and combative, Mr. bin Laden implied that killing American civilians was justified, beseeched Muslims to fight any Sudan peacekeeping force and called for the creators of the offensive cartoons to be turned over to Al Qaeda for punishment.

headline: Alcatel and Lucent Say Technology Not at Risk
abstract: Alcatel and Lucent Technologies said over the weekend that they were confident they would be able to address security concerns about their planned combination that were raised by Representative Duncan Hunter last week.     ''We have put in place an approach that will protect sensitive U.S. technologies,'' an Alcatel spokeswoman, Régine Coqueran, said in a statement on Saturday.

headline: Canada: One-Day Strike Shuts Toronto Transit
abstract: Morning commuters in Toronto, Canada's largest city, faced chaotic traffic jams when a strike by transit workers forced some 800,000 bus and subway users to seek alternative ways to work. News of the strike, set off by a plan to force maintenance workers to work overnight shifts, came late on Sunday, so many commuters were surprised to find locked subway stations yesterday morning. Picket lines were removed by midafternoon after the strike was ruled illegal by a labor relations board. Service was partly in place by the evening rush hour.   CHRIS MASON (NYT)

headline: A family's mission of faith in  Kenya - Africa & Middle East - International Herald Tribune
CBS and Stern Said to Have Settled Lawsuit
abstract: CBS Radio settles breach-of-contract suit with Howard Stern; company, seeking at least $218 million in damages, sued Stern for promoting his move to Sirius Satellite Radio on morning show; agreement has yet to be signed; terms not disclosed (M)

headline: Jury Hears Indignation of Skilling
abstract: His emotions spilling over at times, Jeffrey K. Skilling admitted Thursday that he made mistakes at Enron, even as he continued to profess his innocence and blasted the government for charging him with conspiring to defraud Enron investors.     After nine weeks of listening to former colleagues and friends testify in federal court that he lied to Enron's investors and employees, Mr. Skilling, the former chief executive, fought back hard. On Thursday, his fourth day on the stand, he seemed righteously indignant in speeches deploring the fall of Enron, the former high-flying energy company that collapsed into bankruptcy in late 2001.

headline: Armed Groups Propel Iraq Toward Chaos
abstract: Even in a country beset by murder and death, the 16th Brigade represented a new frontier.     The brigade, a 1,000-man force set up by Iraq's Ministry of Defense in early 2005, was charged with guarding a stretch of oil pipeline that ran through the southern Baghdad neighborhood of Dawra. Heavily armed and lightly supervised, some members of the largely Sunni brigade transformed themselves into a death squad, cooperating with insurgents and executing government collaborators, Iraqi officials say.

headline: For the Serious DVD and CD Collector, a Way to Keep Things Tidy
abstract: Sony Vaio VGP-XL1B2 changer/recorder works with Windows XP Media Center Edition PC's to store, organize and manage up to 200 CD's and DVD's; can be attached to up to four additional units for more storage capacity; costs $799; photo (M)

headline: Yes, the New Macintosh and Windows Can Be Friends
abstract: David Pogue column on integration of Windows XP operating system with Apple Macintosh; flexibility is made possible by Intel chip that is powering many Macintosh models and will power all of them by end of year; innovation came about through contest won by San Francisco-area programmer Jesus Lopez; drawing (M)

headline: When drug trials go horribly wrong
Fees Sought for Oil Leases
abstract: Bush administration wants 56 oil and gas producers to renegotiate leases for drilling in Gulf of Mexico that allows them to avoid $10 billion in government fees; Director of Minerals Management Service Johnnie Burton says Interior Department may ask companies to voluntarily rewrite contracts from 1998 and 1999 to add provision for royalty payments (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Game Over, And Here Are The Keys
abstract: After a fierce public debate, Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott said he would no longer use an official country residence where he was photographed playing croquet while technically running the government. Acknowledging a personal, political setback, Mr. Prescott said his continued use of the state-financed mansion called Dorneywood, on 214 acres of parkland, ''is getting in the way of doing my job in government.''    ALAN COWELL (NYT)

headline: The Tree Doctors Are In. So Are Second Opinions.
abstract: Alina Tugend Short Cuts column on determining health of older trees; says that expert opinions may vary on options such as pruning or cutting down tree completely; warns that costs will be expensive regardless of course of action; photos (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,503 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    LEON, Christopher D., 20, Cpl., Marines; Lancaster, Calif.; Fifth Air Naval Gunfire Liaison Company, Third Marine Expeditionary Force.    MENCHACA, Kristian, 23, Pfc., Army; San Marcos, Tex.; 101st Airborne Division.    TUCKER, Thomas L., 25, Pfc., Army; Madras, Ore.; 101st Airborne Division.    WEBB, Brandon J., 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Swartz Creek, Mich.; First Marine Division.    WHITE, Christopher N., 23, Pfc., Marines; Southport, N.C.; First Marine Division.    WILLIAMS, Benjamin D., 30, Staff Sgt., Marines; Orange, Tex.; First Marine Division.

headline: Militant's Death in Gaza Spurs Violence Between Rivals
abstract: Palestinian militant Abu Youssef al-Quqa is killed when bomb destroys his car in Gaza City, and his associates accuse Palestinian security forces of being involved; allegation prompts gun battles that cause three more Palestinian deaths; violence raises concerns of increased turmoil in Palestinian areas, where Hamas has taken charge of Palestinian Authority government; photos (M)

headline: Hamas and Abbas Clash Over Plan for Security Forces
abstract: Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas today blocked an appointment by the Hamas-led government.

headline: Starting the Day the Quiet Way
abstract: Starting the Day The Quiet Way    Q. My classmates and I often listen to music in the evenings and sometimes forget to mute the sound when we shut down our computers, so we are loudly greeted when we start up Windows the next day. Is there a way to avoid that greeting song when Windows starts up and shuts down?    A. If you'd rather not hear the cheery Windows theme first thing in the morning, you can turn it off or change it to something else. Just go to the Start menu, to Control Panel and open the Sounds and Audio Devices icon.

headline: Skilled Traveler? Good Coach
abstract: Article on travel coaches who offer variety of services to business travelers, including teaching them how to make business trips less stressful, how to improve preparation time and how to make most of time spent on airplanes and away from office; photo (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,385 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    DANIEL, Jason B., 21, Cpl., Army; Fort Worth; Fourth Infantry Division.  EHNEY, Robert W., 26, Sgt., Army; Lexington, Ky.; Fourth Infantry Division.  LASSWELL, Shawn T. Jr., 21, Cpl., Army; Reno, Nev.; Fourth Infantry Division.  SIMONS, Aaron W., 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Modesto, Calif.; First Marine Division.

headline: U.S. warns business against illegal hires
Now in the Rearview Mirror: Low Gasoline Prices
abstract: Analysts warn that gasoline prices, fueled by strong demand, limited growth in supplies and instability in some leading oil-producing nations, could jump higher when driving season begins; Americans say they may adjust to increasingly higher prices by making fewer leisure trips, carpooling and buying or renting more energy-efficient cars but reality is that high prices seem to have had little impact on driving habits; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: U.N. Force Expands
abstract: Security Council votes to add 1,500 peacekeepers to 7,000 already in Ivory Coast as temporary help in political transition to elections in Oct (S)

headline: Ex-Stockbroker Is Sentenced For Illegal Trading in 2004
abstract: Federal District Judge Robert Sweet sentences former stockbroker Lee David Edelman to home detention and probation for trading on secret news about acquisition of Metron Technology by Applied Materials Inc; fines Edelman $22,000 (M)

headline: Chip Maker's Profit Highest Since 2000
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices, the world's second-largest maker of chips that run personal computers, posted its biggest profit in more than five years in the first quarter.      Net income was $184.5 million, or 38 cents a share, after a loss of $17.4 million, or 4 cents, a year ago, the company said yesterday. Sales gained 8.6 percent, to $1.33 billion.

headline: Communist Vietnam Lunges for Capitalism's Brass Ring
abstract: It was Lenin's birthday. The most important Communist Party meeting in five years was under way. And the star of the show was the world's most famous capitalist, Bill Gates.     The president, the prime minister and the deputy prime minister all excused themselves from the party meeting on Saturday to have their pictures taken with Mr. Gates, who has more star power in Vietnam than any of them.

headline: U.N. Reports on Syrian Role in Lebanon
abstract: Syrian intelligence chiefs told Lebanese legislators to extend the term of the pro-Syrian president, Émile Lahoud, in 2004 and warned them that failure to do so would ''put their personal security at risk,'' according to a new Security Council report.     Mr. Lahoud was to have finished his six-year term in November 2004, at a time when Syria feared diminution of its power over Lebanese politics. But two months before that, Lebanon's Parliament changed the Constitution to allow him to remain in power another three years.

headline: Sale of Univision Network Unravels as Auction Receives Only One Bid
abstract: Auction of Spanish-language broadcaster Univision continues to unravel when lone bid, submitted by group that includes investment firms Madison Dearborn Partners, Providence Equity Partners, Texas Pacific Group and Thomas H Lee Partners and media investor Haim Saban, is rejected as too low (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Hollinger Names A Chairman
abstract: Hollinger names Stanley M Beck as chairman, following resignation of Joseph H Wright; owns 17.4 percent equity stake in Hollinger International (M)

headline: Daimler Earnings Rise Despite Setbacks
abstract: Daimler-Chrysler says first-quarter earnings rose slightly, to 299 million euros ($363 million) from 288 million euros ($350 million) year ago despite heavy losses in Mercedes-Benz division; Chrysler's operating profit fell to 119 million euros ($144 million) from 252 million euros ($306 million) (M)

headline: The Martin Agency Ken Belson Wins Two Big Accounts
abstract: The Martin Agency in Richmond, Va., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has been awarded two assignments with combined spending estimated at $100 million a year.     Martin was named to handle the creative and media duties for B. F. Goodrich in Greenville, S.C., part of Michelin North America, with spending estimated at $20 million. Those duties had been handled for 16 years by Doner in Southfield, Mich.

headline: Less Can Be More When It Comes to Overseas Stocks
abstract: Paul J Lim column on how much foreign exposure an American buy-and-hold stock investor should have in his or her portfolio; graph (M)

headline: S.E.C. Asked Grasso if He Buoyed Stock
abstract: Richard A. Grasso, the former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, faced questions from federal regulators about whether he prodded traders to support the American International Group's share price while he was head of the exchange and its regulatory unit, government documents released yesterday disclosed.     During Mr. Grasso's deposition, given before the Securities and Exchange Commission in June 2005, he repeatedly invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, in spite of warnings from S.E.C. lawyers that doing so could be used against him in a civil case.

headline: Gap to Return to TV Ads, Emphasizing Back to Basics
abstract: Gap, preparing to introduce its fall clothing line in July, will resume advertising on television, again use celebrities in print marketing and, for first time, change store window displays once each month rather than once each season (M)

headline: Stocks:3M helps push Dow to fresh 6-year high
In Montenegro resort, a rift over independence
Doctors Object to Gathering of Drug Data
abstract: Although virtually unknown to consumers, the information has long been considered the most potent weapon in pharmaceutical sales -- computerized dossiers showing which physicians are prescribing what drugs. Armed with such data, a drug sales representative can pressure a doctor to write more prescriptions for a name-brand medicine or fewer orders for a competitor's drug.      But now a rebellion is under way by some doctors, who consider the data-gathering an intrusion that feeds overzealous sales practices among the nation's estimated 90,000 drug company representatives. Public officials are also weighing in. A vote on a state bill to clamp down on the practice is scheduled for today in New Hampshire, and similar bills have been introduced in other states, including Arizona and West Virginia.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: Memo Pad column; Eos Airlines, all-business discount carrier, says it is breaking even financially; Sheraton Chicago Hotel is promoting program in which guests can turn in their BlackBerries to help them kick habit; Business.com survey finds 10 percent of nearly 500 business entrepreneurs questioned report 'heavy Blackberry use' while on family vactions and another 18 percent say they are 'always working' and often need to miss family vacation activities; 67 percent of those surveyed by Airlines.ws support continuing ban on cellphone use in flight; other surveys show growing support for allowing use of cellphones for text messaging and other silent forms of communication; Assn of Corporate Travel Executives reports that more than 90 percent of chief financial executives say they are spending same or more on business travel this year compared with 2005 (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Agent 16, New York, hired four employees: Chris Caracciolo, art director on the Winston account; Ayesha Mathews, art director on the Camel account; Ceasar Saingchin, Web designer; and Matthew Schrack, also a Web designer. The Camel and Winston cigarette brands are owned by Reynolds American.     Avaya, Basking Ridge, N.J., selected MediaVest, New York, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group division of the Publicis Groupe, to handle the media planning and buying parts of its account, which had been handled by Universal McCann, New York, part of the Interpublic Media division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Avaya spends $40 million to $50 million on worldwide advertising. The shift of the media assignments came after Avaya chose offices of Saatchi & Saatchi, also part of Publicis, to handle worldwide creative assignments in areas like advertising, direct marketing and promotions.

headline: Pact is seen in German strike talks
Euronext Turns Down Offer From German Exchange
abstract: Euronext shareholders reject proposal to merge with Deutsche Borse in hopes of igniting bidding war with NYSE Group that could reshape business of trading in Europe and US; photo (M)

headline: SMITH AND WOW!
abstract: Smoth & Wollensky Restaurant Group discloses new contract under which founder and longtime chairman and chief executive Alan Stillman could remain on payroll for another decade; company has made him beneficiary of one-fifth of $5 million insurance policy it holds on his life (S)

headline: Treasury Bills Set for This Week
abstract: The schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.     At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.81 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 5 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 4.61 percent.

headline: Gold Keeps Moving Higher, and the Dow Does the Same
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average hits six-year high, rising 55.23 points, to 11,639.77; Standard & Poors 500-stock index adds 0.48 point, to 1,325.14; Nasdaq composite index drops 6.74 points, to 2,338.25; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; graph; chart (M)

headline: Workers' Paradise Is Rebranded as Kremlin Inc.
abstract: Here in the Caucasus, above Sochi, Russia's only subtropical city, an elite ski resort is rising beside the Layura River. The resort, a multimillion-dollar project with a hotel and conference center, cottages, six lifts and miles of trails, is a centerpiece of Sochi's improbable bid for the Winter Olympic Games of 2014.     Even more improbable is the project's developer: Russia's state gas monopoly, Gazprom.

headline: Bombs Strike Revered Indian Mosque and City in Kashmir
abstract: Pair of homemade bombs explode in courtyard of New Delhi's most important mosque, 17th-century Jama Masjid, injuring 13 worshipers; bombing coincides with incident in Kashmir, where grenade attacks kill 5 civilians and injure 17 people, including members of Indian parliamentary forces; photo (M)

headline: Flood in Iraq flips U.S. truck, killing 5
European Bank Raises Rate but Doesn't Signal Future Moves
abstract: European Central Bank raises benchmark interest rate by 0.25 percent, to 2.75 percent, but avoids saying it will sharply tighten credit to control inflation; bank president Jean-Claude Trichet says bank will continue to increase borrowing costs gradually; bank predicts euro-zone economy will grow from 1.8 percent to 2.4 percent this year and 1.3 percent to 2.3 percent in 2007; central banks in South Africa, India, Denmark and South Korea all increase their interest rates, after Turkey day before; photo (M)

headline: Yahoo Profit Falls 22%; Ad Sales Up
abstract: Yahoo reported a 22 percent decline in first-quarter profit on Tuesday but met Wall Street's earnings forecast, helped by solid growth in advertising sales.     As a result, Yahoo's shares rose $1.92, or 6.1 percent, in after-hours trading, after closing up 33 cents, at $31.30, in the regular session.

headline: Discord at European Court Handling Microsoft's Antitrust Case
abstract: Discord among judges on Court of First Instance, European Union's second-highest tribunal, has some lawyers saying court's emergence as check on overzealous European Union officials was long overdue while others are worrying that regulators have become afraid to do their jobs aggressively; panel is hearing Microsoft's appeal of antitrust ruling; photo (M)

headline: That Hedge Fund May Be More Than a Flash in the Pan
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies on National Bureau of Economic Research study that concludes many hedge funds are surprisingly persistent in their performance from one period to next; graph (M)

headline: M.S. Drug Can Return, With Limits
abstract: Federal regulators agreed yesterday to let the multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri return to the market, despite its risk of causing a fatal brain disease, under a program intended to closely monitor doctors who prescribe it and patients who use it.      The drug was withdrawn early last year after only three months on the market, after its risks became evident, but a federal advisory panel recommended this past March that Tysabri be returned to the market. At that meeting, in sometimes tearful testimony, about two dozen people with multiple sclerosis told the committee they were willing to accept the risks of the drug because they viewed Tysabri as the best hope for slowing the progression of their debilitating disease. Tysabri's makers estimate that there may be as many as 150,000 multiple sclerosis patients in this country for whom other drugs are not effective.

headline: Iranian Leader Sees No Need for Talks With U.S.
abstract: Mahmoud Ahmedinejad said talks with the U.S. on Iraq were not necessary now that a government was set up.

headline: Professor, Just Speak Into the Screen, Please
abstract: Belkin TuneTalk connects to video iPod to turn it into audio recorder; $70 device records in 16-bit stereo for CD-quality playback through music player's headphones; photo (M)

headline: Putin Nominee for Prosecutor Draws Praise From All Sides
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.     TODAY'S TOP STORY

headline: Citing a Legal Snarl, Official at Deutsche Bank Resigns
abstract: Unable to shake a long-running legal dispute with a former client of his bank, the supervisory board chairman of Deutsche Bank, Rolf E. Breuer, resigned on Sunday, saying he wanted to ''relieve Deutsche Bank of further discussion'' of his case.     Mr. Breuer, 68, has been under a legal cloud since early 2002, when he publicly questioned the creditworthiness of the German media mogul Leo Kirch in a television interview. Mr. Kirch sued Mr. Breuer, accusing him of precipitating the financial collapse of his empire.

headline: Diplomats Push Iran to Reply Soon to Incentives Offer
abstract: Diplomats from the world's richest countries said Thursday that they expected to receive a ''clear and substantive'' response from Iran by next Wednesday to the package of incentives offered by major powers in exchange for suspending its activities relating to enrichment of uranium.     The statement from the foreign ministers of the Group of 8 industrialized countries was the first reference to an explicit deadline for Iran to respond formally. ''We are disappointed in the absence of an official Iranian response to this positive proposal,'' their statement said.

headline: Italian National Election Remains Too Close to Call
abstract: Italian election pitting Silvio Berlusconi against Romano Prodi remains too close to call; early voter surveys show winner is Prodi, who has claimed victory; photos (M)

headline: An Agency's Worst Nightmare: Ads Created by Users
abstract: Advertisers are increasingly experimenting with user-generated content to market their products in effort to remain relevant to consumers; Sony uses animated spot created by 19-year old Tyson Ibele for Current TV cable network; trend is catching on in industry, causing some concern for agencies; photo (M)

headline: Energy on the Agenda as Putin Meets With European Leaders
abstract: A summary of the top stories in Russian newspapers appears Monday through Friday.     TODAY'S TOP STORIES

headline: Patent Awarded to RealNetworks May Give It a Competitive Edge
abstract: RealNetworks has received a patent on a way to stream multimedia content over the Internet, and the company said last week that it believed the patent would give it leverage as companies rapidly expand their efforts to turn the Internet into a broadcast medium.      RealNetworks competes against Apple, Adobe, Microsoft and other companies in developing and selling software to media businesses that use the Internet to broadcast audio and video. The patent could allow the company to demand royalty payments from those competitors or from media companies.

headline: Video Appears to Show Zarqawi
abstract: Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq has never before appeared delivering a speech in an Internet video.

headline: Atop Hedge Funds, Richest of the Rich Get Even More So
abstract: Talk about minting money. In 2001 and 2002, hedge fund managers had to make $30 million to gain entry to a survey of the best paid in hedge funds that is closely followed by people in the business. In 2004, the threshold had soared to $100 million.     Last year, managers had to take home -- yes, take home -- $130 million to make it into the ranks of the top 25. And there was a tie for 25th place, so there were actually 26 hedge fund managers who made $130 million or more.

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: Merger of FPL and Constellation Threatened By Dispute in Maryland Over Utility Rates  Executives of the FPL Group and the Constellation Energy Group said their planned merger could fail as a result of Constellation's regulatory problems in Maryland. In letters to shareholders, the chief executives of both companies said Constellation's dispute with Maryland legislators over a proposed rate increase poses serious implications for the deal. Later yesterday, however, Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. of Maryland was more optimistic about a possible settlement of the dispute, a spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, Shareese DeLeaver, said the governor met with the Senate president and the speaker of the House of Delegates and made progress toward a resolution. FPL, which is based in Juno Beach, Fla., agreed to acquire Constellation, based in Baltimore, in December in a deal then valued at about $11 billion. (REUTERS)    Ford Motor Cuts the Pay of Its Chief Executive  The Ford Motor Company cut the pay of its chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., for last year 40 percent, to $13.3 million, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing. Mr. Ford, 48, takes most of his compensation in stock options and restricted shares. He got options to buy 1.69 million shares, valued at $7.5 million on the grant date, the company said. He also got $5.33 million of restricted stock and other compensation of $466,755. His total pay in 2004 was $22.2 million. Mr. Ford told shareholders last May he would ''forgo any compensation at all'' until the company's automotive operations achieved ''sustainable profitability.'' He will donate any final award to charity when those equivalents convert to shares after a year, according to a filing in March. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Successful Surgery for Enron Executive's Lawyer  The lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, the founder of the Enron Corporation, had a stent implanted in his carotid artery to relieve blockage yesterday and was expected to make a full recovery, his doctor said in a statement. Whether the lawyer, Michael W. Ramsey, 66, will be able to return to Mr. Lay's federal fraud and conspiracy trial before it concludes is unclear. Mr. Ramsey, above, was absent from the trial this week to undergo medical tests leading up to the stent implantation yesterday. He had one placed in a coronary artery on March 24, but doctors found the carotid artery blockage this week. Mr. Lay's co-defendant, the former chief executive Jeffrey K. Skilling, is expected to begin testimony on Monday in the 11th week of the case. Mr. Lay intends to testify at a later date. (AP)    Time Warner Cuts 250 Publishing Division Jobs  Time Warner cut 250 jobs in its publishing division yesterday as part of an effort to lower costs. The company's Time Inc. unit reduced jobs in advertising sales, production, marketing and public relations, a spokeswoman, Ali Zelenko, said. The company is still hiring at its Internet business. The job cuts ''cover the vast majority of job eliminations for the foreseeable future,'' Ms. Zelenko said. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Tyson Foods to Reduce Production for One Day  Tyson Foods, the meat producer, said yesterday that it would reduce production for one day on Monday in response to poor market conditions and to concerns that a nationwide immigration rally set for that day could affect attendance by its Hispanic workers. The meat industry relies heavily on immigrant workers to operate its plants, and a large percentage of those workers are Hispanic. (REUTERS)    Cablevision Declares Special Cash Dividend  The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the New York cable television provider, declared a special cash dividend of $10 a share. The dividend is payable on April 24 to shareholders as of April 18, the company said yesterday. The approval by Cablevision's board is a victory for the chairman, Charles F. Dolan, and his son, the chief executive, James L. Dolan, who were trying for a second time to make a cash payout to shareholders. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

headline: Canada Issues Arrest Warrants for 7 in Land Dispute
abstract: The Canadian police have issued arrest warrants for seven people involved in an Indian land-claim dispute, accusing them of involvement in several violent episodes on Friday, including the hijacking of a United States Border Patrol vehicle.     Five of the people being sought were identified by the Ontario Provincial Police as residents of the Six Nations Reserve near Caledonia, Ontario. Since February, some of reserve's residents have been occupying a construction site that the Indian group contends is on its land. One person being sought is from British Columbia, and it was unclear where the seventh person lives.

headline: Shares Fall Sharply Early, but Finish With Some Gains
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average adds 7.92 points, to 10,938.82; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 0.14 percent, to 1,257.93; Nasdaq composite index closes at 2,145.32; price and yield of 10-year US Treasury note noted; graphs (M)

headline: ABC Rejects Dual Anchors in 2nd Shuffle
abstract: Less than six months after naming Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff over Charles Gibson as the successors to the late Peter Jennings on ''World News Tonight'' on ABC, the network announced yesterday that it was scrapping its dual-host experiment and installing Mr. Gibson as the sole anchor.     ABC's move comes after Mr. Woodruff was seriously injured by a roadside bomb in Iraq in late January, sustaining head wounds that have since kept him from appearing on television, and after Ms. Vargas announced in February that she was due to give birth to her second child in mid-August.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: 3 Bodies Found In U.N. Plane Wreckage
abstract: Rescue team finds remains of three people aboard UN-chartered plane that crashed in Uganda; plane was transporting relief supplies to Congo (S)

headline: Deal Stirrings Help to Lift Tribune Stock
abstract: The Tribune Company says it is sticking to a stock buyback plan, but investors yesterday reacted as if the company might be in play.     Shares of Tribune rose 4 percent on speculation about the company's future after the Chandler family -- its second-largest shareholder -- made public its dissent to the buyback plan.

headline: U.S. Indictment for Big Law Firm in Class Actions
abstract: The nation's leading class-action securities law firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, and two of its partners were charged yesterday with making more than $11 million in secret payments to three individuals who served as plaintiffs in more than 150 lawsuits.     The indictment is the first instance of a law firm with national reach facing criminal charges, and it could prove to be a fatal blow for the firm. The lawsuits cited in the indictment spanned two decades, occurring as recently as 2005, and generated some $216 million in legal fees for the firm.

headline: Russian Officials Say Arrests End Gang Accused of Racial Killings
abstract: The authorities in St. Petersburg announced Wednesday that they had broken up an extremist group that had shocked Russia with a string of racially motivated killings, including that of an African student in April and of an expert on hate crimes nearly two years ago.     The authorities said they recently arrested five members of the loosely organized group. Two others appeared to have been arrested earlier on separate charges, while an eighth was shot to death as the police tried to arrest him last Thursday. The police seized weapons, explosives and neo-Nazi and other extremist literature in raids of the gang members' apartments, the authorities said.

headline: The Pulitzer, Now a Badge of Controversy
abstract: THE Bush administration has been characterized as relentlessly pro-business, but that all depends on what business you are in.      Those involved in the journalism industry would never confuse the president for a friend. Last week, the long-running custody battle over state secrets, leaks and sources between the administration and the press broke out into public view, with each day bringing a new wrinkle to the deepening conflict. How secret should secrets be? Perhaps it depends on the secret.

headline: When It Comes to Meat, 'Natural' Is a Vague Term
abstract: Agriculture Department lenient requirements specify only that products labeled 'natural' be 'minimally processed' and lack artificial ingredients; requirements say nothing about conditions in which animals lived or how they were fed; graph (M)

headline: Job Growth and Wages Were Weak Last Month
abstract: Labor Department reports unemployment rate dropped to 4.6 percent in May, nearly five-year low; says employers added 75,000 jobs; report, much weaker than analysts expected, prompts new concerns about unexpected economic downturn; graphs (M)

headline: Quake Causes Tsunami Alert, but No Damage
abstract: Two weeks before a scheduled test of a warning system for tsunamis around the Pacific basin, a magnitude-7.9 earthquake yesterday off the islands of Tonga provided a more urgent, unscheduled test, briefly causing tsunami fears from New Zealand to Hawaii.     Tidal gauges recorded a tsunami resulting from the earthquake, but the peak-to-trough height was only about 17 inches, not large enough to cause damage. No deaths were reported from the earthquake.

headline: Delta Shifts Creative Work To Shepardson Stern
abstract: Katharine Seelye Advertising column; New York Times, Tribune and McClatchy newspaper companies, citing stagnant advertising and continuing rise in newsprint costs, report sharply lower first-quarter earnings; New York Times says profit declined 69 percent, to $35 million, down from $111 million in first quarter last year; says total revenue rose 3.3 percent, to $832 million, with Internet businesses now accounting for $62 million, or 7.5 percent of all revenue; announces plans to sell its 50 percent stake in Discovery Times Channel back to Discovery Communications and to invest further in video for newspaper's Web site; Tribune Co says first-quarter earnings fell 28 percent and income declined to $103 million from $143 million year earlier; says overall revenue declined 1.3 percent, to $1.3 billion; McClatchy says net income fell to $27.7 million, compared with $32.3 million year before; reports slight rise in first-quarter revenue, to $282 million; photo (M)

headline: Online Newspaper Ads Gaining Ground on Print
abstract: Julie Bosman Advertising column on estimates from Newspaper Assn of America indicating that newspaper print ad spending in first quarter increased only 0.3 percent, to $10.5 billion, while spending for online advertising surged 35 percent, to $613 million, from year earlier; opportunities for growth, in addition to classified ads, include interactive ads, wallpaper ads and ads with streaming video or audio (M)

headline: At CNN, News That Plays to the Ratings
abstract: ''The news is the star.''  -- Ted Turner, founder of CNN         AFTER dumping the yelling heads of ''Crossfire'' at the beginning of last year, Jonathan Klein, president of CNN's domestic operations, said that the original cable news network was doubling down on straight reporting.      ''We are not about fomenting an agenda,'' he said.

headline: A Mind-Blowing Conference, Now on Video
abstract: A few months back, I wrote about the mind-blowing, perspective-altering four days I spent at TED (Technology * Entertainment * Design) in February. It's a conference that features fifty prominent speakers.     As I wrote at the time: "It's four days of talks, each no longer than 18 minutes. The speakers are either famous, pioneers in their industries or just fascinating people--and often all three...They addressed climate crisis, the depletion of fossil fuels, African AIDS, third-world poverty, human-rights violations, the spiral of West-Islamic global hatred, lethal viruses, and other cheery subjects...The organizer of TED makes no bones about the fact that he wants this astonishing network of speakers and audience members to throw their expertise, brainpower and connections behind efforts to address the world's problems."

headline: With Big Boost From Sugar Cane, Brazil Is Satisfying Its Fuel Needs
abstract: At the dawn of the automobile age, Henry Ford predicted that ''ethyl alcohol is the fuel of the future.'' With petroleum about $65 a barrel, President Bush has now embraced that view, too. But Brazil is already there.     This country expects to become energy self-sufficient this year, meeting its growing demand for fuel by increasing production from petroleum and ethanol. Already the use of ethanol, derived in Brazil from sugar cane, is so widespread that some gas stations have two sets of pumps, marked A for alcohol and G for gas.

headline: Police fight rioting mobs in Egypt
May's Treo Leapfrogs Past January's
abstract: THE electronics industry operates like a very expensive game of leapfrog. You buy something in April, and then a newer, faster, less expensive version comes out in May. Rats!     On the other hand, you might get lucky; you might not buy in until the better version comes along. There you sit on the train, on the plane or at the baseball field, smugly looking over at the poor saps who bought last month's phone, music player or camera.

headline: EU aid sought for poultry 'crisis' - Business - International Herald Tribune
Palestinians Hit Home in Sederot
abstract: A Palestinian rocket slammed into a residential area in southern Israel early Wednesday, hitting a house about 100 yards from the home of Israel's defense minister, Amir Peretz.     No one was hurt, but the rocket damaged the house in Sederot, a working-class town that is most often the target of the Palestinian fire from the northern Gaza Strip.

headline: Here's a New Idea: A Fund Cuts Its Fees
abstract: Here's a New I

headline: One in four €500 bills are in Spain. Why? Crime might be the answer
Nortel to Cut 1,100 Jobs As It Tries For Comeback
abstract: Nortel Networks, continuing struggle to restore financial health, says it will cut 1,100 jobs across US while creating 800 jobs, mostly at new, lower-cost operations in Mexico and Turkey; says cuts will include 350 middle management positions and changes will be made in pension and health benefits (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,323 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:    PADILLAALEMAN, Geovani, 20, Hospitalman, Navy; South Gate, Calif.; Bethesda Naval Hospital, USNS Comfort Detachment.

headline: Washington Post Has an Exit Jam After Buyouts
abstract: Washington Post business news section, which is losing nine people as part of buyouts of 70 reporters, editors and others over next few months, produces one big good-bye cake and faux honorary front pages for five of those who are leaving this month; other four, who are leaving later, will receive their pages later (M)

headline: Netflix, Thy Name Is Customer Service
abstract: When I reviewed DVD-by-mail services awhile back, I pointed out that Netflix is the service, speed and selection king. Blockbuster's DVD-by-mail service took second place in every category but one: value. The mail service cost much the same as Netflix--but included coupons for two *additional* free rentals each month at one of Blockbuster's physical stores. (The plans have changed slightly--in fact, most of Blockbuster's DVD-by-mail plans include *four* free in-store rentals a month now.)     Convinced by my own logic, I actually switched my own membership to Blockbuster. Although the service was soundly maligned by members at the time (March 2005), I was swayed by those free in-store coupons. We have three kids, and sometimes things just come up. Some event gets rained out, one of us has a hard day, or whatever; sometimes, it's nice to just dash over to the video store spontaneously (ours is only five minutes away) to pick up a DVD instead of ordering it via mail. We've really gotten incredible mileage out of these free coupons--and Blockbuster's service, speed and selection have closed a huge amount of its gap with Netflix.But I have to tell you a Netflix customer-service story that made my mind boggle.

headline: After Quick Start in January, Spending Cooled in February
abstract: Commerce Department reports personal spending rose 0.1 percent in February after showing markedly higher gains in prior three months; spending on durable goods fell 1.9 percent in February; University of Michigan reports consumer confidence index rose to 88.9 in March, up slightly from February but below 91.2 reading in January; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Russia covets China nuclear deals
If One Zoom Lens Is Good, Kodak Hopes That 2 Are Even Better
abstract: $450 EasyShare V610 camera from Kodak has two built-in side-by-side lenses to satisfy buyers' demands for slimmer models and more advanced zoom capabilities; photo (M)

headline: No more bread and circuses
U.S. Questions China on Arms Buildup
abstract: China's leadership has not satisfactorily explained its military expansion and goals, even as it modernizes its forces to be able to challenge foreign armed forces operating in the region, the Defense Department said in a report released Tuesday.     ''China's leaders have yet to adequately explain the purposes or desired end-states of their military expansion,'' according to the 2006 report, ''Military Power of the People's Republic of China.'' ''Estimates place Chinese defense expenditure at two to three times officially disclosed figures.''

headline: Vonage Moves to Reassure Nervous Investors
abstract: Vonage says it will reimburse bankers who handled initial public offering if any customers refuse to pay for shares allotted to them; some customers were reluctant to pay in direct share program after stock lost more than 26 percent (M)

headline: Teacher Strike May Influence Mexican Vote
abstract: What started as a teachers' strike here five weeks ago has grown into a major movement to oust the governor of Oaxaca State that could affect the presidential election on July 2.     Last week began with strikers battling the police and ended with failed talks with a federal mediator. Tens of thousands of teachers still occupy the central square and the surrounding streets of this colonial town of 265,000, a cultural center and tourist attraction known for its artists and haunting pre-Columbian ruins.

headline: What if They Built an Urban Wireless Network and Hardly Anyone Used It?
abstract: Peter Shyu, an engineer, spends most of his day out of the office, and when he needs an Internet connection he often pops into one of the many coffee shops in this city that offer free wireless access.      He could use WiFly, the extensive wireless network commissioned by the city government that is the cornerstone of Taipei's ambitious plan to turn itself into an international technology hub. But that would cost him $12.50 a month.

headline: Chinese dash hopes for researcher's release
Peru: Fujimori Freed on Bail in Chile
abstract: Saying he did not represent a threat to society, Chile's Supreme Court freed former President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru on bail of $2,800 but barred him from leaving Chile until it ruled on whether he could be extradited to Peru, where he is wanted on more than a dozen counts of corruption and violating human rights. Peruvian officials say he will be a flight risk. Mr. Fujimori was arrested in Santiago last November, after declaring himself a candidate in Peru's presidential election and arriving unexpectedly from Japan, where he had lived since fleeing Peru amid a corruption scandal in 2000 and resigning his office. Smiling as he left the prison in Santiago, Mr. Fujimori, 67, quickly set off for the wealthy Santiago suburb of Las Condes, where his children have rented a house.   PASCALE BONNEFOY (NYT)

headline: Bomb Explodes Near Shiite Shrine in Iraq
abstract: A car bomb ripped through a crowd of worshippers, killing at least 10 people.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: NTL Agrees to Buy Virgin Mobile
abstract: NTL agrees to buy Virgin Mobile Holdings, controlled by Richard Branson, for 962 million pounds ($1.67 billion) (S)

headline: A Single Trial for 18 Named in Tax Shelters
abstract: A federal judge declined yesterday to grant separate trials for 18 people charged in the sale of questionable tax shelters, affirming that they must stand trial together this fall.     The judge, Lewis A. Kaplan, in United States District Court in Manhattan, rejected motions by lawyers for some of the defendants to be tried separately in California and Texas, where they worked for the accounting firm KPMG, or to have their cases dismissed.

headline: British Filmmaker's Death in Gaza Continues to Resound
abstract: British government has taken up cause of James Miller, documentary filmmaker who was shot to death in Gaza in 2003; his family blames Israeli military, which denies responsibility; photo (M)

headline: Following suit: More drugs coming under legal attack
Zen on Hot Asphalt for a Biker on Business
abstract: Alton Brown, in Frequent Traveler column, discusses his preference for taking his motorcycle on business trips instead of flying; photo (M)

headline: Timeline: Key dates in EU antitrust action against Microsoft
A Big Question Unanswered by a Tiny PC
abstract: ACCORDING to legend, they teach you in journalism school to remember the five W's: who, what, when, where and why.     This week, Microsoft unveiled a new kind of computer called the Ultra Mobile PC -- and has good answers to four of those questions.

headline: Citigroup Punishment Ends
abstract: Federal Reserve Board releases Citigroup from enforcement action taken two years ago for violating law on deceptive lending practices; bank was fined $70 million and cited for weak controls and lying to banking regulators in May 2004 (S)

headline: The Scent of a Co-Worker
abstract: Matt Villano Career Couch column on how to tactfully tell co-worker that he or she has unpleasant odor; drawing (M)

headline: Why Can't I Have Just the Cable Channels I Want?
abstract: Richard Siklos Media Frenzy column on question of why cable operators are unwilling to package channels separately; cable operators say current practice of selling package of 75 or so broadcast and cable channels is better for consumers and public good and a la carte model would lead to higher rates for individual channels; recent USA Today/CNN/Gallup poll found that 54 percent of TV viewers would prefer to buy channels individually; drawing (M)

headline: Asian Officials Call Bausch Slow to React
abstract: When Bausch & Lomb recalled a contact lens cleaner from markets worldwide last Monday, the company explained that it had finally, after months of sleuthing, found a link between the product and a potentially blinding eye infection.     But to the health authorities in Singapore, that seemed tardy at best. Three months ago, they had established a strong statistical connection between Bausch & Lomb's ReNu With MoistureLoc cleaner and Fusarium eye fungus infections.

headline: Prosecutor in Hussein Trial Calls for the Death Penalty
abstract: Saddam Hussein uttered only two laconic words -- ''Well done!'' -- on Monday as the chief prosecutor at his trial demanded that Mr. Hussein and three top associates be given the death penalty for their role in the persecution of a mainly Shiite town after an assassination attempt Mr. Hussein said was made against him there in 1982.     Mr. Hussein's riposte echoed his attitude throughout the eight-month trial, at which he has frequently said that the outcome has been predetermined by American and Iraqi officials. During the trial, the 69-year-old former Iraqi ruler has said several times that he expected the death penalty, that the prospect held no fears for him and that, in any case, he has ''escaped death'' so often that he expected to do so again.

headline: Industrial Output Picks Up; Capacity Use at 5-Year High
abstract: Production at factories, mines and utilities grew at faster pace in March than in February; manufacturers were busiest in over five years; production increased 0.6 percent; share of industrial capacity rose to 81.3 percent; electric and gas utility output rose 0.5 percent last month; mine production increased 0.9 percentage in March after falling 0.7 percent; graphs (M)

headline: To Counter the Doldrums During Summer Reruns, 'Lost' Fans Can Get Lost in a Game Online
abstract: ABC's hit show ''Lost'' will end its second season on May 24 with a two-hour season finale. But plans to keep ardent fans happy during the summer reruns are under way.      The Lost Experience, an interactive, multiplatform game, will begin in early May and echo the story of the TV show, which follows a group of people whose airplane crashes on an enchanted island full of supernatural mysteries and threats.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: CONTROLLING THE PURSE STRINGS To its critics, the compensation committee of the Home Depot board exemplifies the close personal and professional ties among board members and executives at many companies -- ties that can make it harder to restrain executive pay. [Page A1.]    ABC NAMES NEWS ANCHOR Less than six months after ABC named Elizabeth Vargas and Bob Woodruff as successors to the late Peter Jennings on ''World News Tonight,'' the network announced that it was scrapping its dual-host experiment and installing Charles Gibson as the sole anchor. [A1.]    'LAPSE OF JUDGMENT' Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, publicly conceded a ''lapse in judgment'' in telling a television reporter at a Washington banquet last month that investors had ''misunderstood'' him. When reported, Mr. Bernanke's remarks touched off a brief furor among traders. [C1.]    DOGFIGHT OVER PLANE The C-17 Globemaster III cargo jet, a $200 million flying giant, is at the center of a war involving the White House, Pentagon, Boeing and lobbyists. They are battling over whether the military needs more C-17's at a time when resources are being squeezed. [C1.]    EURONEXT BIDDING Shareholders of the Euronext exchange rejected a proposal to merge with Deutsche Börse of Germany. But Euronext's chief executive, Jean-François Théodore, left, who favors a proposed tie-up with the NYSE Group, owner of the New York Stock Exchange, insisted that the German exchange was not out of the picture -- a strategy possibly aimed at spurring the American group to raise its bid. [C3.]    NEWSPAPER DEAL The McClatchy Company announced it had agreed to sell The Philadelphia Inquirer and its sister paper, The Daily News, to a group of local business executives and investors for $562 million. [C1.]    NURSE SHORTAGE As the United States runs short of nurses, senators are looking abroad. They included a little-noticed provision in their immigration bill that would throw open the gate and, some fear, drain nurses from developing countries. [A1.]    FANNIE MAE REPORT In a blistering report, federal regulators said they had found that financial results at Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of mortgages, were ''illusions'' created by its top executives in an $11 billion accounting scandal. The company agreed to pay $400 million in a settlement. [C1.]    OIL PRICES WEIGH ON MARKET Wall Street closed moderately lower after worries about the impact of high oil prices on the economy set off a late-day drop. At the close, the Dow lost 26.98 points, or 0.24 percent, to 11,098.35. [C10.]    CLOSING ARGUMENTS IN ENRON CASE Prosecutors gave closing arguments in a second trial involving Kenneth L. Lay, the former Enron chief executive, in which he faces four charges of fraud and lying to banks. The jury in the first and bigger case deliberated for a fourth day. [C3.]    DATA THEFT The Department of Veterans Affairs learned about the theft of electronic data on about 26.5 million veterans shortly after it occurred, on May 3, but waited some two weeks before telling law enforcement agencies, government officials said. [A22.]    UPDATE ON NEW WINDOWS Microsoft said Vista, the much-delayed new version of its Windows operating system, was ready for its last and broadest round of testing. [C4.]    DELL TO TEST STORES Dell, which built its business selling PC's and other electronics directly to customers by phone and online, has decided to try something new: a storefront. Dell said it would open two mall stores this summer as a test. [C9.]    HOME BUILDER REPORTS The luxury-home builder Toll Brothers reported a 3 percent increase in quarterly income, to $174.9 million, but said higher costs for materials and labor, as well as steeper write-downs, would reduce earnings for the year. [C3.]    SMART SHOES Nike said it was making running shoes that will be able to send data about the wearer's performance to an Apple iPod. [C4.]    ONLINE    THE TREO David Pogue says the Treo 700P smartphone is the Windows Treo without the Windows, and it's almost everything a user could wish it to be. A review is at nytimes.com/technology    TINY SCREENS, BIG DREAMS Media companies are racing to develop the first big hit in games and other original programming for cellphones. A report is at nytimes.com/technology    ONLINE, DEALBOOK: A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    The H.J. Heinz Company has received a proposed growth strategy from shareholders led by the billionaire investor Nelson Peltz, who has sought to pressure the company into increasing its returns. The plan calls for Heinz to cut costs by $575 million a year and reduce deals, allowances and other incentives to retailers by at least $300 million. (AP)    The Borders Group Inc. posted a loss that was bigger than Wall Street expected, hurt by weak sales in the Britain and at its domestic mall-based Waldenbooks stores. (REUTERS)    Medtronic, the medical device maker reported that quarterly earnings more than tripled from the quarter a year earlier. (AP)

headline: Areva leader likes chances for China deal
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,388 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    BANDONILL, Metodio A., 29, Staff Sgt., Army; Honolulu; 101st Airborne Division.    HENRY, Raymond L., 21, Pfc., Army; Anaheim, Calif.; First Battalion, 17th Infantry, 172nd Stryker Brigade Combat Team.    HERREMA, Richard J., 27, Sgt. First Class, Army; Jackson, Tenn.; Special Operations Command.

headline: A Seasoned Executive With His Own Views
abstract: With the stock market showing signs of weakness, the administration has reached out to Henry M. Paulson Jr. to bring calm. But in some ways, he is an executive in the mold of Paul H. O'Neill, a Treasury secretary who was forced out by a White House that could not accept his contrarian tendencies. Like Mr. O'Neill, he has strong views on economic policies that support balanced budgets, which may not be consistent with administration policies.    BY LANDON THOMAS Jr., PAGE C1

headline: Renovating With Profit in Mind? It Just Might Not Pay
abstract: Damon Darlin Your Money column questions soundness of doing major or even minor renovations to homes in order to increase profit; annual Cost vs Value Report in construction trade magazine Remodeling shows just how few projects yield positive rate of return; photos (M)

headline: Recording TV on DVD to Go
abstract: Recording TV On DVD to Go    Q. Can television shows recorded onto a disc with a DVD recorder play on other DVD players, or just on the one that recorded the shows?    A. Watching a home-recorded disc on a different DVD player should work, if you use one of the more common DVD formats and prepare the disc properly when you're done recording. A few older DVD players cannot read homemade discs, however, and will give you a disc-error message if you try to play them.

headline: Russia Oligarch Sent to Solitary After Being Cut
abstract: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the jailed Russian oil oligarch who was recently slashed in the face, has been put into solitary confinement in a Siberian penal camp, Russia's federal prison authorities announced on Tuesday.     Mr. Khodorkovsky, whose nose was stitched up last week after he was cut with a knife by a fellow inmate, was placed in the confinement cell for his own protection, a senior prison official said.

headline: Phelps Dodge Announces Deal to Buy 2 Big Nickel Miners
abstract: Phelps Dodge, the world's largest copper producer, said today that it had agreed to acquire two of the biggest nickel miners in a huge deal worth $40 billion. The deal, for Inco and Falconbridge, would create a mining behemoth that will reshape the industry as commodity prices continue to soar.      The deal comes a day after steel giant Arcelor agreed to merge with Mittal Steel in a $33.5 billion deal. Mining and other commodity-related companies are increasingly seeking to merge to take advantage of the enormous economies of scale involved in the mining and processing of metals. Steel and nickel producers have become particular attractive in the past year as China's appetite for the metals has grown exponentially.

headline: Accounts
abstract: MSNBC.com, Redmond, Wash., a joint venture of Microsoft and the NBC Universal unit of General Electric, named offices of Shepardson Stern & Kaminsky to handle its account, which has had no agency of record since 2000. Spending was estimated at $7 million.

headline: Japan Turns Against a Corporate Raider of Its Own
abstract: When Yoshiaki Murakami, Japan's first homegrown corporate raider, faced certain arrest for insider trading earlier this week, he did something very un-Japanese: he held a nationally televised news conference.     Wearing a somber gray suit and blue tie, his voice rising almost to a nervous squeal, Mr. Murakami, 46, at first apologized for breaking the law, bowing deeply in remorse. But he spent most of his time disputing the prosecutors' allegations, albeit in a low-key, often indirect way acceptable in a society that frowns on open displays of defiance.

headline: A Tangle in Caracas for Exxon
abstract: Tensions build in Caracas after Venezuelan Energy Min Rafael Ramirez essentially tells Exxon that it is no longer welcome in country; statement follows Venezuelan Congress's approval of measures to give government control of 32 privately run fields and Exxon decides to sell its stake in field to Repsol of Spain rather than submit to venture controlled by Petroleos de Venezuela (M)

headline: Hopes fade for ending the carnage in Darfur
As Magazine Readers Increasingly Turn to the Web, So Does Condé Nast
abstract: Getting married and wondering how you would look in a mermaid-style sheath? Brides.com, a new Web site, takes you to a virtual fitting room, lets you pick from one of four body types and examine how each would look in six different styles of gowns.      Brides.com, an upgraded bridal site combining content from three different magazines, comes from Condé Nast, which, like many magazine publishers, is trying to build its Web presence to keep up with a generation of readers who automatically turn to the Internet instead of the printed page.

headline: Australian Leaders Questioned in Oil for Food Probe
abstract: The investigation escalated dramatically today, with the appearance at the hearings of the deputy prime minister and a senior intelligence official.

headline: Paulson to Sell His Goldman Shares
abstract: Goldman Sachs chief executive Henry Paulson, nominee for Treasury secretary, will sell his 3.23 million shares in Goldman, worth about $485 million, as part of agreement with Office of Government Ethics; also agrees to sell some investment funds and exercise and sell all of his options, including those that were not previously vested (S)

headline: British Police Stage Raids, Netting 8 Terror Suspects
abstract: Eight people suspected of plotting terrorist attacks abroad were being held Wednesday after an elaborate series of raids across England that involved 500 police officers, the authorities said.      The eight, who were detained in Manchester, Liverpool and London, were held under various government powers, the authorities said. Those powers included antiterrorism and immigration laws that allow the home secretary to deport foreigners whose presence in the country ''is not conducive to the public good for reasons of national security.''

headline: Business wary of Prodi's image
Harlem Is Rising, but Where to Eat?
abstract: Article explores reasons for dearth of restaurants in Harlem despite neighborhood's renaissance; 2006 Zagat guide lists only 18 restaurants and New York magazine's online restaurant listing shows only 27 within 47-block neighborhood; restaurant consultant Michael Whiteman attributes scarcity to relative lack of high-density office buildings and of tourism; additional challenges are unusually high rents and New York State law that prohibits restaurants from serving alcohol within 200 feet of school or place of worship; some sections of Harlem have church on nearly every block; photos (M)

headline: Finding Happiness in the Pursuit
abstract: M P Dunleavey column on research conducted by Sorbonne economics Prof Claudia Senik which examined impact of anticipating future gains on person's current level of well-being; Senik found that when people aspire to better quality of life within 12 months, attempt to reach goal alone--anticipation independent of outcome--seems to bestow happiness in present (M)

headline: Ancient text amends the Jesus-Judas story
Big Gain for Rich Seen in Tax Cuts for Investments
abstract: The first data to document the effect of President Bush's tax cuts for investment income show that they have significantly lowered the tax burden on the richest Americans, reducing taxes on incomes of more than $10 million by an average of about $500,000.     An analysis of Internal Revenue Service data by The New York Times found that the benefit of the lower taxes on investments was far more concentrated on the very wealthiest Americans than the benefits of Mr. Bush's two previous tax cuts: on wages and other noninvestment income.

headline: A Pocket Pharmacist to Take on the Road
abstract: Excalibur Electronics introduces Rx Master, pocket-size device that can remind you when medicine doses are due, keep track of what you have taken and carry pills in four-compartment drawer; photo (S)

headline: Spotlight: A Western oilman nurtures relationships in Russia
Ukraine's Likely Premier Vows to Review Gas Deal With Russia
abstract: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who is poised to return as Ukraine's prime minister, vowed Thursday to review a disputed deal with Russia on natural gas imports, setting the stage for a new confrontation that could disrupt her country's economy and threaten supplies of Russian gas to Europe.     She spoke as three political parties once closely allied with President Viktor A. Yushchenko -- and then deeply divided -- formally signed an agreement to create a parliamentary coalition and, eventually, a new government that would follow the pro-Western course he set. The agreement ended nearly three months of political paralysis, but did not address many of the issues that split Mr. Yushchenko's supporters after he took office in January 2005.

headline: G.M. Cut Loss in Quarter, but Increased Its Inventory
abstract: General Motors says first-quarter loss was $323 million, compared with loss of $1.25 billion year earlier; says sales fell 5.2 percent; officials decline to project how many workers would choose to take buyouts, which range from $35,000 to $140,000; photo; graph (M)

headline: Millions Vote in Local Races in Britain, Testing Blair
abstract: Millions of people across England voted Thursday in local council elections seen as a litmus test of Prime Minister Tony Blair's standing after a series of embarrassing scandals among his closest aides.     The ballot, the first test of public opinion since the national vote a year ago in which Mr. Blair won a third term, is likely to lead to a rearrangement of his cabinet, possibly after results become final on Friday.

headline: The End User: A third way on music?
Finding Shortcuts in Internet Explorer 7
abstract: Here's a list of keyboard and mouse shortcuts that will make the public beta 2 of Internet Explorer 7 really sing.

headline: A Zulu's last line of defense: Heritage
TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: BILLIONS TO HELP FIGHT DISEASE -- Warren E. Buffett's $31 billion gift to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will help the foundation pursue its goal of curing the globe's 20 leading fatal diseases, Mr. Gates said, along with improving education. [A1.]    SHARED VIEWS OF TWO BILLIONAIRES -- Bill Gates and Warren Buffett both have a disdain for inherited wealth and share the view that the capitalist system that has enriched them is not capable alone of addressing the root causes of poverty.
