[C1.]    GAME MAKER IS SUBPOENAED -- The video game publisher Take-Two Interactive said that it had received a grand jury subpoena from the Manhattan district attorney's office, seeking information about a range of its business practices dating back to 2001 and its inclusion of sexually explicit material in one of its games. A company spokesman said the district attorney had not told Take-Two whether it or any of its executives or directors were the focus of the inquiry. [C1.]    HEART DEVICES RECALLED -- Boston Scientific said that it was recalling 23,000 heart pacemakers and defibrillators and recommended that 27,000 patients who already have the devices in their chests consult their doctors. Market Place. [C1.]    PART OF VIOXX PAPER RETRACTED -- The simmering controversy over data from the 2004 clinical trial that caused Merck to stop selling Vioxx bubbled up again, as the New England Journal of Medicine retracted part of a paper it had published about the trial. [C13.]    FINDINGS ON FOOD AND DRUG LAW -- A 15-month inquiry by a top House Democrat has found that enforcement of food and drug laws declined sharply during the first five years of the Bush administration. [A15.]    EMISSIONS CASE ACCEPTED -- The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the federal government is required to control vehicle emissions of carbon dioxide, the principal greenhouse gas that has been linked to global warming. [A14.]    35,000 TO LEAVE G.M. -- In an employee exodus that is one of the biggest ever, about 48,000 workers at General Motors and Delphi accepted early retirement or buyout offers. [C1.]    ANTI-PORNOGRAPHY EFFORT -- In the face of government pressure, a group of Internet companies is undertaking an effort to help combat child pornography online. [C3.]    SALES OF NEW HOMES INCREASE -- Sales of new homes rose in May, surprising economists who had been forecasting that housing would slow because of rising loan rates. [C3.]    STEEL INDUSTRY AD CAMPAIGN -- The steel industry has inaugurated an advertising campaign to reposition itself as a vibrant and crucial part of the American economy. [C10.]    JUSTICES TO HEAR PHONE CASE -- The Supreme Court said that it would consider a lawsuit that accuses the nation's largest telephone companies of violating federal antitrust law by conspiring to carve up local markets to preserve their monopolies. [C3.]    CHANGE AT THE TOP AT KRAFT -- Amid lackluster earnings growth and a stagnant share price, the directors of Kraft Food ousted the chief executive, Roger K. Deromedi, left, who had been at Kraft for 28 years and its head since 2001. He will be succeeded by Irene B. Rosenfeld, who will become one of 12 women leading a Fortune 500 company. Analysts say that Kraft has lagged some rivals in introducing successful products. [C3.]    NEWSPAPER DEAL APPROVED -- Shareholders of Knight Ridder, the newspaper company, voted overwhelmingly to sell the company to McClatchy. [C10.]    MINING DEAL MAY NOT BE FINAL -- The $40 billion deal by the copper miner Phelps Dodge to acquire Inco and Falconbridge, two major nickel producers in Canada, could yet be upset by another bid, analysts say. [C11.]    BIAS AGAINST RUSSIA SEEN -- The Russian oligarch Aleksei Mordashov lost the battle for the steel company Arcelor for one reason, Russian politicians say: Russophobia. [C11.]

headline: Michaels Stores Is Said to Be Weighing Offers
abstract: Directors of Michaels Stores, US's largest arts and crafts retailer, will consider takeover bids from two private equity investor consortiums; one group includes Bain Capital, Blackstone Group and Thomas H Lee Partners; other is comprised of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co and Texas Pacific Group (M)

headline: Diplomacy Over Diplomas
abstract: BASF chairman-chief executive Klaus Peter Lobbe's The Boss colr

headline: Orders for Durable Goods Fall for a 2nd Consecutive Month
abstract: Commerce Department reports orders for durable goods fell 0.3 percent in May, to $208.67 billion; economists say when volative commercial aircraft industry is taken out of equation, orders actually rose 1 percent for month after falling nearly 2 percent in April; photo (M)

headline: EU halts payments to Palestinian leaders
On a Russian Site, Cheap Songs With a Backbeat of Illegality
abstract: AllofMP3.com, music downloading service based in Moscow, has become site popular with consumers but one that music industry lobbyists say is loophole in Russia's copyright law; site offers vast catalog of music that includes artists not normally authorized for sale online at fraction of cost of services like Apple Computer's iTunes Music Store; music is sold in album-size chunks for less than $1 and downloaded songs can be copied without restrictions; photo (M)

headline: Staking Claim to the Skies Over Denver
abstract: Excerpts of interview with Jeff Potter, chief executive of Frontier Airlines, who comments on airline competition; photo (M)

headline: Iraq president says deal with some rebels possible
Intel to Offer Its Own Plan for Global Internet Access
abstract: Intel Corp plans to announce design for sub-$400 laptop computer and five-year $1 billion program for teachers in order to close worldwide digital divide; Intel's efforts will differ from other technology companies in offering full-featured systems; Intel chief executive Paul S Otellini comments (M)

headline: Coke's Board to Get Bonus or Nothing
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company announced an innovative plan yesterday for paying outside directors: If earnings per share do not rise fast enough over a three-year period, directors will receive nothing. But they will get a significant raise if earnings perform as expected.     While many companies give directors all or part of their pay in stock or stock options, Coca-Cola appears to be the first to have adopted a plan that would provide nothing if the company did not perform well.

headline: Gas Prices Legitimate, Study Says
abstract: Despite suspicions among consumers about rapidly rising gasoline prices and record oil industry profits, a federal investigation concluded Monday that the jump at the pump over the last year had not been the result of unlawful price manipulation.     The Federal Trade Commission said the sharp increase in fuel costs was attributable to market forces -- namely big drops in supply and production and runs on inventories after major damage to refineries, ports and pipelines. In a report that Congress ordered last year after hurricanes struck the nation's refining hub on the Gulf Coast, the commission found no evidence of price collusion or improper reductions of inventory or supplies to increase company profits.

headline: The Secret Word Was Duck
abstract: Aflac chairman and chief executive Daniel P Amos The Boss column on his childhood business experiences, decision to change name of family business American Family Life Assurance Co to Aflac and selecting duck as company mascot; photo (M)

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: In the days before Little, Brown decided to stop selling ''How Opal Mehta Got Kissed, Got Wild and Got a Life'' on Thursday, the book (above) by Kaavya Viswanathan had entered the Top 200 best-seller list. Ms. Viswanathan has said she unintentionally copied passages of her work from books by Megan McCafferty.     Titles for teenagers range from ''Monster,'' a harrowing story of a boy charged with murder, to ''Only in Your Dreams,'' on the glamorous and the wealthy.   SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline: Rice and Straw Keep Pressure on Iraqis
abstract: The secretary of state and her British counterpart pressed Iraqi leaders for a second day today to speed up their efforts to form a new government.

headline: In Attack Mode, a Rightist Surges in Mexico
abstract: Felipe Calderón loves to make allusions to Mexican folk songs. These days, the conservative candidate for president is particularly fond of recalling a song about a nag named Relámpago who upsets a glistening champion, Moro, in a race.     ''I was not the favorite,'' he boomed over loudspeakers to a crowd of farmers, fishermen and business owners in the town of Tonalá on a swing in Chiapas on Thursday. ''I was not the one who was up in the polls, but do you know what I did, gentlemen? I went to work. I set about telling Mexicans what each candidate really stands for.''

headline: Mixed Signals Are Expected for Fed Policy
abstract: FEDERAL Reserve policy makers indicated last week that data on the housing market and on the economy's use of vital resources would influence their decisions on interest rates. Several reports scheduled for Tuesday should supply crucial information on both fronts.     Two indicators of strength in the housing market are expected to provide a cloudy picture. Housing starts are estimated in a Bloomberg News poll of economists to have edged down to an annual rate of 1.95 million units in April, from 1.960 million in March, while a dip is foreseen in building permits, to an annual rate of 2.040 million units, from 2.094 million units.

headline: Back of the Envelope
abstract: Chart shows advisory roles that Evercore Partners, which plans to go public, has played in mergers and acquisitions (M)

headline: Unprecedented flooding threatens cities in Serbia, Romania, Bulgaria
10 Are Killed in Bombing Near Shrine Holy to Shiites
abstract: Striking at the heart of Shiite Islam, a car bomb ripped through a crowd of worshipers and pedestrians near the Imam Ali mosque in Najaf on Thursday, killing at least 10 people and wounding 34, hospital officials said.     The bombing, which comes at a time of increasing violence between Shiite and Sunni Muslims in Iraq, struck a crowd of pilgrims and merchants at the entrance to Najaf's cemetery. The site is just a few hundred yards from the mosque, which is one of the most important Shiite shrines in the world and draws pilgrims on Thursdays and Fridays. The bomb exploded on a street connecting the mosque and the cemetery, a route along which Shiites from around the country carry relatives' bodies for burial.

headline: Chad severs ties with Sudan as tensions escalate
French protesters reject Chirac's compromise
Minister critical on Catalonia steps down
S.E.C. Lost Its Hedge-Fund Authority and Will Be Glad It Did
abstract: Phillip Goldstein, the hedge fund manager who sued the Securities and Exchange Commission and won with his argument that the commission lacked authority to regulate the funds, has also won the kudos of many managers, he says. Officials and staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission, expectedly, have received a lot of grief.      But before the managers crack open the Champagne and the lawyers inside the commission drown their sorrows, consider this: Hedge fund managers should now prepare for the worst and the S.E.C. should be downright relieved.

headline: EU constitution not on June agenda
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Apology For Unprotected Sex
abstract: Newly acquitted of raping the daughter of a family friend, South Africa's former deputy president, Jacob G. Zuma, apologized for having unprotected sex with the H.I.V.-positive woman last November, saying he ''should have been more cautious and more responsible.'' But he bristled at the widespread criticism of his statement during the trial that he had showered after sex to minimize the chance of contracting H.I.V. Mr. Zuma said he had not stated that showers prevent AIDS, explaining that his behavior was an ''additional measure'' to ward off infection, akin to washing one's hands after peeling an onion. Mr. Zuma's statements on H.I.V. and women's sexual behavior were assailed by women's and AIDS activists but supported by many in South Africa's large Zulu population.   MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

headline: Lay Says He May Have Broken Law on Bank Loans
abstract: Former Enron chief executive Kenneth Lay, testifying in new trial on bank loan fraud charges, acknowledges he or his staff may have violated federal law governing use of personal bank loans to buy stocks; says he never intended to defraud banks or lie to them; jury from earlier case against Lay and co-defendant Jeffrey Skilling deliberates for second day; photo (M)

headline: At Least 71 Die as Bombers Hit Mosque in Baghdad
abstract: The mosque is the religious bastion of the Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq, the country's most powerful Shiite party.

headline: Study Finds High Rate of Recalls of Heart Devices Used in Emergencies
abstract: Study based on Food and Drug Administration records from last 10 years finds that about 164,000 emergency external heart defibrillators, or about 20 percent of units sold during period, were subject to agency recall or alert; also finds that FDA received 370 reports of deaths in which defibrillators or critical components malfunctioned during attempts to resuscitate patients in cardiac arrest (M)

headline: Adiós for a Spanish Hotel Where They Dressed to Kill
abstract: Hotel Reina Victoria, traditional hub of Madrid's bullfighting culture and place where Spain's great matadors have been dressing for more than 60 years, shuts down; will reopen as Hard Rock Hotel Madrid; practically all of bullfighting's legendary figures stayed there at one time or another since its construction in 1920's; photos (M)

headline: Breaking Up Is Easy to Do at Liberty
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Gregory Maffei, chief executive of Liberty Media, who discusses plans for company's vast and ever-shifting media interests; photo (M)

headline: Consumer Borrowing Rose 5.9% in April
abstract: Federal Reserve reports consumer spending rose $10.6 billion in April, or annual rate of 5.9 percent, to $2.17 trillion; increase, highest in 10 months, may indicate that consumers are returning to more conventional credit as real estate market cools; graph (S)

headline: Nepal Rebels Will Lay Down Arms Only if Army Does
abstract: Maoist rebels in Nepal said today that they would agree to sequester their troops only if the the Royal Nepalese Army would agree to the same.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oxford Wins Limits On Protesters
abstract: Oxford University wins legal victory in its effort to limit protests by animal rights activists opposed to new biomedical research center; British High Court agrees to extend zone keeping protesters away from center's construction site (S)

headline: Sony to Sell PlayStation 3 for $499
abstract: Sony said on Monday that it planned to sell the base model of its PlayStation 3 video game console for $499, a price that industry analysts said could put it at a competitive disadvantage to rival Microsoft and its Xbox 360.      Sony said that it also planned to sell a higher-priced model with a larger hard drive for $599.

headline: Video Catching Up to Photos When It Comes to Sharing
abstract: Article on rage of new services and companies that make it easier to share digital video from cameras or camcorders without having to burn DVD's or upload to sharing sites; Robert Levitan, founder of Pando, says software programs are able to send large files without using e-mail, which distorts video quality; drawing (M)

headline: Condos, Not Garrets, in West Chelsea
abstract: Bass Associates, in unusual step aimed at helping to prevent artists, galleries and other art-related businesses from moving out of Manhattan's West Chelsea neighborhood, plans to build 20-story Chelsea Arts Tower on site of former parking lot at 545 West 25th Street; $60 million development features full-floor units of 3,100 to 4,700 square feet; buyers will build their own interiors; drawing (M)

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: J. P. Morgan Chase Pays $22.3 Million Each To Its Chairman and Chief Executive  J. P. Morgan Chase & Company said yesterday that it had awarded its chairman, William B. Harrison Jr., and its chief executive, James Dimon, $22.3 million each in compensation for 2005, increases of 39 percent and 47 percent, respectively, from 2004. The gains in pay came as the bank's profit rose 90 percent, to $8.48 billion, largely reflecting its July 2004 acquisition of the Bank One Corporation, which Mr. Dimon ran. Mr. Dimon served last year as chief operating officer, and succeeded Mr. Harrison as chief executive at year-end. Mr. Harrison, 62, and Mr. Dimon, 50, were each given $1 million in salary, an $8.4 million bonus, $12.6 million of restricted stock and other items. J. P. Morgan disclosed the compensation packages in a proxy filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. (REUTERS)    Lazard Raises Compensation for Chief to $14.2 Million  Lazard, the investment bank, said yesterday that it had paid its chief executive, Bruce Wasserstein, left, $14.2 million last year, nearly five times his compensation in 2004. Mr. Wasserstein's salary was increased to $4.2 million from $3 million in 2004, Lazard said in a regulatory filing. He also received restricted shares valued at $10 million, not granted previously because the company was privately held. The stock award was announced in January. Lazard's shares have gained 76 percent since Mr. Wasserstein took the firm public, raising $855 million. The company's income doubled to $172 million last year as the pace of mergers worldwide climbed to the highest since 2000. Lazard is based in New York. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    United and Delta Raise Some Business Fares  United Airlines raised American business-class fares on tickets purchased the same day of travel by $50 each way, the biggest increase since 2000. Delta Air Lines matched the move. United, the operating unit of the UAL Corporation, also raised leisure fares by $2 to $4 each way to counter climbing fuel costs, a spokeswoman said yesterday. Delta also increased those fares, according to a spokeswoman. Spokesmen at the American Airlines unit of the AMR Corporation, Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines said the carriers were considering similar moves. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    A.I.G. Executive Retires After 38 Years at Insurer  The American International Group said yesterday that Thomas R. Tizzio, the senior vice chairman for general insurance, would retire after 38 years with the company. Mr. Tizzio, 68, will stay on as an honorary director and adviser, A.I.G. said. He joined the company in 1967 as an inland marine underwriter and rose to president. His resignation was to be effective yesterday. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Freddie Mac Expects to Post 2005 Results in May  The mortgage finance company Freddie Mac, emerging from an accounting scandal, said yesterday that it had a strong year in 2005 but acknowledged that it needed to make more progress in its financial controls and reporting. The government-sponsored company, which is a buyer and guarantor of home mortgages, said it expected to report its 2005 results in late May. Freddie Mac had previously planned to report them in March, but it needed more time to institute a new method of valuing some assets, which it said would reduce income by about $200 million. The company, based in McLean, Va., estimated 2005 income at $2.5 billion, down from $2.9 billion in 2004. (AP)    Hollinger International Posts a Smaller Loss for 2005  Hollinger International, the newspaper company formerly controlled by Conrad M. Black, reduced its net loss in 2005 to just under $12 million, according to its annual report released yesterday. Revenue fell slightly to $457.9 million for the year ended Dec. 31, down from $464.4 million, as a result of declines in advertising and circulation revenue. The $11.97 million loss is the smallest loss in five years for the company, which at one time was one of the world's biggest newspaper publishers in terms of circulation. However, since its pinnacle in the 1990's, Hollinger has sold most of its papers. Its business is now concentrated on the Sun-Times News Group, which publishes The Chicago Sun-Times and smaller city and suburban papers in the Chicago area. (DOW JONES/AP)    Fidelity Investments Closes 2 Funds to New Investors  Fidelity Investments said yesterday that it would close two of its mutual funds to new investors after a swell of investment inflows raised assets. Fidelity, based in Boston, said it would close the $63.8 billion Contrafund and the $5.5 billion Advisor New Insights fund. The funds, managed by William Danoff, took in a total of $12 billion in the 12 months ended Feb. 28, Fidelity said. The company said it would stop accepting new accounts in the two funds on April 28. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Citigroup Sued by Market Regulator in Australia  Citigroup is being sued for insider trading in Australia, the first time a company has ever faced such charges in the country. The deputy chairman of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, Jeremy Cooper, said in a statement yesterday that Citigroup had used confidential information about the Patrick Corporation, the nation's largest cargo handler, ''against the interest of its client,'' Toll Holdings. Toll, which is based in Melbourne, had made a bid of 4.6 billion Australian dollars ($3.3 billion) for Patrick. Citigroup denied the accusation. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Investors Drop Bid for British TV Concern After Rejection  A private equity consortium dropped a bid for ITV, the British TV broadcaster, after the company rejected the consortium's second approach. ITV said it turned down the £5.37 billion ($9.3 billion) bid from the consortium, which consisted of Apax Partners & Company, the Blackstone Group and the Goldman Sachs Group because it carried too much risk. In response, the consortium said it had decided to abandon the approach, but reserved the right to make another offer in the next six months if ITV agreed on terms or if a rival bidder emerged. (AP)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Prime Minister Apologizes For Outburst
abstract: Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin apologized for accusing the Socialist Party leader of cowardice during an outburst in the National Assembly on Tuesday. ''If some words personally injured you, I regret them and I take them back,'' Mr. de Villepin told lawmakers during a question-and-answer session in the Assembly, as François Hollande, the Socialist leader, looked on. Mr. de Villepin added, ''You will understand, Mr. Hollande, that I have not been spared from personal attacks, from calumny and from lies.'' During Tuesday's session, Mr. Hollande accused the government of irresponsibility in its handling of the crisis involving the delay in deliveries of the newest super-jumbo plane by Airbus and possible insider trading by the French co-chief executive officer of its parent company, EADS, the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company. The accusation prompted Mr. de Villepin's angry outburst.    ELAINE SCIOLINO (NYT)

headline: Seeing the High-Tech World Through Different Lenses
abstract: Every now and then, I get e-mail that reminds me that in the high-tech world, there are so many viewpoints, some of which lead to utter bafflement about the products I review.

headline: Apple opens door for Windows
People
abstract: The Churn column on some recent executive changes (S)

headline: Lab Suspends Testing After F.D.A. Audit
abstract: Canadian drug and medical testing company MDS suspends operations at Montreal lab after another unfavorable audit from US Food and Drug Administration; moves testing to other MDS operations in Britain, Canada, Switzerland and US (S)

headline: Imitating to Compete, Not to Flatter
abstract: William Holstein Airchair MBA column offers excerpts from conversation with Lakshmi Narayanan, chief executive of Cognizant Technology Solutions, outsourcing company with most of its employees in India; Narayanan comments on company's ability to compete against giants like IBM and Accenture by borrowing American-style management techniques; drawing (M)

headline: The High Costs of Cheap Gas and Vice Versa
abstract: BEFORE we were old enough to have jobs, my college roommate and I set out to take a vacation that would cost as little as possible. Our transportation was a borrowed Volkswagen, and friends scattered around the country put us up on spare beds or sofas. Entertainment came from a carefully planned schedule of minor league baseball games and from whatever else caught our eye along the way.     The first trip, in 1992, went so well that it became a near-annual tradition. By the time we stopped it eight years later, we had been to both coasts, the Smoky Mountains, the Great Plains, the Herbert Hoover museum and perhaps the nation's finest ballpark food stand, a barbecue pit in Stockton, Calif. On a good day, we spent $50 between us.

headline: Your Call Is Important to Us. Please Stay Awake.
abstract: Comcast spokeswoman Beth Bacha, commenting on posting on Internet of video by customer Brian Finkelstein showing repairman asleep on his couch, says he has been dismissed; Finkelstein says team of Comcast guys worked for five hours few days later to fix his Internet connection; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Economic Growth Rises Sharply
abstract: The economy grew at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the first quarter, its fastest pace in more than two years.

headline: Sudanese rebels reject peace proposal
Lockheed Profit Rises 60%, but Northrop Earnings Fall
abstract: Lockheed Martin posts higher-than-expected 60 percent increase in first-quarter profit, to $591 million, on rising sales to military; year-earlier profit was $369 million; revenue rose 8.6 percent, to $9.21 billion; Northrop Grumman, citing delays at shipyards off Gulf of Mexico as result of damage from Hurricane Katrina, says profit fell 12 percent, to $358 million from $409 million; says overall sales dropped 3.6 percent, to $7.18 billion (M)

headline: Seed Money, It Seems, Doesn't Need Much Rain
abstract: Matt Richtel column on booming venture capital industry in Southern California, which increased by $2.54 billion in 301 deals, or 17 percent, in 2005 over year earlier; region is challenging Boston corridor as second in allure behind Silicon Valley and may eclipse New England in near future; Robert More, venture capitalists Robert More, Jim Armstrong and others comment; photo (M)

headline: Thaksin steps down as leader of Thailand
A Farewell to Citigroup
abstract: Entering his sun-filled office in Citigroup's Manhattan headquarters, Sanford I. Weill punched a few buttons on a computer near a window before looking over his shoulder and smiling broadly. When asked if he had just looked at Citigroup's stock price, he shrugged his shoulders as if to suggest he could not help himself.     ''It's up 35 cents; it's a good day,'' he noted.

headline: After Shootout, Palestinians Try to Calm Infighting
abstract: The main Palestinian political parties, Hamas and Fatah, sought to reduce tensions on Monday after a predawn shootout in the southern Gaza Strip left three of their members dead and 10 people wounded in the worst internal Palestinian violence since the Hamas-led government came to power.     Members of the two factions have battled periodically since the militant Islamic group Hamas won the Palestinian elections in January, ending decades of political dominance by Fatah, the party of the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas. But the clash on Monday was the most heated so far.

headline: Fearing Inflation, China Tightens Monetary Policy for 2nd Time in 6 Weeks
abstract: People's Bank of China announces tightening of monetary policy for second time in six weeks, indicating fears of inflation are affecting nation; new rules will require banks to hold 8 percent of loan assets at central bank reserves, up from 7.5 percent; photo (M)

headline: TechBrief: Nonaligned nations start Web news service
Friend or foe? Hu visit to test ties with U.S.
BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: DHB Industries receives notice from Securities and Exchange Commission that it is considering lawsuit against company in connection with allegations of securities violations (S)

headline: An Ambitious Lexus Takes On the Europeans
abstract: Lexus unveils LS 600hL hybrid automobile to compete at high-end of luxury market against Mercedes and BMW; uses engine technology that German automakers do not plan to implement until later in decade; 600hL is loaded with features to attract superluxury buyers; photos; graph (M)

headline: Fox is alame duck, but he's running hard
Sliced Lamb in Formaldehyde and Other Market Indicators
abstract: Jenny Anderson Insider column on record-setting art auctions and high-priced sales, fueled by widespread global wealth creation; shares of Sotheby's have skyrocketed to nearly $34 in May from $14 year ago; auction house, during May, sold $207.6 million worth of art in May, compared with $91.3 million year earlier; graph (M)

headline: Buying a New Fridge? Watch the Interactive Video First
abstract: ONLINE retailers have been using product videos for years, and with few exceptions have succeeded only in irritating customers with glitchy pictures or leaving them slack-jawed with boredom.     But retailers and others might be starting to crack the code. ''Retailers are trying to figure out how to put the dopamine of in-store experiences into the online experience,'' said Patti Freeman Evans, an analyst with JupiterResearch, a technology consultancy. ''You walk into a store and see all these wonderful things you didn't know you needed and the endorphins take over. Video may be one way to re-create that online.''

headline: It's Crowded. It's Chaotic. And It's Not Even Summer.
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on chaos and confusion that business travelers face as airlines overbook domestic flights and shift attention to international routes; drawing (M)

headline: Zarqawi Is Dead, but Weary Iraqis Fear the Violence Won't Subside
abstract: Haifa Hassan stared with blank sadness toward a spot on her living room carpet when asked about Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death.      The larger-than-life terrorist had little to do with the killing of her 12-year-old son, whose crumpled body was found beaten, burned and strangled after local criminals kidnapped him several weeks ago. The family had raised $10,000 in ransom. It was not enough.

headline: Wal-Mart Tries to Enlist Image Help
abstract: Wal-Mart, having helped start an advocacy group that trumpets its contributions to America, is now helping that organization recruit Wal-Mart's suppliers to join the public relations offensive -- a move that some vendors say puts improper pressure on them.     The campaign to encourage suppliers to join the advocacy group, called Working Families for Wal-Mart, challenges Wal-Mart's longstanding policy of keeping suppliers at arm's length and shows how eager the company is to fend off a well-organized union-backed campaign critical of its wages and benefits.

headline: How To Give Money as Buffett Does
abstract: WHEN the news about Warren Buffett's huge gift to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation started coming out the other night, I figured there must be something that I was missing. He's giving away $31 billion, and he's not getting a single thing named for himself?      Some people write a $10,000 check to their alma mater and expect to get a plaque celebrating their generosity, and here was Mr. Buffett making a gift that will effectively send $10,000 to the Gates Foundation every three minutes for decades on end. For that amount of money, he could have founded Buffett University in his native Nebraska with an endowment larger than Harvard's, or he could have set up the world's richest foundation -- the Buffett Foundation -- and engaged in a little competitive philanthropy with his fellow bridge player Mr. Gates.

headline: World Briefing: Americas, Africa, Europe and Asia
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: Intelsat wins Justice Dept clearance to purchase PanAmSat Holding Corp for $3.2 billion; sale will add 24 satellite, making Intelsat largest commercial-satellite operator (S)

headline: Company Asks U.S. to Provide Radio Space for Free Internet
abstract: M2Z Networks asks Federal Communications Commission to give it band of radio spectrum for free high-speed wireless Internet network that would cover most of US and be supported by advertising; network, backed by several prominent venture capitalists, says plan could hasten spread of broadband Internet use and lead to lower prices by spurring competition with cable and telephone giants that dominate Internet market (M)

headline: Richard Stengel Is Chosen to Be Top Editor at Time
abstract: Richard Stengel, longtime writer and editor at Time magazine and former head of its Web site, is named to succeed Jim Kelly as magazine's managing editor; Kelly is moving to newly created position of managing editor of Time Inc; photo (M)

headline: 9 Iraq Officers Killed in Ambush; 2 Marines Die in Anbar
abstract: At least 9 Iraqi police officers are killed and 18 wounded when convoy is ambushed by insurgents just north of Baghdad after being denied permission to stay overnight on US military base; 2 US marines are killed and 22 wounded in attack in Anbar Province; photo (M)

headline: ONLINE
abstract: INTERACTIVE GRAPHIC -- A look at executive pay in 2005. Are chief executives being overpaid for their performance? You can create and explore your own graph, based on executive pay statistics for last year, at nytimes.com/executivepay.    DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook.    YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with ''Your Money,'' a free weekly newsletter from The New York Times, at nytimes.com/yourmoney.    MOST POPULAR -- Find out what the most e-mailed, most blogged, most searched and most popular movies are on The Times's Web site at nytimes.com/mostpopular.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: President Refuses A Second Term
abstract: Italy's 85-year-old president, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, declined offers for a second two-year term, depriving Italy of its only clear consensus candidate and opening what is likely to be a difficult fight to choose his successor. ''None of the preceding nine presidents of the republic were re-elected,'' he said. ''This has become a significant custom. It's better not to break it.'' The president, elected by Parliament and above day-to-day politics, is normally chosen with support from both the right and left, and it is unclear who Silvio Berlusconi, the departing prime minister, and his apparent successor, Romano Prodi, could agree on as a candidate.    IAN FISHER (NYT)

headline: 191 Reports of Eye Infection Linked to Lens Cleaners
abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta says reports have increased of rare fungal infection linked to contact lens cleaners; 58 of 191 cases say that they used cleaning solutions from Bausch & Lomb; infection is caused by fungus known as Fusarium keratitis; Bausch & Lomb stopped selling product in Asia after investigation found unusual number of cases from Hong Kong last Nov (M)

headline: Nissan's profit a record for 6th year in a row
Russia's Surging Steel Industry May Seek Role on a Global Stage
abstract: Roman Abramovich, Russia's richest man, purchases 42 percent stake in Russia's largest steel group Evraz for estimated $3 billion; is second major steel deal with Russian company in three weeks; some analysts say strategy is to consolidate Russia's industry around one or two companies and link up with foreign steel makers to ensure export market (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: IEG, Chicago, which specializes in research and in fields like sports marketing, was acquired by the GroupM unit of the WPP Group, London. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: G.I. Dies and 2 Are Missing; Bombing Kills 11 in Mosque
abstract: Two US soldiers are missing and another is killed after they come under attack near Yusifiya, town known as base for Qaeda fighters; suicide bomber blows himself up in Baghdad mosque, killing 11 Shiite worshipers and wounding 25; photos (M)

headline: The Hague: Report on Serb's Suicide Finds No Fault
abstract: UN war crimes tribunal confirms that death of Milan Babic, former Croatian Serb leader who had testified against Slobodan Milosevic, was suicide (S)

headline: A Contrarian Look at Whether U.S. Chief Executives Are Overpaid
abstract: Tyler Cowen Economic Scene column examines whether American chief executives at top 500 companies are overpaid; cites study conducted by Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist Xavier Gabaix and Stern Business School economist Augustin Landier that suggests that, contrary to popular view, higher salaries are result of competitive pressures rather than exploitation of shareholders (M)

headline: Home Sweet Home, Built in a Factory
abstract: Manufactured-housing communities struggle to overcome challenges facing industry; investors are betting on upscale neighborhoods to enhance sector's image of trailer parks and other low-income developments; foreclosures and reposessions plague industry while low mortgage rates have hurt sales in past by making conventional housing more affordable for buyers; real estate investment trusts, which analysts expect to profit in near future are listed; photos (M)

headline: U.S. expansion leads sales growth for SAP
The Virtues of a Second Screen
abstract: Addition of second monitor for Windows or Mac computers offers improved productivity and workflow advantages; survey by Jon Peddie Research shows improvements up to 20 to 30 percent when using two displays; second monitor allows user to see current and earlier drafts, compare spreadsheets or work with different applications simultaneously; video game enthusiasts become more immersed in action when using multiple screens, sometimes using as many as three or four on one computer; software designed for multiple screens includes such titles as Quake, Doom and Microsoft Flight Simulator; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 4 Soldiers Killed In Suicide Attack
abstract: Suicide bomber blows up his car near Pakistani Army convoy in Waziristan, killing four soldiers and wounding seven (S)

headline: U.S. Cancels Nepal Visit as Another Protester is Killed
abstract: With violent street rallies demanding the restoration of parliamentary rule continuing, the U.S. Embassy closed its consular section.

headline: G.O.P. Fails in Attempt to Repeal Estate Tax
abstract: Senate Republicans failed on Thursday to muster the votes needed to abolish the estate tax on inherited wealth, but supporters of a compromise held out hope for a deal this year that could attract enough Democrats to pass.     Voting 57 to 41, with only a few lawmakers crossing party lines, the Senate was three votes short of the number needed to end debate on the bill, dooming it on procedural grounds. The vote all but killed hopes at the White House and among Republicans on Capitol Hill of eliminating the tax on large estates, which under current law would be phased out by 2010 but would return in 2011.

headline: Supplies low as general strike continues in Nepal
In Brazil, Anger at Leader's Mild Response to Bolivia's Bold Move
abstract: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil continued his low-key approach on Wednesday to Bolivia's move to take control of its natural gas and oil industries, drawing a barrage of criticism here for what many consider Brazil's weak response.     Brazil is Bolivia's biggest natural gas customer, with more than half its supply coming from there, and Brazil's state-controlled energy company, with over $1 billion invested, is the biggest single investor in Bolivia's natural gas industry. But Mr. da Silva, who publicly applauded the rise of a fellow leftist, Evo Morales, to Bolivia's presidency last December, has offered a muted response since Bolivia announced on Monday that it would take control of its energy industry. Bolivia has South America's second largest natural gas reserves, after Venezuela.

headline: MySpace begins warnings on sexual predators
A New Headquarters (Continuity Included)
abstract: Article on new headquarters of investment bank Keefe Bruyette & Woods in Equitable Building in Midtown Manhattan, designed by Nancy Ruddy and Eugene Flotteron of Cetra/Ruddy; Keefe Bruyette's offices at World Trade Center were destroyed; photos (M)

headline: Arcelor Indicates Some Willingness to Talk With Mittal
abstract: Steel giant Arcleor rejects 25.8 billion euro ($33 billion) hostile takeover bid from Mittal Steel; says it might be willing to negotiate deal if offer is raised; Arcelor would have to pay break-up fee of 140 million euros to Russian billionaire Aleksei Mordashov, who agreed to exchange his stake in Severstal and other assets for one-third of Arcelor; photo (M)

headline: A Phone Alternative That Offers Something for Nothing
abstract: Skype, which used to be province of college students and technogeeks, is changing how some businesses communicate; Skype and other Internet-based phone services have become extremely popular with rise of broadband; Skype is pursuing small businesses and has unveiled customer-support Web site and accessories that make it easier to use; photo (M)

headline: THIS OLD FILM
abstract: Home improvement expert Bob Vila explains why his foundation Fledgling Fund, which focuses on improving health care for poor families, is giving grants to filmmakers (S)

headline: U.S. Focus on Abstinence Weakens AIDS Fight, Agency Finds
abstract: Insistence by Republican Congressional leaders that American money to fight the spread of AIDS globally be used to emphasize abstinence and fidelity is undercutting comprehensive and widely accepted aid models, the Government Accountability Office said in a report released Tuesday.      The report by the G.A.O., an investigative arm of Congress, examines the effect of a mandate from Congress that at least a third of United States money to prevent the spread of AIDS worldwide be devoted to sexual abstinence and fidelity programs.

headline: In Shake-Up, Putin Fires Head of Russian Customs Service
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin fires Aleksandr Zherikov as head of Russia's customs service and dismisses a dozen or so midlevel security agency officials as well; firings are ostensibly part of anticorruption sweep of Russian bureaucracy, but also undermine German O Gref, pro-Western minister of economic trade and development; four senators will also apparently lose their jobs (M)

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: TIME WARNER, ITS AOL subsidiary and its auditor, Ernst & Young, have agreed to pay $23 million to settle a lawsuit accusing them of defrauding a Pennsylvania pension fund for teachers and state workers.     The suit, filed in February 2004, claimed the companies overstated revenue and subscriber figures after the merger of Time Warner and America Online was announced in 2000, the Pennsylvania attorney general, Tom Corbett, said.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Bees Kill Man As Rite Fails
abstract: African honeybees stung a 73-year-old man to death after a traditional ceremony to remove their hive from a home in Eastern Cape Province went awry. The man, Victor Nyembezi, was among 100 residents of Mgomanzi who were trying to get the bees to leave the homestead, in part by serving home-brewed beer in an effort to enlist ancestral spirits in their campaign. When the bees attacked instead, Mr. Nyembezi was too slow to escape and was killed by the swarm. A bee expert, Prof. Randall Hepburn of Rhodes University, told the South African Press Association that the instructions for traditional bee-removal ceremonies were simple: ''Don't do it,'' he said.   MICHAEL WINES (NYT)

headline: Advertising Out Front, Followed by the News
abstract: For years, many newspapers have been running what the industry calls wrap-arounds, full-page ads that are wrapped around the actual paper. When the wrap-around is removed, you see the real front page, with news.      Last week, The Daily News in New York ran full-page ads in some copies that were, in effect, the front page. On Wednesday, it ran front and back full-page ads for Mazda and on Friday for Toyota, and there was no second, or ''real,'' front page inside.

headline: H&M Names Dutch Pair as Designers for a Season
abstract: Swedish retailer H&M says it will begin carrying bargain version of apparel by comparatively obscure Dutch designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren for one season, beginning in November; communications director Lisa Sandberg says Viktor & Rolf collections epitomize haute couture; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BAE to Sell 20% Airbus Stake to EADS
abstract: BAE Systems, after talks fail, says it will exercise put option to force European Aeronautic Defense and Space Co to purchase 20 percent stake it holds in aircraft maker Airbus (S)

headline: Germans Seek Role in China Rail Project
abstract: German engineering firms Siemens and ThyssenKrupp are negotiating to supply technology for second high-speed rail link in China, worth 4.3 billion euros, between Shanghai and Hangzhou; Chinese statement comes as German Chancellor Angela Merkel rides maglev train during visit to Shanghai; photo (M)

headline: President of Ford Motor Will Retire
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said Thursday that its president, James J. Padilla, would retire July 1. His duties will be assumed by the chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., who is forming an executive operating committee to help him run the company.     Mr. Padilla, who is also Ford's chief operating officer, has held those positions since last year. He will give up his seat on Ford's board when he leaves.

headline: Author on the Court?
abstract: When asked why the onscreen teaming of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers proved so popular, the story goes, Katharine Hepburn replied, ÂHe gave her class and she gave him sex.Â A similar sharing of attributes is the goal of a promotional partnership between a leading publisher and professional basketball.

headline: Packing and Wondering Where Bags Will Land
abstract: Alina Tugend Short Cuts column discusses rise in lost, delayed or stolen luggage at nation's airports; incidents have increased 23 percent nationwide from 2004 to 2005 at cost of $2 billion annually; article offers tips on dealing with airlines and preventing lost luggage; photo (M)

headline: India, Known for Outsourcing, Expands in Industry
abstract: India, known as center for outsourcing, is experiencing beginnings of industrial renaissance; manufacturing, long hobbled by antiquated labor laws, creaking infrastructure and official paperwork and regulation, could have profound effect for vast number of India's poor as well as for international source of wide variety of goods as multinationals seek new places to make goods; at least 75 new special economic zones are in works, with more than dozen already operating; photo (M)

headline: Knight Ridder Profits Slide 53% as Several Expenses Increase
abstract: Knight Ridder says first-quarter profit declined 53 percent, to $28.4 million from $60.5 million year earlier; reports revenue rose 3.9 percent, to $739.9 million (M)

headline: Earnings Top Forecasts at Shell and Total
abstract: Oil companies Royal Dutch Shell and Total report first-quarter profits rose; net income at Shell increased 3 percent, to $6.89 billion, from $6.68 billion year earlier; profit rose 12 percent, to $6.09 billion; oil and gas production fell 3 percent from earlier quarter, to 3.75 million barrels a day; Total's earnings gained 16 percent, to 3.38 billion euros ($4.27 billion), from 2.92 billion euros; production dropped 5 percent, to 2.44 million barrels a day (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of March 26 article about lawsuit contending that hedge fund colluded with research firm to spread false information to drive down stock price of drug maker Biovail

headline: Out of Consumers' Sight, Radio Tags Gain Ground
abstract: The television advertisement from I.B.M.'s "Help Desk" campaign that began running this winter shows a big rig skidding to a halt in front of a desk, blocking the road in a desolate landscape. There, a young woman at the desk calmly informs the astonished truck driver headed for Fresno, Calif., that he is lost.     "This is the road to Albuquerque," she says. How does she know he is off course? "RFID radio tags on the cargo. Helps track shipments."

headline: Tyco Will Pay $50 Million to Settle Case With S.E.C.
abstract: After four years of criminal trials and accounting investigations, Tyco International agreed yesterday to pay a $50 million fine to the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle claims that the company inflated profits by more than $1 billion from 1996 through 2002.     The S.E.C. filed the settlement in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. It plans to distribute the money to Tyco shareholders.

headline: Sales of Existing Homes Rose Slightly in March
abstract: While sales rose slightly last month, the inventory of homes on the market increased noticeably and price increases slowed.

headline: Britain May Take Liberian Ex-Ruler
abstract: Britain said on Thursday that the former Liberian president, Charles Taylor, might serve his sentence in a British prison if he is convicted at his forthcoming war crimes trial.     The announcement paves the way for Mr. Taylor, who is being held in Sierra Leone on charges related to his role in that country's bloody civil war, to face trial in The Hague. The Netherlands has agreed to be host to the trial, but only on the condition that Mr. Taylor would not serve his sentence there if convicted. Other European countries have refused to allow Mr. Taylor to serve any sentence within their borders, but Britain, the former colonial power in Sierra Leone and a country that sent troops there in 2000 to help end the war, said it had started the process, ''and we want to finish it,'' in the words of Lord Triesman, the minister for Africa.

headline: So Many Rackets, So Little Time
abstract: Review of Godfather video game from Electronic Arts for PlayStation 2, Xbox and Windows 2000/XP; game is based on popular movie franchise; player must work their way through ranks of mafia; review of Bethesda Softworks' and Take 2 Interactive's Elder Scrolls IV; varied game takes place in fantasy universe; player must find long-lost son of assassinated emperor; photos (M)

headline: Briefly: France and Italy arrest alleged terror backers
Rice and Rumsfeld stand 'united' in Iraq
Afghanistan Bomb Kills American and Wounds 2
abstract: An American counternarcotics official was killed and two other Americans were wounded in a suicide bombing on Thursday in western Afghanistan, while heavy fighting between forces suspected of being Taliban insurgents and the Afghan police continued in two southern provinces, officials said.      The violence occurred amid increasing reports of many militants moving around rural areas. The fighting killed 13 police officers and possibly dozens of insurgents, officials said.

headline: Some See a 'Pyramid' to Hone Bosnia's Image. Others See a Big Hill.
abstract: Semir Osmanagic stopped to shake hands and have his photograph taken with a group of mud-flecked Bosnian villagers, pickaxes in hand, on a steep hillside above this small medieval trading town on a bend of the Bosna River. They have dug away four feet of roots and clay to expose slanted slabs of sedimentary stone.      ''Look at that megalith, it's got to weigh 40 tons,'' Mr. Osmanagic said eagerly, pointing to one of the roughly rectangular-shaped stones. ''After so many thousands of years, it is amazing that they are still here.''

headline: At a Secret Meeting, Chinese Analysts Clashed Over Reforms
abstract: Officials and scholars who had been convened last month to advise senior Chinese leaders disagreed sharply on how to advance economic and legal reforms, according to minutes of the private meeting that have been leaked on the Internet. They also expressed anxiety about what one official called ''unprecedented controversy and dissent'' among China's elite.      The minutes offered a revealing glimpse into the policy debate among influential people who are considered core supporters of the Communist Party's market-oriented economic reforms.

headline: International unit bolsters Citigroup's profit for quarter
Russia: Lower House Backs Bill to Bar 'Against All' Vote
abstract: Russian Parliament's lower house takes preliminary step to remove from election ballots option of voting 'against all' candidates; option, in place since early 1990's, has served as sort of protest vote (S)

headline: U.S. is seen wanting it both ways on yuan
Armenian Jet Goes Down In Black Sea, Killing 113
abstract: An Armenian passenger plane crashed into the Black Sea on Wednesday morning as it approached the southern Russian resort city of Sochi.     Airline and emergency officials reported that there were 113 passengers and crewmembers on board and that none appeared to have survived.

headline: European Union Moves Ahead With Turkey and Croatia Talks
abstract: The European Union pushed forward with enlargement plans on Monday, conducting a first round of membership negotiations with Turkey and Croatia and signing a pre-membership agreement with Albania.     The talks with Turkey proceeded after a compromise was reached over a demand by Cyprus that Ankara open its ports and airports to trade with new European Union member states, including Cyprus, as it had agreed to do last July. The European Union foreign ministers, meeting in Luxembourg, urged Turkey to do just that, or face delays in ''the overall progress in the negotiations.''

headline: 6,000 Pilots at Delta Air Vote to Strike
abstract: The nearly 6,000 pilots at Delta Air Lines, proving resistant to a second round of concessions, voted overwhelmingly to approve a strike should their contract be voided by an arbitration panel, the pilots' union said yesterday. The panel is expected to issue a ruling by April 15.     The decision by the pilots gives negotiators on both sides more than a week to narrow their differences and avoid a work stoppage that many believe would lead to a liquidation of Delta. Among the issues is the company's request for $305 million in annual pay cuts; the pilots have offered $140 million.

headline: Rebels driven out of Chad capital
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sweetener Patent Suit Filed
abstract: Tate & Lyle, the maker of the calorie-free sweetener sucralose, filed a patent lawsuit against a Chinese company accused of stealing the technology used to make the substance, which is sold under the trade name Splenda. A lawsuit filed in the Federal District Court in Urbana, Ill., said the Hebei Sukeri Science and Technology Company and six United States importers violate Tate & Lyle's United States patent for sucralose, Tate & Lyle said. Hebei could not be reached for comment. Tate & Lyle is based in London.

headline: Americans in Iraq Face Their Deadliest Day in Months
abstract: In the deadliest day for American forces since the beginning of the year, at least nine members of the military were killed in the insurgent stronghold of Anbar Province, including four in a rebel attack and at least five when their truck accidentally flipped over, the American military command said Monday.      Three marines and one sailor were killed Sunday in the rebel assault, the military reported, offering no further information. It was the largest number of American deaths in a single attack in more than a month.

headline: Ontario Terrorism Suspects Face List of Charges in Plot
abstract: The men who were arrested in a suspected terrorist plot to bomb several Canadian buildings faced a rash of terrorism charges, including belonging to a terrorist group, running training camps and smuggling guns and ammunition across the border, according to court documents released Monday.      Canadian police officials said that the sweeping investigation, which has also touched on suspects in the United States and other countries, was continuing, and that more arrests were expected.

headline: Poisonous Tree Frog Could Bring Wealth to Tribe in Brazilian Amazon
abstract: Fernando Katukina is chief of an indigenous tribe that lives largely without running water, electricity, or links to the world outside this remote corner of the western Amazon.     But Chief Fernando says he possesses a treasure that could be at the cutting-edge of biotechnology. If a plan initiated by the chief is successful, his tribe's fortunes will be transformed by an asset he and the Brazilian government believe holds great promise for the global pharmaceutical industry: the slime from a poisonous tree frog.

headline: Inviting Soap Opera Fans (and Sponsor) to the Emmys
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column on trend known as experimental marketing, intended to forge closer ties between products and consumers; focuses on Luminous Color Glaze Fan Zone, which will debut at 33rd annual Daytime Emmy Awards ceremony; Fan Zone, centerpiece of multimillion-dollar ad package sold by Disney ABC Unlimited to promote arrival in stores of John Frieda's Luminous Color Glaze line, will feature events, contests and other promotions; photo (M)

headline: Aid Reaches Indonesian Quake Area, but Volcano's Activity Increases
abstract: Significant amounts of aid began arriving Monday in Bantul, the town south of this city that was hit the hardest by Saturday's earthquake, but a nearby volcano substantially increased its threatening activity.     For the third night in a row, residents in Bantul and in Klaten, another badly ravaged town, slept outside their houses, grouped around campfires and used debris for cover from the sporadic rain. Some softly strummed guitars, while others, kneeling on mats, prayed for help.

headline: Germany Agrees to Open Holocaust Archive
abstract: Germany agreed Tuesday to allow access to a vast trove of information on what happened to more than 17 million people who were executed, forced to labor for the Nazi war machine or otherwise brutalized during the Holocaust.     The German government announced at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum here that it was dropping its decades-long resistance to opening the archives kept in the town of Bad Arolsen. The files, which make up one of the largest Holocaust archives in the world, are more than 15 miles long and hold up to 50 million documents, some seized by the Allies as they liberated concentration camps.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: G.E. to Buy Medical Tool Maker
abstract: General Electric agrees to buy Biacore International, maker of medical research instruments, for 3.22 billion kronor ($436 million); Pfizer, which owns 41 percent stake in Biacore, supports bid (S)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS: BAYER BUYING SHARES IN SCHERING
abstract: Bayer, reacting to Merck of Germany's taking of 10.1 percent stake in Schering, says it is buying shares of Schering on open market (S)

headline: New Drugs for Cancer Could Soon Flood Market
abstract: Big Pharma has discovered cancer.      For several years biotechnology companies like Genentech and ImClone have garnered most of the attention at the nation's largest cancer meeting with new so-called targeted drugs that were in general less toxic than traditional chemotherapy.

headline: Attacks in Sri Lanka kill 6, as peace talks are threatened
Court to Rule on Delaware Public Records Law
abstract: Three-judge US Court of Appeals panel holds hearing on appeal of constitutionality of Delaware's Freedom of Information Act, which denies nonresidents access to legal records in state, legal home of many major corporations; Federal District Judge Joseph Farnan Jr ruled in 2005 for Matthew Lee, consumer advocate, lawyer and New York resident who publishes Inner City Press, nonprofit Bronx newsletter about practices of banking and financial services companies (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Picks A New Top Prosecutor
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin appointed his justice minister to serve as Russia's new prosecutor general. The appointment shed little new light on what Kremlin officials and analysts have described as a new campaign against corruption. The minister, Yuri Y. Chaika, replaces Vladimir V. Ustinov, who was dismissed earlier this month, officials said, amid a wave of arrests and dismissals involving corruption. Mr. Putin, however, announced over the weekend that he had ''no complaints'' against Mr. Ustinov and that he would appoint him to another position in the future. Within hours of Mr. Chaika's appointment, the upper house of Parliament gave preliminary approval to the choice.   STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

headline: A Liberated View of the World as Viewfinders Eclipse Eyepieces
abstract: Digital cameras with LCD displays have dispensed with need for photographers to hold camera close to their eye to frame shot, eliminating type of intimacy between shutterbugs and their cameras; camera makers agree that optical viewfinders are unlikely to disappear soon, but younger people tend to be more comfortable with LCD screen than viewfinders; drawing (M)

headline: What to Do When the Oil (or the Innovation) Is Gone?
abstract: Daniel Altman Economic View column discusses finding cheaper and more efficient resources than natural commodities to replace oil and scarce metals; holds that there may be few alternatives despite advances in technology and science; global demand is pushing prices higher for depleted supplies; graph (M)

headline: Sales Miss Estimates at Barnes & Noble
abstract: Barnes & Noble says first-quarter profit rose less than 1 percent, to $10 million; says quarterly sales rose to $1.11 billion, short of $1.14 billion expected by analysts (S)

headline: 15 arrests in clashes between Copts and Muslims in Egypt
Big Board Says It's Mulling Possible Acquisitions
abstract: New York Stock Exchange is considering possible acquisition of rivals; says no definitive terms or agreements have been reached; possible deals are in response to Nasdaq's $4.2 billion bid for London Stock Exchange (M)

headline: The Economics of Henry Ford May Be Passé
abstract: HENRY FORD was 50 years old, and not all that different from a lot of other successful businessmen, when he summoned the Detroit press corps to his company's offices on Jan. 5, 1914. What he did that day made him a household name.     Mr. Ford announced that he was doubling the pay of thousands of his employees, to at least $5 a day. With his company selling Model T's as fast as it could make them, his workers deserved to share in the profits, he said.

headline: Italy blocks CIA case
May Turned Out to Be Strong for Most Retailers
abstract: For all their grumbling about high gasoline prices, consumers hardly sat on their wallets in May.      Both high-end and mainstream department stores -- from Bloomingdale's to Nordstrom to J. C. Penney -- said yesterday that sales last month were particularly strong. Target also reported healthy sales, but its main rival in the all-purpose one-stop discount store business, Wal-Mart Stores, said its sales growth slowed last month.

headline: We Already Showed You Hawaii? How About Nepal?
abstract: Sony's HDPS-L1 digital photo storage unit offers high-definition output to compatible television screen and ability to synchronize slide shows to music; stores 80 gigabytes worth of photos with variety of options for sorting; costs $300; photo (M)

headline: Mob Takes Car From U.S. Patrol in Ontario
abstract: Indian protesters from Six Nations Confederacy hijack United States Border Patrol car in Caledonia, Ontario, and then use it to try to run over Canadian police officer; American agents were visiting scene of three-month stand-off near American border between Indians, local residents and police over land claim; Ontario police arrested three people and is seeking arrest warrants for seven more (M)

headline: Aramark Gets a Takeover Offer
abstract: Aramark Corp receives $5.8 billion takeover bid from group led by its chairman Joseph Neubauer and Goldman Sachs Group; group also includes J P Morgan Chase, Thomas H Lee Partners and Warburg Pincus; photo (M)

headline: Earnings: DoCoMo forecasts 20% profit drop
Bird Flu Virus May Be Spread by Smuggling
abstract: There is increasing evidence that thriving international trade in smuggled poultry is helping spread bird flu; poultry from bird-flu-infected countries has been banned in Europe since 2002, but smuggling seriously undermines those bans; experts say that bird flu virus is robust enough to survive not just in live birds but also in frozen meat, feathers, bones and even on cages, though it dies with cooking; many are convinced that illegal import of infected live chicks introduced virus into Nigeria; China is source of much of poultry that is smuggled into Europe and Africa; photo (M)

headline: Thai prime minister to step down
South Korea Proposes Meeting With North Korea
abstract: President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea has expressed an eagerness to meet with North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, to propose concessions involving economic aid for the North.     Mr. Roh's overture was interpreted here as a demonstration of his frustration over a stalemate between the United States and North Korea over the North's nuclear programs, and his approach contrasted sharply with the American strategy of applying pressure on the North.

headline: Ford Plans Shift in Focus Away From Hybrids
abstract: Detroit auto companies, which have lagged far behind their Japanese rivals in developing and selling hybrid vehicles, are taking a new direction in a bid to emerge as leaders in their own right on environmental issues.     The latest sign of this shift occurred Thursday, when the Ford Motor Company confirmed that it would not meet its widely publicized goal of selling 250,000 hybrid vehicles a year by 2010, a goal set last fall when energy prices spiked after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Burger King Holdings, an initial public offering of 25 million shares. J. P. Morgan, Citigroup Global Markets, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.     Chipotle Mexican Grill, 4.2 million shares. Morgan Stanley and SG Cowen.     Darwin Professional Underwriters, an initial public offering of 5.2 million shares. Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse.     Illumina Inc., 3.5 million shares. Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch.     Gaiam Inc., five million shares. Thomas Weisel.     Gartner Inc., 9.5 million shares. Goldman Sachs, J. P. Morgan and Lehman Brothers.     GFI Group, 2.9 million shares. Merrill Lynch.     Penson WorldWide, 7.5 million shares. J. P. Morgan and Credit Suisse.     Redback Networks, 8.2 million shares. Goldman Sachs and UBS.     Restore Medical, an initial public offering of four million shares. Deutsche Bank.     Thomas Weisel Partners Group, 4.5 million shares. Thomas Weisel and Keefe & Company.     QuatRx Pharmaceuticals, an initial public offering of six million shares. Bank of America.    (Source by MCM EquityWatch)

headline: Help With Reactor Included in European Offer to Iran
abstract: The leading nations of Europe, working with the United States, are preparing to offer Iran new assistance in building a light-water nuclear reactor for civilian use in return for Iran's ending activities suspected of being a cover for a weapons program, European and American diplomats said Tuesday.     The offer to help with a light-water reactor, which could not easily be used to make weapons, is part of a new package of incentives the Europeans are assembling in one more attempt to salvage their negotiations with Iran. The package is also to contain threats of economic punishments if Iran does not cooperate.

headline: What Fraud? All Was Fine at Enron
abstract: IT was not much of a defense. But I was very young and had little time to decide what to say.     I had violated the rules by sneaking ice cream from the freezer. The carton had slipped and split open on the floor, making a mess and a noise that my mother investigated.

headline: THE GIFT STAYS PUT
abstract: University of Missouri denies former Enron chairman and chief executive Kenneth L Lay's request to return $1.1 million he donated to his alma mater; Lay says he needs money to help pay legal bills after being convicted of securities fraud in collapse of Enron (S)

headline: Company Decides to Cancel Stock Options of Ex-Chief
abstract: Board of Mercury Interactive Corp, software maker, cancels 2.63 million stock options issued to former chief executive Amnon Landan after company inquiry finds that he manipulated price; McAfee, Intuit and Sanmina-SCI Corp say federal inquiries are being conducted; Apollo Group says it will hire independent firm to review its stock-option grants; California Public Employees' Retirement System demands that 25 companies report whether they backdated stock options grants to executives (M)

headline: Meeting vice and folly with the apt lampoon
Clearly, Greenspanese Isn't His Language
abstract: Edmund Andrews Economic View column compares language and code words used by former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan with recent cautionary message sent by new chairman Ben Bernanke; graph (M)

headline: Blair cabinet wobbles under trio of troubles
Saudis Plan Middle East Financial Center
abstract: Saudi Arabia announces plan to build Middle East financial district in capital of Riyadh and to sell majority stake in its stock exchange Tadawul to investors; changes follow recent decline in value of companies traded on Tadawul (M)

headline: Wall St. Develops the Tools to Invest in Climate Change
abstract: Claudia Deutsch Market Place column on Wall Street's new-found ability to profit by holding shares of companies that control their greenhouse gases and shorting shares of those that do not; focuses on Innovest which, in partnership with UBS, has created 'carbon beta basket' fund that will hold 50 stocks in five industries; fund managers would monitor global warming regulations and buy and sell stocks on basis of how companies would be affected by rules (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,371 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:    WEIKEL, Ian P., 31, Capt., Army; Colorado Springs; Fourth Infantry Division.

headline: Televisa to Enter Bidding for the Spanish-Language Broadcaster Univision
abstract: Grupo Televisa plans to bid for Spanish-language broadcaster Univision along with group of five private investment firms that includes Bill Gates's Cascade Investment; Bain Capital Partners, Blackstone Management Assoc, Carlyle Investment Management and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts; Televisa owns 10.9 percent of Univision; chairman Emilio Azcarraga Jean has expressed strong desire to own more (M)

headline: QVC, a Talent Show for Those Who Dream of Dollars
abstract: Article on home-shopping channel QVC's ability to reach national audience with one live sales pitch, which appeals to small businesses; centralized shipping and virtual store location allow QVC to test out products that traditional retailers might not carry, reach far larger audience than at retail store counters as well as allow small business owners to raise needed capital more quickly; photos (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,495 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:    BABINEAU, David J., 25, Specialist, Army; Springfield, Mass.; 101st Airborne Division.

headline: More Rumblings About Net Privacy
abstract: What's Online column; Kim Zetter, in article in Salon.com, offers details about secret room in AT&T building in Bridgeton, Mo, where government spies reportedly are gaining access to millions of private e-mail messages and other Internet traffic; NewScientist.com says National Security Agency is financing research into harvesting of information that people post about themselves on social networks; MarketWatch media critic Jon Friedman says Mad Money host Jim Cramer crossed line when he used box of Uncle Ben's rice as prop to make point about Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke; Museum of Hoaxes reports that Bio-Genica is selling Genpets, which come in clamshell packaging and look like shrunken monkeys; drawing (M)

headline: North Korea still refusing to return to nuclear arms talks
Sent on its way, Iraqi police convoy is ambushed
Dell Lowers Forecast for Quarter
abstract: Dell warned yesterday that its quarterly earnings would be lower than expected, a result of price cuts aimed at stemming the decline in its market share for personal computers.      The company now expects to earn 33 cents a share, including 3 cents a share in stock option expenses, in the quarter ended April 30, down from a forecast almost three months ago of 36 cents to 38 cents a share. It also said yesterday that revenue would be about $14.2 billion, at the low end of its previous forecast of 6 percent to 8 percent growth.

headline: Alltel to Offer Free-Calling Plan, With Limits
abstract: Alltel mobile phone company announces new service plan, first among major carriers, that lets customers make free calls to any 10 numbers regardless of cellphone or land-line carrier of person being called; photo (M)

headline: The Fickle, the Loyal and Howard Stern
abstract: Just under a third of Howard Stern's once-regular listeners have bought, or plan to buy, access to Sirius Satellite Radio, according to a survey of people who listened to Mr. Stern on terrestrial radio. Another 37 percent now listen to the replacement morning shows on Mr. Stern's old stations. And a third have migrated to other stations, according to Jacobs Media, a radio consultancy.     The survey was conducted by e-mail in 20 different markets. Because the 3,300 respondents selected themselves by clicking on an e-mail link, the survey is not statistically rigorous, but it provides a rough early look at how some stations fared after Mr. Stern's January departure.

headline: Agreement by Poland averts clash
Deadline planned for Ulster
The Math Whiz vs. the Media Moguls in a Battle for Millions
abstract: Amid the flash of the Internet bubble, Henry C. Yuen, the chairman and chief executive of Gemstar-TV Guide International, did things his way.      Despite running a company worth more than $20 billion in early 2000 and being partners with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, he operated out of low-rent offices in Pasadena, Calif. A visitor to the headquarters recalls that using a fax machine required unplugging the telephone because there was only one line. A former Gemstar employee recalled Mr. Yuen driving to lunch four blocks from the office, but then parking two blocks away to avoid paying a valet charge.

headline: Global Image of the U.S. Is Worsening, Survey Finds
abstract: As the war in Iraq continues for a fourth year, the global image of America has slipped further, even among people in some countries closely allied with the United States, a new opinion poll has found.      Favorable views of the United States dropped sharply over the past year in Spain, where only 23 percent said they had a positive opinion, down from 41 percent last year, according to the survey. It was done in 15 nations, including the United States, this spring by the Washington-based Pew Research Center.

headline: Pakistan says strike killed Qaeda figure in '98 attacks
Currencies: Russian's comments send dollar lower
World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Lenovo Posts a Loss
abstract: Lenovo Group says fiscal fourth-quarter net loss was 903 million Hong Kong dollars ($116 million), compared with profit of 166 million Hong Kong dollars year earlier; says sales rose to 24.4 billion Hong Kong dollars, from 4.71 billion year earlier (S)

headline: Boycott Threat Roils Guantánamo Hearing
abstract: The Pentagon's effort to move forward with military commission trials for people suspected of being terrorists took another chaotic turn on Wednesday when a Canadian teenager accused of murdering an American soldier in Afghanistan threatened to boycott the proceedings.     From the start of a preliminary hearing on Wednesday morning, the chief military lawyer for the defendant, Omar Ahmed Khadr, 19, clashed repeatedly with the presiding officer over rules for the commissions, the first such tribunals since World War II.

headline: Sri Lankan Military Attacks Rebels in Response to Fatal Bus Blast
abstract: The Sri Lankan military pounded rebel posts in the northern and eastern parts of the country by land, sea and air on Thursday, independent monitors and guerrilla officials said, after a land mine explosion ripped through a crowded passenger bus on Thursday morning in northern Sri Lanka.     [The bombings continued Friday morning, Reuters reported, when jets dropped five bombs on rebel headquarters at Kilinochchi.]

headline: Nuclear Monitor Says Iran Fails to Provide Data
abstract: As Iran weighs how to respond to an international package of incentives intended to curb its nuclear activities, the chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency on Monday faulted Iran for failing to provide information crucial to understanding fully the nature and intent of its nuclear program.     In prepared remarks in Vienna opening the agency's 35-country board meeting, Mohamed ElBaradei, the director general, said his agency ''has not made much progress in resolving outstanding verification issues.'' He added, ''I would continue to urge Iran to provide the cooperation needed to resolve these issues.''

headline: Recycling a Big Urban Navy Yard
abstract: Philadelphia's Navy Yard creates challenge for developers and commercial real estate firms due to downtown area's 12 percent vacancy rate and site's isolation; retailer Urban Outfitters will move all 650 of its employees into Navy Yard; developers hope high-profile anchor tenant's $50 million renovation of four historic buildings will attract further development at 1,000-acre site; photos; map (M)

headline: Oil Drilling Company Loses Twice in One Day in Congress
abstract: Senate Finance Committee votes unanimously to treat as American all companies that made Bermuda or any other tax haven their tax headquarters after March 20, 2002; House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee rejects language that would have allowed Nabors Industries to continue operating 33 ships servicing offshore oil rigs and platforms under temporary exemption to Jones Act, 1920 national security law (M)

headline: G.M., Lucent and CBS Tackle Some Problems
