abstract: Mark Stein Five Days column; General Motors sold majority stake in its General Motors Acceptance Corp for $7.4 billion immediately, with $10 billion expected by closing and total of $14 billion over three years; Apple Computer released software called Boot Camp that will let its Macintosh computers use dominant Windows operating system as well as Apple's own OS X operating system; Lucent Technologies agreed to be acquired by Alcatel in $13.4 billion merger; Katie Couric agreed to become primary anchor for CBS Evening News; Verizon Communications agreed to sell three Caribbean and Latin American businesses to two related Mexican phone companies for total of $3.7 billion; pilots at Delta Air Lines voted overwhelmingly to authorize strike if airline follows through with plans to invalidate its contract with their union and impose up to $325 million in pay and benefit cuts, including further 18 percent wage reduction; Merck & Co lost second lawsuit related to its drug Vioxx, when New Jersey jury found that company had not apparently warned people that drug increased chances of having heart attack when taken for more than 18 months; jury awarded John McDarby $3 million and his wife Irma another $1.5 million (M)

headline: Briefly: Supply convoy arrives in the deprived capital
World Briefing | Europe: France: Car Rams Protesters
abstract: Motorist drives into students demonstrating in Paris against France's new labor law, injuring 12; police say he seemed to hit students on purpose (S)

headline: Cablevision to Offer Flat Rates for International Phone Calling
abstract: Cablevision will announce flat-rate plan for international calls; customers will be able to buy 500 minutes of calls to any country overseas for $19.95 each month (M)

headline: From Jump Shots to Journalism
abstract: What's Online column; Mark Cuban launches Sharesleuth investigative journalism Web site focusing on corporate corruption and securities fraud; business reporter Christopher Carey will run site; faces criticism for his plan to use site to make personal investment decisions; site may offer glimpse of future of journalism; Steve Lovelady, on Columbia Journalism Review's blog, questions Time Inc's decision to pay $4 million dollars for photos of celebrity baby after firing investigative reporters Donald Bartlett and James Steele; Vincent Ferrari posts taped conversation with AOL customer service representative on his blog at insignificantthoughts.com; recording shows difficulty in trying to cancel account; drawing (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: J. P. Morgan Chase to Pay $425 Million To Settle Suit Over Offerings During Boom  J. P. Morgan Chase said that it would pay $425 million to settle its part of a class-action lawsuit that contends that dozens of banks cheated investors out of hundreds of millions of dollars from initial public offerings during the market boom of the 1990's. [Page C1.]    Questions on Proxy Adviser's Pfizer Recommendation  Proxy Governance Inc. recently urged its investor customers to vote for all 13 of Pfizer's directors. A memo written in 2004 by Pfizer's chief executive, Hank McKinnell, urging corporations to buy and promote Proxy Governance's services just as the firm was opening for business, raises questions about whether the advisory firm's recommendation reflects an unbiased point of view or a relationship with the company and its top executive. [C1.]    Alltel Announces Service Plan With Some Free Calls  Alltel, the cellphone company, announced a new service plan that lets customers make free calls to any 10 numbers regardless of the cellphone or land-line carrier of the person being called. The ''My Circle'' plan, a first among major carriers, is premised on statistics that show that many consumers make most of their calls to about half a dozen numbers. Alltel expects that if customers can call these numbers free, they will have more minutes left over to call other people. [C9.]    Google Reports Profit Gain of 60% in First Quarter  Google returned to favor among investors, as its profit for the quarter increased by 60 percent, well above expectations. Its shares, which rose in regular trading, climbed higher after hours, when the results were released. [C1.]    General Motors said it sharply reduced its loss during the first quarter -- a breakthrough for a company battered by accounting missteps and doubts about the future of its chief executive and of the automaker itself. [C3.]    Merck, Eli Lilly and Schering-Plough reported higher first-quarter earnings as sales rose for drugs to treat cholesterol, depression and cancer. [C5.]    Nokia, the cellphone maker, said that its first-quarter profit rose 21 percent from a year earlier as sales surged in North America and Asia. [C5.]    Earnings Reports Help Dow as Nasdaq Drops  Stocks closed mixed. Helped by earnings reports from Merck and G.M., the Dow rose 64.12 points, to 11,342.89, its best showing since it closed at 11,351.30 on Jan. 20, 2000. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.53 points, to 1,311.46, and the Nasdaq fell 8.33 points, to 2,362.55. [C7.]    Democrats Putting Spotlight on High Gas Prices  Democrats running for Congress are moving quickly to use the most recent surge in oil and gasoline prices to bash Republicans over energy policy, and more broadly, the direction of the country. [A1.]    Signs of Tougher Stance on Illegal Immigrants  The apprehension of more than 1,100 illegal immigrants employed by a pallet supply company based in Houston, as well as the arrest of seven of its managers, represented the start of a more aggressive crackdown on employers, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said. [A1.]    A Complex View of Former Enron Executive  The portrait of Jeffrey K. Skilling, former chief of Enron, that emerged in his criminal fraud trial was more complex than the caricature frequently drawn of him as a greedy, arrogant executive. Instead, Mr. Skilling showed himself to be a vulnerable, emotional, even affable character. But jurors also saw a man who did not like to be questioned or told he was wrong. [C1.]    Volkswagen Chairman Says Chief Is Likely to Stay  The chairman of Volkswagen's supervisory board, Ferdinand K. Piëch, said that he expected the embattled chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, to win a contract extension. That was a remarkable change in tone from February, when Mr. Piëch threw Mr. Pischetsrieder's future into doubt by suggesting that he had lost the support of Volkswagen's employees. [C7.]    Roth May Be Replaced as Morning Radio Host  CBS Radio and XM Satellite Radio are in talks to replace David Lee Roth, left, the morning host on seven CBS stations, with Opie and Anthony, the foulmouthed talk team that has been the marquee talent on XM for the last 18 months, according to executives at both companies. Under the deal, Opie and Anthony would do a cleaner version of their usual show -- one acceptable under broadcast standards -- for the CBS audience for three hours each weekday. That portion of the show would also be heard on XM. After that show, the two hosts would do two additional hours of the show, unrestrained. [C7.]    Housekeepers Protest as Hotels Bulk Up on Amenities  Housekeepers at the nation's hotels say that bigger beds and more pillows in rooms are creating more work and increasing the risk of injuries. The hotel workers' union says the issue will be a major factor in negotiations this spring with Hilton, Starwood and other hotel chains. [A20.]    F.C.C. Steps Up Inquiry Into Radio Stations  The Federal Communications Commission intensified its investigation into accusations of pay-for-play practices at four of the nation's biggest radio station owners after settlement talks collapsed, agency officials said. [C5.]    Shell Says Repairs in Gulf Were Completed Early  Royal Dutch Shell said that it had completed repairs on its Mars platform in the Gulf of Mexico and would resume production ahead of schedule. [C5.]

headline: International Business: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Boeing Plans Titanium Venture
abstract: Boeing Co plans joint venture with Vsmpo-Avisma to secure access to titanium amid record demand for production of commercial jets from airlines in Asia and Middle East (S)

headline: Goldman Doubles Its Profit
abstract: Goldman Sachs more than doubled its second-quarter profit from a year ago, fueled by strong results in each of its divisions, the company said yesterday.      Like Lehman Brothers a day earlier, when it too reported strong earnings, Goldman failed to impress Wall Street with its good results and its stock fell nearly 4 percent.

headline: Nepal's capital faces shortages as strike continues
Goldman questioned over role in takeovers
Surf Securely, Carrying Privacy in Your Pocket
abstract: Stealth Ideas introduces StealthSurfer II ID Protect, specialized flash drive that lets users navigate Web anonymously and create e-mail that cannot be read by others; photo (S)

headline: On the Internet Trail of a Fine Formal Shirt
abstract: Tracie Rozhon The Thrifty Millionaire column on Internet search for tailor-made men's formal shirt; photo (M)

headline: Delaware Justices Uphold Ruling on Disney Severance
abstract: Delaware Supreme Court upholds Delaware Court of Chancery decision exonerating Walt Disney Co board and two former executives of charges in shareholder lawsuit that they neglected their duties and wasted company assets; at issue was hiring of Michael Ovitz and his ouster 14 months later with $130 million severance package, both engineered by chief executive Michael Eisner (M)

headline: U.S. and Iran Take Tough Stances in Standoff
abstract: American and Iranian leaders today staked out unyielding positions over Iran's nuclear program.

headline: For a Few Tech Stars, Time for a Second Act
abstract: Article on how mutual fund managers Ryan Jacob, Malcolm R Fobes III and Robert Zuccaro, who were tech stars during late 1990's, are doing now; says Jacob's Internet fund has posted annual return of 47 percent during last three years, putting fund in top 1 percent of all tech funds; holds Fobes's fund Berkshire Focus is down 9 percent, annualized, in last five years, putting it in bottom tenth of such funds; says Zuccaro closed his Grand Prix fund at end of last year; photo (M)

headline: Where Rockets Exit, Shells Enter and Houses Are Ruined
abstract: The Abu Odeh family was finishing Saturday lunch when there was a screaming across the sky.     ''Suddenly there was a huge explosion,'' said Intisar Abu Odeh, the family matriarch. ''The dishes flew and the television jumped in the air.''

headline: Army Cancels Contract for Iraqi Prison
abstract: The Army Corps of Engineers said Monday that it had canceled a $99.1 million contract with Parsons, one of the largest companies working in Iraq, to build a prison north of Baghdad after the firm fell more than two years behind schedule, threatened to go millions of dollars over budget and essentially abandoned the construction site.     The move is another harsh rebuke for Parsons, only weeks after the corps canceled more than $300 million of the company's contracts to build and refurbish hospitals and clinics across Iraq. A federal oversight office had found that some of the clinics were little more than empty shells and that only 20 of 150 called for in the contract would be completed without new financing.

headline: Cisco's Revenue Surpasses Forecast, but Earnings Slip
abstract: Cisco Systems says third-quarter revenue rose by 18 percent, to $7.32 billion, compared with $6.19 billion year earlier; says net income dropped slightly to $1.4 billion, compared with $1.41 billion in same quarter last year (M)

headline: Today In Business | Judge Blocks Sale Of Varig
abstract: Brazilian Bankruptcy Judge Luis Roberto Ayoub cancels proposed sale of bankrupt airline Varig to group of employees after bidder fails to make $75 million down payment (S)

headline: Early Results Show Italian Election Is Too Close to Call
abstract: Projections showed Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi winning the upper chamber of parliament and in a tight race for the lower chamber.

headline: To Revitalize a City, Try Spreading Some Mulch
abstract: Chicago becomes global model for how metropolis can pursue environmental goals to achieve economic success; city has excelled in virtually every conventional category of civic well-being during last decade, and much of credit belongs to sophisticated understanding of benefits of conserving resources, saving energy, expanding parks, constructing environmentally sensitive buildings, reducing amount of storm water, restoring wetlands, generating renewable energy and doing everything feasible to heal instead of harm city's natural systems; photos (M)

headline: Prodi Confident of Victory as Italy Recounts Votes
abstract: The leader of the center-left coalition said he expected that the provisional results would stand.

headline: South Korea warns Japan to stay away from islets
Lebanon Seeks Way to Disarm Palestinian Militia Groups
abstract: The radical Palestinian militiamen operating a checkpoint here south of Beirut seemed to be from another era, vestiges of the bloody civil war in the 1970's and 80's.      But two days after missiles flew from southern Lebanon into northern Israel, prompting Israeli warplanes to pound local camps in the worst cross-border fighting in years, they were also something else: a challenge to the Lebanese government.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Farewell To German Politics
abstract: Joschka Fischer, the foreign minister under Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, said he was giving up his seat in Parliament to become a visiting professor at Princeton University, teaching international crisis management in September, and join the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.   VICTOR HOMOLA (NYT)

headline: White House Letter: New chief with broom gives staff the jitters
Thai Premier Quits His Post, Ending Turmoil
abstract: Thaksin Shinawatra, a billionaire turned populist politician, said Tuesday that he would step down as Thailand's prime minister, ending five years of increasingly tumultuous rule and breaking a political stalemate over demands for his resignation that had gripped the country for the past two months.     It was a sudden reversal for Mr. Thaksin, who a day earlier had claimed victory in national elections held Sunday that had been boycotted by opposition parties.

headline: AS GAS PRICES RISE, SALES OF S.U.V.'S DROP
abstract: Americans shied away from large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks in April as gas prices approached $3 a gallon. With a battery of new S.U.V.'s waiting in the wings, domestic automakers are now confronting the very situation that they had hoped to avoid. Page C3.

headline: Delays in an Effort to Avoid Delays
abstract: Registered Traveler program, which promises to help frequent fliers pass through airport security faster if they pay annual membership fee and undergo background check, has been pulled aside for secondary inspection before its scheduled introduction in June; many corporate travel managers say they remain concerned about crucial issues; program is expected to start expanding next month beyond Orlando, only airport where it is currently operating, to as many as 20 other airports by end of year; travel managers' concerns include potential effects on career of employee who for one reason or another is rejected during federal background check; program at Orlando International Airport has been operated since last July by Verified Identity Pass; photo (M)

headline: Inflation Stirs Worry on Wall St.
abstract: Stock prices fell sharply and broadly yesterday as investors worried that rising oil prices would quicken the pace of inflation and force policy makers to raise interest rates further.     The abrupt drop, which was the largest since January, came after several days of modest but steady increases in the Dow Jones industrial average, which as recently as Wednesday was within 80 points of its record high. It also came a day after the Federal Reserve indicated that it was ambiguous about whether it would raise rates later this year.

headline: Jury Award Is Big Disappointment for Merck
abstract: Merck was found liable today for the death of a man who had a fatal heart attack within a month of taking Vioxx.

headline: China Raises Lending Rate to Slow Booming Economy
abstract: China's central bank today raised official borrowing costs for the first time in a year and a half, trying to slow a spectacular surge in lending and investment.

headline: Top Australian official testifies in Iraq oil case
China, Citing Corruption, Fires Olympic Building Chief
abstract: A senior Beijing official responsible for overseeing construction projects for the 2008 Olympics was dismissed from his post for corruption, the state news media said Monday.     The official, Liu Zhihua, a vice mayor of Beijing and the chief director of the Beijing 2008 Project Construction Headquarters Office, the agency that supervises the city's massive Olympics-related makeover, is likely to face prosecution and be stripped of his membership in the ruling Communist Party.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: INVESTORS SHUN RISK -- The terms differ slightly -- a nervous sell-off, a correction, the beginnings of a bear market. But as markets from India to Brazil to the United States skidded last week, there was little doubt that investors were dumping risk from their portfolios. The question is whether investors feel comfortable with the risk they have left. [C1.]    BIG DOUBLE BILL -- The Nasdaq Tower, left, and the Reuters sign in Times Square are two of the most valuable advertising spaces in the world. Now, with a deal to be announced today, advertisers can rent both spaces at once -- and create a virtual roadblock on the south side of the square. It is a partnership that the two companies hope will leverage both ad spaces to stand out in a sea of advertising. [C10.]    BEATING PEOPLE TO THE PUNCH -- After People magazine won the very expensive rights to the first photographs of Shiloh Nouvel Jolie-Pitt and before they were published, they appeared on gossip blogs and other Web sites. [C1.]    FOX'S MOVIE STRATEGY -- For the year to date, Fox is No. 1 in move theater market share. At the same time, it has fostered a corporate culture that its parent company, the News Corporation, seeks in all its television, news and mobile entertainment divisions: eyes fixed on the bottom line while remaining fearless about creative risks. [C1.]    BOOKS AND PRODUCT PLACEMENT -- Procter & Gamble has made a deal to help market a novel for teenagers called ''Cathy's Book.'' [C1.]    SUPPORT FOR LAW FIRM -- The embattled securities class-action law firm Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman is receiving some political backing with the release of a statement signed by four Democrats from the House of Representatives condemning last month's indictment of the law firm on criminal charges. [C10.]    IRE OVER E-MAIL TAX -- A French member of the European Parliament, Alain Lamassoure, recently uttered the dreaded T-word -- taxes -- in connection with e-mail and mobile-phone text messages, and in so doing earned the wrath of the Internet generation. [C9.]    NOT CHOCOLATE, BUT CAMERAS -- With the installation of new souped-up automated kiosks in three shopping malls this week, Sony hopes to make the purchase of many of its electronics products as easy as buying a piece of chocolate. [C9.]    INTERNET AND OLDER SHOPPERS -- Older consumers, who generally sat out the Internet's first big commercial push, are helping to feed the surging Web economy. And because this group has far more disposable cash than any other, executives who have not already begun tweaking their strategies to reach them will probably do so soon, online analysts and executives say. Philip Charles-Pierre, above, a Travelocity executive, said a program aimed at AARP Passport members has helped the company tap into an increasingly affluent market. [C8.]    DIGITAL REGRETS -- So many years into the digital revolution, even those with presumably the highest levels of computer expertise seem to get caught up and embarrassed by their ''digital trail'' -- that wide wake we tend to leave as we transact an electronically mediated life. Tom Zeller Jr.: Link by Link. [C5.]    ONLINE    WIRELESS LIVING -- Communities around the country getting into the telecommunications business, wireless gambling, simple fixes for Wi-Fi woes, Internet calling without a laptop and more. A special report is at nytimes.com/technology.    THE CLASSICS -- Previous columns from Gretchen Morgenson, Joe Nocera and Floyd Norris can be found at select.nytimes.com/pages/timesselect.    YOUR MONEY -- Look ahead at the news that will affect your finances with ''Your Money,'' a free weekly newsletter. It can be found at nytimes.com/yourmoney.    THE WALK-THROUGH BLOG -- Writers for The New York Times look at residential real estate news, trends and tidbits at nytimes.com/walkthrough.

headline: Governing Party Wins Thai Vote Its Major Rivals Refused to Join
abstract: The party of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra won a landslide victory in Thailand's national election on Sunday, early results showed, though the voting was marred by the refusal of the main opposition parties to participate.     With candidates from the governing party unopposed in 278 of 400 constituencies for the lower house of Parliament, or nearly 70 percent, Mr. Thaksin's majority is expected to be overwhelming, but the outcome is unlikely to resolve the political impasse that has gripped the country for two months.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,348 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    GARDNER, James W., 22, Specialist, Army; Glasgow, Ky.; 101st Airborne Division.    LOVE, Joseph I., 22, Pfc., Army; North Pole, Alaska; 94th Engineer Combat Battalion, Eighth Sustainment Command.    MISSILDINE, Jody W., 19, Pvt., Army; Plant City, Fla.; First Armored Division.    NAVARROARELLANO, Juana, 24, Lance Cpl., Marines; Ceres, Calif.; Ninth Engineer Support Battalion, Third Marine Logistics Group, Third Marine Expeditionary Force.    TAYLOR, Bryan N., 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Milford, Ohio; Second Marine Division.    WALLER, Richard P., 22, Cpl., Marines; Fort Worth; First Battalion, First Marines, First Marine Expeditionary Force.

headline: In Iraq, a zone of hedonism and safety
For leadership, an aging Italy overlooks young
Shanghai Club, Once Obscure, Now Attracts Wide Interest
abstract: Five years after its founding as an obscure regional organization with a nondescript name, the Shanghai Cooperation Organization opened its annual gathering here on Thursday in an unaccustomed flush of interest from nations eager to join.     The growing attention paid to the six-member organization, which groups China, Russia and four of their central Asian neighbors, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan, reflects the expanding power and assertiveness of its two largest members.

headline: Microsoft Fights Europe's Antitrust Ruling on Windows
abstract: Microsoft began its weeklong appeal of the European Union's decision to require the company to provide Windows software without a built-in video and music player.

headline: France Debates Downloads, With Teenager as Top Expert
abstract: In the current debate over laws governing music downloads here, some condemn Aziz Ridouan as an advocate of criminal piracy, while others say he represents the new generation of online consumers.      In either case, just about everyone involved listens to what Mr. Ridouan, an 18-year-old high school student, has to say.

headline: Hyundai's plans for glory stumble over an investigation
Jailed Sudanese Refugees Pose a Moral Puzzle for Israel
abstract: Israel sees itself as both a refuge for Jews fleeing persecution and a light unto nations. So when it was disclosed here that 200 Sudanese, many fleeing the bloodshed of the Darfur region, had found their way to Israel only to be locked up in prison, controversy ensued.     The government says that because Sudan is on the American State Department's list of terrorist countries, it fears that terrorists could be lurking among the Sudanese here. But human rights groups have challenged the detentions in court, and now some of Israel's most loyal supporters are saying the policy is wrong because it allows fear to overwhelm moral obligation.

headline: Awaiting Chinese president in U.S. is unavoidable topic: Oil
World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Cardinal Backs Condom Use As 'Lesser Evil' To Aids
abstract: Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, retired archbishop of Milan, challenges official Vatican policy by saying Catholics could be justified in using condoms to prevent spread of AIDS; his photo (S)

headline: An 'Extra' Takes Shape in a Flash
abstract: Houston Chronicle quickly publishes 'extra' edition at 2 PM on May 25 to proclaim that former Enron chief executives Kenneth Lay and Jeffrey Skilling are found guilty; 10,000-copy two-page edition roll off presses by 1:30 PM; employees pull stacks of papers off newsstands in downtown area and wrap them with special; others hawk papers to swarm of reporters and spectators assembled in front of courthouse just as Lay left courthouse (M)

headline: In South Africa, Star Telescope Could Stir Young Scholars
abstract: Really good astronomy requires three things: a really dark sky, a really powerful telescope and really talented scientists. The nighttime sky here, in this desolate, brush-strewn desert called the Karoo, makes metaphors about coal mines at midnight seem pallid.      But the last time a telescope in these parts was really powerful was during World War II -- until now.

headline: Genital Cutting Raises by 50% Likelihood Mothers or Their Newborns Will Die, Study Finds
abstract: The first large medical study of female genital cutting has found that the procedure has deadly consequences when the women give birth, raising by more than 50 percent the likelihood that the woman or her baby will die.     Rates of serious medical complications surrounding childbirth, such as bleeding, also rose substantially in women who had undergone genital cutting, according to new research being published today in The Lancet, a British medical journal.

headline: Skip the Sitter, and Feed Your Virtual Pet by Cellphone
abstract: MTV Networks plans to introduce cellphone-based version of its Neopets Web site, which lets users adopt, feed and nurture virtual pets and do battle with cartoonish creatures; 10 million to 13 million people, many of them children, play Web version of Neopets each month; mobile phone version will cost $3 per month; photo (M)

headline: Error Disrupts Bond Trading in Japan
abstract: Computer error by employee at Japan Bond Trading cripples trading in Japanese government's bond market for more than two hours, raising new concerns about ability of country to handle its role as Asia's largest and most sophisticated financial market; incident highlights failure of Japanese financial companies and exchanges to make timely upgrades of outdated computer systems (M)

headline: Spotlight: Wealth management with a family theme
Briefing: Immigrants an 'elixir' for U.K.
Europe's Image Clashes With Reliance on Coal
abstract: In the shadow of two hulking boilers, which spew 10 million tons of carbon dioxide a year into the air, the Swedish owners of this coal-fired power station recently broke ground on what is to be the world's first carbon-free plant fueled by coal. The German chancellor, Angela Merkel, presided over the ceremony.     ''We accept the problem of climate change,'' said Reinhardt Hassa, a senior executive at Vattenfall, which operates the plant. ''If we want a future for coal, we have to adopt new technologies. It is not enough just to make incremental improvements.''

headline: Craft Nears Venus to Seek Global Warming Clues
abstract: After getting little attention for more than a decade, Venus is about to receive a visiting spacecraft from Earth designed to investigate its dense, hot atmosphere for clues about runaway global warming that may shed light on potential changes here.     Venus Express, the first mission by the European Space Agency to Earth's nearest neighbor, is set to go into orbit around the second planet from the Sun early on Tuesday.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: U.N. Threat To Scale Back Ethiopia-Eritrea Border Force
abstract: The United Nations Security Council warned that it would scale back the peacekeeping mission on the disputed Eritrean-Ethiopian border if the countries did not accept a boundary decided in a 2000 peace agreement and if Eritrea did not lift a ban on helicopter flights and other restrictions on the movements of the 3,300-member force. The resolution, passed unanimously, extended the mission's mandate only to May 15, when a review will decide its future.   WARREN HOGE (NYT)

headline: Pastoral Site of Historic Inventions Faces the End
abstract: Lucent Technologies Bell Labs building in Holmdel, NJ, will be demolished after being site of technology inventions for 44 years; Preferred Real Estate Investments will maintain site as office space but will have to tear down building to make use of property designed for scientists but unappealing to other types of office workers; chief executive Michael G O'Neill promises community that his development company will keep surrounding property as pastoral as possible; photo (M)

headline: Out Sick for the Enron Trial, and Rethinking It
abstract: It started with what felt like a heart attack.     Just minutes after he had cross-examined Enron's former chief financial officer two months ago, Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, turned to one of Mr. Lay's daughters. ''I think I just had a heart attack,'' he half-jokingly told the daughter, Elizabeth Vittor, looking her in the eye across the defense table.

headline: Teva Gains on Approval of Cholesterol Drug
abstract: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries wins tentative regulatory approval to sell generic copies of Merck & Company's cholesterol drug Zocor; best-selling drug had $4.3 billion sales in 2005 (M)

headline: UN cuts Darfur food aid as donations trickle away
Iran Promises $50 Million in Aid for Palestinian Government
abstract: Iran said Sunday that it would give $50 million in aid to the Hamas-led Palestinian government after the United States and the European Union froze financing.      Iran's foreign minister, Manouchehr Mottaki, announced the donation on the last day of a pro-Palestinian conference.

headline: Chad breaks off diplomatic relations with Sudan
As DVD Sales Slow, Hollywood Hunts for a New Cash Cow
abstract: After more than half a decade as Hollywood's savior, the DVD is looking a little tired -- and the movie studios, for once, are having trouble coming up with a sequel.      DVD sales represent more than half of the revenue studios generate from most of their movies. But those sales are expected to grow just 2 percent this year, a far cry from the double-digit growth the industry enjoyed just two years ago. High-definition DVD's were supposed to pick up the slack, but technical delays and a thorny format war between camps led by Sony and Toshiba have dampened expectations.

headline: Snakes in the Garage Provide Easy Hookups for the Band
abstract: LightSnake from SoundTech is single cable with standard USB port on one end and audio jack on other; serves as input device on Windows and Macintosh computers for electric instruments; features digital sound processing; requires no additional software; costs $70; photo (M)

headline: Israel Is Open to European Plan for Aid to Palestinians
abstract: Israel said Wednesday that it could accept a new and temporary mechanism to deliver aid to the Palestinians so long as the money did not reach Hamas and that Israel was prepared to hand over some of the tax revenues it collected for the Palestinians if the money went to humanitarian ends.     Meeting in New York on Tuesday, representatives of the United States, the European Union, Russia and the United Nations -- the so-called quartet involved in Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts -- agreed to a European plan to establish a temporary financial structure that would allow aid to go to Palestinians directly without passing through the Palestinian Authority.

headline: In Major Projects, Agreeing Not to Disagree
abstract: Developers are increasingly working with neighborhood groups to forge so-called community benefits agreements in order to gain approval for major projects; deals usually contain wage and hiring goals as well as other concessions to quiet opposition; critics in New York City, where agreements are not tied to city contracts, are concerned trend may distort planning process when groups seek concessions that are unrelated to impact on neighborhoods; photo (M)

headline: Oracle to buy software maker
Spinoff at Alberto-Culver
abstract: Alberto-Culver says it will split off Sally Beauty, beauty supply distribution business, and that Clayton Dubilier & Rice will pay at least $575 million for 47.5 percent stake in new business (S)

headline: Public Housing in Private Hands
abstract: Ingolf Rossberg is the mayor of this majestic eastern German city. But watching him stride around his ballroom-size office, wreathed in smoke from his cigarillo, one could mistake him for a European real estate tycoon.     Yet he is that after a fashion. Mr. Rossberg reached a deal in March to sell Dresden's entire stock of 48,000 city-owned apartments to an American private equity firm, the Fortress Investment Group, for $1.2 billion. In a single stroke, Dresden wiped out its burdensome public debt.

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS: ONLINE
abstract: RELIANCE INDUSTRIES, a major energy company in India, said it would expand into retailing there, selling goods like food, clothes and home furnishings.    SARITHA RAI (NYT)

headline: Google Posts 60% Gain in Earnings
abstract: Google returned to favor among investors yesterday as its profit for the first quarter increased 60 percent, well above expectations.     Three months ago, the company disappointed investors, even though its profit grew 82 percent, and its stock sagged. This time, Google's ascent was enough to satisfy.

headline: Trans-Atlantic or Bust? Hardly. Make That a Boom.
abstract: Joe Sharkey On The Road column discusses thriving trans-Atlantic business-class airline markets; United States airlines are planning major upgrades to international business-class cabins to compete with foreign competitors; new low-fare all business-class airlines like Eos and MaxJet perform well as alternatives for travelers who want to spend less than average $5,000 to $9,000 fares; drawing (M)

headline: For Canadian online pharmacies, a bitter pill
Study Finds No Cancer Link to Sweetener
abstract: Study conducted by National Cancer Institute finds no link between consumption of aspartame and elevated risks of brain cancer and blood-related cancers like leukemia; study examined aspartame consumptio among about 567,000 people from ages 50 to 69; Calorie Control Council and American Beverage Assn, which represent beverage companies, hail study as further evidence that aspartame is safe food additive; photo (M)

headline: Ring Tones Acquire Some Classical Tastes
abstract: Many older consumers are personalizing their cellphones using snippets of classical music; part of reason for older people's slowness toward personalizing ring tones is that selection has been limited, but that is changing; drawing (M)

headline: Verizon to sell offLatin units
Reader Responses
abstract: The following are excerpts of readers responses to David Leonhardts June 21 column on hybrid cars and energy policy:     An important aspect of the hybrid tax credit that you do not mention is that anyone who is subject to the alternative minimum tax (A.M.T.) will lose the credit. The credit is available only to taxpayers who pay regular tax. This is particularly important for those people who live in high-tax states such as NY and CA.

headline: British Judge Allows Apple to Keep Logo on iTunes
abstract: British High Court Justice Edward Mann, rejecting claims of Apple Corps, gives Apple Computer right to keep its logo on its iTunes digital music store; says Apple Corps, guardian of Beatles' musical interests, failed to prove that use of Apple Computer's logo for iTunes infringed on 1991 agreement in which companies agreed to stay out of each other's businesses; photo (M)

headline: Veteran Revolutionary Trapped in the Halls of Power
abstract: The long corridors of the Philippine Congress building were dark and empty one recent evening as an elegant gray-haired woman walked toward a lighted room, carrying a bottle of red wine and a treat of grilled pigs' ears.     Security guards sat at a little table playing chess. Inside wearing a bright red T-shirt was her husband, Satur Ocampo, a congressman and arguably the most charismatic Communist revolutionary in the country.

headline: EU moves to restrict golden shares
Bernanke Talks Tough on Inflation
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned Monday that recent inflation trends were ''unwelcome developments,'' indicating that he was far less worried about signs of weaker economic growth than about the danger of higher prices.      In his toughest comments yet about the risks of inflation, Mr. Bernanke said consumer prices were rising faster than he would like. He gave short shrift to evidence of a slowdown in hiring, and he conspicuously avoided repeating his earlier suggestion that the Fed might consider a ''pause'' in its two-year program of steady interest rate increases.

headline: Video Games Struggle to Find the Next Level
abstract: Video games have used dialogue from movie stars, rappers and athletes, but Army of Two may be the first to incorporate a presidential speech.      The game, which is being produced here in a downtown loft by EA Montreal, a development studio for Electronic Arts, will prominently feature a recording of President Dwight D. Eisenhower's farewell address, in which he warned about the influence of the military-industrial complex.

headline: U.S.A. Is No. 1, on London List of Traffic Fees
abstract: As contests go, it may be one the United States would be happy to lose.     But right now, the United States leads the list of countries whose diplomats here have repeatedly failed to pay the $14 congestion charge levied on motorists entering an area of central London that includes Grosvenor Square, where the American Embassy is situated, according to figures released late last week. The charge is an effort to reduce weekday traffic and encourage the use of public transportation.

headline: U.N. Finds New Uranium Traces in Iran
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors find traces of highly enriched, but not necessarily bomb-grade, uranium on equipment linked to Iranian military base at Lavizan-Shian; Iran leveled base more than two years ago, stirring suspicions that it had been part of secret nuclear program, but inspectors, starting in 2004, were able to find some equipment linked to base and to examine it for signs of nuclear materials; diplomats say significance of discovery is unclear (M)

headline: Secrecy as a Tool of Government in China
abstract: The trial of a researcher for The New York Times, which is to begin here on Friday, is evidence of China's increasing reliance on state secrecy laws to tighten control over information, experts in human rights and the legal system say.     The researcher, Zhao Yan, 44, who worked in the Beijing bureau of The Times, is charged with fraud and disclosing state secrets. Mr. Zhao denies the charges. The Times also denies that he disclosed state secrets.

headline: I.B.M. Will Triple Investment in India in Next 3 Years
abstract: IBM chairman and chief executive Samuel Palmisano, underlying growing importance of India as market for technology products and source of high-tech workers, says company will triple its investment in India to $6 billion over next three years; announcement comes at annual global showcase in Bangalore that is traditionally held in New York; investment will be used to establish delivery centers, improve automated management of networks and develop telecommunications services; photo (M)

headline: TODAY IN BUSINESS
abstract: FINALLY, A STEEL DEAL -- Arcelor, the steel maker, has agreed to a takeover offer from Mittal Steel, ending a five-month tussle and creating a new global champion. [Page C1.]    BIG-TICKET INTERNET -- With online advertising revenues growing quickly, sites devoted to big-ticket purchases -- particularly cars, real estate and travel -- are refining features and marketing strategies in the hopes that they can attract the growing number of consumers flocking to such sites for buying advice. Bob Brisco, above, the chief executive of Internet Brands, said the sites had become more specific and niche-oriented. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C6.]    A NEW STRATEGY -- For years, advertisers seeking to reach gay and lesbian consumers concentrated their spending in the print media. But that limited media menu is starting to be broadened. TV, the Internet, radio and even movies are joining magazines and newspapers as places to pitch products to gay men and lesbians. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    A SHIFT AT MICROSOFT -- Microsoft plans to offer a strategy on Monday describing how it intends to transform the telecommunications world in much the same way it changed the computing world in the 1980's. Its new approach centers on systems for the workplace that blend desktop computers with office and mobile phones, a combination known as ''unified communications.'' [C6.]    PETS AND GAMES AT MTV -- MTV, a unit of Viacom, plans to introduce a cellphone-based version of its popular Neopets Web site tomorrow. The site, which MTV bought a year ago for $160 million, lets users adopt, feed and nurture their pets and do battle with cartoonish creatures including the catlike Aisha and the dragonlike Scorchio. [C2.]    ACTIVITY, BUT FEW CUSTOMERS -- Despite WiFly's ubiquity in Taiwan -- with 4,100 hot spot access points reaching 90 percent of the population -- just 40,000 of Taipei's 2.6 million residents have agreed to pay for the service since January. That such a vast and reasonably priced wireless network has attracted so few users in an otherwise tech-hungry metropolis should give pause to civic leaders in Chicago, Philadelphia and dozens of other American cities. [C1.]    A NEW RULE AT MSNBC -- Dan Abrams, an on-air anchor who will become the new day-to-day boss of MSNBC, acknowledged that he was still in the learning stages of his new job, his first management job in television. While steering away from suggestions that an overhaul of MSNBC is imminent, he did suggest that he would push right away for more breaking news coverage during the channel's daytime hours. [C1.]

headline: Troop Cuts in Iraq Won't Meet Goal This Year, Officials Say
abstract: Senior administration and military officials now acknowledge that there is little chance the United States can reach the milestone of reducing American troop levels in Iraq to 100,000 by December, a goal that earlier in the year had seemed within reach.     The subject of future troop levels is certain to be an important part of President Bush's two-day war cabinet meeting, which will start Monday at Camp David. Senior American commanders in Iraq will take part by a video link. In preparation, military planners in Iraq and at the Pentagon have been refining troop-rotation proposals that, in the best case, would reduce levels to 110,000 to 120,000 troops by the end of December, from current levels of about 130,000, administration and military officials said.

headline: Louvre Sees Opportunity in 'Da Vinci Code' Film
abstract: From the refuge of their ancient fortress, the guardians of the Louvre have maintained a faintly disdainful distance from the story that transformed the former royal palace into a murder scene for ''The Da Vinci Code.''     But no longer. After the film makes its debut at Cannes on Wednesday, the Louvre will offer its own officially sanctioned Da Vinci Code audio tours, priced at about $13, undercutting private tours that have sprung up around the film. The audio tours, called ''Step Inside the Da Vinci Code,'' can be rented at the museum or bought online through the iTunes Music Store and the Louvre's own Web site.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Pilot Blamed In Death Of Ex-Rebel Leader
abstract: An inquiry into the death of John Garang, the former longtime Sudanese rebel leader, blamed pilot error for the helicopter crash that took his life in heavy rain in July, just three weeks after he became Sudan's vice president. Officials told Reuters that foul play and mechanical error were ruled out. Mr. Garang's death has shaken the fragile peace process under way in the south.    MARC LACEY (NYT)

headline: Pfizer to Buy Rinat, a Biotechnology Drug Maker
abstract: Pfizer said yesterday that it would acquire Rinat Neuroscience, a privately held company developing drugs for pain, Alzheimer's disease and other neurological disorders, to move further into biotechnology.      Terms of the deal were not announced, though Pfizer is believed to be paying several hundred million dollars.

headline: U.S. Death Toll Rises in Iraq After Drop in March
abstract: At least 32 American soldiers have died this month, many in Anbar Province, the heart of the Sunni Arab insurgency.

headline: House Votes to Sharply Curtail Estate Tax
abstract: House, 269 to 156, votes to permanently abolish estate tax on inherited wealth for all but small number of nation's wealthiest families; Senate Republicans concede they cannot line up enough votes to pass full repeal but hope to pass compromise measure; House, 247 to 172, passes measure, unlikely to clear Senate, that would allow president to temporarily block spending on individual provisions without having to veto entire bill (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Deadline For Fugitive's Surrender
abstract: Serbia has pledged that the former military chief Ratko Mladic will surrender to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague this month, the office of the chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, announced. Her spokesman, Anton Nikiforov, said she received the assurances on a visit to President Vojislav Kostunica in Belgrade last week. General Mladic, who is charged with genocide, has been a fugitive from the tribunal for a decade, and his surrender is a condition for talks about Serbian membership in the European Union. News reports have said that General Mladic is seriously ill and in need of treatment.   MARLISE SIMONS (NYT)

headline: U.S. Envoy to Expose 4 Sudanese in U.N. Debate About Darfur
abstract: John R. Bolton, the United States ambassador, said Monday that he intended to offer a Security Council resolution on Tuesday that would publicly identify four Sudanese individuals responsible for atrocities in Darfur and possibly force a vote on whether the panel would impose sanctions on them.     ''We've been pushing sanctions for years, and the effort was always to make it clear to the government in Khartoum that there would be individual consequences,'' Mr. Bolton said in a telephone interview.

headline: Foreign Stocks and the Allure of Double-Digit Growth
abstract: Paul Lim Fundamentally column on short-term risks involved in investing in foreign stocks, whose current allure is double-digit growth; graph (M)

headline: Wen pledges new aid to Pacific countries
Text of Bush's announcement naming Snow as new spokesman
Opening That Wallet for a Bicycle Built for You
abstract: Growing interest in cycling leads to increase of high-end custom bicycles costing as much as $20,000; customers can choose components, paint color and have bicycle built specifically for their body and riding style; Seven Cycles can build custom order that used to take entire year in roughly six weeks; photo (M)

headline: Airbus and China Select Assembly Plant Site
abstract: Airbus and Chinese government select port of Tianjin, near Beijing, as site for assembly plant for A320 narrow-body jets; Airbus says if factory is built, aircraft production would start in 2008 (M)

headline: Qaeda Bomber Is Reported Killed
abstract: Muhsin Musa Matwalli Atwa, senior Al Qaeda figure accused in bombing of US embassies in Africa in 1998, is killed in Pakistani airstrike on compound along Afghan border; US has not yet confirmed report; Atwa is on FBI's most-wanted list with $5 million reward on his head; photo (S)

headline: Putin Reversal on Pipeline Path Affirms His Authority
abstract: Nearly all Russian newspapers lead with President Vladimir V. Putin's dramatic reversal of plans for a major oil pipeline through eastern Siberia.

headline: French Protesters Set Deadline
abstract: Opponents of a controversial labor law said there would be more protests if the government did not act by April 17.

headline: Asian Finance Ministers Seek Common Currency
abstract: Finance Ministers Jin Renqing of China, Sadkazu Tanigaki of Japan and Han Duk Soo of South Korea announce plans to seek common currency similar to euro; unit's value would be determined by index of participating currencies; United States denies that it opposes plan; photo (M)

headline: Apple Extends Deal for 99¢ Downloads
abstract: Apple Computer renews contracts with four largest record companies to continue offering songs for 99 cents each through its iTunes music store; EMI Group, Sony BMG Music Entertainment, Universal Group and Warner Music Group agree to continue partnership; deals are victory for Apple chief executive Steven P Jobs in fight to maintain current pricing levels (M)

headline: Restaurant Associates to Go Private
abstract: Restaurant Associates will become private company under buyout by chief executive Nick Valenti, chef Joachim Aplichal and Shidax Corporation; will allow company to return to roots and develop restaurant properties (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Hariri Investigator Questions Assad
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad met for the first time with Serge Brammertz, the head of the United Nations investigation into the truck-bomb murder of former Prime Minister Rafiq Hariri of Lebanon in Beirut last year. The meeting in Damascus follows allegations made in January by Abdel-Halim Khaddam, the long-serving former vice president of Syria, that Mr. Assad had threatened Mr. Hariri before he was assassinated. No other details of the meeting were provided. Syria has denied any involvement; Mr. Assad had earlier refused requests for an interview.    HASSAN M. FATTAH (NYT)

headline: Japan railway on track to test pollution-free fuel cell
Managing Globalization: Old tax breaks fade in new world
Europe Fails to Agree on 'Safe' Destinations for African Migrants
abstract: As the European Union scrambled to head off a humanitarian crisis caused by a flood of migrants into Spain, European leaders were unable to agree Wednesday on a list of ''safe countries'' to which asylum seekers could be sent.     The problem arose after the European Union announced late Tuesday that it would deploy planes, boats and rapid-reaction aid teams from its member states to deal with a new flood of illegal migrants from Africa trying to reach the Spanish Canary Islands.

headline: To Hire Sharp Employees, Recruit in Sharp Ways
abstract: William Taylor Under New Management column on creative ways corporate recruiters are using to seek and hire new employees; drawing (M)

headline: Skilling's Temper Is Tested in Day 2 Under Fire
abstract: Jeffrey K. Skilling struggled to keep his temper in check on Tuesday, repeatedly accusing a federal prosecutor of not allowing him to answer questions more fully. But Mr. Skilling, one of two former Enron chief executives on trial here, managed to maintain his composure despite a few close calls during his second day of cross-examination.     The prosecutor, Sean M. Berkowitz, continued to pick away at the credibility of Mr. Skilling, who is accused of conspiring to defraud investors in Enron before it collapsed spectacularly in December 2001. Mr. Berkowitz pressed Mr. Skilling to acknowledge that he participated in schemes to manipulate results at the ends of quarters and was closely involved in moving troubled assets into a risky off-the-books financing structure called Raptors.

headline: Job Growth Was Weak in April, but Hourly Wages Increased
abstract: Job growth slackened in April, the government reported yesterday, but the hourly wages of ordinary workers jumped, and their pay is finally rising faster than inflation.     The nation's employers added only 138,000 jobs, well below the average of 210,000 a month since last November. The unemployment rate, however, held at a low 4.7 percent. The contradictory numbers left economists unsure whether the weaker April job growth was a hiccup or early evidence of a slowdown in the economy.

headline: People
abstract: Richard A. Goldstein, a member of the board of the Interpublic Group of Companies, New York, was named presiding director, succeeding Frank J. Borelli, effective with the Interpublic annual meeting next month. Mr. Borelli, whose appointment in November 2002 was part of the efforts by Interpublic to address financial and operational problems, will remain on the board.     Andrew Langer joined Roberts & Tarlow, New York, part of the Omnicom Group, as chief creative officer, a new post. He had been vice chairman and global creative director on the Johnson & Johnson account at Lowe Worldwide, New York, part of Interpublic. Roberts & Tarlow is also a J.& J. agency.

headline: Hello, Young Workers: One Way to Reach the Top Is to Start There
abstract: Austan Goolsbee Economic Scene column holds that recent college graduates should aim for top jobs instead of accepting low-level work and trying to climb corporate ladder; cites recent evidence that shows starting at bottom creates lifetime of being underpaid in career (M)

headline: Olmert hopes to build coalition with Labor
In Web Era, Big Money Can't Buy an Exclusive
abstract: After winning the very expensive rights to the first photographs of Shiloh Nouvel Jolie-Pitt, the editors at People magazine formed a publicity plan. Appear for an interview with Matt Lauer on the NBC ''Today'' show. Give the photos to the tabloids, which will run them in full color on their front pages. Then, on Friday, release the pictures in glossy form to the world on newsstands everywhere, for an increased cover price of $3.99.     Instead, days before their official publication, the pictures of Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt cuddling their days-old infant first appeared on Gawker, PerezHilton.com and about two dozen other gossip blogs and Web sites. Some photos were taken from a bootleg copy of Hello! magazine, which had obtained the rights in Britain to the photos for a reported $3.5 million. Others that appeared later were from copies of People that the magazine says may have been stolen before official distribution. Within an hour of the first postings, lawyers for the magazine began unleashing cease-and-desist letters to the offending Web sites.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Spying Investigation Approved
abstract: Germany's three opposition parties vote to conduct formal parliamentary investigation into role German intelligence service has played in Iraq war (S)

headline: A Geek, Sure, but No Patsy When It's About Research
abstract: Laurie Pycroft, 16, has become possibly youngest and certainly most scrutinized campaigner in Britain against militant animal rights movement that wants to block building of new animal testing facilities in Oxford; he has used his blog to form Pro-Test, which drew hundreds of people to its first demonstration in Feb; Pycroft photo (M)

headline: Chad drops threat to expel Sudanese refugees
World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: French Bank Buys Holding in Moscow Lender
abstract: Societe Generale acquires as much as 20 percent of Moscow-based OAO Rosbank, delaying initial public offering by Rosbank (S)

headline: But Would the Laptop Survive a Trip Over Niagara Falls?
abstract: OtterBox line of laptop cases protect computers from drops as high as four feet; enclosure is waterproof, dustproof and crush resistant; cost ranges from $120 to $150 depending on model and size; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Varig Receives a Cash Bid
abstract: Varig says second unidentified bidder has offered $450 million in cash for bankrupt carrier; bankruptcy Judge Luiz Roberto Ayoub is scheduled to rule on proposed sale to NV Participacoes (S)

headline: Foreign Minister of Australia Rejects Reports About Kickbacks to Hussein
abstract: Australian Foreign Min Alexander Downer dismisses as insignificant three separate reports that Austrialian wheat company AWB Ltd paid more than $200 million in kickbacks to Saddam Hussein's government; testimony comes as investigation, now in its fourth month, focuses on what government knew about the kickbacks (M)

headline: Earnings Lift Stocks, but Oil Pulls Them Back
abstract: Roundup of last week's stock market activity; graphs (M)

headline: Couric Expected to Announce Her Departure From 'Today'
abstract: Katie couric is will announce decision to leave NBC's Today show as prelude to formal announcement by CBS that she will join network as evening news anchor (M)

headline: A Small Step At Starbucks From Mocha To Movies
abstract: With barely one movie under its belt, Starbucks is moving aggressively toward expanding its involvement in the entertainment business, seeking movies and books to promote in the hope of duplicating the success it has had with music.      The retail coffee giant -- which used its stores to promote ''Akeelah and the Bee,'' a Lionsgate movie that opened this weekend -- is to announce Monday that it has signed an agreement with the William Morris Agency to find more movie and book projects to market. The aim is to have one book in Starbucks stores this year, and at least two or three movies to promote and sell on DVD next year, with more projects in years to come.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hedge Fund Manager Acquired
abstract: Hellman & Friedman to acquire equity hedge firm Gartmore Investment Management from National Mutual Life Insurance Co; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: As China Makes Strides, Russia Stumbles Out of the Stock Offering Gate
abstract: Andrew Kramer Market Place column assesses what looks like wholesale retrenchment as Russian companies delay or scale back initial public offerings; critics say Russian copanies are going public too early, for wrong reasons, or are valuing their shares too high; China is having better success (M)

headline: Digital Marketer to Acquire Smaller Pennsylvania Shop
abstract: Digital marketer Cimbrian agrees to acquire advertising, public relations and customer relations management specialist Kelly Michener; terms are not disclosed (S)

headline: VNU asks investors to accept buyout bid
Syria Imposing Stronger Curbs on Opposition
abstract: Just months ago, under intense international pressure to ease its stranglehold on neighboring Lebanon, the Syrian government was talking about ending the ruling Baath Party's grip on Syrian power and paving the way for a multiparty system.     But things have moved in the opposite direction. Syrian officials are aggressively silencing domestic political opposition while accommodating religious conservatives to shore up support across the country.

headline: Hyundai Chairman Accused of Embezzling
abstract: Hyundai Motor chairman Chung Mong Koo is arrested on charges of embezzlement and breach of trust; Chung reportedly set up $105 million slush fund to bribe government officials and politicians and is accused of causing more than $315 million in damage to company through his misconduct; photo (M)

headline: Alcatel to Sell Satellite Units to Contractor
abstract: Thales agrees to purchase satellite and security businesses from Alcatel for 1.7 billion euros ($2.1 billion in cash and stock; chief executive Denis Ranque says deal will add 2 billion euros to 10.3 billion euros in annual sales; Airbus parent company EADS has long considered aquiring Thales; declines to comment on takeover (M)

headline: Battle for Euronext Heats Up; Nasdaq Gains Edge on London Exchange
abstract: Deutsche Borse reveals plan to merge with Euronext as New York Stock Exchange is also actively pursuing exchange; Nasdaq raises stake in London Stock Exchange to 25.1 percent; blocks London exchange from entering major deals without its approval; mergers will transform exchanges into trans-Atlantic businesses; photo (M)

headline: Plane diverted to Scottish airport after bomb threat
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Drug Extraditions Begin
abstract: Mexican government, fulfilling pledge to Pres Bush, starts extraditing drug traffickers facing life sentences in US, beginning with Santiago Goicochea Diaz, whom US authorities have charged with transporting large amounts of cocaine and methamphetamines into US (S)

headline: A Busman's Holiday For Disney's Chief
abstract: Walt Disney Co chief executive Robert Iger comments on his reaction to his first time riding Expedition Everest, runaway train ride that has opened at Disney's Animal Kingdom in Florida; photo (S)

headline: Looking to the West for new tools of the trade
Iran closes U.S. door for talks about Iraq
Men Join the Migration to the Halls of Diet and Fitness
abstract: Article on rise in number of men who are joining diet centers and health spas in effort to learn how to eat less, exercise more and control weight; photo (M)

headline: U.S. pushes to limit generic-drug rights in trade pacts
World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 2 More Terrorism Arrests
abstract: The police arrested two people under terrorism legislation in Bolton, outside of Manchester, in the latest in a series of antiterrorism raids -- some linked, some independent -- across England in the last few weeks. The two suspects, who have not been formally charged, were taken into custody in the aftermath of a search of eight properties in order to target ''individuals suspected of possession of information that could be used for a terrorism purpose,'' a police spokesman said. The spokesman said the operation was not linked to other antiterrorism investigations in London and elsewhere.   SARAH LYALL (NYT)

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT
abstract: Mutual funds report for first quarter of 2006

headline: Chemical Companies Look to Coal as an Oil Substitute
abstract: Coal for fuel? Pretty common. But coal as the main ingredient in wall paints, fertilizers, even grocery bags?     With oil and natural gas prices showing no signs of plummeting, and with incentives to use coal built into the Energy Policy Act of 2005, it just might happen. And chemical companies, which use oil and gas as feedstocks -- industry jargon for raw materials -- are hoping it will happen soon.

headline: Cease-fire endangered by Sri Lanka killings
High oil prices drag down growth in euro countries
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,341 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:    SESKER, Daniel L., 22, Specialist, Army National Guard; Ogden, Iowa; 113th Cavalry.

headline: France's top diplomat caught in a harsh light
An Internet Phone Pioneer, Poised to Go Public, Has Rivals at Its Heels
abstract: Thanks to its relentless marketing and low prices, Vonage has quickly become synonymous with phone service over the Internet. But when Brandon Sehlke and his wife, Jennifer, moved into a new home in San Antonio two weeks ago, they chose a new Internet phone service from Time Warner Cable, not Vonage or AT&T, his old provider.      The deal Time Warner offered was just too good: phone service with a television package and a broadband connection for a promotional price of $89.95 a month.

headline: As U.N. Inquiry Drags on, Syrians Ask if They Should Relax
abstract: Even as the United Nations Security Council voted Thursday to extend the investigation into the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister, there was a sense here that the pressure was off, that Syria was no longer in imminent danger of being charged with the crime or punished by the international community.     ''After 14 months, there is no concrete evidence that incriminates Syria,'' said Georges Jabbour, a Baathist member of Parliament. ''Since the world rushed to blame Syria, I think that the damage to Syria's image is something that must be rectified by those who are responsible.''

headline: On Advertising: A big shift for AOL
Birdwatching by a Remote Monastery
abstract: C.J. Chivers of The Times Moscow bureau describes his visit to some of the earliest sites of Georgian Christianity, and his vigil over the timeless wonder of birds in flight.

headline: Philadelphia Investors Buy Two Newspapers
abstract: A group of local investors bought The Philadelphia Inquirer and its sister paper, The Daily News, yesterday, promising not to interfere with news-gathering operations, although critics question whether editorial independence will be possible.     The new owners paid the McClatchy Company $562 million for the papers, and said they would keep publishing The Daily News, a tabloid with a declining circulation whose future has periodically been in doubt. And they pledged not to interfere in the running of the newspapers, addressing concerns that the papers might cater to their business interests.

headline: Prosecutor Denies Pressure on KPMG to Cut Off Legal Fees
abstract: Asst US Atty Stanley Okula says, during hearing, that government did not pressure KPMG to cut off legal fees to 16 former employees as condition of not seeking indictment over creation and sale of questionable tax shelters; acknowledges he thought it was mistake for firm to advance such fees (M)

headline: Times Promotes Advertising Executive
abstract: New York Times promotes Alexis Buryk to senior vice president; Buryk will succeed Jyll F Holzman who has resigned for family reasons; will report to chief advertising officer Denise F Warren; photo (S)

headline: Apple Tells of Problems on Options
abstract: Apple Computer said yesterday that it had uncovered irregularities related to stock options awarded between 1997 and 2001, a move that raises questions about whether a grant made to Steven P. Jobs, one of the largest ever, was properly disclosed.     The announcement, after the close of regular stock trading, makes Apple  the latest company to acknowledge possible problems with option grants. More than 60 companies, from Silicon Valley start-ups to industry giants like Microsoft, have announced that their option practices are under review.

headline: Car bomb strikes Shiite worshippers in Iraq
Honest, All Types Cheat on Taxes
abstract: What's Offline column; Stephanie Albert writes in Psychology Today that many who cheat on taxes do so for thrill rather than greed; holds that people cheat because they believe everyone else does; Internal Revenue Service says tax evasion is $300-billion-a-year problem; FHM includes tax trivia in latest issue of magazine; consultant Andrew Sobel writes in Strategy and Business that Beatles music is example of how to forge cooperation and creativity inside organization; American Baby reports that four years at public university will cost $180,000 in 2020; private tuition will cost $260,000; photo (M)

headline: How Many Miles to the Bushel?
abstract: What's Offline column; Popular Mechanics calculates cost to drive from New York to California using seven types of fuel; electricity is cheapest at $60; Hydrogen power would cost most at $804; Wired determines complete conversion to bio-based fuels would require more resources than are available; Hotel magazine reports that hotels are losing money on minibars due to lack of interest and expired items; many hotels are choosing to replace high-priced minibars with empty refrigerators for guests; Health magazine reports 25 percent of employees working from home actually work less than one hour; photo (M)

headline: Seizing Intangibles For the G.D.P.
abstract: Economic View column on calculating Gross Domestic Product; says numbers show that profit portion of GDP has risen mildly in recent years, while wage-and-salary share has shrunk slighty; holds there is evidence that because of way GDP is calculated, actual shift is much more pronounced; says Bureau of Economic Analysis, which issues GDP, and Federal Reserve seem to be finding that current methods for calculating GDP undercount dollar returns from research and development; notes payoff is not showing up in workers' paychecks (M)

headline: Queen Elizabeth Turns 80, While Charles Waits
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II, Britain's monarch for 54 years, celebrates her 80th birthday, occasion that raises questions about her succession; photo (M)

headline: U.S. raises possibility of friendly-fire deaths
Mexico's Enforcers Take On Election-Year Mudslingers
abstract: On the surface, Mexico's presidential election looks a lot like modern campaigns in the United States, a battle of image makers wielding television advertisements, sound bites and, at times, attack ads with less truth than venom.      But in one crucial respect it is different: Mexico's referee, the powerful Federal Election Institute, has waded into the fray involving the three candidates, ruling that some television spots are too false to be on the air and others simply too rude.

headline: Spain moves to dissolvecity hall roiled by scandal
Public Broadcasters Use Web to Make Their Budget Case
abstract: With the federal budget dance getting under way in Washington, public broadcasters are not waiting until the last minute to line up listener and viewer support for their share of the money.      Ten days ago, National Public Radio, the Public Broadcasting Service and the lobbying arm of the Association of Public Television Stations introduced a joint promotional Web site to generate grass-roots messages to members of Congress. Local stations are publicizing the site (www.tellthempublicmatters.org).

headline: Verizon Settles Charges
abstract: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission says Verizon Communications will pay $48.9 million to settle charges its predecessor companies Nynex and Bell Atlantic discriminated against employees who were pregnant or on maternity leave; says it expects another $23.6 million will be paid in future pension benefits under settlement (S)

headline: Where Wall Street Meets to Eat, the Last Lunch
abstract: What was once the site of Wall Street's quintessential power lunch is preparing its last meal.     The Stock Exchange Luncheon Club, a wood-paneled dining room that has served members of the New York Stock Exchange and other Wall Street power brokers since 1898, is closing at the end of business today.

headline: A Million Here, a Million There. Still Real Money?
abstract: Merrill Lynch and Capgemini study finds that number of millionaires worldwide nearly doubled in decade, to 8.7 million; graph (S)

headline: EU data show more than 1,000 CIA flights over Europe
Long Trip by Sea and Into a Political Maze for Papuans Seeking Independence
abstract: Herman Wanggai and over 30 other Papuans arrived in Australia on Jan 13 after six-week voyage in motorized outrigger; Australia granted Wanggai and all his passengers, save one, political asylum; decision set off diplomatic firestorm that has brought issue of Papuan independence to international attention, which is just what Wanggai and his wife, Ferra Kambu, wanted; Indonesia has recalled its ambassador and Indonesian politicians have called for trade sanctions; map; photos (M)

headline: Hundreds of Iraqi Detainees Get First Taste of Freedom
abstract: The first of 2,500 Iraqi prisoners set for release stepped off a bus to freedom on Wednesday morning at Baghdad's central bus station, with many dropping to their knees and pressing their foreheads to the scalding pavement to offer thanks.     The roughly 100 male detainees, ordered to be set free in a good-will gesture on Tuesday by the new Iraqi prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, walked to an awning to take shelter from the fierce sun. They each collected a $200 gift from a local Sunni political party, listened to a speech by one of its members and then wandered into the city where they had been taken prisoner by American soldiers months ago.

headline: Brand-Name Bankers Rule the Street Again, for Now
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin Dealbook column on plethora of boutique investment banks that are going or planning to go public; focuses on Evercore Partners, founded by former Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger Altman; photo (M)

headline: Freed Cleric Is Hailed by Students, but Support Could Be Waning
abstract: Hundreds of Muslim students, thrusting their fists toward the night sky and chanting ''God is great'' in Arabic, welcomed their revered spiritual leader, the militant Islamic cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, home from prison on Wednesday night.     Mr. Bashir was escorted here from prison by police officers, after serving 26 months for immigration violations and criminal conspiracy.

headline: Circumcision Studied in Africa as AIDS Preventive
abstract: For well over a decade, southern Africans have battled the spread of H.I.V. with everything from condoms and abstinence campaigns to doses of antiretroviral drugs for pregnant women -- and yet the epidemic continues unabated.      Now a growing number of clinicians and policy makers in the region are pointing to a simple and possibly potent weapon against new infections: circumcision for men.

headline: Israeli Cabinet Revises Route of Separation Barrier
abstract: The new route seeks to speed up construction while still incorporating several settlements inside the West Bank.

headline: Nasdaq Buys 15% Stake in London Stock Exchange
abstract: The purchase makes Nasdaq the largest shareholder in the London exchange and comes a month after Nasdaq's $4.1 billion bid to buy the exchange was rebuffed for being insufficient.

headline: Muslim's Loss of Dutch Citizenship Stirs Storm
abstract: The Dutch immigration minister's decision to cancel the citizenship of a Somali-born Dutch legislator has set off a political storm in the Netherlands, with Parliament demanding that the move be revoked.     At the center of the storm is Ayaan Hirsi Ali, 36, who gained fame -- and received death threats -- while campaigning against militant Islam and opposing the abuse she said Muslim women suffered even in Europe.

headline: Verizon to End Airline Telephone Service
abstract: Verizon Communications marketing director Jim Pilcher announces company will end 21-year-old Verizon Airfone service on commercial airliners before end of year and instead focus on its faster-growing broadband, cellular and television businesses (M)

headline: Hear the Noise or Block It Out. It's Your Choice, Instantly.
abstract: Shure's E500 noise-blocking earphones come with push-to-hear switch that mutes music while external microphone picks up ambient sounds; will be available for $499; switch will work with standard earphones and will be sold separately for $59; photo (M)

headline: Tokyo shares flat amid day of quiet
Justices Drop Consideration of Boundaries for Patents
abstract: Supreme Court, with three justices dissenting, backs away from ruling on case brought by LabCorp against Metabolite Laboratory that could have set boundaries on what kinds of discoveries and inventions can be patented; decision upholds medical diagnostic testing patent and averts decision that some patent lawyers said could have undermined thousands of patents on medical tests; decision voices concern that patents in areas like biotechnology and financial services are being granted too liberally and should be rolled back (M)

headline: Sensing Opportunity, Rightist Seeks the French Presidency Again
abstract: France's aging right-wing firebrand, Jean-Marie Le Pen, building on a recent surge of popular support after successive national political crises, on Monday called on the country's increasingly fragmented far right to unite behind him in next year's presidential election.     Speaking to thousands of supporters at his traditional May Day rally in central Paris, Mr. Le Pen, 77, predicted that he would make it into a runoff election next year just as he did against Jacques Chirac in 2002. But this time, Mr. Le Pen said, he expects to win.

headline: Last call for Chirac to decide fate of youth labor law
'Ka-ching!' Tricks of airline trade
Nepalese Maoist Proposes That Rebels and Army Curb Troops
abstract: The second in command of the Maoist rebels in Nepal said in an interview on Thursday that his organization would agree to isolate its troops during the election period for a new constitution if the Royal Nepalese Army would agree to the same.     The Maoists on Wednesday announced that their People's Liberation Army would abide by a three-month unilateral cease-fire intended, as they put it, to enable a new government to keep its promise to hold an ''unconditional'' referendum on the country's Constitution, including giving Nepalese citizens the right to choose whether they want a monarchy at all.

headline: By Demand, Saks Revives Petite Dept.
abstract: Scolded by short women across the country, Saks Fifth Avenue said yesterday that it would re-establish its petite women's clothing department, which the company had quietly dropped several months ago because of poor sales.      The decision, a victory for millions of women shorter than 5-foot-4, came after Saks received scores of letters from smaller shoppers who complained that they could no longer find clothing that fit and that they felt alienated in a store that had dressed them for decades.

headline: The Fever for Exotic Stocks
abstract: Simon Nocera runs a hedge fund that invests in emerging markets, and so, perhaps not surprisingly, prides himself on having a keen appetite for risk. But even he had to draw the line when his broker tried to get him into Zambian treasury bills.     ''It was pure, baseless speculation,'' said Mr. Nocera, who has been investing in developing markets for more than 15 years. ''If I am going to play the casinos, I would rather go to Las Vegas.''

headline: Chief Says Google Won't Fight Chinese Censorship
abstract: Eric E. Schmidt said that obeying Chinese law is unavoidable if Google wants to enter the market.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Acquisition by Nestlé
abstract: Nestlé said that it had agreed to buy the Uncle Tobys brand from Burns Philp & Company for 890 million Australian dollars ($670 million) to expand its range of cereals, soups and fruit snack bars in Australia. Uncle Tobys' cereal unit will become part of the Cereal Partners Worldwide breakfast-food venture with General Mills, Nestlé said. Nestlé, which is based in Vevey, Switzerland, said it was also acquiring the rights to the Uncle Tobys brand in New Zealand.

headline: Briton Wants Guantánamo Closed
